HEADLINE: The Greening of U.S. Diplomacy: Focus on Ecology

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Environmental threats like the beautiful water hyacinths choking Lake Victoria and the desert sands eating away the sparse pastures bordering the Sahara are some of the issues deemed urgent today by American foreign policy makers in much the same manner as military threats like new surface-to-air missile sites alarmed policy makers several decades ago.
These days, intelligence officials are being asked to look at softer targets -- those flowers and sand dunes -- to shed light on this decade's hot wars. Through this optic, Somalia and Rwanda can be interpreted not as spontaneous outbreaks of clan warfare or ethnic violence, but as conflicts nourished by the underlying strains of hunger, drought and a lack of arable land in Somalia, and huge population growth and population density in Rwanda. 
 So in addition to their traditional intelligence gathering -- arms, nuclear weapons programs, expansion of foreign armies -- American policy makers are looking more than ever before at natural phenomena in their search for the deeper roots of war and threats to global security. They are expecting more wars like Somalia, where the United States sent troops to calm a desperate situation spawned by environmental calamities and the brutal political response to it. To prepare for such future wars, they are analyzing subjects like the water table levels in Central Asia and the water hyacinths in Central Africa.
In August, the Defense Intelligence Agency finished a study on the rapid spread of the water hyacinth plant in Lake Victoria, which provides 120,000 tons of fish each year to Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania. The agency noted with due seriousness how a single water hyacinth can multiply into a million plants in one year and, the report warned, these plants could ultimately strangle the lake and kill most of its fish. The consequences would be serious: famine and such political instability in neighboring countries that the United States could be called in to help.
In looking at the underlying causes of war and crisis, the intelligence community now examines an expanded menu of subjects, including agriculture, demographics, economics and epidemiology. It looks, for instance, at China's economic boom and how it is causing considerable overcrowding in China's cities; at the AIDS epidemic in East Africa and how it is affecting the region's military and political elites; and at Mexico's industrial leap forward and how it has left millions of peasants behind.
Some old-line intelligence officials disparage this new focus on what they call "soft stuff." But the Clinton Administration, led by Vice President Al Gore, has deliberately added this new focus on environmental and natural factors -- famine, soil erosion, rapid population growth, the expansion of deserts -- that they believe will produce many of the world crises of tomorrow.
"During the cold war, most security threats stemmed from state-to-state aggression, so most of the analysis was of factors that could produce state-to-state aggression," said James Steinberg, the State Department's director of policy planning. "Now we're focusing more on internal factors that can destabilize governments and lead to civil wars and ethnic strife. Now we're paying much more attention to early warning factors, like famine and the environment."
The United States looks less than before at who is sitting where in the Kremlin and more at how good this fall's harvest will be in the Central Asian republics.
The Central Intelligence Agency recently commissioned a study to determine whether there was a correlation between a country's infant mortality rate, the openness of a country's trading system to imports and the stability of its government, hoping that finding a way to view these factors collectively would help the C.I.A. predict where the next crisis might erupt.
Gathering of the so-called soft intelligence has become routine. The C.I.A. now does an annual study, called "Global Humanitarian Emergencies" that forecasts which countries are most likely to suffer from natural disasters. It set up a global affairs department two years ago that analyzes environmental matters, the global food situation and other issues the agency once gave little attention.
"We've been looking at some of these softer issues for a long time," said one intelligence official. "What's different now is these issues have moved from the periphery to take a more central role."
Angelo Codevilla, an intelligence expert who teaches at Boston University, said this new approach is misguided. "All this soft stuff is a silly idea," he said. "The purpose of intelligence is to ferret out secrets from people who want to keep those secrets. To turn intelligence into environmental reports is not to understand environmental problems or intelligence."
Professor Codevilla said it was wrong to switch from harder to softer intelligence. "The hard stuff is as important as ever because guns will determine the future of the world as much as they ever did," he said.
Toby Gati, Assistant Secretary of State for Intelligence, disagrees, saying, "This soft stuff immediately becomes hard when you have to send in the Marines."
George Moose, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, is a promoter of this new approach and says that if the intelligence community had studied Somalia's water table levels in the three years before the outbreak of famine and clan warfare there, the information might have warned diplomats of an imminent crisis. Since Africa is his responsibility, Mr. Moose is particularly sensitive to the role of natural disasters in human conflicts. He argues that the rapid spread of the Sahara desert set off the 1989 conflict between Senegal and Mauritania, when herdsmen from the two countries went to war over a dwindling amount of grazing land.
In recent years the Pentagon has sent troops to Somalia, where American soldiers made it safe for relief groups to deliver food to starving people, and to Zaire, where the United States set up emergency camps for Rwandan refugees. Even in the more traditional Haiti operation, American troops were called upon to restore an ousted, democratically elected president who vowed to combat poverty rather than to take up arms in a classic government-to-government confrontation like the wars in Korean and Vietnam.
The Administration says the American people care about the problems addressed recently. "The issues of overpopulation, of refugees, of famine, of human rights problems are issues the American people have become more interested in," said one National Security Council official.
This shift toward softer intelligence has brought with it another shift: more than ever before, the intelligence community is using public material, particularly relief reports produced by organizations like the International Committee of the Red Cross.
In Africa, where the the C.I.A. is cutting back its presence, intelligence officials acknowledge that the thousands of relief workers there are a trove of information about the continent. To take advantage of this, the Clinton Administration is setting up a computer information network, called "Relief Net," to speed the flow of information from the Red Cross and other relief groups to Government agencies.

GRAPHIC: Chart: 'A Closer Look: National Fears, Old and New'
Factors looked to assess national security threats.
 
Traditional Factors
1) Massing of troops.
2) Development of weapons of mass destruction.
3) The pecking order in the Kremlin.
4) Arms shipments to cold-war surrogates in the third world.
 
New Factors
 
1) Rainfall and water table levels as predictors of famine and the collapse of governments.
2) Infant mortality rates as a predictor that a government will collapse.
3) High population growth and density as a predictor of rebellion or ethnic strife.
4) The spread of the Sahara Desert as a predictor that ethnic strike will result when tribes are forced to compete for the remaining grazing and arable land.
5) Inflation rates and trade deficits as a way to predict financial and political instability.
6) The ability of a third world country to absorb young people into the labor market.

HEADLINE: White House Skirts Moynihan Proposal

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
White House Chief of Staff Leon Panetta expressed wariness today about proposals by some Democrats and Republicans in Congress to ease the budget crunch by changing the formula the Federal Government uses to measure the cost of living.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is the ranking minority member of the Finance Committee, wants to reduce the Consumer Price Index by one percentage point a year. A panel of economists commissioned by the Finance Committee concluded last month that the index overstated the true level of inflation. 
 Since the index is used to fix the level of many Federal expenses, including Social Security payments, an overstatement of one percentage point, which the economists call the most plausible figure, would cost the Government $600 billion over the next 10 years, the panel said.
On the NBC's "Meet the Press," Mr. Panetta was cautious about Mr. Moynihan's proposal.
"It should not be a deal in which everybody looks into the budget and says, 'Oh, my God, we're $50 billion to $60 billion short. Let's throw the C.P.I. into that mix in order to make up the difference," he said.
Appearing later on the same program, Senator Moynihan expressed frustration at the White House's reluctance to support the idea.
"They're scared of what the American Association of Retired Persons will say and others will say," he said.

HEADLINE: Nafta Trade-Off: Some Jobs Lost, Others Gained

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Twenty-one months after the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect with ebullient projections that it would create hundreds of thousands of jobs, the experience of the Key Tronic Corporation, a big manufacturer of computer keyboards in Spokane, Wash., is a reason some critics argue the trade pact has cost the United States dearly.
Key Tronic, which faces stiff competition from Japanese manufacturers, has laid off 277 workers and moved their jobs to a plant in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, where wages are a fourth of those in Washington. In fact, tens of thousands of factory jobs in this country have been lost since the agreement took effect for precisely the same reason. 
 But as it happens, Key Tronic is also an example of the benefits created by the trade pact. Ronald F. Klawitter, the company's chief financial officer, said that Key Tronic's sales had jumped because of the lower costs of manufacturing in Mexico, which enabled the company to lower prices and win new orders. And since many of the components used in the keyboards assembled in Ciudad Juarez come from plants near Spokane, overall employment in the area has actually increased to keep up with the demand.
"Some of the business we've picked up we wouldn't have gotten if we didn't have the Mexican plant," said Mr. Klawitter, who added that without Nafta the company might have had to consider manufacturing in low-wage Asian countries.
Mexico's President, Ernesto Zedillo, is coming to Washington on Tuesday, and Nafta will weigh heavily on both his talks with President Clinton, and how critics will assess the relationship between the countries. When the pact was passed by Congress in November 1993, Mr. Clinton called the agreement "a defining moment for our nation" and his economists said it would create 170,000 jobs in the first year. Clearly that has not been the case, because of the deep Mexican recession. But many businessmen and economists say jobs were the wrong way to measure Nafta's effects; as in the case of Key Tronic and many other companies, Nafta is all about corporate efficiency.
Even within Mexico there is some disappointment with Nafta because of its perceived failure to create jobs and the fact that last December's peso crisis created a deep recession that for the time being has outweighed any potential benefits.
On the political level, much of the debate in the United States has involved hyperbole and oversimplification. Conservatives like Pat Buchanan, a Republican Presidential hopeful, and labor unions have found common purpose in calling for Nafta's repeal. Backers say it is just a matter of time before benefits begin to outweigh short-term job losses.
Perhaps more important, the peso crisis, which caused the Mexican currency to plummet by nearly 50 percent and sent the economy into a paralyzing recession, has made it even more difficult to assess just how the lowering of tariffs and other barriers under Nafta has affected American companies and workers. Clearly, economists say, some job losses in this country are a result of the steep drop in demand in Mexico for goods of all kinds, not Nafta.
But as the Key Tronic example demonstrates, Nafta has not been a zero-sum game, where one country's gains translate into the other country's losses. The Nafta experience has borne out the fact that the effects of trade involve a powerful dynamic in which many forces push and pull to reshape the economic structure of both countries, and that those changes are not without much pain.
For instance, one of the big pluses for the Chrysler Corporation is not just the potential increase in the sale of its cars and trucks in Mexico -- sales are down considerably this year because of the recession, after a huge jump in sales last year -- but the fact that it can now sharply increase the efficiency of its Mexican plants.
James D. Donlon, a Chrysler vice president, said one Mexican plant previously produced several models in relatively small numbers, largely for sale in what was then a protected Mexican market that was highly resistant to imports from the United States. Now, with many of those barriers being phased out, that plant will produce just one model, in far greater numbers and thus at less cost per vehicle, in a few years. And those autos will be sold both domestically and in the United States. In addition, Chrysler will be able to export autos from the United States to Mexico, making a wider range of vehicles available to Mexican consumers.
"Our ability to integrate our marketing and our production represents a total operation well beyond what the two could have been separately," Mr. Donlon said. "But we won't see the full benefit for two or three years."
Then there are workers like Manuel Lepe. Mr. Lepe, a mechanic who works on apparel-cutting machines, lost his job last year at a Los Angeles factory after 20 years with the company.
The blow was softened by the fact that the company helped Mr. Lepe find a new job with another apparel contractor. But there was one problem: his new job came with a pay cut to $6.25 an hour from $8.50.
And consider what has happened to California farmers. Exports to Mexico of many agricultural products, like lettuce and peaches, have risen since Nafta lowered tariffs on many of those commodities.
"It turned out that it was cheaper to produce lettuce here using Mexican labor than in Mexico," said Philip L. Martin, an agricultural economist at the University of California at Davis.
"But the perverse effect of that is that it has increased the demand here for Mexican workers," who are willing to do this tough, low-wage work, Mr. Martin added. "We're still sucking in workers to export these commodities."
That, of course, contradicts the Clinton Administration's claims that Nafta would reduce the floodtide of illegal immigrants by creating more opportunities in Mexico. It also counters the argument of Ross Perot that jobs would flow one-way under Nafta -- to Mexico -- creating "a giant sucking sound."
"We reject that," said Mr. Donlon of Chrysler. "We firmly believe that there will be more total jobs and more jobs in the U.S. It is hard for me to put my finger on and prove because of the peso crisis and what that has done to our business. But if you look at what has happened with Canada, there's one heck of a lot more commerce on both sides of the border."
Other businessmen say that many low-wage jobs will inevitably migrate overseas, but that now some will move to Mexico rather than East Asia.
"The great sucking sound is not the sucking of our jobs to Mexico, it is the sucking of jobs from the Orient," said Robert Paltrow, president of N. A. Communications, a marketing concern based in Armonk, N.Y.
His company has built a plant in Tijuana that assembles one million direct mailing packets a day and that also has a section doing high-tech sewing. The plant has 400 employees after 7 months of operation.
Mr. Paltrow said that with wages roughly one-seventh the level in the United States, "Tijuana and Baja are going to become monstrously large sewing centers," and that will fuel expansion in the United States, where design and other knowledge-intensive operations take place.
Jagdish Bhagwati, an economics professor at Columbia University and a strong proponent of free trade, said that the Nafta experience had left him with some reservations. He said Nafta does appear to be putting downward pressure on American wages and is causing some net reduction in jobs without providing sufficient help for displaced workers.
The Department of Labor, in fact, has documented the loss of 42,221 jobs because of Nafta as of Sept. 30. But that is regarded as a low count since it includes only those workers who have applied and qualified for a Government program to assist them in job training and in finding new jobs.
There are also complaints that Mexico is dragging its feet in carrying out some of the pact's provisions. For instance, the United Parcel Service has said that before Nafta it was able to use only small, inefficient vans to move packages in Mexico, because the Government would not grant it the permits to use the big trucks that its Mexican competitors freely used.
Nafta was supposed to have changed that immediately, but U.P.S. says the Mexican Government has refused to grant it the permits. So it has filed the first complaint under a procedure Nafta set up for resolving such disputes.
Nevertheless, U.P.S. said it still backs Nafta and believes that in the long run it will benefit both countries. It also says that for every increase of 70 packages that it moves to and from Mexico, one job is created in the United States.
"The main point was not that tariffs were lowered under Nafta; they were already pretty low," said Edward Leamers, a professor at Yale and the University of California at Los Angeles. "More important was that Nafta guarantees the tariffs won't suddenly be raised. It is a major risk reduction document for investors."
"If your time clock is year by year, then Nafta was definitely oversold," Mr. Leamers added. "If your clock runs decade by decade, this is a more important event."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 11, 1995, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Monday with an article about the impact of the North American Free Trade Agreement incorrectly described the data shown. The graph showed the number of American workers who have qualified for a Federal job retraining program intended to cushion the effects of Nafta, not the number of jobs lost as a result of the accord.

HEADLINE: For Mexico, Nafta's Promise Of Jobs Is Still Just a Promise

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico, Oct. 7

 BODY:
So many people expected this brawny city of steel and glass to become a showcase of free trade and open competition after the three nations of North America signed a trade pact in 1993 that Monterrey officials put up an eight-foot monument to the agreement called "A Hope for Development."
The North American Free Trade Agreement, or Nafta, was supposed to reach its full potential here, creating more jobs, more prosperity, more hope that Mexico's future would be bright enough to keep struggling Mexicans from illegally crossing the border. 
 Besides an artistically questionable monument on the main highway into town, however, what Monterrey's million residents got during the last two years is typical of what Mexico has gotten since joining Nafta: unfulfilled promises.
Few Mexicans have lost sight of Nafta's basic accomplishment: permanently linking Mexico's struggling economy to the world's largest consumer market, the United States. That alone has made Mexico the envy of Chile and most of the other countries of the hemisphere lining up to join Nafta.
Still, the long-range promise of the agreement has not alleviated unemployment in Monterrey, which approaches 10 percent and is consistently the highest in Mexico, and the $3-a-day minimum wage buys less than ever before. Retail sales have plummeted.
"I thought that after Nafta there would be more jobs, and a greater flow of information and goods," said Marcela Acosta, a 22-year-old from Monterrey who was recently seeking her first permanent job since graduating with a degree in international commerce from a Mexican university last December. "I thought that was the future."
Hundreds of businesses in Monterrey have closed, with few new ones opening. And some American demographers say the number of illegal emigrants streaming north out of Mexico may have actually increased in recent months.
But Monterrey is not complaining too loudly. When President Ernesto Zedillo meets with President Clinton in Washington on Tuesday to discuss Nafta and other economic issues, few Mexicans plan to protest against the trade pact.
Most businessmen here recognize that Monterrey's misery is caused more by Mexico's current recession than by Nafta. The trade pact has helped some people here do quite well. The Vitro glass company, Cemex, a cement maker, Grupo Alfa, which makes steel among other items, and a handful of other big Monterrey companies have sharply increased exports.
"Many people say the cause of the crisis is Nafta," said Hiram Peon, a spokesman for Vitro, which increased exports of flat glass and drinking glasses almost 30 percent this year, but without adding any jobs. "But when the markets recover, all the infrastructure and trade contacts are going to give us the chance to sell our products and take advantage of the North American market."
Nafta did not make the border between the United States and Mexico disappear. Trucks still back up in mile-long lines at the border.
But Nafta is the guarantee that Mexico is committed to the kind of no-holds-barred economy that Washington has long tried to get it to adopt. Perhaps more than anything, Nafta, and the years of trade liberalization it capped, have increased United States influence in Mexico.
The combination of Nafta's passage and the economic crisis have pushed Mexico to accelerate the sale of Government-owned railroads, airports and the oil monopoly Pemex. Mexico has also liberalized its foreign investment law so that United States companies are now major players in banking, telecommunications and almost every part of the economy, bringing in direct investment capital that Mexico, after devaluation of the peso, sorely needs.
President Clinton has been criticized because Nafta and the devalued peso have combined to tip the trade balance in Mexico's favor. By the end of July, Mexico had sold the United States almost $9 billion more in merchandise than it had imported. Mexican exports of cars, winter tomatoes, frozen strawberries and many other products are up sharply, and this year Mexico will record its first trade surplus with the United States since 1990.
Mexico's trade advantage has irritated opponents of Nafta in the United States, even though Mexico has often sold more to the United States than it bought. American surpluses from 1991 through 1994 were the only ones since 1981. Before that, Mexico's economy was so restricted that trade between the two nations was largely limited to Mexican oil and American machines.
Opponents of Nafta, led by organizations like Public Citizen and by politicians like Patrick J. Buchanan, have recently accused the Mexicans of reneging on the deal. They say the peso devaluation, combined with Mexico's low wages and the lowering of tariffs by Nafta, gives Mexican products an overwhelming advantage over American goods.
Such criticism is not surprising considering that Nafta represents the first time that fully developed economies, like those of the United States and Canada, agreed to throw down trade barriers with a low-wage developing country like Mexico. Under Nafta, tariffs on most goods dropped substantially when the pact took effect on Jan. 1, 1994, and will be phased out completely over 15 years.
Despite a rebellion in the southern state of Chiapas that started on the day Nafta took effect, the deal worked pretty much as it was supposed to during most of 1994. Mexican exports to the United States increased, but so did American exports to Mexico. Then the economy collapsed last December.
Most economists say Nafta had little or nothing to do with the crisis. But they agree that the current Mexican economy should be seen as the outcome of a decadelong process of tearing down barriers that began with Mexico's application to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trades, or GATT, in 1986. Tariffs dropped from as high as 100 percent to 20 percent or less. Nafta brought the tariffs on most goods down to zero or slightly above.
That was supposed to have given American producers and retailers a market of 90 million prosperous Mexicans, but so far it has remained just a marketer's dream.
Expectations seem to be on hold at the huge new Wal-Mart on the outskirts of Monterrey, just west of the Nafta monument. On a recent Sunday, only half of the 44 cash registers were operating. When the store opened in June 1994, its shelves were packed with Dustbusters and other American products.
Now, store managers say, higher import prices caused by the devaluation have forced them to cut back American goods to only 20 percent of stock. The Dustbusters are still there, but most other items come from Mexico.
That is not what President Clinton had in mind when he promised that Nafta would create 200,000 new American jobs by this year. Nor does it coincide with the 600,000 new Mexican jobs that some economists had predicted for Mexico in 1995.
The United States Labor Department reports that because of Nafta, 41,201 American manufacturing jobs have been lost since January 1994. But America's loss was not always Mexico's gain; the latest Mexican Government figures indicate that a million Mexicans have been put out of work this year alone, continuing a trend. Manufacturing employment has dropped every month since September 1990.
So far this year, 1,664 businesses in Monterrey have closed while only 346 new ones opened, the chamber of commerce says. Retail sales have plummeted to half their 1994 level.
It's not that Nafta has not given Monterrey anything to smile about.
Last month the Blue Bird Corporation, an American company, opened a plant that is building buses in Monterrey for sale in Mexico and export to Central and South America.
And the Mexican construction company ICA, Northern Telecom of Canada and Fluor Daniel of the United States have joined in a new venture to build more than 2,500 miles of fiber optic network for MCI Communications Corporation and the Mexican bank Banamex.
Although President Clinton twisted Mexican arms on wages, labor rights and the environment, the accords have not done much to improve conditions in those areas.
Mexican minimum wages are now indexed to increases in productivity, as the Mexicans promised, but inflation has eaten away any real improvements.
Mr. Clinton told a skeptical Congress that by creating jobs, Nafta could reduce the number of illegal emigrants who cross the border.
Then after the disastrous peso devaluation last December, the administration warned that unless Washington helped Mexico with a multi-billion-dollar bailout, a half million new illegal immigrants would flood into the United States.
How many Mexicans have crossed the border in recent months is hotly debated. But no one on either side of the border claims any more that Nafta has slowed immigration by invigorating Mexico's economy, as the treaty's backers promised.
The net gain for Monterrey and Mexico after Nafta is not anywhere near what either expected. But in a city that is about to mark its 400th anniversary, many Mexicans, like Flavio Ortega, a 35-year-old former computer technician who now shines shoes outside the Howard Johnson Hotel here, have learned the value of patience.
"I really didn't expect much to happen in two years," he said. "I thought it would take more like five years.
"But if it's true we've hit bottom in the crisis, and we don't know if what they tell us is the truth or a lie, three years will still be enough time to recover."

Japan Knew of Daiwa Loss Weeks Before U.S. Officials
The Japanese Government knew of a huge loss by a rogue trader at Daiwa Bank six weeks before American regulators were told of the $1.1 billion scandal. American officials are privately outraged by Japan's failure to disclose the scandal, which led to the resignations of top officials of Daiwa Bank. Stocks Tumble; Dow Loses 42.99
The stock market stum bled badly, pulled down by a broad retreat in technology stocks and growing concerns about corporate profits. The Dow industrials, which at one point dropped as much as 57.47 points, closed at 4,726.22, down 42.99 points, or nearly 1 percent. The Nasdaq composite index fell 27.30 points, or 2.7 percent, to 984.74. [D14.]
 
Disappointing Motorola Results
Motorola's earnings rose 30.5 percent in the third quarter, to $496 million, but were less than some analysts' expectations. The compa ny said after the markets closed that declining prices for cellular phones contributed to the disappointing earnings. [D2.]

World Bank Pushes for Full Aid
The World Bank pressed Congress to restore large amounts of money it is planning to cut from the nation's contribution to the Inter national Development Association. [D10.]

Those attending the final session of the 86th annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers were treated to a panel on the creative process and a fashion show. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D11.]

HEADLINE: 5 Million Strike in France to Protest Pay Freeze

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 9

 BODY:
France and its conservative Government braced for chaos as more than five million public-sector workers began a general walkout tonight to fight a pay freeze.
From trains, subways, telephones and air travel to buses, mail, schools, hospitals and weather forecasts, France's vital functions are expected to be reduced or suspended completely for more than a day. 
 The strike is the first major labor challenge to the conservative Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, who came to power in May with promises to cut France's huge deficit as well as 11.5 percent unemployment. He is grappling with a public sector that accounts for half the nation's productivity.
The Government says nearly 40 percent of its deficit-ridden budget goes into public sector employee paychecks. Unions counter that they are being made scapegoats for France's economic crisis.
The Organization for Economic Development and Cooperation says state workers in France made up 25 percent of the work force in 1993, compared with 14.5 percent in the United States, 16.9 percent in Britain and 14.9 percent in Germany.
Mr. Juppe also is under fire for his role in a housing scandal. His office has denied persistent rumors that his resignation is imminent.
The walkout began when the nation's train system shut down at 8 P.M. Workers said it would not resume until 6 A.M. Wednesday. Paris train stations were eerily empty as the last travelers straggled away.
Unions planned demonstrations for Tuesday, and their leaders threatened more strikes, demonstrations and work slowdowns unless the Government backs down.
It is the first time that all seven Government service unions have united to strike since 1986, when Jacques Chirac, now France's President but then its Prime Minister, froze wages.
The French railway company said most international trains scheduled to leave Paris on Tuesday would be canceled, as would 75 percent of domestic trains.
The Government said the police would not issue parking tickets or read parking meters on Tuesday, to help people forced by the bus and subway shutdown to drive to work.
France's Civil Service Minister, Jean Puech, said today that the Government would hold new salary talks with public sector unions in the second quarter of next year. He criticized the strike for upsetting citizens' lives.
But a recent public opinion poll published by the newspaper Le Figaro indicated that the French are divided on the issue: 47 percent approved of the strike and 48 percent opposed it.
The franc and the French stock market have fallen since Mr. Juppe pressured Finance Minister Alain Madelin to resign in August after he urged cuts in civil service jobs.

HEADLINE: Technology Stocks Lead Market Dive

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Technology stocks fell sharply yesterday in a broad retreat that many analysts interpreted as the beginning of the long-awaited selloff in this high-flying group.
The dive in technology stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite index down 27.30 points, or 2.7 percent, to close at 984.74. The negative sentiment also spilled over into blue-chip stocks, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 42.99 points, to 4,726.22. [Page D14.] 
 The initial catalyst for the decline was an announcement late Friday by Novell Inc. that its fourth-quarter financial results would fall far short of Wall Street estimates. But analysts noted that Novell was only the latest in a series of big technology companies to disappoint in the September quarter, and they expected more to follow.
Technology stocks, which have led the broader stock market higher all year, have had a series of one-day selloffs in the last few months that were followed by immediate rebounds. But because there was more bad news after the close of the market yesterday, some analysts concluded that this decline might last longer.
Motorola Inc. reported earnings of 81 cents a share, slightly below the average estimate of 83 cents, based on 25 analysts surveyed by IBES International. Sequent Computer Systems also said that its earnings would fall below estimates.
In addition, orders for computer chips dropped 2.1 percent in September, although the ratio of new orders to sales remained positive, an industry association reported.
"We're going to see a selloff until you see some flow of good numbers," said Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter, "and that will not happen until next week, if it happens at all. The rest of this week is going to be anticipation and fear of more negative surprises."
The Microsoft Corporation is to report its third-quarter earnings next week, and many analysts expect them to be positive. But if they are disappointing -- or perhaps, just on target -- this could lead to more selling.
After any sharp run-up in the market, analysts worry about what they call corrections -- sharp selloffs as investors decide that the rally is over or that it has just gone too far too fast. Because of such correction jitters, bad news is more damaging and even usually positive news can be interpreted negatively, setting off selling as money managers try to lock in profits before prices plunge.
But corrections are also seen as positive because once over, there is room for stocks to rally again.
Novell attributed its expectation of lower earnings to a steep drop in the sales of its Wordperfect line of personal computer applications, primarily due to the fact that the company had not yet shipped versions of the programs tailored to Microsoft's new operating system, Windows 95.
Novell said applications sales could fall 56 percent, to $59 million, from $134 million in the period a year earlier, and that it expected earnings of 15 cents to 18 cents a share while the consensus estimate had been for the company to earn 28 cents.
In response, Novell shares plummeted $2.75 yesterday, to $14.625, in Nasdaq trading.
Although Novell's problems in the quarter were partly predictable, and partly specific to the company, analysts said they contributed to a growing anxiety among investors about technology stocks in general. After a dramatic run-up in the first eight months of the year, many analysts have suggested that the group is ripe for a selloff, and any piece of bad news from a major company can act as a catalyst. I.B.M. began a series of earnings warnings from large companies on Sept. 13.
"Anybody who follows Novell closely was probably not surprised by the announcement Friday, but in terms of the technology-stock anxiety, it just reinforced what was already going on," said Peter Rogers, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company in San Francisco. He noted that his index of 31 software stocks was up 135 percent since June 1994, so some sort of correction was inevitable.
"One has to view this as painful in the short term, but healthy in the long run," Mr. Rogers said.
Technology companies appeared to defy their usual seasonal dip this summer, and confident analysts began talking about a "secular change," spurred largely by the unexpected growth of the consumer computer market and a similarly unexpected surge in use of the Internet. The introduction of Windows 95 in August was also seen as a spur to continued growth.
But as third-quarter results begin to be announced, there is a growing perception that growth has slowed, and indeed, that Windows 95 may not have met analysts' high expectations.
Mr. Murphy said that after a few false starts, technology stocks had entered the long-anticipated correction.
"It's what we had feared; the industry had built up too much inventory in anticipation of Windows 95," he said. "They believed the Microsoft hype, and it clearly is not happening." He said he expected canceled orders for chips and other components, and retail price cuts that would keep technology stocks depressed for three to four months.
Firm numbers for Windows 95 sales are not yet available, and will not be until Microsoft reports its results next week, but anecdotal evidence is beginning to show up indicating that its sales are strong, but not up to the most optimistic estimates. Microsoft's European president, Bernard Vergnes, said yesterday that there was excess Windows 95 stock in distribution channels.
"The problem is they shipped 8 million to 10 million copies on Day One, and we only expect them to sell 10 million copies in total over the next 18 months," said Rick Sherlund, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs. "The distribution channel was reluctant to under-order -- they didn't know what would happen -- so everyone over-ordered," he said. "The sell-through rate is not living up to the original hype."

HEADLINE: JAPANESE DELAYED LETTING U.S. KNOW OF BIG BANK LOSS

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The Japanese Government said today that it knew of a huge loss by a rogue trader at Daiwa Bank's New York operation six weeks before American regulators were told of the $1.1 billion scandal. The failure to inform Washington comes as both Governments have said that they are working closely on sensitive financial issues.
Several American officials said in private that they were outraged by Japan's failure to disclose the scandal, which led to the resignations today of top officials of Daiwa Bank. In public, they said simply that the issue of notification was just one of many aspects of the incident under investigation. 
 The disclosure raised a host of questions about why officials in Japan's Ministry of Finance kept their counterparts in Washington in the dark for so long, particularly when Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has been expressing grave concern about the solidity of the Japanese banking system. Mr. Rubin has said recently that the cooperation between Tokyo and Washington is close on issues ranging from efforts to support the dollar to Japan's program to revive its economy.
Treasury Department officials declined to be interviewed on the subject, but even from the muted statement the department issued today it was clear that Japan's failure to notify Federal regulators was regarded as a serious breach.
"The Daiwa Bank situation is an open investigation at the Justice Department, and I cannot comment on this issue," said Howard Schloss, the chief spokesman for Mr. Rubin. "As a matter of policy if Japan or any country's regulatory authorities become aware of significant financial issues of concern to the United States, we would expect to be fully informed in a timely manner. If this were not to occur, it would be a matter of great concern to us."
Federal and state banking regulations require a bank operating in New York to report immediately any significant improprieties that it discovers and any development that significantly affects its previous financial statements. Daiwa has said that it was not aware that this was a legal requirement and that it regarded as only an opinion the advice of its American law firm that it report the losses promptly.
Today's disclosures effectively spread responsibility for the scandal beyond the bank to include the Japanese Government as well. Japanese officials insisted that while they knew about the suspicions of improprieties -- including a letter describing the huge losses sent by the rogue trader to Daiwa's president in July -- they were under no obligation to tell American officials that United States laws might have been broken. Kyosuke Shinozawa, Japan's Vice Minister of Finance, said today that it was Daiwa's responsibility, not the ministry's, to notify American regulators.
"If it is true, it's certainly a dent to their credibility," S. David Snoddy, a bank analyst with Jardine Fleming Securities Ltd., said of today's disclosures and the ministry officials. "And it shows they knowingly allowed a bank under their supervision to basically break the rules of another country."
"It certainly changes how the public sees them," he added. "It moves from a situation of Daiwa being on trial to the ministry being on trial."
There were also suggestions today that Daiwa issued misleading statements two weeks ago when the scope of the loss was made public.
At the time of the initial disclosures, it appeared that Toshihide Iguchi, a Japanese-born bond trader in Daiwa Bank's New York office, had deceived the bank for 11 years, losing $1.1 billion and forging 30,000 trading slips and other documents to cover up his mounting losses. Daiwa has said that it first learned of the huge deception from the rambling 30-page confession that Mr. Iguchi sent to Tokyo in July.
Daiwa had earlier said that Japanese and American regulators were notified simultaneously, on Sept. 18, about the scandal. But Daiwa executives said at a news conference today that they had informally advised the Ministry of Finance's top banking official, Yoshimasa Nishimura, of the problem on Aug. 8.
While the ministry confirmed that the meeting with the bank occurred, it tried to play it down, suggesting that it was a chance meeting and that Mr. Nishimura was given only sketchy information. It also denied that it was backtracking on previous statements about exactly when it was told of the losses by Daiwa.
"It was a very difficult and delicate case," said a ministry official, who insisted on not being identified. "At that time, the financial authorities judged it was premature to share the information with other authorities."
At the Aug. 8 meeting, Akira Fujita, the president of Daiwa, told the ministry that he had received a letter from an employee in its New York branch. Mr. Fujita added that the letter stated that the trader had incurred a big loss from United States bond dealings, according to Toshio Muraki, the director of the commercial banking division at the ministry.
Mr. Fujita said then that the bank was not sure of the letter's accuracy and was investigating it, according to Mr. Muraki.
Mr. Nishimura at the ministry then told Mr. Fujita to "find out the situation as soon as possible and report to us immediately when you do," Mr. Muraki said.
On Sept. 12, Daiwa told the ministry of the $1.1 billion loss and gave a general outline of how it happened. Daiwa did not make its official report to United States authorities until six days later, and Finance Ministry officials did not inform the United States either.
Another ministry official emphasized that it was the bank's responsibility, not the ministry's, to inform American authorities of the scandal.
"We receive all kinds of whistle-blower calls everyday, but we do not report it before we clarify whether it is true," Mr. Muraki said today in a phone interview. "On Sept. 12, we told the bank to report to authorities including the Bank of Japan and the United States institutions as soon as possible, but I did not tell them they should do it within a certain number of days."
Mr. Muraki also mentioned that Sept. 15 was a national holiday. However, on Sept. 14, Daiwa Bank reported the losses to the Bank of Japan, according to news reports in Tokyo.
"We just said we received a report on Sept. 18 because that was the date the official report was submitted," Mr. Muraki said, referring to the day Daiwa turned in its official report of the loss to the ministry.
David Threadgold, a bank analyst at BZW Securities (Japan) Ltd., said of the Federal Reserve, "If I were the Fed, I'd be furious."
Daiwa officials also disclosed today that its United States subsidiary, Daiwa Bank Trust, had hidden $97 million in losses from financial authorities since 1987.
Today's disclosures were made at the same time that Daiwa announced the resignations of Mr. Fujita and Sumio Abekawa, the chairman. Mr. Fujita's resignation takes effect immediately, but Mr. Abekawa will not step down until March.
Mr. Iguchi has been arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Three other Daiwa employees in the New York branch office worked with Mr. Iguchi in trading Treasury bonds, but it is unclear whether they were aware of Mr. Iguchi's deception, Japanese newspapers reported today. Still, the reports speculated that American authorities might consider the three Japanese employees as accomplices because they worked under Mr. Iguchi.
The Daiwa scandal has further tainted American perceptions of Japanese financial institutions as Japan's banks try to deal with at least $500 billion in bad loans. Because of all these problems, even the best of Japan's banks are paying at least a quarter of a percentage point more than prevailing interest rates when they raise funds in overseas money markets.

SECTION: Section D; Page 14; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 818 words

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 42.99 Points; Technology Issues Feel Pressure

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market stumbled badly yesterday, pulled down by many of the same technology stocks that have been the leaders of this year's rally.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 42.99 points, or nearly 1 percent, to close at 4,726.22. 
 Of the major market indicators, the greatest fall was taken by the Nasdaq composite index, which is loaded with technology issues. It sank 27.30 points, or 2.70 percent, to 984.74. This decline, on better than average trading volume on the Columbus Day holiday, brought the index to its lowest level since Aug. 3, when it closed at 983.75.
"It was a one-story market focused on technology earnings," said Barbara G. Marcin, vice president of Citibank Global Asset Management. "It will be important to see what carries through tomorrow when everyone is back."
Wall Street has become increasingly worried that corporate profits for the latest quarter will prove disappointing. In the last month, almost 100 companies have warned that their earnings would be sharply below analysts' expectations.
"When companies pre-announce lower-than-expected earnings, they are really getting clipped," Ms. Marcin noted.
With the Treasury bond market closed yesterday because of the holiday and little in the way of outside news to influence stocks, prices were more related to anticipated or reported weak profits than to any other single factor.
The selling on Wall Street sent the Dow industrials down as much as 57.47 points during trading. As soon as it fell 50 points, the New York Stock Exchange invoked its "circuit breaker" rules, which were established after the 1987 market crash to limit excessive market volatility.
Computer-guided trading was responsible for almost half the decline in the Dow, according to Birinyi Associates. "Program trading played a major part in the drop in the Dow, but it was not the only factor," said Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst at Birinyi.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks eased 4.12 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 578.37. And the American Stock Exchange market value index closed at 527.48, down 6.06 points, or 1.14 percent.
Declining issues on the Big Board exceeded advancers by more than 2 to 1, at 1,641 to 623. But in contrast to the steady turnover on Nasdaq, only 275.3 million shares changed hands in slow trading on the New York exchange, compared with 313.7 million shares on Friday.
Nasdaq volume on the holiday was 416.3 million shares, compared with an average daily volume in 1995 of 374 million shares. Turnover on Nasdaq has exceeded 500 million shares during eight sessions in 1995, including the all-time record volume day of 597.5 million shares on July 19.
Nasdaq's automated trading system was closed down for an hour yesterday, officials said, because of a computer failure. The problem is the latest in a series of glitches related to a broad upgrade of Nasdaq computer systems aimed at handling the market's rapid growth. In July 1994, a software problem led to several shutdowns of the nation's second-largest market, one of which lasted for two and a half hours.
Among technology issues, three companies that projected disappointing earnings on Friday all suffered declines yesterday. Novell fourth-quarter fell 2 3/4, to 14 5/8. DSC Communications sank 5 1/8 a share, to 39 1/4. And BMC Software dropped 8 3/4, to 34 1/2.
Other technology shares that fell included those of Micron Technology, down 5 5/8, to 65; Microsoft, down 2 3/4, to 83 1/8; Intel, down 1 7/8, to 60 1/8; and Cisco Systems, down 2 5/8, to 64 7/16.
I.B.M. fell 2 1/8, to 92; Hewlett-Packard lost 2 5/8, to 78 1/4, and Texas Instruments dropped 4 1/2 to 70 3/8.
The Andrew Corporation, which was downgraded yesterday by a Merrill Lynch analyst, plunged 10 7/8 a share, to 43.
Scientific-Atlanta said late last week that its first-quarter profits would not meet Wall Street estimates; yesterday, its shares tumbled 3, to 12 5/8. Performance Systems International predicted a third-quarter loss and dropped 1 1/2, to 15 1/8.
Duracraft lost a third of its value, falling 12 1/2, to 24 3/4. The company, which makes heaters, said its third-quarter earnings would fall more than 60 percent.
Shares of forest products and paper companies -- one of the so-called cyclical groups that are highly sensitive to changes in the economy -- were also sluggish, as traders demonstrated concerns over their economic prospects. International Paper closed at 37 5/8, down 1 3/8 a share; Georgia-Pacific closed at 82 5/8, down 2 3/8; Mead closed at 54 3/4, down 1 1/2; Boise Cascade closed at 37 7/8, down 1 5/8, and Weyerhaeuser closed at 44 3/4, down 3/4.
Some brand-name consumer stocks bucked the downward trend, with analysts citing their ability to export successfully even if the United States economy weakened. Shares of Coca-Cola rose 7/8, to 71 5/8, and those of Procter & Gamble advanced 1, to 81 1/8.

HEADLINE: World Bank Urges Congress To Restore Promised U.S. Aid

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Finance ministers joined with the president of the World Bank today in pressing Congress to restore large amounts of money it is planning to cut from the United States' contribution to a key international development agency. They said such reductions would deal a severe blow to very poor nations.
The World Bank's development committee said the proposed cuts facing the International Development Association, the bank's soft-loan agency, "present a very serious risk to poverty reduction and economic growth in the world's poorest countries." 
 The 24-nation development committee "expressed great concern that potential reductions in contributions to I.D.A. were likely to jeopardize its future," and it stressed that other contributing nations attached great importance to "equitable burden-sharing," meaning that the United States should pay its share of the $18 billion fund.
If a nation fails to pay its contribution, others have the right to cut back their payments proportionately, as Germany and several other countries have hinted they may do if Congress withholds funds. The World Bank's new president, James D. Wolfensohn, responded with a terse "no" when asked if he had received any assurance that others would maintain financing if the United States reduced its contribution.
Mr. Wolfensohn, at a closing news conference here, said today, "For me, this is the single most important challenge in recent years to development assistance," adding that "a weakened I.D.A. would greatly hurt world stability." His remarks came at the end of a weekend of meetings here of finance ministers and central bankers of leading industrial nations.
Today's appeal reinforced a similar one over the weekend by the Committee of 24, a body representing all regions of the developing world. Both are 11th-hour efforts to influence Congress on the eve of a crucial conference between House and Senate representatives later this week that will seek agreement on a new United States aid bill.
The Clinton Administration has agreed to contribute $1.25 billion annually over three years to the fund, but the Senate has cut this year's installment to $775 million, and the House wants to provide $575 million.
The International Development Association offers long-term loans at nominal rates of interest to 78 countries with per-capita incomes of less than $865, in an attempt to jump-start their economic development.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Earnings at Motorola Rose By 30.5% in Third Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Motorola Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 30.5 percent in the third quarter, less than what some analysts had expected.
A slowing United States economy and declining prices for cellular phones contributed to the disappointing earnings, analysts said. 
 Motorola earned $496 million, or 81 cents a share, up from $380 million, or 65 cents, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 21.1 percent, to $6.85 billion, from $5.66 billion.
The results were slightly below the average estimate of 83 cents, based on 25 analysts surveyed by Ibes International Inc. The highest estimate was 89 cents.
The results were announced after the stock market had closed. Earlier, shares of Motorola, which have fallen 9 percent in the last week, rose 25 cents, to $69, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Noting the number of big technology companies that have disappointed Wall Street in recent weeks, analysts said they expected Motorola's shares to fall today.
And the declining demand in the cellular industry portends a more difficult fourth quarter for Motorola, with slowing growth, analysts said.
"The December quarter coming up may be less than stellar overall for the industry," said Rakesh Sood, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist, who had expected Motorola to have sales of more than $7 billion and per-share earnings of 84 cents.
In the third quarter, sales in the company's general systems business rose 21 percent, to $2.6 billion, with orders rising 14 percent. Motorola said growth in the cellular business was moderating in the United States and Europe, but continued to grow in other international markets.
"Cellular revenue was lower because the U.S. cellular market hasn't shown good growth this year," said Nikos Theodosopoulos, an analyst with UBS Securities.
Prices for cellular phones fell "somewhat more quickly" during this quarter than in the past, said Chris Galvin, president and chief operating officer for the company.
Sales of semiconductor products rose 28 percent, to $2.3 billion, with orders increasing 23 percent. Demand for chips in the personal computer and work station markets was highest, especially for the company's reduced instruction set microprocessors.
The company's gross margin narrowed to 35.9 percent, from 37.5 percent in the quarter a year ago because of increased start-up costs for chip manufacturing plants.
Motorola, like most other chip makers, is scrambling to add capacity for making chips. The company announced plans to spend $3 billion on a chip plant near Richmond to build Power PC microprocessors.

HEADLINE: Silent for Months, Health Lobby Takes On G.O.P.

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
For months, Republican plans to curb Federal health care spending have sailed along on a silent wave of interest group approval, or at least resignation, that seemed remarkable after the brawl over President Clinton's health care legislation.
While Democrats denounced the plans, advocates for the elderly were all but silent. Doctors bought an advertisement praising the plan. The insurance industry approved. The hospitals stuck out in their unhappiness, but even they seemed to have toned it down since last spring. 
 But now, cracks are showing. The American Medical Association is starting to complain about the impact on care; the American Association of Retired Persons is planning an advertisement campaign to declare that the cuts are too deep.
Weeks of flattering courtship and consultation of one group after another in Speaker Newt Gingrich's office, an effort that resulted in many provisions dear to their hearts, may not be enough to satisfy the major players because of one simple problem: money. If Republicans succeed in squeezing half a trillion dollars out of the health care system, hardly anyone will avoid a serious hit.
Some players worry that the trade-offs they were offered will be watered down or eliminated, while the Republicans stick to their overall dollar figures. At the heart of the plan in both houses of Congress is an effort to save $270 billion from Medicare, the health program for the elderly and disabled, and another $182 billion from Medicaid, the state-Federal program that serves the poor. The Medicaid program includes elderly who have become poor because of medical and nursing expenses.
Doctors know that the sharp curbs on malpractice lawsuits that Mr. Gingrich favors face a tough future in the Senate. Nursing homes worry that promises of access to the financial resources of their patients' adult children may not be kept. And all those, like teaching hospitals or community health centers, who were promised some sort of financial safety net know that such a commitment may be hard to maintain in a time of shortage.
Some of the earlier silence may have been dictated by a sense that Republican success was inevitable. But there was that same sense, for a time, about the Clinton plan; indeed one of the main reasons it failed was that many groups that liked it generally spent all their energy on their own particular interests, and none on overall support.
The pace of the Republicans' efforts may diminish the influence of the growing doubts. Their actual legislation only became available for inspection in the last week or so, and until then, the uncertainty about it stilled most lobbying forces. Republicans plan votes in both houses later this month, which leaves potential opponents little time.
The players had more time to focus on the Clinton plan. Its details were available in late September 1993, the bill itself by Oct. 28, and nobody expected votes on the floor before late spring of 1994. (In the end there were none at all because the plan was bleeding to death, riddled by months of attack advertisements.)
This year there has been less time to react, which may make the lobbyists less effective. But the shifts among interest groups are still important.
Take the American Medical Association, among the most ardently wooed organizations and a natural Republican ally. It negotiated early and often and started out supporting the plan until it soured on it last week. Indeed, as recently as Sept. 27, the A.M.A. bought an advertisement in The Washington Times to say: "Now it's time for action. Let your Representatives know you support the House Leadership's effort to reform Medicare."
And last week Kirk Johnson, the A.M.A.'s general counsel, said the group still believed that the plan faced up to long-term financing problems and liked its effort to reduce the threats of antitrust and malpractice lawsuits against doctors -- changes that enrage some consumer advocates.
"We are willing to take our fair share of pain for all the positive things that are in the bill," Mr. Johnson said.
But he continued, "What we can't agree to is price rollbacks that will impact on the quality of care."
The reductions were so severe, he said, that they "will unquestionably cause some physicians to leave Medicare."
The A.M.A.'s overall position is not settled. Officials have been promised another meeting with Mr. Gingrich; something might be worked out then.
Another case is the National Association of Community Health Centers, a smaller player, which represents centers in inner cities that treat about nine million people a year, most of them on Medicaid.
The Senate Finance Committee went out of its way to insulate these centers, a War on Poverty invention from the 60's that even House Republicans used to say was the real route to medical care for everyone. The committee voted to set aside for the centers 1 percent of the new state block grants that will replace the existing Medicaid program.
But Dan Hawkins, the policy director of the health center association, said his group remained "deeply concerned that the level of resources in this bill and the structural changes that the legislation would make in the Medicaid program are going to have significant negative effects for not only access to care for low-income Americans, but on the cost of care for all Americans."
Or consider the American Association of Retired Persons. Its friendly nonendorsement of the Clinton plan in 1993 and 1994 was a grave disappointment to the Administration. Instead of bolstering the President's plan, the association campaigned for more commitments to the elderly beyond the ones the President promised, like coverage for prescription drugs.
With its 35 million members, the retirees' group has been of particular interest to Speaker Gingrich. Its legislative director, John Rother, acknowledged last week that the Republicans "have been responsive to some of our concerns, by taking off the table increases in co-payments and deductibles, and even more by fundamentally permitting the fee-for-service Medicare program to continue."
But on Thursday, Tess Canja, an association board member speaking for the organization, told Senate Democrats that "the $276 billion in Medicare spending reductions in the Senate Finance Committee proposal is too much, too fast."
And Mr. Rother said today that his group's leaders would start taking their concerns to the membership.
Money is not what bothers the Health Insurance Association of America, the industry's dominant trade group, whose television advertisements made stars of Harry and Louise and devastated the Clinton plan.
What bothers the trade group are the rules surrounding a provision designed to please the doctors and the hospitals, enabling them to join to provide care in what are called provider sponsored networks, without going through insurance companies.
Bill Gradison, president of the insurance association, scoffed at the Republican plan as a "tip of the hat to the doctors and the hospitals," and he warned against the lack of regulation.
"This is shades of the S & L situation," Mr. Gradison said. "If these entities are allowed to operate and become insolvent, who picks up the tab?"
But that is the provision before Congress that the hospitals like best. Richard J. Pollack, executive vice president of the American Hospital Association, said, "If we are to be able to manage in the future, this is critical."
Insurers "don't want the competition," Mr. Pollack said.
But Mr. Johnson of the A.M.A. said, "The challenge to find economies and efficiencies is something that ultimately doctors are going to have to do." It is essential to give networks a boost at the start, he said, by freeing them from "the potentially heavy hand of regulation by the states."
Mary Nell Lehnhard, speaking for another foe of the Republican plan, the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, said, "We're concerned that all the consumer protections are going out the window."
The problem could be severe, Ms. Lehnhard said, because the provider networks "will be in the individual market, which is so high-risk."
The dispute over provider networks is the biggest example of how complicated any political intervention in the health business can be. Without extra money, it is hard to please one player without displeasing another. And when the money is less, not more, it is just about impossible not to displease many.
The only criticism that is yet on the airwaves is in television advertisements by unions and the Democratic National Committee. Neither is spending much money. Among the providers, the disagreements have thus far been relatively mild. Only the retirees' group is talking about any full-fledged public campaign, and it does not plan to use television.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1717 words

HEADLINE: The Rebellion in 'Pole City'

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: CLYDE, Ohio

 BODY:
Two sets of poles carrying a welter of transmission lines run parallel down the narrow streets of this town -- one for the big regional power company, Toledo Edison, and the other, newer set for a municipal utility created six years ago, Clyde Light and Power.
This conservative farming community of 6,000 people nestled amid the cornfields and fruit orchards of northeastern Ohio might seem an unlikely recruiting ground for a consumer rebellion against America's powerful utility industry. But in the late 1980's, soaring electricity bills persuaded residents to break their ties with Toledo Edison and set up their own transmission system. Today, most of them are hooked up to it -- and enjoying a savings windfall averaging more than $200 a year. 
 "It's a new ball game of lower costs," boasts Dennis E. Benesh, the manager of Clyde Light and Power, as he guides his Jeep Cherokee along streets so jammed with utility poles that newspapers in the region have taken to calling it Pole City.
Clyde officials may not have realized it at the time, but in kicking out Toledo Edison they were helping to revive a movement that briefly swept the country early in the century: municipalization. The original wave created thousands of publicly owned systems. Today, about 2,000 survive and serve one in seven Americans, mostly in small towns but also in some big cities like Seattle, Nashville and Los Angeles.
And now, a growing number of localities again are opting for ownership. In a trend that runs counter to the groundswell to privatize city services from garbage collection to running airports, 33 municipal systems have been formed since 1980, industry analysts say. Currently, 25 communities are actively pursuing conversion and scores more are studying the idea. Among those furthest along are Palm Springs, Calif.; Las Cruces, N.M., and Alma, Mich. Voters in Aberdeen, N.J., will decide in a referendum on Nov. 7 whether to make the switch.
New York State's proposed takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, while a special case largely because of the mothballed Shoreham nuclear power plant, would follow a similar path of converting to public ownership in an attempt to get rates down. [Page D6.]
In the old days, the motive was necessity: rural areas could not get investor-owned utilities to come in because there was no profit in it. Today, the driving force is economics, with towns trying to get the utilities out.
But while municipal utilities offer savings averaging 25 percent, according to one industry study, creating them is fraught with dangers, as the town of Clyde found out. The cost can be considerable for localities with narrow tax bases. Opposition from established utilities can be fierce. And the investment could turn out to be a losing proposition over the long term.
It was not just higher electricity rates that prompted many municipalities in the 1980's to take a new look at an old idea. The United States was enjoying a surplus of electricity-transmission capacity, and changes in Federal law made it easier for big utilities to sell power outside their service areas. Most important, American industry was reorganizing -- and putting pressure on towns where its plants were situated to shop around for cheaper energy.
Sometimes, just threatening to abandon a utility can pay off. Brook Park, Ohio, considered but ultimately dropped plans to form a municipal system five years ago. The Ford Motor Company, which operates two engine plants in Brook Park, a Cleveland suburb, used its support for the proposal to negotiate lower rates from the Cleveland Electric and Illuminating Company. Ford donated part of the $8 million savings to Brook Park, which uses the money to send checks of about $185 to each utility customer in town every December.
"It's an important issue even in areas where it might be difficult and costly to accomplish," said Barry Abramson, a utility analyst for Prudential Securities. "It puts a lot of pressure on the local utility. That often leads to a negotiated resolution for lower rates."
Here in Clyde, most residents are delighted with the change, which has resulted in rates 25 percent below those charged by Toledo Edison. Even so, other localities contemplating public ownership would do well to study the town's example. Not only did it have to fight a rancorous battle to dislodge an entrenched energy provider, it also took a huge long-term gamble that it might yet lose.
"You may get most of the savings dropped in your lap anyway," as a result of deregulation in the power industry, said Robert D. Glynn Jr., president of Pacific Gas and Electric, the nation's largest utility.
Moreover, like other small utilities, Clyde Light and Power could be vulnerable to sudden changes in business conditions. For example, some critics wonder how well the Clyde system would do if the local Whirlpool Corporation plant, which generates 60 percent of the utility'srevenue, was to unexpectedly close or switch to another supplier.
And recently, Clyde officials disquieted even some supporters by trying to force Toledo Edison to cut off service to its few remaining customers and tear down its transmission lines, in effect replacing an old monopoly with a new one.
The idea for cutting loose from Toledo Edison was first floated in 1986 by a new town manager, Nelson Summit. The advantages seemed clear-cut: A municipal utility can shop around for cheap power, does not have to pay taxes or dividends to stockholders, and can raise money cheaply by issuing tax-free bonds. The town hired a consulting firm, which issued a report favoring municipalization. Meantime, a series of sharp rate increases by Toledo Edision had town residents grumbling.
Clyde officials gained a powerful ally when the Whirlpool factory, which employs 3,200 workers and is the anchor of the local economy, decided to support their drive.
Clyde tried to buy Toledo Edison's distribution system, but was rebuffed by an unrealistic asking price of $32 million. Then it explored the idea of setting up its own system of poles and lines. At town meetings and in full-page newspaper ads, Toledo Edison attacked the plan and reminded residents of the frequent outages that occurred with the old municipal utility that Clyde abandoned 25 years ago.
Even after voters approved bond issues totaling $11 million to build a system, Toledo Edison fought a rear-guard action, filing suit to retain the right to serve the community. Clyde ultimately agreed out of court to let Toledo Edison continue offering service. Toledo Edison has been able to hold on to some apartment buildings because the landlords prefer its policy of holding tenants, not landlords, responsible for unpaid bills. It has also kept some elderly and low-income customers by providing special services to them.
For John Courtney, one of the consultants instrumental in organizing the transition, the lesson of all this was clear. "Utilities will not roll over and play dead," he said. "If you don't have the stomach for this politically, don't waste your money."
Mr. Courtney, who heads his own consulting firm, crisscrosses the East and Midwest by plane and car advising more than a dozen towns on setting up municipal systems. He is skeptical about the notion that municipalities will get cheaper energy by sitting back and waiting for changes. While a number of states, including California, are lifting restrictions on the purchase of cheap power from providers in other states, change is coming slowly, he says.
Meantime, the industry remains highly regulated, and many utilities are burdened by cost overruns from nuclear power plants or other special costs that they are forced to pass on to consumers. Even Clyde's supplier of electricity is under pressure. Ohio Power, a unit of the American Electric Power Company, one of the country's largest utilities, faces enormous expenses for bringing many of its coal-fired plants into compliance with clean-air laws.
Mr. Benesh, the manager of Clyde Light and Power, is upbeat. He says the city negotiated a deal with Whirlpool that would require the company to pay $3 million of the utility's debt if Whirlpool switched to another energy provider. He also says he is keeping costs low with a staff of just five that operates out of a house that the city already owned, with the maintenance crew also using an older city-owned building.
For all his confident talk, doubts about Clyde's municipalization persist. And a recent effort by the town to establish itself as the sole energy supplier only galvanized a faltering opposition.
In January, the City Council decreed that all new hookups must be to the Clyde system, and it began proceedings before the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio to require Toledo Edison to take down its lines, an action that would force the remaining holdouts to switch to the Clyde system.
The move touched off a furor. A group of residents, mostly from the 300 remaining Toledo Edison customers, formed a protest group called Voice for Choice. Some of them showed up at City Council meetings, wearing T-shirts emblazoned with the group name.
"What's frightening people is that they will be a monopoly," said Tami Keegan, one of two founders of the group. Phyllis Wyss, the other, questioned the long-term viability of the local utility. "You have to look down the road," she said. "They have no way to generate electricity on their own."
Toledo Edison itself is counterattacking. It has gone to court to fight the town's move to take away its remaining customers. It has asked the state utility commission to force Clyde to reimburse it for a portion of its past investments. And it has undertaken a new public-relations offensive, warning residents that its forced withdrawal would deprive the town of $85,000 in taxes.
Fred J. Lange, the president of Toledo Edison, acknowledges that Clyde residents are getting lower rates for now, but estimates that the reduction is 15 percent, not 25.
Besides, he says, his utility is working to hold rate increases to a bare minimum, and that effort will eventually be evident when comparisons are made. "The spread will narrow," he said. "In the short term there will be savings. In the long run it's not the right way to go."
