HEADLINE: Kukrit Pramoj, Thai Ex-Prime Minister, Dies at 84

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Kukrit Pramoj, a former Prime Minister of Thailand who steered the country through a difficult and politically dangerous period after the end of the Vietnam War, died yesterday in Bangkok. He was 84 and had been hospitalized for heart disease and diabetes.
Mr. Kukrit -- who was usually addressed with the noble title of Mom Rajawong because he was the son of a royal prince -- was one of Thailand's most colorful, outspoken and versatile characters. He co-founded a newspaper and wrote political commentary, mastered classical Thai dancing and opened a school to teach it to younger generations, acted in a film -- "The Ugly American" with Marlon Brando -- and remained an unashamedly opinionated elder statesman until the end of his life. 
 It was as a defender of nascent Thai democracy in the 1970's that Mr. Kukrit is best remembered by historians of contemporary Southeast Asia. Prime Minister for only 14 months in 1975-1976, he faced the collapse of South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia to Communist movements, which many believed would soon threaten Thailand.
But Mr. Kukrit, rejecting the domino theory, established diplomatic relations with China and asked American troops to leave the huge bases from which they had mounted much of the war in Vietnam.
These bold steps were popular with Thai intellectuals, particularly leftists who had a influence on his thinking, John Bresnan, executive director of the Pacific Basin studies program at Columbia University, said yesterday. But his policies quickly provoked a conservative backlash. Mr. Kukrit and his Social Action Party were defeated in an election in 1976 that he had called in the hope of strengthening his political hand.
While Prime Minister, Mr. Kukrit tried to build a democratic polity strong enough to resist persistent pressures from the Thai Army, which has staged repeated coups over more than half a century. As late as 1987, when he was in his 70's, he was still defying the generals. After a speech in which he accused the military of trying to establish the equivalent of a Communist-style "politburo" to run the country, 250 ill-disciplined Thai Army rangers, troops known for violent behavior, arrived in buses from the remote northeast and tried to break into his home to threaten him.
When the Army commander, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, who is now Defense Minister, did not discipline the troops, a storm of criticism arose in the ever-bolder Thai press. Students from 21 institutions of higher education -- precursors of the student leaders and young professionals who would take to the streets to defend democracy in 1992 -- came to his home with bouquets of flowers, a touching, traditional Thai way of showing respect or making amends.
Mr. Kukrit was born on April 20, 1911, and was educated in Thailand and at Oxford University. At 25, he married Pakpring Tongyai and they had two children: a son, Rongrit, and a daughter, Visumitra. His political career began in 1946 with his election to the Thai Parliament. Several years later he co-founded the Thai-language newspaper Siam Rath. He did not withdraw formally from politics until about four years ago.
A quiet nationalist -- his dog barked only at Westerners, he would tell visitors with a chuckle -- Mr. Kukrit became a strong advocate of holding on to Thai traditions in architecture, language and the arts while others were rushing into the Westernization that accompanied a phenomenal economic takeoff. In the center of booming Bangkok, surrounded by rising concrete apartment blocks and offices, he lived in a classical Thai house built of tropical wood, and filled it with Thai treasures. He set a powerful, if increasingly lonely, example.
"We Thai can lead a life that is genuinely Thai and be quite happy about it," he said in an interview in 1987. "We don't have to live in Western houses or employ Western methods in our daily lives. If we were to limit ourselves to just being Thai people, I think we would be happier all around."
In addition to his immediate family, Mr. Kukrit is survived by a brother, Seni Pramoj, 90, also a former Prime Minister.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
South Africa McDonald's Loses Name

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 9

 BODY:
In a court ruling that could profoundly discourage American businesses planning to enter South Africa, the McDonald's Corporation has lost the right to call its restaurants now under construction here "McDonald's."
On Friday, a provincial court in Pretoria ruled that the company had abandoned its trademark by failing to use it since it first registered it in South Africa in 1968. It also closed two possible avenues for American corporations fighting for their trademarks: It held that McDonald's contention that it did not open a restaurant here because of apartheid sanctions made no difference, and it ruled that it did not matter that McDonald's is a household name in America since it is unknown here. 
 The International Trademark Association said the decision might be interpreted as turning South Africa into "a safe haven for trademark pirates."
McDonald's plans to appeal to a higher court. Also it hopes that the Registrar of Trademarks might reject the application by the winner of last week's lawsuit, a South African man who owns the Chicken Licken chain here and a hamburger stand in Durban that has been operating under the name McDonald's since 1978.
The new South African Government is even more upset. It is very eager to attract American investment and to get off the United States Government's "watch list" of countries that do not adequately protect intellectual property.
The Minister of Trade and Information, Trevor Manuel, said he would ask the Justice Ministry for a quick hearing of the appeal. "It is the Government's firm belief that foreign companies are entitled to proper intellectual property protection," he said.
The American Embassy has expressed its "surprise, dismay and concern" over the decision.
If Mr. Samboros does win, other American corporations may be even more hesitant than they are to invest in South Africa or open franchises here.
South Africans love things with American cachet, and the country is full of logos that look familiar but have something slightly off about them. There is a Toys R Us chain with the R backwards, but its mascot is a blue elephant, not Geoffrey the Giraffe. In the upscale Sandton City mall north of Johannesburg, there's a Spago's restaurant that serves salad by weight, a Ghirardelli's that doesn't sell chocolate and a Trumps that the Donald surely never licensed.
For now, George Samboros is the closest to owning the South African rights to Ronald McDonald, Big Macs and even the golden arches themselves. Using the profits of his chicken franchises, he plans to open a chain of McDonald's here.
"We will wait until we are the registered owner, and then, if the American corporation opens a restaurant called McDonald's, we will sue them for trademark infringement," said Sean Ryan, a lawyer for Mr. Samboros. Winning, he estimated, would entitle his client to about 5 percent of the gross sales of the outlets.
Inviting a court battle, McDonald's still plans to open its first two outlets, in Johannesburg and Cape Town under its own name on Nov. 16.
There's no reason to assume that politics or anti-American bias are behind the decision. South Africa has long had an independent judiciary, one that often overturned attempts by the apartheid-era Government to illegally imprison or ban dissidents. In this case, the court seems to be following the letter of the law.
McDonald's registered its trademarks here in 1968, 1974, 1979, 1980, 1985 and 1993. But under South African law -- as under American and British -- a company must use a trademark within five years to keep it.
McDonald's never opened a restaurant or licensed a franchise, and did not seem to have serious plans to do so until Mr. Samboros, in early 1993, asked the trademarks office to grant him the McDonald's name.
McDonald's sued to stop him, arguing that the law said well-known companies need not use their trademarks locally to protect them.

HEADLINE: Progress on Cuba

 BODY:
Neither Fidel Castro's Government in Havana nor hard-line Cuban exiles in the United States are happy with the Clinton Administration's eased policies on travel, humanitarian relief and cultural exchange with Cuba. But the new approach, incorporated in an executive order signed last week, well serves American interests. By letting ordinary Cubans receive more financial help from their American relatives and gain wider exposure to American ideas, Washington improves the chances for a liberalized political climate in Cuba.
Most of the travel and family assistance restrictions Mr. Clinton is now easing were imposed after Mr. Castro allowed thousands of Cubans to set sail across the Florida Straits last year. A new diplomatic agreement to expand legal migration of Cubans to the United States resolved that crisis. Mr. Clinton's order also allows American human rights and relief groups to widen the scope of their work in Cuba and American news organizations to open permanent bureaus there. 
 As advance word of the new American approach leaked out, Havana reacted warily. It correctly reads Washington's goal as undermining Cuban Communism. Hard-line Cuban-American groups object to any easing of restrictions. But more moderate Cuban-American voices welcome the chance to ease the suffering of family members back home, widen channels of communication and make it possible for American newspapers and broadcasters to report on conditions in Cuba.
Meanwhile, a harsh Republican bill that would tighten the outdated American economic embargo on Cuba has passed the House by a large margin and will soon be considered by the Senate. While Mr. Clinton has stopped short of lifting the embargo, he offers a much better approach to encouraging democracy in Cuba.

HEADLINE: Coffee Trading Move in Doubt

 BODY:
New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange Inc. canceled a special meeting that had been scheduled yesterday to vote on a proposed move to New Jersey, raising doubts about its relocation plans.
In a statement to its membership dated Oct. 5, the exchange noted that the meeting had been scheduled before New York City and New York State offered millions of dollars in a bid to keep the exchange in New York. 
 The statement added that the Coffee Exchange's Board of Managers would consider New York's new financing offer at its next regular meeting, scheduled for tomorrow.
Last week the city and state offered an incentive package worth $75 million to $80 million to the Coffee Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange, including $30 million in cash, in an effort to keep them in New York.
The Coffee and Cotton exchanges announced in July that they intended to build a joint trading facility in Jersey City, across the Hudson River from their current home at the World Trade Center in downtown Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Price of Global Warming? Debate Weighs Dollars and Cents

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
IF the world's climate is warming because of the burning of fossil fuels, how much will it cost to fix the problem? And is the fix worth the cost?
Some economists say that reducing emissions of heat-trapping carbon dioxide by 20 percent, as has been proposed to nations that signed the the 1992 climate treaty, would crimp the economy, reducing the gross domestic product of the United States by 1 percent to 2 percent. Others are more upbeat, saying that simply making energy production more efficient would take care of the problem -- at a net profit to the economy. 
 The debate over the costs and benefits of averting climate warming has suddenly assumed new pertinence now that the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is concluding for the first time that at least part of the global warming of the last century was probably caused by the heat-trapping greenhouse gases emitted by the burning of fossil fuel.
The panel's scientists have estimated, according to recently revealed drafts of a new report, that the world's average surface temperature will rise by 1.4 to 6.3 degrees Fahrenheit over the next century unless emissions of carbon dioxide are reduced, and that this amount of warming will probably cause widespread dislocations in the economies and environments of nations.
The economic argument over how best to address these consequences will come to a boil starting tomorrow in Montreal, where a subgroup of the intergovernmental panel is to meet for three days to draw up its final report to policy makers on the costs and benefits of reducing greenhouse gases. The intergovernmental panel's mission is to advise the parties to the 1992 treaty.
As the Montreal meeting convenes, there appears to be a wide measure of agreement on one major point: that the world has significant opportunities to control emissions by making its energy system more efficient, and that these opportunities should be seized. Since energy efficiency is desirable for economic reasons, many economists argue, achieving it in the interest of heading off global warming amounts to a policy of "no regrets."
But there the arguments begin.
One school of thought holds that by carrying out the available means of improving energy efficiency, likemore efficient automobiles, emissions could be reduced by 60 percent over the next few decades. At the same time, according to this analysis, the more efficient use of energy would increase the gross domestic product by 1 percent to 2 percent. This gain does not include the benefits of averting the damage caused by climate change.
On the other side are the economic modelers, whose simulations show that reducing emissions by 20 percent below 1990 levels by the year 2010 would reduce the gross domestic product of the United States by 1 percent to 2 percent. This calculation also does not include the benefits of reduced damage to the climate.
The flaw in the modelers' analysis is that it assumes that the economy is already using energy as efficiently as possible and therefore underestimates the potential of more efficient energy practices, said Dr. Florintin Krause, an author of the intergovernmental panel's chapter covering the subject. Dr. Krause is an energy economist with the International Project for Sustainable Energy Paths, a research organization in El Cerrito, Calif.
The modelers reply that these efficiencies cannot be achieved on the scale that Dr. Krause believes. "We all agree there is some free lunch out there," said Dr. Richard Richels, an economist at the Electric Power Research Institute, an organization in Palo Alto, Calif., that is supported by the power industry. "What we don't agree on is how much." Dr. Richels, an expert on modeling, is also an author of the intergovernmental panel's report. "It's somewhat of a gamble as to who's right," he said. "Over time, we'll learn who's right."
Another author of the panel's report, Dr. William R. Cline of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said that even if Dr. Krause was right, the early and relatively easy "no regrets" reductions would represent a one-time windfall whose impact would not come close to solving the emissions problem in the long term.
Both Dr. Richels and Dr. Cline argue that the long-term view should prevail, and this raises perplexing issues as to the timing of emissions reductions. Too large a reduction now, Dr. Richels said, could work a financial hardship on the economy by forcing it to replace physical plant and equipment with new technologies prematurely.
The intergovernmental panel, in a draft report, said there would be at least two replacement cycles over the next century. Each would offer an opportunity to adopt alternative fuels and technologies like solar and wind power, electric and hydrogen-powered vehicles, fuels made from wood or grain and nuclear power if safety concerns can be met. It makes economic sense, Dr. Richels argues, to use the cheaper fossil fuels now, while investing in the research and development that can bring down the cost of alternative fuels and technologies and make them more attractive in the next investment cycle.
Another point of contention has to do with the trade-offs involved in deciding whether to take stronger action sooner rather than later. Some economists say the only economically efficient course is to make very modest emissions reductions and to delay even those. Others say this merely delays effective action, thereby favoring the economic well-being of the present generation at the expense of future ones: today's consumers would behave like grasshoppers rather than ants.
Few analyses of the costs and benefits of dealing with climate change look more than a century ahead. But Dr. Cline said this was not far enough for a true reading. He said that if no emissions reductions were made, enough fossil fuel remained to allow atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations to rise for 300 years before mixing processes in the deep ocean started to stabilize them.
Placing a dollar value on the benefits of avoiding damage from climate change is an even more difficult exercise than calculating the costs. Some experts say that in some ways it may be impossible: what is the worth, for instance, of the culture of an ocean island destroyed by rising seas? Nevertheless, a number of attempts to calculate benefits have been made. The potential damages to be avoided include, for example, agricultural losses, damage to natural ecosystems, inundation by rising seas, higher cooling bills, human illness, displacement of populations and damages from extreme weather.
Typically, studies value the benefit of avoiding damages caused in the United States by a doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide at 1 percent to 2.5 percent of the nation's gross domestic product -- roughly the same range of the modelers' estimates of cost. The benefits are probably higher for developing countries, Dr. Cline said.
But he points out that if the world pursues business as usual, atmospheric concentrations will not stop at a doubling. Concentrations three centuries from now could be eight times those of today, leading to a global average temperature about 18 degrees higher than now, he said. This would return the climate to something like that of the Cretaceous period, the heyday of the dinosaurs.
For this scale of warming, Dr. Cline calculates that the benefits of damage prevention in the United States would amount to at least 6 percent of the gross domestic product. The benefits of modest but increasingly stringent emissions reductions would exceed the costs at first, according to his analysis. But as soon as the early efficiency gains in fossil-fuel use have been exhausted, costs would outpace benefits for a few decades before benefits again exceeded them.
This calculation excludes what some scientists consider the possibility of catastrophe brought on by climate change. Some studies have suggested that a possible quadrupling of atmospheric carbon dioxide would so change the climate that the Gulf Stream would shut down. Without the Gulf Stream's warming influence, Northern Europe's climate could become as cold as that of Hudson Bay.
Many scientists also warn that there is no guarantee that warming or other climatic disruptions would be gradual; the system could suddenly shift to an unstable and highly damaging state. This possibility makes the estimate of climate damages and the benefits of preventing them even more uncertain.
In the face of this, many environmentalists invoke what is called the precautionary principle: although it is necessary to reduce costs as much as possible, cost should not stand in the way of whatever action is necessary to avoid the risk of catastrophe. A draft of the policy makers' summary of the working group about to meet in Montreal says that all told, the risk of "aggregate net damage" and the adoption of the precautionary principle "provide rationales for action beyond 'no regrets.' "

HEADLINE: Selloff Becomes 'Opportunity' as Stocks Reverse a Plunge

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Investors dived into a rapidly falling stock market yesterday morning to snatch up shares of stocks -- particularly those of computer, software, communications and other technology companies that had plunged more than 5 percent in less than three days.
The result was a sharp reversal of a stock market decline that swept around the globe yesterday, producing big losses in Asian and European markets. The rebound also provides an illustration of how fiercely American investors have embraced the faith that stock prices will continue to rise over the long term. 
 After dropping more than 60 points in the first half-hour of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average finished the session down 5.42 points, at 4,720.80, a decline of just eleven-hundredths of 1 percent. Similarly, the Nasdaq composite index, which is rich with technology issues and initially fell more than 25 points, or 2.6 percent, finished down a mere 1.27 points at 983.47. At its lowest point yesterday, the index was down 5.4 percent since Thursday and 10.1 percent since peaking at 1,067.40 on Sept. 13.
"What that tells me is that the decline in the technology stocks that led to a drop in the market is overdone," said Steve G. Einhorn, portfolio strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "These corrections are being increasingly and properly viewed as opportunities rather than an indication of any substantive problems."
Blindly buying stocks when the market declines could prove foolhardy if, as some market strategists believe, a general downtrend in stock prices continues through the end of the year. For his part, though, Mr. Einhorn believes that the stock market will be higher at the end of 1995 than it is now, the Dow by as much as 200 points.
Indeed, while the leading market averages finished slightly lower and more stocks declined in price than rose yesterday, share prices of several American technology companies rebounded yesterday to finish higher. Shares of the Intel Corporation, for example, rose $1.50, to $61.625, while those of the Microsoft Corporation rose 62.5 cents, to $83.75.
Investors in Motorola Inc. fared less well, though. The company, a maker of semiconductor chips and cellular phones, said on Monday night that it expected growth of its American and European cellular subscriber base to slow. Investors responded yesterday by sending its shares plummeting $5, to $64, on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was the day's most active issue.
By the time American equity markets opened yesterday, investors the world over had already spent most of the day generally selling shares, both in response to Motorola's news and the disappointing earnings estimate from Novell Inc., a computer software company, released on Friday night. The Novell report helped send the Nasdaq down 2.7 percent Monday while the Dow fell nine-tenths of 1 percent.
In addition, overseas investors turned skittish as further signs emerged of sluggish economic growth around the globe. In Hong Kong, stocks prices fell 1.4 percent; in Australia, where Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, said earnings at the media company might have fallen in the September quarter, prices slipped a similar amount. Markets in Japan were closed for a national holiday.
European markets followed with one of their worst days of the year. The FT-SE 100, the bellwether London stock index, fell 1.4 percent following forecasts that the British budget deficit would be higher than expected. Stock prices experienced similar declines in Germany and in France. And in Finland, home of Nokia A.B., a cellular-phone maker that competes with Motorola, share prices plunged 4.7 percent.
"Things sort of came undone today," said Nicholas Knight, head of strategy at Nomura Research Institute Europe in London. "There is a general feeling that the economic and interest-rate environment through the end of the year is going to give Europe a very rough time, that it is going to be weaker than that of the U.S."
In the United States, though, investors repeated the pattern they followed after a sharp selloff in technology stocks in mid-July. Then, Microsoft and Intel warned Wall Street analysts not to be too optimistic with projections, leading to a two-day decline of more than 5 percent in the Nasdaq composite index.
But any investor who bought stocks at that time would be in the black since then. Even after yesterday's decline, the Nasdaq composite remained more than 3 percent ahead of its close on July 19, when the index recorded its largest one-day drop since 1987.
Investors can expect more such situations in coming days in American markets and overseas, analysts said. "We're going to see more volatility the rest of the month," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers.
After seven quarters in which earnings exceeded expectations, "we're seeing something new to the market -- a lack of earnings momentum," he added. "But in order to have the weakness in technology stocks turn into a more general decline, the selloff will have to extend to the consumer and financial companies. That hasn't happened yet."
Technology stocks and the mutual funds that invest in them have taken a beating, though. In the last two sessions, funds that invest primarily in the shares of technology companies have fallen an average of 3.5 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services. Among the biggest losers were the First American Technology fund, which slumped 5.4 percent, and the FMR Corporation's Fidelity Select Software fund, which declined 4.8 percent.
Several diversified equity funds that invest heavily in technology shares also fell sharply. Robertson Stephens & Company's Value and Growth fund, which earlier this year had as much as 70 percent of its assets in technology stocks, fell 4.3 percent in the two-day span. Navellier's Aggressive Small Cap Equity fund plunged 6.9 percent in value in the same stretch.
The Fidelity Magellan fund fell only 2.8 percent, equal to the two-day decline in the Nasdaq composite index. At the end of July, the most recent report available, the Magellan fund had 43 percent of its assets in technology stocks.
While buyers rushed into the market to support technology issues after their sharp fall, broader economic trends might continue to work against stocks.
Charles Clough, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said that disappointing corporate earnings and declining profit margins were likely to hurt stocks enough to make bonds look more attractive for the rest of the year.
While the stock market is not suffering the sharp contraction in liquidity that occurred in 1987, Mr. Clough said stocks were likely to undergo a correction of about 10 percent between now and the year-end. At yesterday's close of 577.53, down 0.84 point, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was just 1.6 percent below the recent high of 586.77 it reached on Sept. 20.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Leaders Tell Clinton To Get Serious on the Budget

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Republican leaders today demanded that President Clinton stop playing politics and negotiate seriously on the budget. If he does not, they threatened, they would pass their own bills and let him take the blame if he vetoes them and the Government shuts down.
"The White House doesn't quite get it yet," Speaker Newt Gingrich said. "The legislative branch has very legitimate prerogatives." 
 At a news conference, Mr. Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, repeatedly assailed Mr. Clinton's political tactics of accusing Republicans of reducing Medicare spending to pay for tax cuts. Mr. Gingrich said the President used "scare talks on Saturday morning to frighten 85-year-olds in order to get through the next election." Mr. Dole said, "He's just prepared to play politics every day."
But clearly the Republican attack had some underlying internal problems. The complaints about Mr. Clinton's sharp attacks suggested that those denunciations were getting through to voters, even though Mr. Gingrich contended "we are gradually winning the fight" for public opinion on Medicare. Mr. Dole acknowledged that "there are some Americans who don't think we are going to produce."
For his part, President Clinton today returned the accusation of a lack of good faith about negotiation. He said, "There are a lot of ways we can meet and talk together, but we don't need to get into a fight about it." He said, "My door is open and we'll walk through it." He also said, "It's not clear to me what is going on in Congress."
What appears to be going on is that each side thinks the other is displaying no give at all. Each side is hoping to sell the public on this view, so that if no budget agreement is reached, the other side will get the blame.
With less than five weeks to go until temporary spending authority approved by Congress last month expires, Republicans have been increasingly quarrelsome. Mr. Dole was criticized even by Mr. Gingrich for a suggestion 10 days ago that the promised $245 billion in tax cuts might not be delivered. And Republican conservatives in the House killed two spending measures despite leadership appeals that they act responsibility.
Today the Republicans claimed perfect unity in their party, but at the same time announced two moves designed to improve it. One is a steering committee of leaders from both houses that will meet daily on budget and spending measures. Tony Blankley, Mr. Gingrich's press secretary, said the purpose was to make sure that both chambers moved in as much harmony as possible, "so there will be no daylight between our shoulders." That would minimize problems in House-Senate conferences, another highly placed aide said. Congress is so far behind schedule that lengthy conferences could make it Congress's fault if deadlines are missed.
The other step was to postpone a markup on the budget reconciliation scheduled for Wednesday in the House. The purpose is to hold a party caucus, and in particular to permit moderates whose votes could sink the plan, to vent their unhappiness at ideologically pure but legislatively difficult proposals like oil drilling in the Arctic National WIldlife Refuge.
Some moderates have grumbled that there was no point in asking them to cast politically dangerous votes for provisions that leaders knew would have to be scrapped before the Senate would agree to them as part of a House-Senate compromise on the budget resolution.
And while White House aides gleefully put today's Republican display down to fear of the Republican right, it seemed just as likely that concessions would be made to moderates in order to get legislation to Mr. Clinton before the temporary spending measures expires on Nov. 12.
Mr. Clinton spoke before the Republican news conference. But Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, seized on the Republican tone at a later news conference.
He said he was confident that the Democrats were scoring with the argument that Republicans were cutting Medicare, the health care program for the elderly, in order to finance a tax cut. "It's not just the seniors who are scared," he said. "I think the Republicans are scared." Senator Bob Graham of Florida joined in, saying Republican rhetoric was being employed as a substitute for any answer as to why they were cutting Medicare $270 billion to make up a shortfall of $89 billion.
The tone was certainly sharp, about as harsh as Mr. Clinton has been employing against Republicans lately, as when he accused them on Sept. 30 of planning to install "a Medicaid police with vast power to seize your assets and put you out of your home and make sure you have nothing left to pass on to your children."
When Mr. Gingrich was asked about the President's suggestion that the two sides compromise on economic assumptions, he said that that amounted to saying, "Let's find one more excuse to lie to the American people."

HEADLINE: Upbeat White House Visit For the President of Mexico

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The rescued came to thank the rescuer today, as President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico met President Clinton for the first time since the Administration sidestepped Congress to bail out the Mexican economy. The two leaders declared that jobs and prosperity had been saved on both sides of the border.
Mr. Zedillo's visit was an effort to turn a political liability -- the perception among many Americans that closer economic ties with Mexico have brought more misery than profit -- into a celebration of the country's return to some semblance of financial stability. 
 Mr. Clinton praised Mr. Zedillo's "courage and determination" in keeping Mexican markets open to American goods despite huge political pressure at home to exclude foreign products at a time when a million Mexican workers have lost their jobs in a deep recession.
For his part Mr. Zedillo, who was feted at a state dinner tonight, praised his host's "vision and courage" for lending funds to Mexico over Congressional and public objections, saying that Mr. Clinton had prevented a systemic economic crisis "of world scope."
Beyond the mutual praise, a few concrete agreements were announced today. The two countries ended a long-running dispute over the labeling and inspection of tires made in Mexico by American manufacturers, and the United States announced $70 million in financing from the Export-Import Bank to allow Mexico to purchase radar equipment for anti-narcotics operations.
But two other major trade disputes remain unresolved, despite last minute efforts before Mr. Zedillo's arrival: Mexico's refusal to speed up a reduction in tariffs on wine imports, and a continuing dispute with the United Parcel Service over its desire to use large trucks on Mexican roads.
But today was hardly a day when either side wanted to dwell on problems. Mr. Clinton made the case that the $12.5 billion loaned to Mexico -- another $7.5 billion was promised but will probably not be necessary -- profited both nations.
The United States Treasury has already received roughly $470 million in interest, in addition to an early repayment of principal on the loan, which Mr. Zedillo engineered last week by floating a bond issue on the private markets, a step that would have been impossible when the country seemed a far larger risk in the spring.
Responding to conservative critics like Patrick J. Buchanan and liberal opponents of the bailout like Ralph Nader, Administration officials have argued in recent days that their emergency loan program also succeeded in stemming far worse economic disruption and a surge of illegal immigration across the border.
"A strong, democratic Mexico will be an even more effective partner in the struggle against drugs and crime and pollution," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference at the White House.
But as Mr. Clinton's advisers have conceded privately in recent weeks, even the most favorable statistics, including the Administration's somewhat optimistic estimate that 340,000 jobs have been created as a result of the North American Free Trade Agreement, cannot shake the perception that the free trade accord and the bailout have yielded few benefits for American workers. And that, in turn, has fed into the broader political problem of an American work force seized by insecurity.
"This is a tricky political problem for the President," one of his close economic advisers said recently. "We were doing fine until the peso crisis. You could make a credible case that the Nafta was benefiting us. But now you get an earful wherever you go."
Even if Mexico resumes strong economic growth, however, it is unlikely that the Mexican market will become an engine of growth for American exports before the Presidential election. That has far more to do with the depth of Mexico's recession than with the trade accord itself. But in the public mind, the trade accord and the bailout are fused into one, and that has dampened any political enthusiasm for Mr. Clinton's biggest free trade initiative.
"Nafta has become a mirror for our political dilemma over trade," said Jeffrey E. Garten, the Undersecretary of Commerce for international trade. "While many gain, others lose, and the losers are much more visible."
Such realities have frustrated many of Mr. Clinton's closest aides. "There is a fiction around that U.S. personal income has gone down since Nafta was enacted; in fact, it has gone up," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. "Our share of imports in the Mexican market has gone up. Our total exports to Mexico are above what they were in 1993, despite the recession there. And it would have been an even greater success had it not been for the peso crisis."
Nevertheless, Mr. Buchanan, the most overtly anti-free-trader of the Republicans seeking the presidential nomination, wins huge applause whenever he makes the point that the United States' $2 billion trade surplus with Mexico has turned into a $15 billion trade deficit this year.
Mr. Zedillo dwelled on none of that today. Instead, he offered assurances that his administration would continue to fight drug trafficking and would attempt an experimental program of "repatriating" illegal immigrants caught in the United States, sending those who volunteer back to their hometowns rather than letting them sit on the southern side of the border, where they are likely to attempt another illegal crossing.
But most of all, Mr. Zedillo promised to continue his austerity program, the chief requirement American officials placed on his country in return for the loans.
"I am fully confident that we are going to achieve our growth goal," Mr. Zedillo said to Mr. Clinton today, "because throughout history the Mexican people have risen to the challenges and proven that we are capable of great achievements."

HEADLINE: Unlikely Allies Battle Congress Over Anti-Immigration Plans

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
As Congress today considers some of the most severe anti-immigration measures since the 1920's, it is facing resistance from a surprising alliance of high-technology manufacturers, religious leaders, conservative think tanks, civil liberties organizations and tiny, grass-roots immigrant groups.
From Microsoft, which is fighting limitations on visas for foreign computer scientists, to the Roman Catholic Church, which is battling for the rights of political refugees, the coalition is giving some heft to the loosely organized opposition by immigrants, who belatedly realized that the mood of the country had turned against them. 
 "There's a wide array of groups that think the legal immigration system is not broken and doesn't need radical changes," said Ira Rubinstein, a senior lawyer for Microsoft.
It is a loose alliance, and each group has its own concerns with the Omnibus Immigration Bill, which is to be taken up by the House Judiciary Committee today, as well as with similar proposals in the Senate. In New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has sided with the proposal's opponents and against many Republican leaders nationally.
The diversity of the opposition reflects the broad sweep of the various Congressional proposals, which began as an attack on illegal immigration and were broadened to restrict legal immigration as well.
Manufacturers, insistent that they need foreigners with special skills to remain competitive, oppose attempts to limit visas used by United States companies to hire foreign engineers, computer programmers and scientists. Ethnic groups in cities across the country denounce a proposal that would cut the annual level of legal immigration by 30 percent and restrict their rights to bring their foreign relatives here. Church organizations and immigration lawyers oppose pending cuts in the number of refugees and the rights of people seeking political asylum.
And a proposed national computer system to enable employers to check the legal status of prospective workers has drawn opposition both from civil liberties groups, who fear it would lead to discrimination, and from anti-regulation libertarians and business groups, who see it as an expensive and invasive growth of government.
"Most of these groups have never worked together before," said Rick Swartz, a lawyer who started the National Immigration Forum and is instrumental in the current coalition. "Some of them may have found this difficult to imagine a year ago."
These groups do not speak with a single voice, nor do they have a single agenda. But the cumulative effect of their activities is expanding what was a one-sided debate about how immigrants are draining the American economy to include at least some emphasis on the role of immigrants in helping the country stay competitive in the global economy and in restoring forgotten inner-city neighborhoods.
While it is unclear whether they are having any impact beyond that, the opponents of the new restrictions seem to have pushed the Judiciary Committee to consider splitting the omnibus bill into two, one focusing on illegal immigration and the other on legal.
Representatives have been lobbied from all sides. Both the Massachusetts Immigration and Refugee Advocacy Coalition and Reebok International, the shoe company, have lobbied Representative Barney Frank, a Democrat of Massachusetts who serves on the Judiciary Committee. The National Association of Manufacturers, Intel and the Cato Institute, a conservative study group in Washington, have lobbied Representative Lamar Smith, a Republican of Texas whose legislation contains the strong restrictions.
The most interesting union is between traditionally liberal immigration groups and pro-growth, free-trade conservative organizations, which defend immigration as a matter of principle and espouse the virtues of most immigrants. They have always agreed on the benefits of immigration, but rarely allied themselves publicly.
Steve Moore, an economist with the Cato Institute, called the restrictive proposals "anti-business, anti-family, anti-freedom."
And Luis A. Miranda Jr., the president of the Hispanic Federation of New York, said, "Unless we begin to educate the general public that immigrants don't make the cities and country worse, people see lack of employment, lack of opportunity and think we should close the door."
In June, President Clinton endorsed a recommendation of the Federal Commission on Immigration Reform to cut legal immigration by one-third. Dick Day, the chief counsel to the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, said the alliance fighting the proposals was "Washington groups and on the other side are the American people" who have asked for "some breathing space" from immigration. The subcommittee is led by Senator Alan K. Simpson, a Republican of Wyoming who is a chief proponent of the restrictive measures.
Representative Smith has said that opponents have overstated his bill's effect on both family members and skilled workers and that he was responding to a national consensus that legal immigration should be reformed.
John L. Martin, the research director of the Center for Immigration Studies, which supports the restrictive measures, said the opponents were "the very liberal element that is in favor of diversity in the country, business interests that benefit from a free flow of labor and people who simply don't like big government." He said the lobbying had led some members of Congress "to water down some of the proposals."
Opposition to the proposals has just recently been organized, two years after the anti-immigration movement began gathering steam behind California's Proposition 187, which bars illegal immigrants from public education and other benefits. California voters approved it overwhelmingly in November 1994.
"I think we are at the beginning of a pretty ferocious debate about the role of immigrants: Do we still want to be a nation of immigrants or do we want to throw up the walls and say 'No More'?" asked Frank Sharry, the executive director of the National Immigration Forum.
Pope John Paul II, during his United States visit last week, warned of the threats to the country's tradition of welcoming immigrants, a theme already sounded by the National Council of Catholic Bishops.
The anti-immigrant sentiment has created a sense of siege among immigrants, unifying ethnic groups that often exist in parallel worlds and stirring political activity in organizations initially established to serve the more basic housing and economic needs of immigrants.
"If you're a new immigrant, you're trying to hold down three or four jobs and get your kids in school," said Marjie McHugh, executive director of the New York Immigration Coalition. "There has not been time for political organizing. But because of what's been going on nationally in terms of the debate, it's speeding up that process."
The strength of the activism by immigrants and business leaders was demonstrated last month when, on one day, about 300 immigrants went to Washington to lobby members of Congress against restricting the immigration of family members. The next day, representatives of 65 companies organized by the National Association of Manufacturers and the American Immigration Lawyers Association showed up to make similar arguments against imposing restrictions on visas for skilled and professional workers.
Mr. Rubinstein, of Microsoft, disputed the contention that foreign workers were taking corporate jobs from Americans. He said that 25 percent of the job openings his company had last year -- about 1,000 positions -- remained vacant because qualified people could not be found, either here or abroad.
Last month, the National Immigration Forum held a series of news conferences in major cities to release a study titled "Together In Our Differences," profiling immigrant enterprises working to rebuild poor city neighborhoods.
The strong presence of business has added a new dimension to the issue, said Austin T. Fragomen, a New York lawyer who represents such companies as I.B.M., Procter & Gamble and Walt Disney. All three are concerned about how the proposals would restrict their freedom to hire foreign workers for jobs in the United States.
"When Congressmen think of immigration, they typically think of the Polish-American Alliance coming to beat up on them," Mr. Fragomen said. "They never had any idea business was interested in immigration."

HEADLINE: Opponents of Gay Topics Press Crusade

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Buoyed by fresh victories at local school boards in New Hampshire and Iowa, conservatives who believe that homosexual topics have no place in public-school curriculums are preparing to make their case to Congress.
A 34-year-old English teacher at a rural New Hampshire high school, Penny J. Culliton, was dismissed last month for insubordination because she had distributed novels, without school board approval, that depicted gay and lesbian characters. One was "Maurice" by E. M. Forster. 
 Two weeks earlier, Jonathan C. Wilson was defeated for re-election to the Des Moines school board, after having served 12 years. In a debate in January on gay and lesbian topics in the curriculum, Mr. Wilson, a 50-year-old father of two, publicly disclosed his homosexuality.
The Rev. Louis P. Sheldon, chairman of a nationwide church network called the Traditional Values Coalition, said he was "very much encouraged" by these developments. Mr. Sheldon and other conservative leaders oppose Federal aid to school districts in which there are gay and lesbian programs. They are marshaling witnesses for a Congressional hearing this fall.
Conservatives worry that teaching homosexual issues, themes and characters, particularly in a positive light, can sway students toward homosexuality at a vulnerable time. They also say parents are denied a voice in deciding how much their children should learn about such a divisive subject.
Mr. Sheldon said the introduction of such topics amounted to "parental rights being denied at the classroom level while Federal dollars, through different agencies, are used to promote and advocate the homosexual life style."
On the other side are those who maintain that all students benefit from lessons in diversity and acceptance of others, while homosexual and bisexual youths benefit especially from learning that they are not isolated, either culturally or historically. Advocates suggest this may inculcate a self-esteem that can carry a gay or lesbian teen-ager through suicidal despondency.
"They need to know that there are gay and lesbian people in history," said Jean Genasci, a vice president of Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays. "They need to know that they're O.K. as people. They have a right to feel safe in schools."
The Congressional hearing is to be held by an Economic and Educational Opportunities subcommittee. Representative Peter Hoekstra, Republican of Michigan, is the subcommittee chairman.
Although the hearing has been criticized as a tax-financed platform for Mr. Sheldon's views, Mr. Hoekstra's press secretary, Jon P. Brandt, said the panel would hear from all sides.
It was three years ago that the battle over the curriculum on diversity, the "Children of the Rainbow," erupted in New York City. Such fights have now reached rural areas like the Mascenic Regional School District in New Hampshire, about 25 miles southwest of Manchester.
That is where the board dismissed Ms. Culliton for distributing "Maurice" to seniors and "The Education of Harriet Hatfield," by May Sarton, to juniors. The books had been bought with a grant awarded for projects that focus on the needs of gay and lesbian youths.
Ms. Culliton said she chose those works because "each of them shows gay and lesbian people going about their lives, not perpetuating the usual stereotypes we see in literature, that if you're gay you must be psychotic or a child molester or promiscuous or alcoholic."
When she handed out the books last spring, Ms. Culliton had not been authorized to do so by the board. She said it had never before been the board's policy to require approval for anything except textbooks. But the board said that "thematically sensitive materials" were subject to special consideration and that Ms. Culliton's actions amounted to "willful insubordination."
The board emphasized that professional conduct was the issue, not anti-gay bias. "It definitely is not homophobia," said Steven B. Lizotte, the chairman.
Ms. Culliton disagreed, as did her union, the National Education Association. "If these books were about any other subject than homosexuality, Penny Culliton would not have been fired," said Dennis Murphy, public affairs director for the union in New Hampshire.
Ms. Culliton said she hoped to win her job back through arbitration. The day after her dismissal was announced, 40 students held a protest demonstration. "I think we can handle reading a book," said Amy Malboeuf, a sophomore.
In Des Moines, a curriculum fight exploded when a list was made public of an advisory committee's recommendations on how homosexual issues might be "thoughtfully infused in the educational program." The recommendations included a "discussion of how homophobia impacted the governmental response to H.I.V. disease" and "information on the Stonewall riots."
In the ensuing debate, Mr. Wilson disclosed he is gay, saying he did it so opponents could not use rumors of his homosexuality as a weapon. He had served on the seven-member Des Moines board since 1983, for three terms as president and two as vice president.
"We should defer to mom and dad and churches on the right and wrong of homosexuality," Mr. Wilson said. "But with respect to tolerance, respect and discrimination, even though we have kids coming to school thinking it's O.K. to discriminate, the schools should teach otherwise."
A leader in the fight against the curriculum and Mr. Wilson's re-election was Bill Horn, the Midwest regional director of the Report, a group that reports instances and evidence of what it calls the "gay agenda," which is also the title of a videotape it distributes.
"We want respect and tolerance for all students -- period," Mr. Horn said. "You don't have to single out homosexual students. There are more overweight people than gay people but we don't have classes on the historical contributions of overweight people."
Mr. Horn's efforts were endorsed by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination. "Thank God for Bill and the thousands of parents who would not be intimidated by the liberal media or the radical homosexual community," Mr. Gramm declared in a letter to Iowa voters just before a straw poll in August.
Mr. Wilson said he raised $60,000, an extraordinary sum for a school board race, and "was still outspent by my detractors by about 2 to 1." On Sept. 12, nearly 30,000 voters cast ballots, more than four times the normal turnout. Mr. Wilson placed last in a field of four candidates for two seats.
"We're dealing with a new phase in the evolution of the radical right," Mr. Wilson said, "because now they have demonstrated their confidence in their ability to turn out voters who'll march in lockstep, or perhaps I should say goose step.
"Even my detractors knew I was the best qualified candidate. They all know that the reason this person didn't get the job was solely and exclusively because he was a gay man."
But Mr. Horn said Mr. Wilson had only himself to blame. "He wasn't defeated because he was homosexual," Mr. Horn said. "He was defeated because he became a homosexual activist."
Dan Woog, author of "School's Out: The Impact of Gay and Lesbian Issues on America's Schools" (Alyson Publications, 1995), said he saw benefits from the Culliton and Wilson cases.
"When I was in school in the mid-70's," Mr. Woog said, "the 'G' and 'L' words were never spoken. Now they're being talked about, even if negatively. Kids are recognizing they're not alone. They're learning that people are out there fighting for them."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
World Bank Chief Backs Public Projects

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The new president of the World Bank, James D. Wolfensohn, said today that he wanted the institution to do more to encourage private investment in developing countries, but that it would also continue to back large public projects.
He also again criticized Congress for planning sharp cuts in the United States' contribution to the International Development Association, the World Bank's agency that helps poor countries; he warned that American companies could be excluded from overseas contracts as a result. 
 Speaking to world finance ministers here, Mr. Wolfensohn said the World Bank would increase its efforts to help developing countries "attract private and public investment in high-quality projects."
These would include "helping governments strengthen their business regulatory and financial systems in order to provide the assurance to private investors that they will have no nasty surprises in carrying out their plans," he said.
But Mr. Wolfensohn made clear that he still saw an important role for the World Bank in its traditional business of financing large public projects despite his recent decision to cancel a $1 billion dam in Nepal.
The institution's "original genius remains as valid, if not more valid, today than it was five decades ago," he said, referring to the developing world's need for power plants, ports and roads -- especially in the fast-growing economies of Asia.
Some of those who heard Mr. Wolfensohn today, in his first address to members of the World Bank, were disappointed that he did not offer a more sweeping vision of the bank's future. President Clinton's choice of Mr. Wolfensohn, a 61-year-old investment banker, had raised expectations that he could revitalize the international development effort much as Robert McNamara did when he took over the World Bank in 1968.
In addition to his criticism of planned Congressional cuts in financing for the World Bank, Mr. Wolfensohn said that American corporations as well as the poor would both lose if Congress enacts the cuts later this week.
At a news conference before his address, he said that if other countries made up the expected shortfall in the American contribution to the International Development Association this year, they would probably try to bar American corporations from bidding for the dams and other projects the money would finance.
"I'm not sure they will put in the money," he said. "But if they do, they will seek to exclude the U.S. from benefiting from the funds."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Are Mostly Down in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
After a three-day weekend, Treasury prices ended generally lower yesterday.
But prices of short-term maturities rose, benefiting from investors fleeing the turmoil in the stock market for more security. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 9/32, to 105 24/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.44 percent, from 6.42 percent on Friday. The cash market for Treasury securities was closed on Monday in observance of Columbus Day.
But the price of the three-month bill rose, with its rate falling a basis point, to 5.28 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The rate on the six-month bill was unchanged at 5.33 percent.
Traders said some market participants initially held back in the early going to see how the stock market would perform at the opening, after the battering it took on Monday. Investors did not have to wait long as the Dow Jones industrial average sank nearly 66 points within the first 15 minutes. The Dow later recovered, ending down 5.42 points for the day.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston in New York, said prices were largely stuck in a trading range yesterday. "Earlier weakness in stocks prompted a positive bond market response," he said, "and after equities settled down, so did bonds."
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist and director at First Albany Corporation, said: "The most important help to bonds today, has been the disarray in stocks. And many investors have shifted from stocks in general, and technology issues in particular, into safe havens, such as utility stocks and bonds."
Mr. Alexy said he expected that the market would maintain its narrow trading patterns. "The only risk for the market is that it is being left to its own devices," he said. "Most people are content in waiting for new information rather than speculating ahead of it."
It was the same in futures trading yesterday, he said. The futures market, which strongly affects the cash market is "sort of bidding its time," he said. The December bond contract hit a new contract high at 116 on technical buying yesterday, about the time stocks were way down.
There were signs of buying in the five-year and 10-year maturities, and as the December 10-year approached a 6 percent equivalent cash yield there was speculation that a rise above that level could prompt more buying in Treasury securities and selling in mortgages. Companies holding mortgages might seek to extend the duration of portfolios and look for protection against the risk of mortgages' prepayment if interest rates continued to fall.
The December bond contract, whose high price was 116, closed at 115 21/32.
In the cash market, bond prices received some support from two reports showing retail sales weakening. The Johnson Redbook Service's survey for the first week of October showed a decline of 1.2 percent, while a weekly report on chain-store sales from Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. and Schroder Wertheim & Company showed a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent.
"There are still ongoing worries about the economy which are providing the support to bonds," Mr. Johnson of First Albany said.
The employment report released on Friday did little to change the market's view that the economy is enjoying moderate growth and low inflation. But important price reports are due out this week, which could shed more light on the direction of interest rates. Data on producer prices in September will come out tomorrow, and reports on consumer prices and retail sales will be released on Friday.
"A lot of this is all about waiting," Mr. Johnson said, "with producer prices on Thursday and consumer prices and monthly retail sales on Friday."
Because of the Columbus Day holiday, the Treasury delayed until yesterday the auction of new three- and six-month bills.
Bill rates at auction declined to three-week lows, with the three-month bills down 3 basis points, to 5.31 percent, and the six-month rate down 6 basis points, to 5.32 percent.
Tomorrow, the Treasury plans to sell $18.25 billion of new one-year bills. The rate for a one-year bill yesterday was 5.29 percent, up a basis point.

HEADLINE: A Nobel Award for a University of Chicago Economist, Yet Again

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Robert E. Lucas Jr., a 58-year-old professor at the University of Chicago, was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday -- the fifth winner in economics from the University of Chicago in the last six years.
In enumerating Professor Lucas's achievements, the Swedish Royal Academy of Sciences said that he was "the economist who has had the greatest influence on macroeconomic research since 1970." 
 That assessment squares with the views of his peers, even those who disagree with many of his views on policy issues. "Lucas deserves the recognition," said James Tobin of Yale University, the winner of the prize in 1981. "He changed the methodology of the profession," forcing a more disciplined look at the assumptions about human behavior that underlie economic models, Mr. Tobin said.
Mr. Lucas helped lead a shift in the profession away from the government interventionist approach identified with John Maynard Keynes and toward a more skeptical attitude about the ability of government policy makers to fine-tune the economy. And he thinks that the change has paid off.
"The U.S. economy is in excellent shape," Mr. Lucas said at a news conference in Chicago yesterday. "The Government is not trying to do things with economic policy that it isn't capable of doing."
Mr. Lucas holds a bachelor's degree (in history) and a doctorate (in economics) from the University of Chicago. He spent the first decade of his career as a teacher at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh and returned to the University of Chicago's department of economics in 1974, where, save for a brief stint as a visiting professor at Northwestern University in 1981, he has been ever since.
His path-breaking work is best understood in the context of its times. Once a field without clear demarcations, economics diverged in the 1920's and 1930's into microeconomics, the study of markets, and macroeconomics, the analysis of whole economies. By the late 1960's, microeconomic theory was painstakingly erected on an edifice of clear assumptions, with only incidental application to real world problems.
Macroeconomics, by contrast, was cast in the crucible of the Depression. A simple theoretical framework, accessible to any bright undergraduate, rationalized the use of government fiscal and monetary tools to tame the ups and downs -- particularly the downs -- of the business cycle. It was assumed to be correct largely because it seemed to work, not because it had been constructed from universally accepted first principles. And while its senior practitioners were certainly able scholars, they were primarily hands-on problem solvers.
Mr. Lucas went back to basics, asking how people would act in maximizing their own interests in the face of changing government policies. And the more closely he looked, the less plausible it seemed that individuals would play by the Keynesian rules.
Take, for example, the impact of monetary policy on business activity. Keynesians assumed that a cut in interest rates would stimulate demand for a wide variety of products, increasing overall business activity. Building on the earlier research of John Muth, who asked how farmers would incorporate knowledge of past prices and costs to generate future plans, Mr. Lucas focused on the impact of monetary stimulus on a single producer of, say, thingamabobs.
The immediate, positive impact on demand for thingamabobs would lead to an increase in their market price, probably convincing the producer to increase output and hire more workers. But the monetary jolt would presumably have the same effect on thousands of other products, raising the cost of producing thingamabobs more or less in proportion to the increase in potential revenue from their sales.
The only way monetary policy can work, Mr. Lucas concluded, is to mislead in systematic ways. But if producers are rational, they will learn from the error of assuming that the price of thingamabobs will go up more than the costs. Indeed, he theorized, after enough learning from changing government policies, the impact of monetary stimulus ceases to be predictable: the residual impact comes from unanticipated effects, which can even be the opposite of what policy makers intend.
"Lucas was smart," said N. Gregory Mankiw, an economist at Harvard University. The incorporation of "rational expectations" in macroeconomic theory was just too good an idea to ignore. "But Lucas was also lucky," Mr. Mankiw added, because the ideas came along in the mid-1970's, when the world was open to new concepts just as policy makers were losing confidence in Keynesian fine-tuning.
Indeed, Mr. Lucas is reluctant to toot his own horn. Unlike most leaders of the economics profession, he spends little time offering advice to politicians or second-guessing them in print. And in a telephone interview after winning the Nobel prize he was quick to share the credit for rational expectations theory with others. "Ed Prescott and Tom Sargent applied the ideas at about the same time," he said, referring to former colleagues at the University of Chicago.
Mr. Lucas also acknowledged disappointment that his work had done more to wreck the credibility of Keynesian prescriptions than to create replacements for the old rules -- a disappointment shared by many economists. To get solid results from rational expectations models of economic behavior, Mr. Tobin said, "you have to specify who knows what when" -- an overwhelming task in a complex economy.
What everyone agrees, however, is that Mr. Lucas remains one of the most inventive economic minds at a university that can also boast of Nobel prizes in economics for Robert W. Fogel (1993), Gary S. Becker (1992), Ronald H. Coase (1991), Merton H. Miller (1990), George J. Stigler (1982), Theodore W. Schultz (1979) and Milton Friedman (1976).Indeed, Mr. Lucas may become the first economist to win two Nobel prizes: His later work on the forces driving economic development has helped generate an avalanche of research in what is now called the "new growth theory."

HEADLINE: All a Matter of Perspective

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
To Ronald and Bridgette Lathern, Nationsbank is guilty of racial discrimination, a biased lender that unfairly rejected their mortgage application because they are black. That rejection, they said, caused them to miss out on the tidy three-bedroom home in suburban Maryland they had their hearts set on.
"We had high hopes, and to be turned down like that was the worst thing," Mr. Lathern said. "The first thing I felt was that as a black man, they just don't give us a break." 
 John Taylor has a very different view. Mr. Taylor, president of the National Community Reinvestment Coalition, acknowledges that Nationsbank -- America's fourth-largest bank -- may have treated minorities unfairly on occasion, but he notes that it is still considered an industry leader in lending in minority and low-income neighborhoods. In fact, the bank has fought efforts by Republican to weaken a Federal law meant to encourage such loans.
The two views -- some say two faces -- of Nationsbank have been highlighted by a lawsuit filed last month, accusing the bank, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., of violating Federal anti-discrimination laws in its mortgage lending in the Washington area.
Lawyers for the plaintiffs argue that no matter what the bank's overall record is, their clients were treated unfairly. Oficials at Nationsbank say that figures alone give a distorted picture, since lenders that aggressively seek to make loans in low-income and minority neighborhoods -- as Nationsbank has -- can end up denying loans to more people.
"They stuck their neck out at the risk of it getting chopped off by others in their industry," said Mr. Taylor, whose group represents housing and community groups seeking to encourage investments in minority and low-income areas.
The truth may lie somewhere in between. "They may not be the Mother Teresa of banking, but they are far from the Mark Fuhrman of banking," said Kenneth Thomas, an independent consultant based in Miami. "These are not the bad ones they should be going after. There are many other banks, usually small banks, that are much worse."
The Nationsbank case highlights a broader issue in banking. One difficulty in trying to sort this out is that the only way to gauge bias in the industry -- which is a vexing, continuing problem across the nation -- is by looking at statistics that banks have been required to provide to the Government since 1990. In conflicts, each side tends to provide numbers that bolster its particular legal point.
The class action suit filed by the Washington Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights and Urban Affairs on behalf of 11 African-American plaintiffs -- including the Latherns -- may be a harbinger of things to come, experts in the field say.
Starting under President George Bush, the Justice Department reached out-of-court settlements with a number of banks that it accused of showing bias in lending. The 1990 law requiring deposit-taking institutions and mortgage companies to report approval and denial rates for loans by sex, income and race has provided civil rights and fair- housing groups with fertile statistical grounds to bolster their claims.
The action against Nationsbank is the first lawsuit filed by either the Government or a private organization accusing a major bank of lending discrimination.
"This is the second wave, a new era where the private sector is beginning to pick up these cases," said John P. Relman, a lawyer for the plaintiffs who is also director of the Fair Housing Project at the Lawyers Committee. "I don't think it's going to matter so much any more who is in the White House and what is politically going on in the Justice Department because the private sector will bring these cases."
The suit contends that among other things, Nationsbank refused to give African-American applicants a fair chance to provide an explanation if they have poor credit histories -- an opportunity, the suit states, that whites are normally given. It also maintains that the bank required blacks to meet unnecessarily high standards to qualify for loans -- often higher than what is required by those who repurchase mortgages in the secondary market -- and failed to offer black applicants advice on how to lower their monthly debt to qualify for mortgage loans.
Lawyers for the Lawyers Committee seek to bolster their claim that the 11 black plaintiffs were treated unfairly by citing statistics indicating that at Nationsbank in Washington black applicants were turned down at a rate five times that of whites. That, the lawyers say, is the largest racial disparity of any bank among institutions that received at least 400 mortgage applications in the Washington area.
The lawyers also assert that while 10.2 percent of African-American applicants were rejected for poor credit histories, fewer than 1 percent of whites were; again, the largest disparity of any lender in the area.
Lawyers for the plaintiffs say the large disparity in rejections occurred regardless of income group and despite the fact that many lower-income blacks seeking loans from Nationsbank were pre-screened for credit problems by a community group before applying to the bank.
Nationsbank officials deny the accusations and vow to fight the case in court. They argue that looking at disparities alone does not take into account factors like the state of a local economy and housing stock. "We may have more strikeouts, but over all we're going to make a lot more loans than anybody else, because we go to bat a lot more times," said Cathy Bessant, senior vice president for Nationsbank.
With assets of more than $170 billion, Nationsbank is notable for its size -- it has grown rapidly through acquisitions in recent years -- but also for its image as a relative paragon of corporate responsibility. Its chairman, Hugh L. McColl, has given speeches defending affirmative action. It has pledged to lend $10 billion over a 10-year period in minority communities. And it has sponsored conferences to help grass-roots organizations and housing advocacy groups devise ways to draw more capital into poorer neighborhoods.
Earlier this year, Nationsbank officials testified against changes proposed by some Republican lawmakers that would have weakened the Community Reinvestment Act, a measure that seeks to encourage investment in low- and moderate-income neighborhoods by linking approval of a bank's mergers and acquisitions to its lending record in all communities where it operates. The effort to change the law was eventually defeated in the Senate.
In January, the National Community Investment Coalition released a study of lending activity in the country's 20 largest cities and it gave Nationsbank relatively good marks for the way it marketed, approved or denied loans to minority communities. The study did, however, point out that of all the markets in which Nationsbank operated, its Washington operation had the worst record.
Officials at Nationsbank, which needs a good public image if it wants to keep up its rapid expansion through mergers, have not been shy in pointing out their record as they try to rally grass-roots support among housing and community development advocates. And they are also not shy about pointing out what they see as one possible consequence of the lawsuit.
"One of my big concerns about this case is that it will discourage other lenders from being as aggressive as they might have been," Ms. Bessant said in a telephone interview from the bank's corporate headquarters. "This lawsuit says, 'Don't be aggressive, because if you're aggressive we'll come after you.' "
But Mr. Relman counters that whatever Nationsbank's record in Congress defending the Community Reinvestment Act or the number of mortgages it approves in minority areas around the country, it still treated his 11 plaintiffs unfairly and should be held responsible.
"The question is: Are they immunized from judicial scrutiny and should we not be protecting and advocating rights of people?" Mr. Relman said. "Should we turn a blind eye because this bank has people who stand on the Hill and defend C.R.A.?"
The Latherns certainly don't think so.
Mr. Lathern said Nationsbank loan officers turned him and his wife down in March 1994 because his wife was late on three payments on her Sears credit card. He said the officers did not give them a chance to explain the late payments and refused to consider solely Mr. Lathern's credit history, which he said was flawless.
Mr. Lathern, a mailroom supervisor at the Federal Trade Commission, said he earned enough to qualify for the mortgage without counting his wife's income.
Three months later, the Latherns bought another house, also in suburban Maryland. This time, a different bank also questioned his wife's late payments. But after she wrote a letter explaining that she had been short of cash after helping to pay funeral expenses from two deaths in her family, the bank approved their application.
The second house, unlike the first, needed fixing up and was not in as pretty a neighborhood, the Latherns said. And interest rates had risen in the interim, so they were not able to get as good a deal on their loan.
"The first house had a lot more features," Mr. Lathern said. "It was in better shape. That was the house that we wanted to get. It was tailor-made."

HEADLINE: Susan F. Glass, 60, A Selective Publicist

 BODY:
Susan F. Glass, a highly particular public relations woman who made a career being paid for advancing causes she believed in, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 60, and until she went on medical leave at the end of 1994, she was a senior vice president of the Urban Development Corporation.
The cause was lung cancer, her friend Sandy Silverman said. 
 Whether she was writing speeches for Dore Schary at the Anti-Defamation League, editing Albert Shanker's newspaper columns for the United Federation of Teachers or, more recently, advancing her friend Mario M. Cuomo's economic development programs at the U.D.C., Ms. Glass pursued her work with a passion that seemed to go far beyond her professional obligations.
That, her friends say, was because Ms. Glass, a fierce supporter of Democratic politicians from Robert F. Kennedy to Mr. Cuomo, was such an intense idealist that she made a point of working only for those institutions she deemed worthy of her passions.
Ms. Glass was born in Richmond Hill, Queens, graduated from Queens College and received a master's degree in English from New York University. She began her career at the old Long Island Press, working as women's news editor before shifting to public relations.
She is survived by a brother, Michael, of Miami.
