HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Up, Yielding Most Of Its Early Gains Against Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed yesterday, giving up gains in Europe after stocks fell for a second consecutive day in the United States and fresh concerns arose over Mexico's economic health.
The currency made modest progress in Europe overnight against the German mark as the mark's rally against the French franc stalled. But a lack of follow-through buying in New York caused the dollar to retest the day's lows. 
 Traders expect tight dollar ranges to continue. "The dollar remains in a choppy range and we expect more of the same this week," said Philip Vasan, managing director for foreign-exchange derivatives at CS First Boston.
Weakness in the stock market also put pressure on the dollar, as the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted in early trading after falling 42.99 points on Monday.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 100.88 Japanese yen from 100.43 yen on Monday. It rose to 1.4184 marks from 1.4124 and to 1.1485 Swiss francs from 1.1425 Swiss francs.
The Mexican peso unnerved dollar holders yesterday as the peso fell as much as 4.2 percent. The collapse of the peso last winter had dragged down the dollar because of the close economic ties between the United States and Mexico.
But Mexican financial weakness is not as threatening to the dollar as it was last winter, according to some traders, including Mr. Vasan of CS First Boston, who said, "Overseas holdings of Mexican assets are not as large as they used to be."
The peso settled at 6.7450 to the dollar yesterday, weaker than the rate of 6.6500 to the dollar late Monday.
The reversal of the mark's sharp climb against the French franc helped support the dollar versus the mark overnight, traders said. The mark rose sharply against the franc on Monday before an increase in French short-term interest rates halted the franc's slide.
"We saw some selling of marks in Europe, and that gave a lift to the dollar," said Paul Farrell, managing director for foreign exchange at Chase Manhattan Bank.
The dollar traded as high as 1.4231 marks before retreating.
Currency traders remain wary that central banks will buy dollars in support of a call for a stronger dollar made over the weekend by the Group of Seven industrial nations.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
African Athletes in New South

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: LAGRANGE, Ga.

 BODY:
As a civil rights leader, Andrew Young said he warily drove the roads of intolerance through this former cotton mill town during the days of the segregated South.
"When I lived in southern Georgia, I was scared to go through there on my way to Alabama," said Young, the former ambassador to the United Nations who is co-chairman of the Atlanta Olympic Organizing Committee. 
 Attitudes have changed in LaGrange, about 60 miles southwest of Atlanta, where an international vision has supplanted racial myopia. The town that Young once shunned because of its Jim Crow prejudice is now embraced by him for its training and cultural exchange programs with mostly African athletes who are preparing for the 1996 Summer Olympics.
Southern hospitality has not been extended so warmly by every Georgia community. The city of Winder rebuffed Somali athletes who sought a training site in Barrow County, and Cobb County lost the Olympic volleyball competition after passing an anti-homosexual resolution.
But even as the O. J. Simpson trial has underscored the depth of the racial divide in this country, LaGrange is preparing to play host to a sort of Olympic rainbow coalition: the entire delegation from South Africa; track-and-field athletes from such places as Mozambique, Mauritius, Swaziland, Zambia, Saudi Arabia and the Czech Republic; female basketball players from Brazil; softball players from the Netherlands; the equestrian team from France and race walkers from the United States.
Last week, Bobby Rearden, a member of the Atlanta organizing committee and one of the people responsible for the "I Train in LaGrange" program, said: "I think Andy is overwhelmed by this. He told me once, 'People in L.A. and New York will never believe this happens in the South.' "
LaGrange, population 26,000, has evolved from cotton-mill dependence into a regional center of industry and textiles that expects to be home to 400 athletes from 14 countries as they become acclimated to Georgia's heat and humidity before the centennial Games open next July 19.
Some of the foreign athletes have already arrived. Since 1991, the "I Train in LaGrange" program has played host to 60 international track and field athletes who have come here to train under Ron Davis, a New Yorker who spent 17 years coaching in Africa. The program is supported by local philanthropy, city and county funds, corporate sponsors and scholarships offered by the International Olympic Committee to athletes from developing countries.
The athletes train on a modern running track, attend the Methodist-affiliated LaGrange College or West Georgia Technical College, visit the children at local elementary schools and socialize with local residents through an adopt-an-athlete program.
Ruth Mangwe, a sprinter from Equatorial Guinea, arrived in LaGrange last New Year's Eve, never having run on anything but a grass track and unable to say as much as "Good morning," in English. Because she spoke Spanish, she was paired in the adopt-an-athlete program with Adolfo Benavides, a native of Colombia who is chairman of the business and economics department at LaGrange College. Less than a year later, her English has improved as dramatically as her times at 200 and 400 meters.
"Everything was very difficult for me; I didn't know English, I missed my parents and my brothers and sisters," Mangwe said. "But when I'm talking to Mr. Benavides, I'm home."
Benavides is a runner himself, a marathoner who trains on the track with the Olympic hopefuls, who opens his house to them on Thanksgiving and sees a bit of himself in them -- foreigners who need a friend far from home.
"They have a big adjustment to make," Benavides said. "The adjustment is a lot easier if they have a friend."
Lynn Dye and her husband have been host for two years of Barnabe Jolicoeur, a sprinter from Mauritius. Jolicoeur, like the other foreign athletes here, lives in a dormitory at LaGrange College, but he and others attend with their adoptive families such weekend gatherings as church, dinners and high school football games.
"I've gotten to know athletes from countries I had never heard of," Dye said. "It makes the world a lot smaller, which is the purpose of the Olympics."
The athletes seem welcomed at Turner Hall on the LaGrange College campus, even if the warm and fuzzy feelings of their fellow students are sometimes met with an equally fuzzy sense of geography.
"Do you know where Mauritius is?" Davis, the track coach, asked a freshman named Shelly Mathews about the island nation off the coast of eastern Africa.
"Is it in Brazil?" she replied.
Tina Paulino of Mozambique is the most accomplished athlete training in LaGrange. Last month, at the African championships in Harare, Zimbabwe, she finished second at 800 meters to her cousin, Maria Mutola, the world's top-ranked runner in the event. Mutola is only a phone call away at her training base in Oregon, Paulino said, but so is a to-be-avoided temptation -- junk food.
"I have to watch everything I eat here," Paulino said. "In the middle of the night, you can call for a pizza. In Africa, that doesn't happen."
Paulino is one of five athletes in LaGrange on a scholarship provided to athletes from emerging nations by the I.O.C.'s Olympic Solidarity program, which provides a stipend of $1,800 a month as long as certain performance standards are met. She is also studying education at LaGrange College. It is the educational triumphs, not the running victories, of these athletes that give him the most satisfaction, said Davis, their coach.
"These people are going to go home and contribute to their countries; some will become leaders," Davis said. "You've got to have education behind the sporting activity."
Tommy Asinga, a native of Surinam and a former standout 800-meter runner at Eastern Michigan University, has completed a year of veterinary school at Tuskegee Institute, 50 miles away in Alabama. When his I.O.C. scholarship was terminated, the LaGrange Sports Authority helped him secure a loan to remain in school, and they have provided money for food and housing.
"Without their help, I could not have afforded school," Asinga said. "When I came here, I only knew about five veterinarians in Surinam. I don't think there are many more than that."
The program evolved from an effort by Young and Davis to train African athletes in Atlanta before the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. Young was an aspiring Olympic sprinter while at Howard University in the early 1950's, while Davis was a steeplechaser and coach at San Jose State in the 1960's. Five years ago, when Atlanta was awarded the 1996 Summer Games, the mayor of LaGrange at the time, Chris Joseph, sought to have a piece of the Olympic pie carved for his constituents.
LaGrange has since become 1 of 48 Georgia communities that will serve as pre-Olympic training sites. Not everything has gone smoothly here. The training program suffered an embarrassment last year when Horace Dove-Edwin of Sierra Leone took second place to Olympic champion Linford Christie of Britain at 100 meters at the British Commonwealth Games, only to be disqualified after failing a drug test.
Other athletes have left the program, uncomfortable with dormitory life and the rigors of school. Also, the LaGrange Sports Authority must raise about $2.5 million from foundations and corporate sponsors to meet its goal of becoming a regional training site for American athletes after the Atlanta Olympics. Still, the city has opened its arms in a way once thought unimaginable.
"It has become like a home," said Stephen Lugor, a 400-meter runner from Sudan. "I was away for three weeks this summer, competing in Sweden and Egypt, and I was lonely to come back."

HEADLINE: Mexico's Political Crisis

 BODY:
Two years of upheaval in Mexico has cracked a once-monolithic political establishment, but the transition from authoritarianism to democracy is incomplete. President Ernesto Zedillo, who met with President Clinton yesterday, has demonstrated more commitment to political reform than any recent Mexican leader. But he has run into strong opposition within his own, ruling party.
The Clinton Administration can help him by demonstrating that the United States attaches as much importance to his desire to free Mexico's politics as it does to opening its economy. Mexico's economic and social stability will be increasingly at risk until an outdated system of unaccountable political power is transformed. 
Washington has always offered rhetorical support to Mexican democracy, but its private messages have been ambiguous. Successive Administrations have known that elements of Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, stole elections and protected drug traffickers. But as long as Mexican leaders promoted market reform and presented themselves as guarantors of stability, Washington raised no protest.
The PRI in its present state, however, is no longer a force for stability. Its original 1994 Presidential candidate was assassinated, and rogue elements of the PRI are suspected of involvement. Its Secretary General was gunned down in Mexico City, and the brother of former President Salinas is accused of masterminding the crime. Armed rebels in Chiapas won widespread support by demanding a more democratic political system.
Mr. Zedillo won the presidency last year in the least tainted election in decades. Though thrown off balance by an inherited financial crisis, he took promising early steps to cleanse the political system, for example appointing an independent attorney general to probe last year's assassinations. But Mexico still has a long way to go. Judges are not independent. Police torture of suspects is common. Recently the assassination investigations have stalled. Opposition from ruling party barons may be just too powerful.
Mr. Zedillo must break through this impasse. He must thoroughly separate the ruling party from the machinery of government. Without this, there can be no fair multi-party competition.
Debate on Mexico in this country has focused on the North American Free Trade Agreement, which despite the setback of the peso crisis is working reasonably well, and on this year's loan guarantees, which Mexico is paying back.
The issue of political reform is no less important, and there is not much time left for Mexico to get it right.

HEADLINE: Rebuilding New York Creates Jobs and Votes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New York City's Capital Needs" (editorial, Oct. 6), while on the money in calling for renewed capital funding to revitalize the city's ailing infrastructure, omits an important piece of the financial pie: Capital projects create jobs for thousands of (voting) New Yorkers. 
From architects, engineers, designers, consultants and construction managers, support staff, building tradespeople and unskilled laborers to such spinoff businesses as blueprinters and messengers that serve the industry, these jobs impact class, color and neighborhoods in the entire metropolitan area.
State politicians and city budgeteers, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, must remember that investing in infrastructure not only enhances our environment but also strengthens the work force and tax base.
New York's design and construction industry has been an important part of the city's economy. As public spending on capital projects for hospitals, housing, schools, jails, courts and other essentials has decreased, so has the vitality of this industry, leaving large and small businesses hard hit by the triple whammy effect of Federal, state and city cutbacks.
 
BARBARA A. NADEL
Forest Hills, Queens, Oct. 6, 1995
 
The writer is an architect.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Plea for Simpler Living as the World Warms Up

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

HOPE, HUMAN AND WILD
True Stories of Living Lightly on the Earth
By Bill McKibben
227 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.
This new book by Bill McKibben is a kind of sequel to "The End of Nature," which attracted a great deal of attention when it was published six years ago and made Mr. McKibben perhaps the nation's most prominent literary environmentalist. The book's stark concept was that global warming, caused by hydrocarbon consumption, erased nature as something separate from human civilization. Too much carbon dioxide affects all of nature, altering "the most fundamental phenomena," with consequences likely to be disastrous.
"Writing that book depressed me," Mr. McKibben declares near the beginning of "Hope, Human and Wild." In his new book, which is "devoted to strategies for retooling our societies and economies so they do less damage," Mr. McKibben tries to improve the mood by providing evidence that we could live more "lightly on the earth" and still be all right. He talks about three places, the Adirondacks where he lives, the city of Curitiba in Brazil and the densely populated state of Kerala in extreme southwestern India. Curitiba and Kerala, he writes, make do with far less than we have, and yet they have not sacrificed health, longevity or the possibility of happiness. They therefore provide the sort of hope and vision that might help us to think more boldly about home. 
 Mr. McKibben is certainly not wrong to emphasize the gravity of our ecological situation or to advocate simpler ways of life in which we would use bicycles for transportation, do without bananas (and the environmental cost of shipping them), join rural cooperatives for our fruit and vegetables and begin to think of other economic paradigms besides continuous growth. His new book, which often has the homiletic tone of a Sunday school sermon, is nonetheless disappointing as an environmentalist's prescription for a new future.
In part this is because Mr. McKibben is not a sophisticated thinker on economic matters. He does not generally take into account the consequences of the measures he proposes. A reduction in the huge North American consumption of bananas, to take one small example, would increase poverty among South Americans who grow them, yet reconciling ecological needs with basic economic needs is the nub of the issue. Meanwhile, Mr. McKibben's descriptions of places like Curitiba and Kerala are too breathless to provide the inspiration he intends.
To be sure, Mr. McKibben is much too smart to fall into a simple utopianism as he searches for lessons in these locales. He allows that the communities he has studied, including the American one where he lives, are poor and want to be less so. But Curitiba and Kerala, he argues, can ease our understandable fear that living with less "would plunge us into a world of poverty, disease, ignorance -- that it's either our life in all its detail or a grim, short, narrow life." Kerala, for example, has achieved life expectancies, infant mortality rates, levels of literacy and an atmosphere of liveliness that rival our own, but on one-seventieth of what we spend per capita. "It gives the lie to the idea that only endless economic growth can produce decent human lives," Mr. McKibben writes.
But one month in Brazil and another month in India do not make for great expertise on either place, and one senses that Mr. McKibben's descriptions are both too rosy and too thin. "Romanticizing Kerala is a mistake," Mr. McKibben writes, but he does romanticize Kerala. While Japan, Taiwan and South Korea have gone in for economic growth, "Kerala has been much more interested in sharing what wealth is available," he writes. But Japan et al. have achieved Western standards of living and of cultural and scientific advance. Kerala has a per capita income of $330, and its chief source of hard currency is the tens of thousands of its sons who leave their homes and families to labor in the oilfields of the Persian Gulf. One critic cited by Mr. McKibben calls Kerala "a bloated social welfare state without the economy to support it."
And still Mr. McKibben glows with admiration. "If there's a general lesson about socialism provided by Kerala, it's that the government benefits from having to answer to voters," he writes, not explaining why this is a lesson in socialism rather than democracy. Mr. McKibben interviews a Gandhian disciple named Vishwanathan who describes to him "a future as close to the one envisioned by E. F. Schumacher or Thomas Jefferson or Gandhi as is currently imaginable on this planet." On a per capita income of $330?
Mr. McKibben surely does us a service in raising the possibility of alternative concepts of the good life, but he often leaves difficult questions unanswered. He disparages the new policies of economic growth in China, but plainly the Chinese people, who were forced to endure three decades of a political philosophy that largely prevented economic growth, want it now. Is there really a Kerala-style alternative? Early on, talking about his home territory, Mr. McKibben describes the regeneration of the Northeastern American forest, calling it "the great environmental story of the United States -- in some ways, of the whole world." But wasn't this natural regeneration made possible by agribusiness in the Midwest and by the replacement of wood by oil as a primary source of fuel, in short by the sorts of development he deplores? Later, Mr. McKibben speaks approvingly of efforts in the Northeast to revive farming, so the region can be more self-sufficient, even if it means food will be more expensive. But wouldn't such a revival on a scale sufficient for self-sufficiency lead again to the cutting of the forests?
What we seem to need, especially in light of possible global warming, is a way of making environmental prudence compatible with development to alleviate global poverty and perhaps produce more new technology, like fiber optics, to ease the strain on the earth's natural resources.
Hard thinking will be required on this, and there are probably few more qualified to do it than Mr. McKibben. He just hasn't done enough of it yet.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Bill McKibben. (Nancie Battaglia/Little, Brown & Company)

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
A DEATH in California, an anniversary in Maryland, a winery closing in France: three events, none directly related, but all of them worthy of note for anyone interested in wine as a cultural and social phenomenon and as a part of history.
When Leon D. Adams first wrote his "Wines of America" (McGraw-Hill), in 1973, there were 254 bonded wineries in 18 of the 50 states. In 1990, when he published the fourth edition, there were 1,200. There have been more learned treatises on American wine over the years but few as readable and none as opinionated. Mr. Adams died on Sept. 14 at 90. 
 Mr. Adams was a journalist in his early days, but when his interest was drawn to wine, he became an advocate -- and a feisty one at that. Throughout his long life, his nemesis was prohibition and its adherents. He excoriated the temperance advocates who condemned wine drinking on moral and economic grounds, and then the current wave of fitness enthusiasts who see wine as harmful to good health (he described them pungently as "health fascists").
Long before the American middle class thought of wine as anything but a foreign affectation or a drink for poor immigrants, Mr. Adams was crusading for it as a healthy, moderate substitute for hard liquor -- a food product as deserving of a place at every dinner table as bread.
He was an unabashed chauvinist. "In the quantity of wine it produces annually, the United States ranks sixth among wine-growing nations," he wrote. "In the quality of its wines, it ranks first."
As much as he railed at the idea of prohibition -- and he was old enough to remember the real thing -- Mr. Adams believed it was a major factor in this country's subsequent wine-making achievements. "Reborn when national Prohibition ended in 1933," he wrote, the American wine industry "chose the scientific approach to quality."
The Americans rejected "the traditions, cobwebbed cellars and primitive methods that long hindered wine progress in Europe," he wrote, to utilize "the new research in viticulture and enology in which the United States has led the world."
Mr. Adams's writing seems confrontational, almost belligerent now, in a time when wine has pretty much achieved its place in the sun. But few among us realize what an uphill battle he and his colleagues fought, not too many years ago, to make wine not even popular -- just respectable.
A longtime editor of food magazines recalled those days -- which were as recent as the 70's. "If we published a recipe for coq au vin," she said, "we had to make it clear that the alcohol in the wine boiled off during the cooking."
Mr. Adams spent a lifetime trying to make wine, especially American wine, a part of American life. He lived long enough to see his dream come true.
On the other side of the United States, just five years after Mr. Adams's "Wines of America" first appeared, a young Baltimore lawyer borrowed $2,000 from his parents and mailed out 6,500 copies of a wine newsletter he had just prepared. Now, 18 years later, Robert M. Parker Jr. is celebrating the 100th issue of that newsletter, known among wine enthusiasts worldwide as The Wine Advocate.
It took Mr. Parker six years to reach 10,000 in paid circulation, the point at which he had promised himself that he would leave law and devote all his energy to wine. That was in 1984, the year he announced in his newsletter that the 1982 vintage in Bordeaux was one of the greatest ever. Other American wine critics disagreed, but in denouncing Mr. Parker's position, they gave him, he readily acknowledges now, the publicity he needed to make wine his career.
Six times a year in The Wine Advocate, Mr. Parker reviews hundreds of wines. He pioneered the use of the 100-point system, familiar to anyone who attended American schools, in evaluating wines. The system has made his critiques accessible to his American audience but has also irritated some critics and segments of the wine trade, who argue that numbers are inadequate to the judgment of something so complex.
Mr. Parker's influence is formidable. Stories, mostly apocryphal, circulate about rich collectors of uncertain tastes who demand of their wine merchants "$10,000 of 1990 Bordeaux, all above 95 in Parker." There is gossip, too, about French wine makers who supposedly change their vinification procedures to make wines that Mr. Parker might conceivably praise.
More important, perhaps, is the fact that, after tasting literally thousands of wines, his enthusiasm remains undiminished. Reporting on Burgundies in the current issue of The Wine Advocate, he finds the 1993's of the Domaine Meo-Camuzet to be "thrilling wines." On the Domaine Leroy, he explains that his tasting notes will be brief because "it is almost criminal to describe wines that may be the greatest red Burgundies I will taste in my life." Of the 1986 Penfolds Grange Hermitage, from Australia, he writes, "This may turn out to be superior to the 1971 and 1976 -- imagine that!"
Mr. Parker, who is 48, represents a different generation from that of Mr. Adams, but he is as passionate about furthering the cause of wine as Mr. Adams was. Mr. Adams fought for wine's recognition. Mr. Parker takes that for granted: he fights for better wines by challenging all wine makers to make them better.
Traditions, in wine writing or wine making, are new to the United States -- they are really just starting. In France last week, a venerable one came to an end. In Argenteuil, a suburb of Paris, Jacques Defresne, a part-time grape grower and wine maker, announced that 1995 would be his last vintage. Mr. Defresne's half-acre of hybrid Seyve-Villard grapes is almost all that remains of what was until the 18th-century an important wine producing area.
"My family has cultivated the vine in Argenteuil since 1342," Mr. Defresne told his local newspaper, "but I'm 73 now and even my little plot is too much work. I'm going to concentrate on my fruit trees."
 
Tasting
 
Rodney Strong Zinfandel, River West Vineyard
Old Vines, 1993. About $14.
 
Rod Strong has retired from the remarkable wine business he founded more than 35 years ago, but his legacy lingers on -- not just in his name, but also in wines like this delicious, medium-bodied zinfandel. Even in Sonoma County, California's optimum zinfandel region, River West Vineyard is prime. The old vines are valued, not for their productiveness, which can be very low, but for the concentration of flavor in the few grapes they do provide. The current vogue for richly flavored, darkly hued California wines made from robust warm-climate grapes like mourvedre and sangiovese owes much to zinfandel. It sometimes lacks the finesse of the best cabernets, but its rustic quality fits those robust, uncomplicated dishes of the chilly months ahead.

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
New Love, Without Walls or Artifice

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
The New York City Opera tends to wring as much as it can out of its standard-repertory productions, but even this economical company sometimes scraps its old favorites and starts fresh. Its durable old production of "La Boheme" dated from 1966, the year the City Opera moved to the New York State Theater, and although it served the company well, it looked increasingly shopworn in recent seasons.
To replace it, the City Opera brought in Graziella Sciutti, an Italian soprano who gave up the stage in 1977 and became a director. Her version of the Puccini classic, which had its premiere on Saturday night, is a handsome, traditional staging, nicely detailed yet uncluttered and unlikely to grow dated quickly. Its stage pictures, designed by Michael Anania, are appealingly panoramic. The sparsely furnished garret of the first and last acts radiates around a huge window with the walls only suggested, so that one looks through them over the roofs of Montmartre. 
 The walls of the Cafe Momus are similarly transparent; the revelry in the Latin Quarter streets on Christmas Eve merges with the hubbub inside the cafe. And the third act unfolds before a graceful, arching gateway to a snowy lane lined with bare trees. Jeff Davis's lighting suggests the Parisian midwinter chill as well as the warm glow of the finale.
The company has cast this attractive staging with singers who sound and look right in the roles, and Ms. Sciutti moves them through the piece with an unpretentious efficiency that yields a sense of realism. A minor but telling touch is her direction of the landlord Benoit and of Musetta's sugar daddy, Alcindoro. Often played as slapstick by a single singer, the roles are taken here by Don Yule and William Ledbetter, who do them straight and let the comedy come from the music and the text, not from overacting.
This sensible approach to the smallest roles was a bonus in a show that was consistently well cast. Stella Zambalis played Mimi as sweet and demure, but with a reserve of strong personal will that blossomed in the last two acts. Vocally, Ms. Zambalis was a delight: her high notes floated without strain, and she sang with vibrato and a sense of color that were regulated to suit the shape of the line.
John Fowler matched her nicely as Rodolfo. His tenor seemed small in the opening horseplay scenes, but by the time he reached "Che gelida manina," his sound was heftier and better rounded. He sang that tenor showpiece with considered lyricism, and occasionally with a touch of old-fashioned coloration, and he gave Rodolfo dimension, particularly in the emotional juggling of the third act.
Robert Perry was a robust, likable Marcello. Stephen Powell and Dong-Jian Gong might have been more colorful as Shaunard and Colline, but they were unobjectionable and unobtrusive. And if Jane Thorngren did not quite match Ms. Zambalis's beauty of tone, her Musetta was an endearing firebrand.
Robert Duerr, the conductor, has proven himself a strong asset to the company this year, stepping in to conduct the difficult "Mathis der Maler" while preparing his own productions. His approach to "Boheme" was unusually flexible, beginning at a brisk pace that stripped away the glutinous overlay that too often weakens the opening scenes, yet allowing his Rodolfo and Mimi enough leeway to convey the exploratory moments of a new love affair. Later Mr. Duerr was more expansive, both in his tempos and in his expressive toying with dynamics, and in the last two acts he drew from the orchestra as rich a sound as it has produced in recent memory.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Fowler as Rodolfo and Stella Zambalis as Mimi in City Opera's new production of "La Boheme," staged by Graziella Sciutti. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A California savings and loan takes some shots at the big banks, and meets with apparent success.

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson 

 BODY:
IN the typically genteel world of financial-institution advertising, tradition remains important. Messages suggest stability and financial might, most making no claim bolder than "Our C.D. Rates Add Up to Big Numbers." Comparisons are indirect, if at all.
But in California, one institution is rewriting those rules. Glendale Federal Bank has ditched gentility for a bare-knuckle attack, spending $16 million to specifically take on the state's biggest banks, Bank of America and Wells Fargo, in a contentious campaign by the BBDO West unit of the Omnicom Group in Los Angeles. 
 "You Deserve Better," one Glendale Federal billboard declares; the red "no" slash symbol appears over the words "B of A." The sign encourages Bank of America customers to call 1 800-41-FED UP.
A print ad aimed at Wells Fargo & Company and its famous logo says, "After spending five minutes with the stagecoach bankers, maybe you'll want to get the hell out of Dodge."
This is a landmark campaign in an industry where hard-sell advertising aimed at rivals is rare, Gail J. Liberman, editor of the Bank Rate Monitor, a weekly financial trade publication in North Palm Beach, Fla., said, "It's fairly controversial to give equal weight to a competitor."
But other banks using aggressive advertising to try "to create a whole movement in the marketplace" have seen it pay off, Ms. Liberman said, like the Bank South Corporation in Atlanta and the Washington Mutual Savings Bank in Seattle.
The spirited ads by Bank South and Washington Mutual spoke to consumers with bruised loyalties after out-of-town banks took over local institutions in those markets.
"There was an opportunistic period where we took advantage of the situation," said Craig Metz, advertising director of Bank South. Ads knocking the bank's four main rivals on issues like convenience helped Bank South increase its market share to 33 percent from 15 percent in less than three years, he said. (After the campaign ended in 1994, Bank South was bought by a target of its ads, Nationsbank.)
In Seattle, an eight-month ad blitz in 1992 that urged consumers to "merge with" Washington Mutual is credited with doubling the institution's account growth.
"We felt there was an opportunity to attract disenchanted customers from other institutions," said William Ehrlich, a spokesman for Washington Mutual.
It has been two years since California's largest bank merger, between the BankAmerica Corporation and Security Pacific. Even so, "people will readily tell you they're dissatisfied," said Stephen J. Trafton, chief executive of Glendale Federal, which is based in Glendale, Calif. "It's alienated the customer base," he added, which is "ripe for attack."
Early this year, as Mr. Trafton sought to distance Glendale Federal from its troubled past, the savings and loan scrapped its previous campaign, a snoozer that emphasized savings. After nearly being seized by regulators, Glendale Federal was replenished with fresh capital last year, partly from the sale of out-of-state holdings, narrowing its focus to 148 branches in California.
The attack ads are not merely marketing ploys; they underscore a substantive effort by Glendale Federal to expand beyond just mortgages and offering better rates on certificates of deposit. Like other savings institutions, Glendale Federal is becoming more like commercial banks, wooing checking-account customers to try selling them an array of financial services.
It has also helped that Glendale Federal's stronghold is Southern California, which had been Security Pacific's home turf.
"Glendale has really come alive since March," said Barry Rubens, president of the California Research Corporation in Santa Monica, publisher of a bank newsletter. "They are feeding on existing discontent with B of A.
"If they keep hammering, it becomes more than a perception," he added. "It could be effective."
Besides the attack campaign, BBDO West has created memorable but less pointed TV commercials that ridicule big banks for poor service. More print ads and television spots are planned for next month.
Since the campaign began in January, according to two analysts' reports, Glendale Federal has seen deposits increase 20 percent, while other California savings and loans saw growth of 10 percent or less. At the same time, the reports said, Wells Fargo, First Interstate Bancorp and Bank of America lost deposits.
Still, Glendale Federal is a piggy bank compared with its giant rivals; it has $15 billion in assets, while Bank of America, for example, has $180 billion. And Bank of America is estimated to have outspent Glendale 4 to 1 in advertising last year.
Mr. Trafton credited the aggressive campaign with lowering the average age of Glendale Federal clients to 38 from 58 and improving the savings and loan's profit margins.
Have the big banks counterattacked? "No," he said, asserting, "That's how much they care about retail customers."
Bank of America, for its part, said it intended to stick with a campaign carrying the theme "Banking on America," created by Ketchum Advertising, a unit of Ketchum Communications Inc. Harvey M. Radin, a BankAmerica spokesman in San Francisco, said that "we're not seeing any impact" from the tough-talking Glendale Federal ads.
Lorna Doubet, a spokeswoman for Wells Fargo in San Francisco, said her company chose to take the high road: "We don't do this kind of advertising, and don't respond to attacks like this."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

New Mini-Vans and Rebates Hurt Chrysler's Profit
Chrysler reported that its third-quarter earnings fell 46 percent, citing the costs of introducing new mini-vans and of priming a reluctant market with rebates.
Chrysler's earnings fell to $354 million, or 90 cents a share, from a $651 million a year ago. Chrysler's worldwide vehicle sales dipped slightly in the quarter, but revenue climbed 2.6 percent, to $12 billion from $11.7 billion. The earnings were in line with analysts' expectations, and Chrysler stock rose 12.5 cents, to $52.75. [Page D2.]
 
S.E.C. Assails Gibson on Derivatives
The S.E.C. sanctioned Gibson Greetings for its handling of derivatives trading, sending a message that companies need to be more strict in the way they account for and control their complex financial dealings. [D4.]

Technology Stocks Lift Market
Technology stocks led the market higher, with the Nasdaq index rising 18.10 points, or 1.84 percent, to 1,001.57. The Dow industrials climbed 14.45 points, to 4,735.25. [D10.]

Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Lands Fisons
Fisons P.L.C. of Britain surrendered to a hostile takeover bid by Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, advising its shareholders to accept the $2.89 billion offer. [D8.]
 
Help to Mexico Pays Off
President Clinton's decision to act as lender of last resort to Mexico has apparently paid off, economists say. While Mexico's recession has been deeper than expected and unemployment remains high, exports have surged. And Mexico has managed to refinance its short-term debts without exhausting its line of credit. News Analysis. [D9.]
 
CBS Earnings Down 43%
CBS reported that its earnings fell 43 percent, to $33.4 million, or 52 cents a share, in the third quarter, pulled down by weak ratings and higher payments to its affiliates. [D6.]
 
Dow Corning Move Questioned
Dow Corning is not part of a tentative agreement to settle thousands of lawsuits over silicone breast implants, but the company could end up even worse off, the possible victim of its own miscalculations. [D4.]

Business Support of the Arts Rises
A survey shows that business support for arts organizations in the United States reached an estimated $875 million last year, up from $518 million in 1991. The survey showed a shift in spending toward arts education and performing-arts centers at the expense of museums and conventional theaters. [C15.]

Clinton Wants Funds for Aid Agency
President Clinton lent his support to an effort by world finance ministers to reverse intended Congressional cuts in the United States' contribution to the World Bank's International Development Association. [D8.]
 
New Publishers for Two Magazines
American Express Publishing is expected to announce today that Ed Kelly, publisher of Food & Wine, will succeed Richard Barthelmes as publisher of Travel & Leisure, the division's flagship publication. Julie McGowan, advertising director of The New Yorker and before that founding publisher of Family Life, will replace Mr. Kelly. [D6.]
 
More Cuts at The Miami Herald
The Miami Herald announced more cost-cutting measures, saying that its newsroom staff would shrink to about 415 in 1996 from about 455 earlier this year and that the total staff at the paper would drop to 1,900 from 2,200 by the end of next year. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Russia Answers Capitalism: Let the People Have Fur!

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: PUSHKINO, Russia

 BODY:
A sharp hint of winter has begun to fill the air here. Most days the frost is still gone with the sun, but now is the time when Russians begin to dress like Russians again: the season of fur has returned.
And this year it has returned with a twist that has astonished everyone from the people in this small town who run the country's largest fur farm to shopkeepers in Moscow and importers across the globe. 
 With six types of mink, huge reserves of fox, and sable so luxurious that, according to legend, the ancient Greeks and Romans called it the Golden Fleece, fur exports have always helped fix the Russian identity in Western minds.
Not anymore. Fur exports have slowed to a fraction of what they were just five years ago, but not because prices have soared or animal-rights advocates have turned off the West entirely to fur.
It's simpler than that. Russians themselves -- often newly rich, profoundly ostentatious and hellbent on staying warm throughout the six-month winter -- are buying fur as never before.
"The market in Russia is simply exploding," said Jay Mechutan, a New York fur importer who has been working with the Russians for more than 50 years, longer than any other American fur company.
"They used to send us anything they could. Now they are buying even the most expensive of their own products, and when that isn't good enough you find them at every world auction from Greece to Stockholm to Hong Kong. With the possible exception of the Koreans, they have become the largest consumers in the world market. And it pretty much happened overnight."
Well, maybe not quite overnight. Fur and caviar, after all, are Russia's two most famous luxury items. And fur has been a signature status symbol here for centuries.
It was the magnificent and elusive sable, with its rich silky undercoat, that helped lure Russians 5,000 miles across Siberia over much of the world's most inhospitable terrain. By the middle of the 17th century Europe had lost its mind over the stuff, and it was worth more than gold. Long before, however, some fanciful 10th-century designer even tried to stitch sable and mink along the edges of a few early Russian Knights' shining armor.
But fur sales have had their rough spots lately, particularly in the United States. In the 1980's retail sales of fur cruised up to about $2 billion. But the 80's are over, at least in the West. Tighter money, the second warmest winter in a century and the clear impact of animal-rights protests nearly halved retail sales in the United States last year from what they were in 1987.
In earlier decades that might have devastated the market here. But, at least for the privileged few thousand, times are better now.
While no statistics are issued on domestic fur consumption, in 1991, the Russian state statistical agency says, there was almost exactly $60 million worth of fur purchased for export. The next year the figure inched up to $62 million, and it grew again in 1993, when for the first time more than 50,000 pounds of pelts, worth $64 million, were sent abroad.
But last year the export market appeared to crash, falling to only $30 million worth of sales, even though more skins were culled than ever before. This year that trend will surely deepen.
"We were taken by surprise at first," said Andrei P. Nyukhalov, deputy director of the Pushkino fur farm here less than an hour north of Moscow, where thousands of sables live their very abbreviated, caged lives under security that would make the old leaders of the K.G.B. proud.
"We thought nobody was going to buy the fur," he added. "Then we realized they were buying it all in Russia."
The fur stores of Moscow are having a busy autumn. The expensive skins are selling briskly, but the cheaper coats are almost impossible to keep in stock.
"Of course I have always wanted a fur coat," Irina P. Titova, a 35-year-old secretary, said as she tried on a dark mink that cost about $6,500 in a store at Petrovsky Passage, one of Moscow's tonier shopping malls. "The question I have been asking all summer is, 'Do I buy something this good or do I settle for less?' "
She reluctantly settled for fox at less than half the price. But many people, in Moscow at least, no longer have to. It is possible to buy a full-length mink coat in Moscow for less than $5,000 -- still unimaginably expensive for most Russians -- but a trifle for the truly wealthy new Russians who would not think twice about dropping that amount in a brief night at a casino.
Sable, of course, is another thing. At Pushkino, where 40 percent of the caged sable in Russia is raised each year in individual cages not much bigger than the animals themselves, each pelt can go for up to $500 -- and it can take 100 of them to make a coat. But the average price for a sable coat is more than $50,000 -- because it is so difficult to match the pelts properly.
"If you've ever managed to scrape up enough money to find some fur to wear through a Russian winter you will never turn back," said Valintina V. Ponikova, the deputy director of one of the city's largest fur stores near Red Square, named Fur Store, which is what they all used to be called in the Soviet era.
Mrs. Ponikova has worked in the same store for 35 years, so she can lay claim to some perspective. "Russian women come in here every day and buy $10,000 coats now," she said, still a little taken aback by it all. "But the real growth has been in the cheaper furs. Not everyone has the money for a real good mink, but often people can pay for something less rare."
As the Russian consumer starts earning enough money to make the leap from a fur hem on a wool coat to a genuine fur hat or a fur coat itself, producers here are trying to accommodate them by raising breeds ordinary people can afford. Many Russian fur producers are turning away from mink and sable to less expensive products like lambskin, nutria and cheaper varieties of fox that can all sell for less than $1,000 a coat.
This is driven partly by the desire to meet a market, but even more powerfully by today's farm realities. It costs a lot of money to feed a sable or mink -- at least $250 in the six months of its existence -- and the food has to be rich in vitamins if the skins are going to be warm and soft. The food investment has driven hundreds of small fur farms out of business, although bigger companies like this one in Pushkino are always ready to sweep up the spoils.
There are few countries that have as much right as Russia to be gung-ho on fur. Two-thirds of the Russian land mass stays frozen from October to April. Most of the rest of the country has winters far colder than say, Dallas or Miami, two of the cities where, according to the Fur Information Council, American fur consumption never seems to dip.
Even animal-rights activists here do not waste too much energy on the issue.
"We have so many serious problems with the way animals are treated in this country that I cannot honestly say this is one of our biggest concerns," said Vera Maksimova, head of the Russian Society for the Protection of Animals. It is the only major animal-rights agency remaining in Russia.
"We are against the wearing of fur," she said. "But I have to admit that it's a sign of a strong economy, and that is something in the end I can hardly oppose. I guess I think asking Russians not to wear fur is a little bit unrealistic, even for me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fur exports from Russia are falling because its own newly rich, like this woman in Moscow, can afford more. (Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times) (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chrysler Posts Drop in Profit As Kerkorian Hones Attack

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 11

 BODY:
As Kirk Kerkorian turned up the heat on the Chrysler Corporation today by accusing it of complacency and highhandedness toward shareholders, the company reported sharply lower earnings for the third quarter, citing the costs of introducing new mini-vans and of priming a reluctant market with rebates.
In line with analysts' expectations, Chrysler's net income fell 46 percent, to $354 million, from a record $651 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. Chrysler's worldwide vehicle sales dipped slightly in the quarter, but revenue climbed 2.6 percent, to $12 billion from $11.7 billion. 
 The earnings came to 91 cents a share, down from $1.76 a share a year earlier. With Chrysler predicting a return to strong profitability in the fourth quarter, its stock rose slightly, closing at $52.75 a share, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The stock might also have been buoyed by the saber-rattling in Mr. Kerkorian's camp, analysts said. Jerome B. York, Mr. Kerkorian's chief strategist, assailed the company today in a speech in New York, saying his weeks spent analyzing Chrysler had convinced him that its costs were rising dangerously.
In the clearest articulation yet of a theme crucial to Mr. Kerkorian as he takes on Chrysler, Mr. York portrayed himself as an avatar of shareholder activism squaring off against top managers and directors who are unresponsive to shareholders' concerns. "They can't stand the thought of having directors on the board that really represent shareholders," said Mr. York, who once was Chrysler's chief financial officer.
Mr. York said that Chrysler was trying to paint the Tracinda Corporation, Mr. Kerkorian's wholly owned company, as hostile to create an excuse to dismiss Tracinda's criticisms. "The comments emanating from Chrysler suggest they want to roll back the hands of time to the 'good old days' -- as they would view it -- before shareholder activism," Mr. York said.
Mr. York said Chrysler's fixed costs had risen from slightly more than $8 billion in 1992 to $10.5 billion this year, and would reach $11 billion in 1996. He also said warranty costs had risen 50 percent since 1993, to $2 billion or more. In a telephone interview, Mr. York said the increased warranty costs probably arose mostly from faulty engines and transmissions.
The rising costs, he said, are increasing Chrysler's break-even point, the level of sales at which the company is profitable, to about 70 percent of factory capacity this year from 65 percent in 1994. Mr. York's speech, before the Nationsbank 1995 Corporate Bond Conference, had been scheduled before he left I.B.M. on Sept. 5 to join Mr. Kerkorian, Tracinda said.
Chrysler dismissed Mr. York's numbers, but declined to address them point by point. In a statement, the company said, "Kerkorian and his people are out of touch with the auto industry in general and Chrysler in particular."
The company said it welcomed "constructive dialogue" with shareholders, but added, "Given Kerkorian's past record of sucking out cash and selling off assets, we are not convinced that his motives are in the best interests of all Chrysler shareholders."
For the three months ended Sept. 30, Chrysler's woes centered on mini-vans. A shortage of new-model mini-vans cost the company sales, while a surplus of the old ones drove up incentive costs. In addition to those costs, Chrysler said it spent $70 million in the quarter to introduce its new mini-vans and $30 million to start production of its full-size Ram pickup truck at a plant in St. Louis.
Incentives in the quarter averaged $870 a vehicle, up from $520 a year earlier, but down from $1,035 in the second quarter. David Healy, auto analyst with Burnham Securities, said that incentives declined to an average of $671 by the end of the quarter, as Chrysler sold out of its old mini-vans. That bodes well for the rest of the year, he said.
Gary C. Valade, Chrysler's chief financial officer, said: "We see good things for the fourth quarter. The mini-van launch is behind us." He said Chrysler would have full production of mini-vans by the end of the year.
Asked whether Chrysler would post a year-over-year increase in profits in the fourth quarter after three quarters of declines, Mr. Valade said, "We have a shot at having more favorable earnings."
Chrysler finished the third quarter with $6.4 billion in cash on hand, down from $6.6 billion a year earlier and $6.9 billion at the end of the second quarter. Mr. Valade said the declining reserve did not reflect pressure from Mr. Kerkorian, who has said Chrysler should be keeping no more than $5 billion on hand to protect it in a downturn.
Mr. Valade said Chrysler expected to have about $7 billion in cash at the end of the year. Chrysler has set a target for the reserve of $7.5 billion.
Chrysler said that its sales in Mexico dropped to 6,000 vehicles in the third quarter from 24,000 a year earlier, costing the company about $100 million in revenue.

HEADLINE: Police Bullets Among Those That Wounded an Officer

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
A police officer who was shot four times in an East Village bodega Tuesday night was caught in a hail of gunfire between the police and drug dealers, the police said, with two of the bullets striking him fired by fellow officers.
As the wounded officer, Keith Prunty, 29, remained in very serious condition yesterday at Bellevue Hospital with bullet wounds in the chest, groin, shoulder and thigh, investigators tried to reconstruct what they said they believed was a robbery gone awry at the Lopez Deli at 272 Third Street off Avenue C. One of four men the police said were robbing the bodega of heroin and cash was fatally shot, and the other three men were arrested. 
 Officer Prunty and his partner, Officer Gerald Derby, were patrolling in their radio car around 11 P.M. when a pedestrian flagged them down to report a robbery on the block. The officers called for backup as they sped toward the bodega. When they arrived, "there was a fusillade," said Assistant Chief John J. Hill, commanding officer of Manhattan detectives.
John F. Timoney, First Deputy Police Commissioner, said at a news conference late yesterday that a man in the bodega had reached for a gun, and Officers Prunty and Derby had shot him. When Officer Prunty moved to search the suspect, a second gunman emerged from a rear door of the bodega.
By then four more police officers had arrived at the bodega, and Officer Prunty was caught in the ensuing gunfight, Mr. Timoney said. A total of five police officers fired, including Officer Prunty, with two of their bullets striking Officer Prunty, the police said. Officer Prunty fired 15 shots, emptying his gun. There were at least 30 shots fired altogether, the police said. All of the officers were wearing bulletproof vests.
Officials said that all of the officers would be questioned and that ballistics tests would be done to determine which officers fired and when. The officials emphasized that while officers are trained to avoid endangering one another, in the case of wild shootouts, accidents can happen.
The police found 50 small bags of heroin and three semiautomatic handguns yesterday at the bodega.
"It appears like it was a drug ripoff," Chief Hill said in a brief interview.
A man whose apartment is in the same building as the store and who spoke on the condition of anonymity said he heard intense arguing in Spanish among three or four men for several minutes before he heard shots.
Police officials said the owner and employees of the bodega are being questioned. They said that the bodega has been under surveillance by the police and the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration for a year and has been the scene of three shootings since April, including Tuesday's.
Officer Prunty of Levittown, L.I., is the son of a retired New York City police officer. He is married, with two daughters, ages 9 and 3 months. He has received several commendations during his four-year career.
Mr. Timoney, speaking from Bellevue Hospital, said that Officer Prunty was in good spirits. "He gave a thumbs up and wrote a note to his wife saying he loved her," Mr. Timoney said.
"He is a good solid cop, a good street guy," said Deputy Inspector Richard E. Seta, who was Officer Prunty's commanding officer until December. "He was responsive to the community and very reliable."
The police could not immediately identify the man killed in the shooting. The three men who were arrested and charged with assault and robbery were Benjamin Lugo, 18, of 662 Water Street in Manhattan; Sigfredo Mendez, 22, of 934 East Seventh Street in Manhattan, and Edwin Rivera, 20, of 89-01 202d Street in the Hollis section of Queens.
Neighborhood residents complained of open drug dealing and of young lookouts armed with beepers who stand at the corners of Avenues C and D to warn of police patrols.
"Everywhere you go you see a grocery store and they're dealing drugs," said George Rodriguez, a 40-year-old unemployed man who lives a block away. "Nobody's safe."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
2 Magazines To Appoint New Publishers

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
The American Express Publishing Corporation, which has struggled to overcome the effects of poor management and a lack of investment in the early 1990's, is finally feeling cocky again. Today it is expected to announce new publishers for Travel & Leisure and Food & Wine.
"We are putting the finishing touches on the turnaround of our magazines," said Daniel B. Brewster Jr., president and chief executive of the corporation, which is the publishing arm of the American Express Company. 
 Ed Kelly, publisher of Food & Wine, will succeed Richard Barthelmes as publisher of Travel & Leisure. Julie McGowan, advertising director of The New Yorker and prior to that founding publisher of Family Life, will replace Mr. Kelly. Mr. Barthelmes is leaving to pursue other endeavors.
The division also publishes Departures, Your Company and Sky Guide, an in-flight directory. It has a book group and a new media group.
Even as many magazines are feeling the effects of increases in postal rates and paper costs, Mr. Brewster said that the American Express group's profit would rise for the first time since 1991. He said that revenue is up 10 percent from last year.
Figures from Publishers Information Bureau, which tracks ad pages and revenue, show Travel & Leisure down 3.2 percent in ad pages for the first nine months of the year compared with the corresponding period last year, a time when Conde Nast Traveler, published by Advance Publications, passed Travel & Leisure in ad pages for the first time.
Mr. Brewster said that while the third quarter was weak, Travel & Leisure would finish strongly because of a strong fourth quarter. Its circulation of 962,000 is up 4.7 percent for the first six months of 1995.
Food & Wine, with a circulation of 789,000, is up 30 percent in ad pages for the first nine months of the year.
Since 1993, the company has been managed by Time Inc. Ventures, a unit of Time Warner, under the terms of an unusual deal signed in March 1993. Mr. Brewster, who is employed by Time, reports to a board of officials from Time Inc. and American Express Travel Related Services. Time Inc. receives a management fee and profits above a benchmark level are shared.
When Time Inc. took over, an advertising recession besetting the magazine industry had been in effect for three years. Circulation and ad pages were down, the American Express magazines were stagnant and the parent company had virtually ceased investing in the publications.
Individuals at Time Inc. said that Time Inc. tried to sell the magazines. But it learned that the loss of the American Express data base made them far less attractive to potential buyers, so it decided to try to turn the magazines around.

HEADLINE: All 36 of Pataki's Nominees Confirmed by State Senate

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The State Senate today confirmed 36 of Gov. George E. Pataki's nominees -- many of them his political supporters and campaign contributors -- to an assortment of posts, rejecting none.
The confirmations, ranging from the important to the minor, included two men named to run the state's Mental Health Department and the Division of Human Rights. The approvals of the nominees came as Democrats complained that the Pataki administration had used a number of posts to reward supporters. 
 "I think it's excessive the way that they are using the levers of government to reward people for their partisan political activities and their fund raising," said Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Democrat from Manhattan. "I find it disturbing."
Criticism focused on three nominees for directors of the state's Science and Technology Board, which awards large grants to research institutes and companies to encourage high-technology industries in the state.
The men -- Charles Dorkey 3d, David Feinberg and Anthony Gioia -- have collectively made contributions of more than $86,000 to Mr. Pataki's campaign. Their confirmations are expected to be taken up by the Senate on Thursday.
But Mr. Gioia, a businessman from Buffalo, dismissed the criticism and said that it was not unusual for a politician to appoint someone who was a campaign supporter.
"It's not the first time this has happened in the history of either party," said Mr. Gioia, who like the others would receive no salary if confirmed. "I supported Governor Pataki because we shared the same ideology, and he would like that ideology implemented through his appointments."
Mr. Pataki also nominated to minor posts a number of other people who contributed to his campaign, including James Ortenzio, a business executive from New York City, and Louise Woerner, who heads a home health care company in Rochester.
Their collective contributions totaled $25,500. The Senate voted to approve Mr. Ortenzio's nomination to the board of trustees of Cornell University, as well as approving Ms. Woerner's nomination to the Public Health Council.
The Governor also nominated the Rev. Calvin Butts to both the Science and Technology Board and the Empire State Development Corporation, an economic-development agency. The Rev. Butts gave Mr. Pataki's campaign a major push last year after he invited the Governor to speak to his congregation at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, a prominent black church in Harlem.
The formal vote in the Republican-controlled Senate took place this afternoon after a roughly one-hour hearing before the Senate Finance Committee in which every one of the 36 nominees was accepted with no resistance. The Senate will resume the nomination hearings on Thursday.
James L. Stone, 55, a former director of mental health and community services in Monroe County, was approved as Commissioner of the Mental Health Department, one of the nation's largest mental health systems, with 2,300 employees and a $2 billion annual budget. He has been Acting Commissioner since his nomination in August. His salary will be $102,335.
The Senate also filled two other important posts today, voting to accept Edward Mercado as the new Commissioner of the Division of Human Rights and Roland M. Malan as the new Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transit Authority. Mr. Mercado's salary will be $82,614, while Mr. Malan will earn $102,335.

HEADLINE: Geisha Tradition In Heart of Manhattan;
Clubs Provide a Familiar Atmosphere For Relaxing and Conducting Business

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

 BODY:
Sitting in the dimly lighted Club Ohogi around a $150 bottle of Martell Cognac and a tiny plate of peanuts, Isahiro Asami and Fumio Yoshida sip from crystal tumblers as the three hostesses at their table fawn over them, searching for unlighted cigarettes and half-filled glasses. For two hours, the two business executives talk, chat with the hostesses and play bar games.
For all this, the two will pay a $250 tab before sauntering off to the Club Stella a block away. By the end of the night, they will spend several hundred more dollars. The peanuts are free. 
 "It's very relaxing," said Mr. Asami, a jovial, gray-haired printing broker in Manhattan who goes out clubbing with clients twice a week. "This is traditional Japanese-style business."
Paying exorbitant sums for a drink has long been a tradition in places like the Ginza district in Tokyo, where business relationships that will last a lifetime are forged in clubs that cater to men with expense accounts. But over the last two decades, driven by the influx of Japanese executives to America, these exclusive kurabu, as they are known in Japanese, have been transported -- stale peanuts and all -- to a quiet stretch of midtown, just west of the United Nations. Several dozen are scattered over roughly 16 square blocks.
The migration has been so discreet that many people who live nearby have no idea the clubs exist. Usually, the only marker is a tiny plaque, purposely small to keep passers-by, no matter how well heeled, from inadvertently stumbling into this world.
For the legions of executives who stay in the United States only a few years before returning to Japan, the clubs are a welcome taste of home -- a place to relax and engage in ritualized flirting with hostesses that harks back to the days of the geisha.
But in their migration to the West, the clubs also have changed in subtle ways as the geisha traditions of female service clash with the sensibilities of Americanized hostesses.
"It's good money, it's flexible and has short hours, but a lot of women get angry doing this," said Etsuko Kizawa, a hostess at Club Ohogi, who said she is paid about $100 an evening for about five hours' work.
She came to the United States seven years ago to flee the oppression of Japanese society. "I was searching for a paradise in New York," she said, "but I've ended up playing the same old role."
Club Ohogi sits on a quiet block of East 49th Street, just east of Third Avenue, filled with brownstone co-ops and doctors' offices, a street that gets eerily quiet for Manhattan after 8:30 P.M. There is little to indicate a club except for an awning over the front door with the single word Ohogi, in Japanese and English.
"If you don't know, you're not going to know," said Franz Stephens, a doorman at a building across the street who for years watched the groups of businessmen enter the building at night and wondered what went on inside.
Through the front door, up a spiral staircase that winds past a large photograph of a woman's leg, each customer is met by a hostess, dressed for the office, whose standard greeting is to present a business card.
Next to the stairway is a case filled with bottles of Chivas Regal, Johnny Walker Black Label, Martell and other liquors, each bearing the name of the customer who bought it.
The club owner, Takeshi Okazaki, said most Westerners who come with Japanese customers have a hard time grasping what the club is about. At $120 a person just to get inside, some assume that more than drinks and peanuts are offered.
Hostesses said the Ginza-style clubs, where businessmen and hostesses sit at prudish distances from each other, are as innocent as they proclaim, although other Asian clubs may be involved in prostitution.
Officer Steve Cohen of the Manhattan South vice unit said the police had never received any complaints or reports of prostitutions at the Japanese clubs. "They really don't cause a problem," he said.
Mr. Okazaki said the clubs in New York date back 15 to 20 years. When he arrived in New York in 1980 as a salesman for a Japanese chemical company, there were already a dozen in the quiet side streets near the United Nations.
Mr. Okazaki was a typical Japanese executive expected eventually to return home after a few years in the United States. But like thousands of others who have come to this country, he never did.
"Well, my kids wanted to stay," he said. "They liked it here."
He could have stayed as a salesman, but after years of drinking in Ginza-style clubs, he struck out on his own in the club business. He claims, however, "It's not as profitable as you think." The high prices, he said, reflect the expense of paying the hostesses, who receive about $100 a night.
Compared with clubs in Tokyo, said Mr. Asami, the printing broker, the New York clubs are a bargain since going to one of the fanciest in Ginza can cost $600.
But the camaraderie with the client is the same. After spending several hundred dollars on a client and joking together with a young woman for several hours, Mr. Asami said, "When I call them the next morning, there is a different feeling between us."
A former Ginza hostess, who refused to allow her name to be used because she owns a boutique in the West Village, said: "These men really don't know how to relax. That's why they need us."
In Ginza, hostesses at the best clubs are required to read the major newspapers every day and keep up with economic developments. In New York clubs, the requirements are less stringent.
Inside Club Ohogi, the rituals of the hostess can be as formal as a tea ceremony and as bawdy as an afternoon talk show.
As Mr. Asami and Mr. Yoshida, the owner of a Manhattan insurance company that caters to Japanese clients, puff on their cigarettes, Ms. Kizawa delicately places ice cubes in each glass. It is a ceremony that takes minutes to complete.
Then she lifts the bottle of Cognac and pours, after turning the bottle so the label is clearly visible to the men.
After some small talk, she has the table laughing raucously with a game in which everyone at the table has to answer a true-or-false questions by slipping a quarter under a napkin. Heads for true, tails for false.
"O.K., did anyone make love last night?" she asks as the table breaks into laughter.
Ms. Kizawa came to the United States in 1988 to study film making, one of the thousands of young Japanese turning away from the strict regimen of Japanese life.
Her father had worked for a large electronics company all his life, but she saw herself as a rebel.
"I just felt I really didn't fit in there," she said. "By the time I was 15, I already knew I wanted to get out. There wasn't a space for me there."
Like many other young Japanese, she took up the bohemian life in the East Village and became immersed in studying film. For several years, she supported herself by working in Japanese restaurants, but eventually discovered that the best pay came from working at the clubs.
In her search for freedom, she found herself working in the most traditional role she could imagine, which she describes as being a modern geisha.
Last year, she finished a film about her club experience, "New York Geisha." In the film, a student project for the School of Visual Arts, she portrays a harsh and humiliating world in which women grovel before men, laughing at their jokes with forced smiles. In the end, the her protagonist leaves the world of the clubs.
Unlike her film heroine, Ms. Kizawa still works at Club Ohogi three nights a week. It is a job that allows her to work on film projects by day.
"It's not that degrading and it's not dangerous, and I do sometimes make good contacts with people," she said. "It's tolerable and, after three years of this, I'm used to it."

HEADLINE: Manzi Departure Unlikely To Derail I.B.M.'s Plans

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
For I.B.M., the abrupt departure of Jim P. Manzi is less a strategic blow than a sobering reminder of how quickly the human assets of a software company can take flight.
It was less than four months ago that Mr. Manzi, the 43-year-old chief executive of the Lotus Development Corporation, agreed to sell Lotus to I.B.M. for $3.5 billion and join the executive ranks of I.B.M. 
 Most analysts expect other Lotus executives to leave the International Business Machines Corporation in the wake of Mr. Manzi's move. But they say a trickle of departures should have scant effect on I.B.M.'s strategy for making Lotus software -- especially its Notes program -- a vehicle for growth during the next several years.
The real danger, analysts say, would be if there were a wholesale exodus of key Lotus people from I.B.M., like the team of developers behind Notes, which enables computer-linked employees to work in far-flung teams. The head of the Notes team is Ray Ozzie, whom William H. Gates of Microsoft once called "one of the top five programmers in the universe."
"Manzi's departure is not any kind of derailing of I.B.M.'s strategy for Lotus," said Stuart Woodring, an analyst at Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. "But if Ozzie and a few others left, that would be a real problem."
I.B.M. paid cash for Lotus, which means that people like Mr. Ozzie instantly became multimillionaires thanks to their Lotus shares. And despite reports that Mr. Ozzie has a contract to complete two more upgrades of Notes, which could keep him at I.B.M. for another 18 months or so, one executive close to Lotus said there was no contract holding Mr. Ozzie. Mr. Ozzie could not be reached for comment yesterday.
Keeping the key Lotus developers and managers within the I.B.M. fold, and keeping them motivated and productive, is vital if I.B.M. is going to make a success of its software business in the future.
Today, I.B.M.'s sizable software business is largely dependent on the company's mainframe and mini-computer lines, and is growing very little, according to Stephen K. Smith, an analyst for Paine Webber Inc.
Since 1988, I.B.M.'s software revenues have increased by just $1 billion, to $11 billion last year, Mr. Smith estimated. During the same period, he said, the total computer software market has grown to $75 billion from $30 billion.
"I.B.M. desperately needs to get growth from the software business, and that's what the Lotus acquisition was about," Mr. Smith said.
Armed with Lotus Notes, I.B.M. hopes to retain its corporate customers and to finally beat the Microsoft Corporation in an important product category. Despite spending heavily, I.B.M. has been unable to make its OS/2 desktop operating program any kind of a rival to Microsoft's Windows.
Major corporations increasingly want their employees to share documents, reports and financial information across time zones and borders. Lotus Notes is the leading program that enables this kind of teamwork -- a software category called groupware.
Recently, Notes has become a hot product among large industrial companies, banks and high-tech concerns. Installations are expected to double this year to roughly 2.6 million. And significantly for I.B.M., Microsoft has been an uncharacteristic laggard in groupware.
Yet so far, most analysts said, the early signs from the I.B.M.-Lotus merger look encouraging, despite Mr. Manzi's surprise departure. Last July, for example, I.B.M. executives announced that Lotus products like cc:mail, Lotus Organizer and Lotus Approach would be the standard desktop offerings from I.B.M.
"To date, the integration of the two companies is ahead of schedule," said John B. Jones Jr., an analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc.
Investors apparently agreed, shrugging off news of Mr. Manzi's resignation. I.B.M. shares closed yesterday at $92.50, up $1.75.
"The direction of change at I.B.M. is still upward," said Dan Mandresh, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Faults Gibson Greetings's Accounting in Derivatives Deals

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Sending a message that companies need to be stricter in the way they account for and control their complex financial dealings, the Securities and Exchange Commission sanctioned Gibson Greetings yesterday for its handling of derivatives trading.
The commission issued a cease-and-desist order against the company, mandating improved controls and better accounting, but did not impose any fines. The S.E.C. typically does not fine publicly held companies for accounting violations because such punishment would fall on the shareholders that the commission is trying to protect. 
 But the action is significant because it comes after Bankers Trust settled S.E.C. charges that it misled Gibson on the risks of derivatives. Gibson, a Cincinnati-based greeting-card company, lost $20.7 million as a result of the derivatives. Bankers Trust, which paid $10 million to settle the commission's complaint, also settled a suit brought by Gibson by agreeing to void $14.5 million of the loss.
"The S.E.C. is telling companies they ought to do much more in disclosing their derivatives activities to the public," said Henry Hu, an expert in derivatives law at the University of Texas at Austin.
Colleen P. Mahoney, deputy director of enforcement for the commission, said, "The fact that Bankers Trust committed fraud in selling derivatives does not absolve Gibson from making sure they have the internal controls necessary to control the risks of these transactions and to account for them accurately on their financial statements."
Accounting experts said the S.E.C. could bring similar charges against other companies that faced derivatives losses, including Procter & Gamble, which is in the middle of a bitter fraud suit against Bankers Trust.
"The cases of Gibson and Procter & Gamble seem very similar," said Michael S. Joseph, a partner with the accounting firm Ernst & Young. But he noted that the commission might not need to bring additional cases to make its point. "They are trying to make a good example of a company, then move on," he said.
Ms. Mahoney of the S.E.C. declined to comment on whether the agency was considering other cases involving derivatives.
Derivatives are contracts with values that are based on -- or derived from -- an underlying financial asset like stocks, bonds or currencies. They are often used by companies to reduce, or hedge, their risks -- for example, to lock in an interest rate on their debt. Derivatives can also be used to invest or speculate on a market's direction.
The commission is expected to propose a more general set of rules in coming weeks about how companies report their derivatives positions.
The S.E.C. said Gibson was speculating on interest rates with derivatives, but was using accounting rules meant for hedging that allowed the gains or losses from the transactions to be postponed until they matured. It found that Gibson should have recorded its profits and losses from the derivatives in each quarter.
The commission also criticized Gibson for not disclosing the nature of the risks of its derivative position in the management discussion and analysis section of its quarterly financial reports.
Separately, it found that by not maintaining adequate internal controls to keep tabs on the risk of its derivatives positions, Gibson violated securities laws that require companies to maintain accurate books and records.
Gibson agreed to the provisions of the S.E.C. order, although it neither admitted nor denied the findings. "We are pleased this matter has been resolved," Benjamin J. Sottile, the company's chairman, said in a statement.
