HEADLINE: 6 Companies Lose Control At Market

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
In its boldest move yet to break the Mafia's grip on the Fulton Fish Market, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's administration has decided to remove six companies that have long controlled the flow of fish into the market, officials said yesterday. It plans to replace them with a new company that has no experience in the seafood-distribution business.
The new system, which will begin Sunday, affects companies, known as unloaders, that collect $2 million in fees annually for unloading seafood supplies, the officials said. 
 Speaking on the condition of anonymity, the officials and city investigators said that reinforced police contingents would be assigned to the market in lower Manhattan to head off any work disruptions because of the changeovers and dismissals of employees who work for the six unloading companies.
A major revision in the unloading system will require for the first time that the new company unload and deliver seafood from refrigerated trucks on a first-come, first-served basis to 60 wholesale dealers in the market. More than 100 trucking companies deliver 150 million pounds of fish and seafood each year from Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports and from airports.
Under the old unloading system, each of the six companies had specific territorial rights, and decided among themselves the order in which trucks were unloaded and how quickly. Because seafood is perishable, the unloaders had economic strangleholds over truckers and wholesalers, the officials said. City officials and Federal investigators said that in the past, the truckers and merchants had no choice in selecting an unloading company, and were forced to pay the prices the unloaders dictated.
City officials said they expected that the new system would lower prices for merchants by about 20 percent. The wholesalers generally pay most of the unloading charges. In the past, officials said, unloaders also charged illegal fees to truckers who wanted their fish unloaded more quickly. The officials said such supplemental fees would now be banned.
The concern chosen by the city to take over the exclusive unloading duties is Laro Maintenance Company of Bay Shore, L.I. The company, according to business records, has specialized in cleaning and maintenance services for office buildings in the New York area.
Aides to Mayor Giuliani said the Laro company had passed a background check by the city's Department of Investigation.
Rudy Washington, the city's Commissioner of Business Services, will inform the six ousted firms and the wholesalers in the market today of the new setup.
The Laro company will be licensed for two years, officials said. It will not be required to hire any of the 40-odd employees now working for the six expelled unloading companies.
Without city licenses, and acting on their own authority, the six firms had for decades been in charge of unloading seafood when they arrived at the market in refrigerated trucks and transporting them short distances to the wholesale dealers. The dealers then sold the produce to retail merchants and restaurateurs.
In 1987, when Mayor Giuliani was Federal Attorney in Manhattan, his office cited the principal owners of the six unloading companies in a civil racketeering case as associates in the Genovese crime family.
The owners have denied links to organized crime and no criminal charges were brought against them.
Ousting the unloading companies is the most significant move by the administration since a licensing law went into effect on Sept. 1, empowering the city to determine who can do business and who can work in the market. The law is intended to end corruption in business practices and to rid the market of organized crime.
In its 160 years of existence, the market has inspired colorful tales of gritty merchants and laborers who toil from midnight to dawn on the banks of the East River to supply the New York area with fresh seafood. But Federal and state investigations have produced another story of a rough, insular landscape in which mobsters thrive on extortions, no-show jobs and illegal gambling and loan-sharking rackets.
For the last 60 years, law enforcement officials have said the Genovese crime family and to a lesser extent the Bonanno family control many wholesale dealers and companies in the market through their influence in groups like the unloaders.
The companies that are to be removed are: P.A.S. & G. Unloading Company; Seaport Unloaders; Dead Fish Relocators (formerly Fish Unloaders); J. Fox Unloading; R. Fox Unloading, and Jet Unloading.

HEADLINE: New York Makes Staying Put Irresistible to Coffee Exchange

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
Offering one of the most lucrative packages of subsidies ever provided in New York City, state and city officials persuaded the board of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange yesterday to cancel plans to move the exchange to Jersey City, and instead to build a new trading center in Manhattan.
Officials described the exchange's decision as a critical victory in the economic development war with New Jersey, which had offered a valuable set of incentives to lure both the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the Cotton Exchange across the Hudson River. 
 Together, the two exchanges directly employ about 3,500 people, but city and state officials estimated that a total of 5,000 jobs would be lost if both moved to Jersey City.
The Cotton Exchange's 30-member board had voted earlier this week to move its operation to Jersey City. But after its sister trading group's announcement, the Cotton Exchange issued a terse statement that it would reconsider its decision next week. Relocation plans for the two have been linked, and are expected to stay that way.
New York officials were hopeful that the Cotton Exchange's board would reverse itself.
"We're elated that the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange voted to stay in New York," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the state's Empire State Development Corporation. "But our proposal is for both of them to act in unison. The bottom line is to keep 5,000 jobs here in New York."
To keep the exchanges in New York, the city and state offered $91 million in subsidies, which places the deal among the largest the city has offered to keep a business. Only one other recent retention deal has compared. In August 1994, the New York Mercantile Exchange threatened to move to Jersey City and was granted $184 million in subsidies to build a facility in Battery Park City. That building is under construction.
With the new offer, the city and state have offered a total of $275 million over the past year to keep the futures industry based in Manhattan. According to the New York City Economic Development Corporation, the largest retention package in the city's history was for $235 million, to Chase Manhattan Corporation in 1988. Measured against the number of employees involved, 4,600, the Chase deal cost the city $51,000 per employee.
By comparison, the city's offer to the Coffee and Cotton exchanges cost about $26,000 for each of the 3,500 employees. The deal with the Mercantile Exchange cost $22,700 for each of the 8,100 employees. But to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the benefits outweigh the costs. "It's important for New York City, within the balance of the things that we can negotiate, to retain these exchanges," he said at a news conference. "It helps to secure our position as the financial capital of the world, and particularly if they're going to also build a new exchange. That really solidifies they're remaining here."
In July, the Cotton and Coffee exchanges signed a tentative agreement with New Jersey to build a $118 million trading floor at the site of the former Colgate Center. Under that pact, the exchanges had until yesterday to confirm their plans with New Jersey officials.
"We know that the Cotton Exchange has voted to accept a proposal from New Jersey," Brian Kelly, the Coffee Exchange's chairman, said in a prepared statement, "but additional benefits were made available from New York subsequent to that vote which significantly impacted the C.S.C.E. decision.
"We are hopeful that the Cotton Exchange will agree with us on the quality of the New York deal and join us so we may finally move forward to develop the trading facility we so desperately need for the members of both of our exchanges."
Under the terms of New York's offer, the exchanges, which together represent about 17 percent of the commodity trading volume in New York City, will build the trading center in the TriBeCa section of lower Manhattan, on a site bordered by Murray, Warren, Greenwich and West Streets.
Specific details for the building are still unclear, but a Coffee Exchange spokeswoman said the new TriBeCa operation would be "fundamentally the same" as the one planned for Jersey City. That facility was designed to provide 275,000 square feet of space, and a 25,000 square-foot trading floor.
The decision marked a bitter setback for New Jersey, which had hoped that its own package of subsidies as well as the lower costs of doing business would persuade the exchanges to abandon Manhattan. Although several New York-based firms have opened large back-office operations in Jersey City, the exchanges would have been the first major front offices based there.
"Obviously we're disappointed," said Thomas Gallagher, press secretary for Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City. The presence of the exchanges, he said, "could have a massive impact not just from the influx of jobs, but also the prestige factor."
Jersey City and state officials refused to disclose the value of their incentive package, which included cash, financing for infrastructure, and tax and utility abatements. People familiar with the negotiations say that the dollar amount was several million less than the amount New York offered. However, when the difference in cost structures in the two states is taken into account, according to these sources, New York's offer was only slightly better than New Jersey's.
"The large incentive package that New York had to offer to keep the exchanges shows the competitive strength of the Jersey City waterfront," Mr. Gallagher said.
The commodities exchanges have threatened to accept subsidized relocation offers from New Jersey on at least three occasions over the last several years, but each time the city and state have countered with retention packages that include new trading facilities. Even so, the Mercantile development is the first one of those that has actually gone forward with construction.
In lower Manhattan, retaining the exchanges bolsters prospects for recovery from the losses and personnel cutbacks that have hit the financial services industry recently.
In addition to the jobs that would be lost to a relocation, an exodus of futures exchanges would decentralize commodities trading activity in the New York area, which according to the Futures Industry Association accounts for about 20 percent of futures trading in the nation.
Chicago, home of the Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange, dominates the U.S. commodities market, with more than 75 percent of domestic futures trading volume.
Futures exchanges are marketplaces in which contracts for the future delivery of commodities such as coffee and cotton are traded according to pre-established conditions. The contract itself is a transferable agreement to deliver or receive the commodity at a specified time and at a specified price.
By retaining the Coffee Exchange, New York also maintains an important position in an industry that is growing worldwide. Although the Coffee Exchange only accounts for 2.3 percent of the commodities trading volume in the United States, the total worldwide volume of futures trading has more than doubled over the last 25 years. "It's gone up, up, up," said John Damgard, president of the Futures Industry Association, a Washington-based trade group.
This rapid growth has left New York's commodities markets physically squeezed inside their current home at the World Trade Center, where they share a crowded trading floor that is both inefficient and outdated. Competition from new foreign exchanges with modern operations is forcing improvements on domestic exchanges. "If those markets can't attract business on an efficient basis," Mr. Damgard said, "then that business is going to go someplace else."
According to the terms of the proposal, New York will give the exchanges a cash grant of $36 million. It will also provide about $55 million in tax and other noncash incentives. In addition, it has offered to help finance the construction of a facility by guaranteeing up to $20 million in loans. Under the terms offered, the cash grant would be provided as long as the Coffee and Cotton exchanges stayed in New York, regardless of the outcome of a proposed merger with the Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks Approved to Spur Growth in Lower Manhattan

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The New York State Senate, clearing a political snag that had delayed an ambitious economic development plan for New York City, yesterday approved a tax abatement bill intended to spur office and housing construction in lower Manhattan.
The tax abatements are part of a plan announced by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that is meant to help reverse the decline of Wall Street and the rest of the financial district. Office vacancies there are high, many buildings are outdated for the computer age, and its streets are all but deserted at night. The bill that passed the Senate is meant to encourage redevelopment to attract businesses, and, for the first time, spur residential use of the area. 
 Although the Mayor's plan has won wide support -- it has been passed by the Assembly and endorsed by Gov. George E. Pataki -- it was held up in June when the leader of the Senate's Republican majority, Joseph L. Bruno of Rensselaer County, refused to allow it to reach the floor for a vote.
The squabble erupted after the Senate's minority leader, Martin Connor of Brooklyn, refused to deliver Democratic support for a resolution to legalize casino gambling, which was sponsored by Mr. Bruno.
But yesterday, the tax abatement bill cleared the Senate on a 53-to-1 vote, with Senator Franz Leichter, a Democrat of Manhattan who has long criticized tax breaks for business, voting against the measure.
Business people said that Senate passage, coming on a day when Mayor Giuliani won a battle to persuade the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange to stay in lower Manhattan, was critical to a broad effort to improve the area.
The tax abatements in the bill would benefit developers who renovate buildings below Chambers Street that were built before 1975, or help those who build new ones. The inducements are intended in part to encourage conversion of old buildings into apartments or to modern offices equipped with the wiring necessary for computers.
Some abatements would flow directly to office tenants. They include a sharp five-year cut in the city's commercial rent tax, which is assessed at 6 percent of total rent and is almost always paid by tenants.
As an inducement to developers, the abatements would also include a five-year reduction in property taxes, and a 10-year exemption from higher property tax assessments based on the improvements.

HEADLINE: Cash Needed For Investing, Chrysler Says

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 12

 BODY:
To rally support against Kirk Kerkorian, the Chrysler Corporation has prepared a detailed defense for stockholders that illustrates how the company has broadened its justification for a $7.5 billion cash reserve, judging by a draft report of the presentation.
In the past, Chrysler executives stressed that the cash fund was intended to cushion the company in the next economic downturn. But as Mr. Kerkorian has attacked the target as excessive, urging Chrysler to return more money to stockholders, the company has begun to speak of the cash cushion as though it were also a vast checking account, enabling it to pursue unexpected opportunities. 
 The company plans to take that approach when it meets with institutional investors this month, judging by the draft report. As one might expect, the draft also shows that Chrysler intends to defend vigorously the quality of its cars and trucks, the return on its stock and its long-term plans.
Chrysler confirmed that the document, which was provided to The New York Times by a person who insisted on anonymity, was an early draft of its presentation. "Financial Flexibility/Cash Target" is the title of the page in the draft presentation that outlines the cash goal. "Cash reserves are necessary to provide flexibility for new investment opportunities, as well as to provide reserves for a downturn," the text reads, in part. Chrysler said it planned to make the same point in the final presentation.
In May, in an address to shareholders at the company's annual meeting, Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, did not mention investment opportunities as a rationale for the cash reserve. "Considering what a downturn can do to an auto company's cash flow, that cushion is altogether reasonable," he said of the $7.5 billion.
Chrysler currently has $6.4 billion in its reserve fund.
Steven Harris, a Chrysler spokesman, acknowledged that Chrysler had recently begun to emphasize that its cash reserve could finance unexpected investments. He said Chrysler had always had that motive for storing up cash, but did not communicate it before. With so much public discussion of the reserve, he said, "we just felt we need to explain it as fully as we can."
But George Sard, a spokesman for the Tracinda Corporation, Mr. Kerkorian's wholly owned company, said, "This is a backhand acknowledgement by Chrysler that they really don't need $7.5 billion in cash to ride out the next recession." Mr. Kerkorian is Chrysler's largest shareholder, with a stake of more than 14 percent.
According to the draft, Chrysler intends to argue that its cash target is in line with those established by its competitors. Its target is 15 percent of automotive revenue, compared with 11 percent at the General Motors Corporation, 16 percent at the Ford Motor Company, and 33 percent at the Toyota Motor Corporation, according to the document.
Mr. Harris said that the presentation had changed in subsequent drafts. "It's definitely not the final," he said of the draft copy. Although the draft says the presentations are scheduled to run from Oct. 18 to Oct. 20, Mr. Harris said no final dates had been set.
After Mr. Kerkorian hired Jerome B. York, a former Chrysler chief financial officer, on Sept. 5, Chrysler appeared to go on the defensive as Mr. York criticized its financial management and the quality of its vehicles. But Chrysler has recently appeared to regain its footing. The draft presentation echoes a speech Mr. Eaton delivered to institutional investors in New York last week in which he strongly defended his management of the nation's No. 3 auto maker.
In the document, Chrysler proudly points to its rich mix of sales, with highly profitable light trucks increasingly outselling its cars. The document also underlines Chrysler's plans for international growth, to 500,000 sales by 1999, from 229,000 this year.
But the draft presentation does not knock down all of Mr. York's criticisms, and it selectively addresses others.
For example, the draft says that problems covered by warranties had dropped 26 percent since 1992. It does not mention that warranty costs per car have risen somewhat.
And while it correctly notes the performance of Chrysler's light trucks in the J. D. Power & Associates Initial Quality Survey, it does not mention that Chrysler cars, as a group, lag behind many competitors in the survey. Mr. Harris pointed out, as does the draft report, that five of the nine most-improved car models in the Power study were Chrysler products, including the two most improved.
In the draft report, Tracinda is mentioned only in the penultimate item on the summary page. "Tracinda is a distraction -- not acting in best interest of all shareholders," reads the item.
It is followed by one last, even briefer note: "Need your support."

HEADLINE: Follow the Leader

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
In September 1993, Arnold P. Cohen arrived in Eldersburg, Md., as chief executive of the London Fog Corporation, the raincoat maker. He soon announced that he was closing the company's five plants there, moving production overseas and the headquarters to Darien, Conn.
"The reality is that the fashion industry is located in Manhattan and we wanted to move closer," Mr. Cohen told reporters. 
 The reality is also that Darien is even closer to Westport, Conn. -- about a 20-minute drive -- than to New York's Fashion Avenue. And Mr. Cohen had a home in Westport.
In August 1994, with the company dizzy and near financial collapse, Mr. Cohen, who said his predecessors had decided to move to the New York area, exited. In January of this year, only two months after the migration was completed, a new chief offered a new idea, since adopted: head back to Eldersburg.
An isolated case? Hardly. London Fog's move was just one of many corporate relocations in which a declaration of high corporate purpose happens to coincide with making the boss's life more convenient.
Earlier this year, Albert J. Dunlap, an avid golf and tennis player, announced plans to move the Scott Paper Company from Philadelphia to Boca Raton, Fla. The announcement came just days after he bought a $1.8 million home there. Over dinner before the move, he had told a local member of Congress that it could be his first home or his second. Mr. Dunlap confirmed recently that his wife was not so coy. According to an account that he did not dispute, she had said, "I don't know about you, Al, but it's going to be my first home."
Just last month, Tenneco Inc. announced a move from Houston to Greenwich, Conn. Dana G. Mead, the chief executive, said he wanted to shuck his company's oil-patch image. Yes, he lived in Greenwich for four years until he joined Tenneco in 1992, he said, but wanting to go back there played no role in the decision.
Mr. Mead might study the example of Armco Inc. , the steelmaker. The company, wanting to diversify and distance itself from its smokestacks, moved in 1985 from Middletown, an Ohio steel town, to Parsippany, N.J. Eight years later, after continuing losses, the company moved back to steel country, to Pittsburgh, under a new chief, a Pittsburgh native.
Executives seldom need prompting to provide business rationale for relocations. But many bosses seem most alert to the rationale for moving to Connecticut's executive havens or, increasingly, to southern Florida's beachfront resort areas, where the golf season never ends. Larry Pelton, a business recruiter in Palm Beach County, which includes Boca Raton, boasts that he is in relocation talks with four Fortune 500 companies whose top executives all have local homes.
Although statistics are few, relocation specialists and attentive investors say corporations are becoming more mobile, with executive fancy figuring ever larger in their moves. "It seems to be escalating," said Anne S. Hansen, deputy director of the Council of Institutional Investors, representing pension funds with $800 billion in assets. "It's our money, and it's being used to pay for moving expenses we are not really convinced are necessary."
Having fought to limit executive pay, shareholders are starting to watch out for bosses who turn a headquarters move into another perk. "It's just a sneakier way of getting more compensation," Ms. Hansen said. "Now that people are attuned to these sky-high compensation agreements, you're getting paid in different ways. One of the current ways to escape scrutiny for higher compensation is to move the company to your favorite place to live."
The ability to manage by telephone, fax and computer has made it easier for a core of executives to plop down in a verdant suburb or resort, leaving everyone else behind. Mr. Mead's new headquarters, for just 100 employees, will have the latest in video-conferencing gear, allowing the Greenwich bosses to glare at division managers in places like Evanston, Ill.; Newport News, Va., and Houston.
Companies moving only their top management put the cost at a few million dollars to $25 million, depending on how many go, whether the new headquarters are bought or leased and what the company considers as a relocation expense. But that does not include the human costs of dislocation or layoffs for underlings.
As much as 90's-style chief executives talk about re-engineering, right-sizing and maximizing shareholder value, real estate agents sense a different message. "That's always been the big joke in the real estate business," said Randy Strait, a senior vice president with the Transwestern Property Company in Houston. "You try to find out where the chairman lives and show him a building nearby."
This inspiration helps Palm Beach County convince many an executive that the business climate is as balmy as the beaches. Besides Scott Paper, in the last few years the county has snared W. R. Grace & Company and the Thompson Medical Company from New York, and several more concerns, including the Wackenhut Corporation, from the Miami area.
Two years ago, county planners quietly began approaching virtually any executive with a local home valued at $1 million or more. "They don't have to live in the Northeast nine months of the year and visit here three months," said Mr. Pelton, with the Business Development Board of Palm Beach County. "They can reverse that, and just visit the Northeast for three months." Instead of blowing its budget on a national publicity campaign, the development board has found it can reach all the right people just by advertising in The Palm Beach Post over the winter.
W. R. Grace became the first big corporation to hit the local beaches when it moved to Boca Raton from New York in 1991. Chuck Suits, a spokesman, says the company's chairman at the time, the late J. Peter Grace Jr., and J. P. Bolduc, then the president, were absolutely not influenced by having vacation homes nearby. "The decision to relocate was part of an extensive three-year study of 100 cities on the Eastern Seaboard," he said.
It was Mr. Bolduc, Mr. Dunlap said, who helped lure him and Scott Paper. Mr. Dunlap had bought a home and moved to Boca Raton, wanting to retire there. In April 1994, Scott Paper hired and brought him to Philadelphia, buying his Boca Raton home for $3.3 million.
But Philadelphia proved too chilly for Mr. Dunlap. In a December speech at the Union League Club, he derided the wintry climate and the city's failure to appreciate his rescue of Scott Paper and the huge payoff for shareholders. Instead, he said, reporters vilified him, presenting the plaints of workers caught in vast layoffs.
Other cities, he said, named buildings for him, held parades for him. "Of course," said John Claypool, executive director of Greater Philadelphia First, a business development group, "those were situations where he had moved companies to town.'
Having slashed the size of the office staff, Mr. Dunlap next wanted to dispose of Scott's tranquil 55-acre headquarters in Philadelphia. "We had a pond, we had geese, we had walking trails," Mr. Dunlap said recently. "It was idyllic, except nothing much happened there."
Development officials of Boca Raton took full advantage of Mr. Dunlap's discontent, offering $780,000 in local and state subsidies. Local bankers, developers, medical leaders and politicians trooped up to see him. In March, Mr. Dunlap closed on a $1.8 million mansion at the Boca Raton Hotel and Resort. A week later, he announced that he was moving the company, too.
"My decision to move down here was done solely on economics," Mr. Dunlap said. And any demands from his wife? "She had zero influence."
Then, four months later, Mr. Dunlap agreed to sell the company to the Kimberly-Clark Corporation for $7 billion. The merged company will keep enough jobs in Boca Raton to justify the incentives, he said.
Tenneco, however, has decided to go for the geese, reversing the usual, southward course of the corporate flock.
As an executive of the International Paper Company, Mr. Mead had a major role in moving the company from Manhattan to Purchase, N.Y., in 1987. He lived across the Connecticut border in the Cos Cob neighborhood of Greenwich until Tenneco recruited him as president in 1992.
When he became chief executive of Tenneco early last year, he followed through on his predecessor's search for a new corporate home. He announced the move to Connecticut, costing as much as $25 million, last month. The destination is an estate once owned by Henry R. Luce, the co-founder of Time magazine. There, a flock of Canada geese will find a new protector.
Mr. Mead, a Midwesterner, said Tenneco was becoming less of an energy company than a maker of auto parts, packaging and other goods, and thus needed to be near New York deal makers. "This is a business decision," he said. "We clearly picked a place where we'd like to live. But when you get down to it it's one word: New York."
Or maybe two or three words, among them "Greenwich." Greenwich, Mr. Mead said, is "as close as you can get to New York and still be in Connecticut."
The consultants who help corporate chiefs choose their new quarters can readily serve their own cause, too. As Moran, Stahl & Boyer, the relocation agency, prepared to move out of Manhattan in May, it was pulled in two directions. Charles K. Elliott, the second-in-command, lives in Irvington, N.Y. But the agency's new chief lives in Atlanta.
Trust the consultants to find a solution. Several members of the firm are going to Atlanta and others to Valhalla, N.Y., the home of the agency's parent company, a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company. Valhalla is about 15 minutes from Mr. Elliott's house.
"We didn't think this out strategically," said W. Kurt Foreman, a consultant at Moran, Stahl & Boyer. "We sort of did the Boca thing."


GRAPHIC: Scott Paper's old corporate campus was in cold Philadelphia. But Albert J. Dunlap, the company's chief executive, bought a $1.8 million house in Boca Raton, Fla. A week after he closed on the house in March, Mr. Dunlap announced that the company would be moving, too.

HEADLINE: Rowland Sets Stage for Casino Battle

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: CROMWELL, Conn., Oct. 12

 BODY:
Faced with an uphill battle to win legislative approval for a casino in Bridgeport, Gov. John G. Rowland today started using the tool that so often wins votes: He began promising people money.
In a speech to the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, whose members represent the state's 169 cities and towns, Governor Rowland announced that the casino would increase state revenues by $200 million during the next three years. That money, he said, would go directly to cities and towns for property tax relief. 
 Mr. Rowland's plan represents a remarkable shift in his priorities and an apparent bow to pragmatic politics. In his election bid last year, Mr. Rowland, a Republican, said that massive cuts in the income tax would be his first order of business, and that property tax reductions favored by his Democratic opponent were a secondary concern.
Now, 10 months into his term, and still $300 million short of meeting his original goal for an income tax cut, Mr. Rowland has apparently changed his focus to win the legislative support he needs for a casino.
"This morning I would implore all of you to do what's best for your community, for Bridgeport and for the state of Connecticut: join us in this effort," he said, asking the mayors and selectmen to lobby their legislators.
Then, describing Bridgeport as a dying city that cannot even attract a new car dealership, he sounded a plaintive note, "I don't have any other solutions."
Mr. Rowland's plea comes two weeks before a special session of the legislature is to consider the Governor's recommendation to allow the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe to open a casino in Bridgeport. The tribe, which operates the Foxwoods Resort Casino in Ledyard, near the Rhode Island border, has proposed spending $875 million for the new waterfront casino complex that would include a hotel, restaurants and a shopping arcade.
It would be the closest casino to New York City -- about a one-hour train trip. And Foxwoods executives have predicted that it would be the most profitable casino in the world.
Still, it has generated opposition in the legislature from an unlikley alliance of two groups. Some lawmakers are opposed to any expansion of casino gambling in the state. Others are opposed to the Pequots, pointing to their refusal to allow slot machines in the jai alai fronton in Milford, the dog track in Plainfield and off-track betting parlors. These lawmakers favor a more expansive gambling proposal by the Las Vegas-based Mirage Resorts, which Mr. Rowland rejected.
For Mr. Rowland, the decision boiled down to economics. The Pequots last year paid the state $135 million from Foxwoods in return for the state granting them and another tribe a monopoly on slot machines. The Indians would cease paying this money if Mirage were allowed to build a casino in Bridgeport.
While Mirage officials claimed that they had submitted a letter of credit that would make up for any loss of revenue the state might suffer, Mr. Rowland today dismissed their offer. "It was not worth the paper it was written on," he remarked, clearly trying to discourage lawmakers who want to revive Mirage's bid.
Mr. Rowland's bid for support seemed to persuade some officials.
H. Richard Borer Jr., the Mayor of West Haven, said he had been "indifferent" about the new casino until this morning's speech. "Right now we receive $1 million," he explained, referring to the money his town receives from the Foxwoods payments. "If we could increase that and lower property taxes, I'm all for it."
Mr. Borer said he planned to call the four lawmakers who represent his town, including three who have been critical of the Pequots' proposal, to urge them to support the Bridgeport project.
Others, however, were skeptical that the towns would ever receive more of the revenue. The state promised two years ago to forward all Indian revenues to the towns, but last year kept 37 percent for its own budget. "It's an enormous pie in the sky," said Arthur S. Rosenblatt, First Selectman of Norfolk.
Still, property tax relief has been a cherished dream for the Connecticut Conference of Muncipalities for years, and the group, an important player in state politics, will decide next week whether to endorse Mr. Rowland's proposal.
Mr. Rowland was cautious today in predicting the outcome of the casino vote, giving it a "50-50" chance for approval. But he made it clear that he would not hold back in his push for the project.
"I've got my prestige on the line," he said.

HEADLINE: Producer Price Index Is Up, But Increase Is Discounted

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The Labor Department reported today that prices paid to American producers rose in September by the biggest amount in eight months, but economists dismissed the jump as the result of only temporary factors and quirks, not accelerated inflation.
The Producer Price Index for finished goods rose three-tenths of 1 percent, but economists said that it mainly reflected short-term surges in the cost of vegetables and other food as well as the effect of seasonal adjustment. 
 "I don't see anything here that's bothersome," Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., said of the report. "I don't think we've got an inflation problem."
Indeed, goods at the intermediate stage of production, like bolts of cloth, posted their first decline since late 1993 and raw materials other than food and energy fell 2.1 percent.
"Inflation fundamentals look as good as they have in 30 years," Daniel Friel, senior economic analyst at Nationsbank in Charlotte, N.C., said.
Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
A spot-check of corporate executives confirmed that the ability to raise prices had largely vanished in many industries and seemed unlikely to return anytime soon.
"We're having a very difficult time" passing along even small cost increases, said Carroll D. Curless, vice president and controller of Eagle-Picher Industries, a Cincinnati producer of industrial products. He said pressure to hold down prices was the most intense in at least two decades, especially in the automotive industry, where about 60 percent of Eagle-Picher's output is focused.
In a separate report, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta found that business activity in the Southeast ebbed a bit last month, while the number of companies getting lower prices expanded to balance those getting higher prices. The proportion of companies paying higher prices, though still a majority, shrank.
A second set of Labor Department figures today showed that first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose by 6,000, to 348,000, in the week ended Saturday, the second straight increase following a large decline for the week ended Sept. 23.
The rise in producer prices, which was the first for finished goods since May, brought the annual pace for the third quarter to nine-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in the April-June period. But excluding the erratic food and energy components, prices eased to a 2 percent pace in the July-September quarter compared with a 2.9 percent pace during each of the first two quarters of 1995.
The advance in core producer prices for September alone was two-tenths of 1 percent, the same as the average for the preceding six months. Without seasonal adjustment, core prices actually fell five-tenths of 1 percent.
Food prices climbed 1 percent last month as fresh and dry vegetables soared nearly 40 percent after dropping 13 percent in August. Prices of shortening and cooking oils and pasta turned up while declines for beef and veal slowed sharply.
Energy prices eased five-tenths of 1 percent, partly reflecting a fourth consecutive drop, 2 percent, in the price of gasoline. Prices of passenger cars rose five-tenths of 1 percent but fell 3.1 percent without applying the seasonal adjustment factor.
"The P.P.I. report is yet another sign that inflation remains under control," Merrill Lynch told clients. "We do not expect any cyclical pickup in inflation during the next 12 months and there is a possibility of some further price deceleration."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Producer Prices" tracks index of finished goods prices, seasonally adjusted, from April 1994 through September 1995. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: The Vietnamese in Germany: No Jobs, No Country

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Oct. 10

 BODY:
If there is a German version of the American dream, it begins and ends for some in Block F of a housing project at 6 Gehrenseestrasse, in what was once East Berlin.
Here, framed by the concrete symmetry of Communist-era architecture, hundreds of Vietnamese trade gossip, buy newspapers in their own language, pay high rents for mediocre housing and scout for jobs. But they also keep one eye out for the police and wait for the answer to a question that hangs over them all: Will they be among the 40,000 Vietnamese that Germany plans to deport to Vietnam over the next five years? 
 This plan for systematic expulsion of contract workers hired by the Communist Government in the former East Germany, who were never given permanent residency status, and of other Vietnamese who have immigrated illegally, was devised this year. It has been smoothed by a $140 million German aid package for Vietnam -- what some Germans are calling "head money."
It is a tangled tale of many strands and few heroes -- of cold war divisions that have worked to the advantage of organized crime.
But, most of all, the deportation, which could become the biggest of its kind in postwar Germany, exposes the central paradox of the country's attitude toward foreigners. To prevent a revival of xenophobic neo-Nazi violence, officials insist, unwanted and undocumented foreigners should be kept out of Germany. But that, in turn, means that the agenda of the far right -- summed up in its slogan, "Foreigners go home" -- is being fulfilled by a Government that says it seeks social peace and justice.
Interior Minister Manfred Kanther, a man of both tough words and strong action, says that such a policy is "the only guarantee against the abuses of uncontrollable movements of immigrants in the future and against popular discontent turning to radical political forces."
That is not how it seems in the hostels and apartment houses here that are so densely and exclusively filled with Vietnamese that some Germans call them ghettos.
"The people are afraid," said Son Vu Van, who runs a counseling service for Vietnamese at another drab housing project nearby. "They are afraid to talk. They are afraid they will be expelled."
A 33-year-old man who lives in Block F declined to be identified because he feared that publicity would draw the immigration authorities' attention to him. "Who knows who will be expelled, or why?" he said. "All we can do is wait and see. There's nothing for us in Vietnam, so no one wants to go. But it's not good here, either."
His home, he said, is a 150-square-foot room that he shares with one other person in the five-story, government-run workers' hostel where many Vietnamese have found homes. The toilets, kitchens and showers are all communal. The rent is around $370 a month -- about half his earnings from construction work, the man said.
The residents of Block F are among an estimated 100,000 Vietnamese currently in Germany, the product of decades of uneven immigration.
In the 1970's, tens of thousands of South Vietnamese -- the so-called boat people -- found willing asylum in the former West Germany, which introduced a special law to give them permanent residence rights.
After the Communist victory in Vietnam, East Germany imported some 70,000 Vietnamese as contract laborers in the 1980's, just as the West Germans imported hundreds of thousands of Turks as laborers in the 1960's.
Then came the collapse of Communism and German unification.
With too many workers and too few jobs as the newly unified state sought to implant a free-market economy in the east, the Government offered each Vietnamese contract worker a $2,000 payment and a ticket home. As many as 50,000 Vietnamese took the money and left.
But, as Europe's border restrictions began to crumble with the end of Communism, up to 20,000 more Vietnamese workers who had been brought in by other countries of Eastern Europe came here unlawfully, adding to the flow of Poles, Russians, Gypsies and others already being drawn to what Mr. Kanther, the Interior Minister, called "the magnet-like attraction of an economically strong Germany."
The response to the influx of foreigners was a violent neo-Nazi upsurge from 1990 until 1993 that persuaded the German authorities not only to crack down on the far-rightists, but also to strengthen immigration controls.
Germany's longstanding constitutional guarantees of asylum were scrapped. New legislation narrowed guarantees of asylum only to those fleeing persecution who had valid identity documents and who had not traveled through any other country to reach Germany.
A separate set of rules was adopted to cover the anomalous situation of the Vietnamese from the former East Germany. These rules offered limited residence rights for a maximum of two years, but only to those who had jobs, homes and no criminal record.
In one way, the new rules worked. In 1992, 430,000 people sought asylum in Germany. In 1994, the figure was 120,000 and of these, only 12,000 were given residence permits.
Germany's crackdown carries heavy emotional and political cargo: if Germans seem too tough on non-Germans, it inevitably evokes the country's Nazi past. German officials respond by boasting that Germany has a large number of foreigners -- some seven million in a land of 81 million people.
Mr. Kanther said in a recent published interview that Germany spends between $8 billion and $11 billion a year to enforce its immigration laws and to provide social services for people seeking residence.
"That is exemplary," he said. "For me there is not the slightest cause to suggest that German asylum laws are inhumane."
That did not stop him from ordering the expulsion last month of seven Sudanese asylum-seekers after a court dismissed their contention that they faced political persecution at home. They were sent back to Khartoum aboard a chartered Romanian plane despite the protests from the opposition Social Democrats and the German Foreign Ministry. For Mr. Kanther, the point was to prove that Germany is no easy touch for unlawful immigrants.
In the former East Germany, contract workers lived in small rooms and forfeited part of their salary to the Communist authorities in Vietnam. Then, after Communism's fall, Vietnam refused to take back the Vietnamese workers who had not availed themselves of the initial $2,000 offer.
The German authorities, however, were under pressure from German industry to normalize economic ties with Vietnam and thus to secure access to an emerging Southeast Asian market. So last January, Germany and Vietnam agreed to a deal promising aid and export guarantees if Vietnam would take back 40,000 of its own people -- the first 2,500 by the end of this year.
The agreement, which does not affect those who were granted legal asylum, went into effect last month. No one has been expelled yet because the Vietnamese authorities have not approved an initial list of 200 to be deported.
"People are very worried about their stay here," said Hang Trinh Thu, a 25-year-old woman from Hanoi who has been in Germany for six years and who works at a counseling center in Block F.
"Some of them gave up everything in Vietnam to come here. Here, they have jobs, houses, children at school. They will do everything they can to stay in Germany. In their own land, they are strangers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Vietnamese woman hanging her laundry in the hallway of a hostel at Gehrenseestrasse No. 6 in Berlin. Germany has said that 40,000 of the estimated 100,000 Vietnamese there will be deported in the next five years. (Christian Schulz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Daiwa Scandal: As Serious a Question as Barings

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
When Barings P.L.C. collapsed last spring after a trader in Singapore lost more than $1.3 billion, some regulators and financial analysts worried out loud about a possible threat to the stability of the international financial system.
There was nothing like the same level of alarm last month when the Daiwa Bank of Japan said that one of its traders in New York had lost $1.1 billion in unauthorized Treasury bond trading and managed to conceal the loss for 11 years. 
 Yet that loss now appears to have highlighted gaps in global financial supervision that are every bit as serious, if not more so. The Daiwa losses have also raised a serious question as to how well the overseers of the world's two largest economies -- the United States and Japan -- are working together to enforce these rules.
After the Barings collapse, some Western regulators privately suggested that bank oversight in Singapore might simply have been inadequate and that similar losses were unlikely in Western industrial countries. Yet the Daiwa losses occurred in an office overseen by the Federal Reserve, one of the best-regarded regulators and a leader in setting standards for the international coordination of banking rules.
The Barings collapse produced considerable relief among regulators that close international cooperation had limited the extent of the damage. Yet Japanese regulators now acknowledge that they had known for six weeks of the mammoth losses at Daiwa's office in the United States, but said nothing to American officials.
When Barings went under, regulators were able to contain the damage quickly, arranging a fast takeover of the venerable Barings and settling its transactions without losses to other financial institutions. Daiwa's losses, while fully absorbed by the parent bank in Tokyo, have only added to the current taint on the international image of Japanese banks at a time when they are already struggling with immense losses on bad loans.
And while regulators had a partial excuse in the sheer speed with which Nicholas W. Leeson, the Barings trader in Singapore, managed to accumulate his losses, the Daiwa losses were built up over 11 years. During that period, the Daiwa Bank's office in New York was repeatedly examined by a succession of Japanese and American regulators.
"The best regulator in the world, the Fed, clearly failed to unveil this problem," said Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, the Republican chairman of the House Banking Committee.
The overall effect of the losses is to underline the extent to which bank regulation still relies on the honesty, good judgment and good sense of bankers. At the same time, the most important cushion against mistakes is the bank's own capital base, which proved adequate in Daiwa's case. Regulators have required banks to increase their capital over the last several decade.
Nonetheless, the losses are a deep embarrassment for the Federal Reserve, which learned of the lack of internal controls at Daiwa three years ago but then failed to notice the losses that this deficiency produced. And the delay in disclosing the losses continues to bedevil the Japanese regulators, who appear, officials here say, to have put their loyalty to fellow nationals ahead of their duties to their international counterparts.
Many regulators and bank industry experts, although not all, say that regulators at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the New York State Department of Banking should not have been expected to spot the losses at Daiwa sooner. Regulators in the United States review whether a bank has an adequate financial cushion against losses and look at whether it has rules and procedures that will prevent risky activities that could lead to the bank's collapse. But they seldom check specific transactions for fraud, almost always leaving that responsibility to the banks' internal auditors.
Federal Reserve officials may not have done a particularly good job at detecting the fraud, said L. William Seidman, the former chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "But did they do a miserable job?" he asked. "I don't think so."
In November 1992 and again in November 1993, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned Daiwa about the mingling of trading operations with the back office processing of trades, a combination that makes it hard to detect fraud. The bank made some changes but the Fed now contends that those changes did not halt the problem. The Fed has declined to say what, if anything, it did to follow up that order with a review of whether improprieties had already taken place.
Peter Bakstansky, a spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, would only say today that "this incident is another wake-up call about the importance of internal controls and the need for constant vigilance on the part of financial institutions to protect their assets."
Still, some banking experts said the Fed should also be held to account. "They should have realized that they had to be aggressive in following up on that," said Bert Ely, a financial consultant in Alexandria, Va. "Every indication is that they had come across a serious control problem."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Make Big Gains On Reports of Japanese Buying

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Signs of resurgent Japanese demand drove copper prices up sharply on the Commodity Exchange of New York yesterday, bolstering a fledgling rally in the volatile market.
On other commodity markets, natural gas prices fell for a third consecutive session, and corn and soybeans gave up some of Wednesday's strong gains. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities slipped 0.59 point, to 240.24. 
 Copper for December delivery rose 1.95 cents, to $1.27 a pound.
Analysts cited reports that a large Japanese dealer had purchased rights to copper in warehouses registered with the London Metal Exchange. Demand from Japan, which accounts for 13 percent of world consumption, has been weak this year because of declining automobile and machinery production.
News of the Japanese purchase of the warrants surprised traders. "That was the first sign that demand has kind of turned around," said Stephen Platt of Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
Strength in the United States economy and tight near-term supplies have kept copper trading near six-year highs, but domestic demand slackened in September after prices topped $1.40 a pound. The recent drop below $1.30 has reignited demand, analysts said.
When the December copper contract neared $1.23 in trading on Wednesday, "there was very good trade buying," Bernard Savaiko, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said.
Natural gas futures tumbled for a third consecutive day on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting unseasonably warm weather and aggressive stockpiling of gas for winter. November deliveries fell 2.6 cents, to $1.735 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Natural gas producers injected 48 billion cubic feet of gas into underground storage facilities last week despite sharply reduced production from temporary shutdowns of offshore platforms that had been threatened by Hurricane Opal, the American Gas Association, a trade group, reported after the close of trading on Wednesday.
Corn and soybean prices gave back about half of the gains they posted a day earlier on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Soybeans had risen about 10 cents a bushel, and corn gained about 5 cents a bushel on Wednesday after the Agriculture Department lowered its American production estimates to reflect insect damage and an early frost in the Midwest.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Weaker Amid Doubts About Central Banks' Intentions

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was weaker yesterday as currency traders decided to test the leading central banks' commitment to a stronger dollar.
Concern that central banks would enter foreign exchange markets had kept traders cautious since the weekend. On Saturday, the Group of Seven industrialized nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy -- said they would welcome a stronger dollar and vowed to "cooperate closely" in the foreign exchange market. 
 But with little sign of central bank intervention and the dollar higher on Wednesday because of a retreat in the German mark, traders decided to test the price levels of the dollar.
"I don't hear intervention being talked about as much now," said Ian Spence, currency trader for Rabobank Nederland in New York. "As each day goes by with the absence of intervention, if and when it does happen, it will be less effective" in lifting the dollar, he said.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 100.21 yen from 101.07 yen on Wednesday. It also fell to 1.4180 marks from 1.4260 marks. But it edged up to 1.1489 Swiss francs from 1.1485 Swiss francs. The British pound rose to $1.5761 from $1.5718.
Orders from Japanese exporters to sell dollars at 101.20 to 101.30 yen drove the dollar down from its Asian high of 101.25 yen, said David Eddy, chief currency trader at Sumitomo Bank in London.
The dollar fell further against the yen than against the mark yesterday because traders were buying yen for marks. Some of those transactions are executed via the dollar, meaning traders were buying dollars for marks and selling those dollars for yen.
The mark had risen 7 percent against the yen from Sept. 1 through Tuesday, as the German economy has grown steadily while Japan's has stagnated.
"This is just a slight correction" for the mark, as it rose too far, too fast against the yen, said Jay Wertheimer, senior currency trader at Banco di Sicilia in New York.
Many traders expect the dollar to move no more than 3 percent in either direction against the mark and yen over the next three weeks. Solid economic growth in the United States will attract foreign investment, which will give the dollar a boost, they said.
Still, the mark's strength against other European currencies, particularly the French franc, will prevent the dollar from rising much, traders said.

HEADLINE: Shortchanging Inmates on Death Row

 BODY:
In their zeal to limit death penalty appeals, both houses of Congress have approved legislation that is apt to have the perverse effect of dragging out appeals and increasing their cost to the taxpayer. Worse yet, the legislation will increase the chance that innocent defendants, or defendants whose trials were constitutionally flawed, will be executed.
The bills would end $20 million in Federal funding for Post-Conviction Defender Organizations, a network of lawyers in 20 states who handle death row inmates' appeals and advise private attorneys on such cases. Unless the money is restored, death row inmates will spend additional years sitting in prison as states scramble to find lawyers to represent them in Federal court, as required by Federal law. These lawyers are likely to be less experienced, less competent and vastly more expensive than Defender Organization lawyers, who make an average of $30,000 a year. 
 The organizations were founded in the mid-1980's in response to Federal judges' concerns that states were taking years to find lawyers for inmates and that many of the lawyers did not know what they were doing. At minimal cost -- Pennsylvania has five lawyers to work with nearly 200 prisoners -- the organizations keep track of cases and prevent inmates from losing the right to a hearing simply because they had no lawyers or their lawyers missed filing deadlines. Most important, they have kept many innocent or unfairly tried people out of the electric chair.
Good appeals lawyers are important because bad trial lawyers are common. Incompetent or unprepared lawyers crop up so often that Federal judges, largely Reagan and Bush appointees, send back 40 percent of the death sentences they see.
The organizations' success is, of course, the reason death penalty advocates are so exercised. Many states have also ended their portion of Defender Organization funding and several defenders' offices have already closed. The House bill would shut them all immediately. The Senate bill would shut them as of next April 1. Both bills are part of an appropriations measure that President Clinton has threatened to veto for other reasons.
The defenders' program deserves to live. A Congress committed to the death penalty cannot in good conscience deny competent legal counsel. Abolishing the Defender Organizations harms the causes of economy, speed and justice.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Cloistered Japanese Banks

 BODY:
The recently disclosed trading loss of $1.1 billion at Daiwa Bank will not hasten the collapse of the bank itself. Nor will the losses seriously damage Japan's banking system or economy. But Japan's long delay in informing American regulators of a scandal involving the bank's New York branch has impaired the trust that was developing between the two countries on economic issues. The arrogant and clumsy way the matter was handled in Tokyo also raises doubts about the sincerity of Japan's promised effort to open up its economic system.
In other recent trading debacles, including the $1.3 billion in losses at the Singapore office of Barings P.L.C. of London, bank regulators were among the first to investigate. By contrast, the Finance Ministry in Japan appears to have closed ranks with Daiwa to minimize embarrassment and cover up the damage. 
 With Japan stagnating in its longest postwar recession, it may be understandable that the Government would not want to create a panic about its banking system. The collapse of stock and real estate prices has led to $400 billion in bad loans held by Japanese banks. Many analysts say the loss is twice as big as that. But the Government's impulse has been to let the banks hide the extent of their losses, as if public ignorance would make matters better. A Ministry official offered the remarkable suggestion yesterday that a prompt investigation would have been unseemly in light of the Government's great trust in Japanese banking executives.
American officials make no secret of their disappointment at Japan's action, especially because they have been touting the supposedly extraordinary cooperation they have achieved with their Japanese counterparts on exchange rates and trade matters. But the insular and secretive ways of the Finance Ministry have also drawn criticism in many influential quarters in Japan. A leading Japanese newspaper called the ministry an "anachronistic monster," noting that its bureaucrats havegreater say than elected officials over public works outlays and government spending.
It is up to Japan to determine how best to open up its economy to outside scrutiny. But the United States has a clear interest in Japanese banking reforms. The Daiwa Bank may have violated laws of the United States and New York State. The weakness of Japanese banks has led to higher Japanese interest rates, hampering a recovery that affects the United States as well as Japan.
The United States needs to remind Japanese leaders that the obligation to disclose is a foundation for all international dealings of financial institutions. In Japan, the Government should use the banking crisis to redouble its once promising drive to open up the economic system and make it more accountable to those who depend on it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Tunnel Dwellers Give Us No Easy Answers on Homelessness

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Homes for the Invisible" (Op- Ed, Oct. 7) by Margaret Morton, on the relocation of homeless tunnel dwellers in New York City under a Federal program set up to provide vouchers for permanent housing to people living underground:
The dilemma hinted at in Ms. Morton's bracing account merits elaboration, if only to hedge the notion that here is living proof of "solutions to homelessness." 
 Nor is the successful relocation she documented a demonstration of the economies of housing over shelter: the tunnel dwellers avoided the public shelters, after all. What we have is an object lesson in the futility of making policy through gesture.
Consider the alternative perspectives of advocates and officials.
Advocates have no choice but to welcome any addition to the housing stock for single adults and will surely labor to demonstrate that such an offer is not wasted upon those who have refused the city's grudging assistance. At the same time, they must find it troubling to target an obscure group of subterranean homeless as the object of a special set-aside of scarce housing vouchers.
When lines are long, distress is widespread and resources are slim, the logic of queue-jumping ought to have a certain face validity. Here, it seems merely the capricious chords of sympathy struck on a haphazard tour of the lower depths.
For city officials, the tunnel dwellers are a standing reproach to the public shelter system. This comes as the terms and conditions of access to the shelters are being tightened, the better to force those who have recourse elsewhere to make use of it.
Enforcement of "quality-of-life" standards in public spaces is at a postwar high. Detection of irregular accommodations rarely translates into relocation assistance.
So the lesson for city officials will be to insure that the rule of last resort continues to apply to the shelters, while disabusing those who evade the shelters of the notion that they've earned any special consideration. The message to the street-dwelling homeless? Hide better.
 
KIM HOPPER
Research Scientist, Nathan S. Kline
Institute for Psychiatric Research
Orangeburg, N.Y., Oct. 9, 1995

HEADLINE: Why Colin Powell Can't Win as Independent;
Paving the Way

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Brent Staples's "West Indian Reaganaut" (Editorial Notebook, Oct. 3) does not fully explore the nuances of that dilemma. West Indians are primarily a New York City phenomenon, where they are primarily low-level office workers, bank tellers and transit workers. They do not enjoy the nationwide visibility of black Americans or their successes.
Colin Powell's success is that of an individual who benefited from the civil rights struggles of the 1950's and 60's. Gen. Daniel (Chappie) James Jr. preceded him into the four-star ranks. 
 Black Americans have paved the way for successes by any person of color within the United States. The black American economy exceeds $400 billion a year, 100 times greater than that of all Caribbean nations and sub-Saharan Africa combined.
It is time for West Indians to criticize the system, rather than to remain quiet while others do the dirty work. Colin Powell will soon have to speak to the issues. We will then see how many whites remain colorblind to his campaign.
 
JOHN A. JONES
New York, Oct. 8, 1995

HEADLINE: At Boeing, a War Over Job Exodus

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The last time production workers at the Boeing Company went on strike, in 1989, the issue was too much work. Turning out airplanes at the rate of nearly one a day, they said they were exhausted by forced overtime and wanted some relief.
Six years later, the people who assemble airplanes for the world's leading jet manufacturer are again on strike. But this time their concern is too little work, which they say has them fighting for their very survival. 
 The biggest issue in the week-old Boeing strike, by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, stems from an announcement that the company, based here, made a few months ago. For the first time in its history, Boeing said, it will try to have a majority of its work done outside the company. By contracting out 52 percent of its work rather than the current 48 percent, management said, it can save $600 million a year.
To Boeing machinists, who earn an average of $22 an hour, that announcement was like being handed a plane ticket to oblivion.
What they now realize, they say, is that even here, in a region more dependent on foreign trade than any other in the nation, playing by the rules of a global economy can exact heavy casualties. Boeing workers are in the awkward position of rooting for free trade to bring in business that keeps the company flourishing, while bemoaning one effect of an open world economy: the lower labor costs that American companies find overseas.
"I've been with Boeing since 1966, and I've given the company my knees, my back and my heart and soul," Jon Fulwiler, 47, said as he walked a picket line in the drizzle near one of Boeing's plants in the Seattle area. "What I realize this time around is that there is no other place in America where a guy like me, without a college degree, can go to make $22 an hour."
Mr. Fulwiler was surrounded by pickets carrying signs that said, "Boeing -- Stay in the U.S.A." and "Export Planes -- Not Our Jobs."
But Boeing officials say it is impossible to export planes without sending a significant number of jobs overseas as well.
Boeing is the nation's leading exporter: 70 percent of its sales are overseas, and it manufactures 6 of every 10 airplanes bought worldwide. But when a foreign nation agrees to buy planes from Boeing, it typically does so on the condition that some of the work will be done in that country.
Beyond those contract requirements, Boeing has been trying to cut costs by having more of its work done either overseas or by nonunion contractors in the United States.
"Our customers -- airlines and governments alike -- tell us our products simply cost too much," Boeing's chairman, Frank Shrontz, and its president, Phil Condit, said in a letter to machinists before their vote to strike last week. "We need to take decisive action to control our destiny. If we don't, our competitors will control it for us."
The machinists, while concerned about Boeing's demand that they pay more of their health insurance premiums and accept a wage increase of about 3 percent in a three-year contract, say pay and benefits are not the real issues. They want the right to review work that is going outside the company and to offer an alternative bid for that work, demands that Boeing says are not feasible.
"Wages are not the issue -- we make good money," said Dave Hopkins, an 11-year employee. "But if you want to remain a world-class company, you have to retain world-class workers."
A union survey of machinists last spring showed that job security was their No. 1 concern. "Our biggest competitors are not McDonnell Douglas and the Airbus consortium of Europe," Mr. Fulwiler said. "It's workers in Mexico and Poland."
As it is, the machinists have lost a considerable number of jobs in a Boeing production cutback that resulted from hard times in the airline industry. The company now employs 105,000 people around the country, mainly in the Seattle area, down from a high of nearly 150,000 six years ago. Boeing plans to deliver 235 airplanes this year, a little more than half the 446 it delivered in 1992.
The strike has idled about one-third of the company's work force. Boeing, though slowed, expects to continue production on a limited basis by using supervisors and other employees.
Outside experts say the machinists may never be able to stem the tide of jobs flowing across the oceans.
"They're fighting a losing cause," said Prof. Charles Hill of the University of Washington School of Business. "Boeing has to get its cost structure down, because the airlines are simply not willing to pay the present price for planes."
Professor Hill said there were some things -- like making blankets and doors -- that outside contractors could do better and cheaper than can Boeing machinists. Like other experts who have studied the company, he expects production to pick up in the late 1990's, but with far fewer employees.
Boeing says it will always do the most skilled parts of its airplane assembly in the United States. Fewer than 2,000 jobs that could have been held by Boeing workers in this country have instead gone overseas, said Paul Binder, a Boeing spokesman. But the machinists' demands that such jobs stay here would ultimately put the company in decline, Mr. Binder said.
"They would rather have all the jobs for a little while," he said, "than a fair amount of jobs for infinity."
Boeing machinists say that if the company is interested in cost-cutting, it should not be giving five top executives stock options totaling nearly $6 million, as was recently announced. Boeing officials say stock options of that size are typical of compensation for leading executives of major companies.
But noting that the price of Boeing's stock had risen more than 50 percent in the last year, Connie Kelliher, a spokeswoman for the union, said: "We simply want our share. These workers helped to bring in those profits. They helped to get that stock price up."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Boeing Company says it must contract out a larger share of its work, much of it overseas, to keep the prices of its planes competitive. That is the central issue in a week-old strike by Boeing production workers, many of whom gathered outside the company's headquarters in Seattle on Wednesday for a rally where they heard from Robby Stern of the Washington State Labor Council. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: SENATE G.O.P. UNIT UNVEILS TAX PLAN; A $245 BILLION CUT

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Republican tax-writers in the Senate agreed today to a seven-year, $245 billion package of tax cuts that includes a $500 per-child tax credit for most families, significant reductions in capital gains taxes and a break for corporations.
Today's presentation of the majority's tax plan was the first step down a tortuous road for the tax bill, which has drawn nearly universal opposition from Democrats and the White House and only grudging support from some Senate Republicans. 
 The tax package must be approved by the full Finance Committee -- a formality since the Republicans hold a majority -- and then placed in a huge reconciliation bill that includes the welfare and Medicare programs among others. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said he expected the tax package to go to committee by next week and the reconciliation bill to be voted on by Oct. 24.
It is likely, nonetheless, that a bill resembling the one presented today will ultimately make its way to President Clinton, and almost equally likely that he will veto it.
Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the chairman of the Finance Committee, released only a bare-bones sketch of the tax plan today, saying that staff members were still fine-tuning some of the numbers.
But the highlight of the package is the $500-per-child credit for families, a provision that is also the centerpiece of the House's tax-cut bill. The tax credit has also become a source of wrangling by the major contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Within an hour of the Republicans reaching agreement, the two leading candidates in the 10-man Republican field -- Senator Dole and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas -- had each staked out political credit for the bill.
Whatever bill clears the Senate floor must then be reconciled with the eventual House version before being sent to President Clinton, who has threatened to veto the big package over numerous of its elements.
The House of Representatives approved a seven-year, $350 billion tax cut in April, but in negotiations with the Senate agreed to lower the target to $245 billion. The House must still wrestle with how to pare its original tax savings back to the compromise level.
Even though the bottom line is identical for both chambers, there are significant differences in their versions.
The House bill makes the $500-per-child credit available to taxpayers with adjusted gross income of up to $200,000 per family. The Senate set its caps for the credit at $75,000 a year in taxable income for a single parent and $110,000 for couples. The lower caps were meant to help rebut charges by Democrats that the Republicans' tax plans favored the well-to-do.
Mr. Gramm succeeded in turning back an effort by committee colleagues to make the credit temporary, ending it in 1999. But to make it more affordable, the Senate agreed not to make it retroactive to Jan. 1, which some members had wanted in order to put the money into taxpayers' pockets next year.
"You make it retroactive, you create a big budget problem the first year," Mr. Dole said.
Both Mr. Dole and Mr. Gramm said, however, that they supported giving the tax credit to families with higher incomes as well, but neither has publicly stated a figure.
The Senate and the House are in closer step over capital gains taxes. Each plan would allow individuals to protect from income taxes 50 percent of any profit from selling securities, real estate or other assets. That would effectively reduce the capital gains tax rate for those in the highest tax bracket to 19.8 percent, from 28 percent.
For corporations, the rate would go from 35 percent to 28 percent in the Senate plan and to 25 percent in the House version.
Both plans offer major changes in Individual Retirement Accounts, which allow savers to deduct $2,000 in contributions to such accounts.
Although the Republicans did not give full details of the changes today, they said that the bill would allow penalty-free withdrawals from I.R.A.s for first-time home purchases, major medical expenses, long-term unemployment and for college education. All taxpayers, including homemakers with no income, would be allowed to set aside $2,000 in an I.R.A.
The Senate plan also would phase out certain corporate tax breaks, like the credit that some pharmaceutical manufacturers receive in Puerto Rico and other United States territories. But to offset that tax bite, the Republicans would extend other corporate tax breaks for research and development and the creation of drugs to treat rare diseases.
The Senate agreement came after two days of closed-door negotiations among the 11 Republican members of the tax-writing Finance Committee. Democrats, who hold nine seats on the committee, refused to participate, saying that whatever the outcome they would probably oppose the package.
In a televised interview nearly two weeks ago, Mr. Dole had cast doubt on whether the Senate would support the entire $245 billion tax cut. The majority leader said that even some of the most conservative Republicans were worried about the wisdom of giving such a large tax cut at a time when Congress was trying to balance the budget by 2002.
But Mr. Dole backpedaled from that position under a withering attack from Mr. Gramm and other Republican Presidential rivals.
By the time the Senate Republicans finally sat down to work out a tax plan this week, the fight had shifted to another front.
"What the battle was over here was temporary versus permanent," Mr. Gramm said. "That's where the basic struggle has been in the last few days."
Mr. Gramm, the newest member of the committee, led a group of hard-line conservatives who threatened to oppose any deal that did not include permanent tax cuts and a bottom line of $245 billion.
The Texas Senator's threat was more than just political bluster. With the 11-to-9 party split on the Finance Committee, a single Republican defection would create a tie vote and a defeat of the legislation in committee.
