HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Under the Exquisite Spell of Japanese Screens

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
JAPANESE SCREENS, WITH THEIR striking images of flowers, landscapes, battles and folk tales, are back in the spotlight in America. They're being avidly collected, they're on view in major exhibitions, and, after some softening in the early 90's, the market for them shows signs of rebounding.
On Wednesday, the most important show of such works ever held in New York, "Worlds Seen and Imagined: Japanese Screens From the Idemitsu Museum of Arts," opens at the Asia Society, where it will run through December. In addition, seven screens, collected at the turn of the century by Frank Lloyd Wright, are part of an exhibition of his Japanese art at the Los Angeles County Art Museum. 
 Surprisingly, some of the 57 examples in the Asia Society exhibition were actually bought in New York in the last decade, when prices for the best Japanese screens escalated sharply at the auction houses, going from less than $100,000 to $1.8 million. Such prices were also seen at galleries as Manhattan became the dominant outpost in the West for the sale of Japanese screens. Meanwhile, in Tokyo, the Idemitsu Museum paid $3 million to $6 million for screens on several occasions.
But there were bargains too. In 1986, the museum, run by the Idemitsu petrochemical company, acquired a pair of 19th-century screens by Suzuki Kiitsu that had cost $17,600 at Christie's in New York. "I'm sure the pair is now worth more than $1 million," said Sebastian Izzard, who heads Japanese art sales at Christie's.
Leighton Longhi, a prominent dealer in New York, regrets missing out on those gloriously patterned floral screens. "That's the pair that got away," he said.
In 1988, a year after the market for Impressionist paintings took off, fueled in part by Japanese buying at auction, prices for screens finally reached six figures. That year, a Japanese dealer paid $473,000 at Sotheby's for a pair of 16th-century screens. Then, in 1991, a pair of gold-leafed screens from the 19th century were auctioned at Christie's for $440,000, more than three times what the set had sold for in 1985.
Americans began their on-again, off-again love affair with Japanese screens in the 1880's, when collectors -- most often on trips to Japan -- became mesmerized by them as exotica. The screens, of painted paper or silk, summoned up ravishing images of samurais, emperors and dancing girls in this land of fragile teacups and towering mountains. The first wave of buying eventually enriched many museums. Henry O. Havemeyer, the sugar magnate, and his wife, Louisine, gave their screens to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Charles Lang Freer, a Detroit industrialist, sent his to the Freer Gallery of Art in Washington. Boston's two exceptional collections remained in the city: Isabella Stewart Gardner left her screens to the museum that bears her name, and William Sturgis Bigelow donated his to the Museum of Fine Arts.
After a lull during World War II, Americans resumed buying screens in Japan in the 1950's and 60's. John D. Rockefeller 3d acquired several and gave them to the Asia Society. But John W. Gruber, a New York accountant, took the auction route and rocked the market in 1990 when he sold an extraordinary 17th-century pair, depicting Kyoto street scenes, for $1.8 million at Christie's. The buyer was an unidentified Japanese museum.
Today's dedicated collectors, Mr. Longhi said, vie with American and Japanese museums for screens by famous artists. Among the top-ranking collectors who have been buying for 30 years or more are Joe D. Price, an oil heir from Oklahoma City; Mary Griggs Burke of New York, whose family was in lumber and railroading; and John Powers, a former book publisher, of Carbondale, Colo. Mr. Longhi said that at least 10 other collectors had spent several hundred thousand dollars each for one or more pairs of screens.
But the global recession in the 90's has taken its toll on medium-priced screens, costing less than $100,000. They had sold well in the 80's, but "sales are very spotty right now," Mr. Longhi said.
When it comes to the finest screens, however, even at public sales, buyers are paying large sums. "When we get the right things, we are able to sell them for strong prices," Mr. Izzard said. In 1991, Christie's sold a 16th-century pair of landscapes with monkeys for $572,000. These are now owned by the Metropolitan Museum. Last year, for $662,500, Christie's auctioned a 17th-century screen depicting a Portuguese sailing ship. Mr. Longhi bought it and sold it to the Peabody and Essex Museum in Salem, Mass. Also in 1994, Sotheby's in London auctioned a 17th-century screen, depicting six dancers, for $1.6 million, a record for a single screen.
Mr. Izzard said he was optimistic that buying would increase again, especially in America. "Screens were always much more popular here than in Europe," he said. "They work better in modern architecture than in period rooms. And screens are very large and very decorative. With a screen 5 feet high and 12 feet long, you get a lot of bang for your buck."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Air Traffic System Feeds Flight Delays in Europe

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
ALITALIA flight 3901 from Venice to Rome left 40 minutes late one sunny September day, and the pilot's excuse was one passengers heard a lot this summer on intra-European routes.
"There's just a lot of congestion in the sky," he said. 
 In fact, Alitalia was hobbled this summer by an Italian air traffic controllers' strike. But this particular flight was not among those affected, and even disregarding strikes, clogged skies sharply increased flight delays this year. This rekindled an old debate between European airlines and governments about why, every couple of years, there is an surge in delays.
From April to June, according to the 25-member Association of European Airlines, 17 percent of aircraft takeoffs were late (defined as more than 15 minutes after scheduled time), compared with 12 percent in the same period last year. In June, almost 20 percent of flights left late, the worst figure in three years.
The association's secretary general, Karl-
Heinz Neumeister, ascribed the delays to the slow pace of improvements in Europe's splintered system of air traffic control. While some delays were caused by weather or crowded airports, he said, almost two-thirds were caused by poor air traffic control.
According to a 1992 study by the association, Western Europe had 54 air traffic control centers, compared with 20 in the United States. The European centers used 31 different computerized systems made by 18 manufacturers. The airlines estimate that the excess time planes spend circling in the air or parked on runways increases the cost of their operations by about $5 billion a year. Since those costs are passed on to the customer, travelers pay an average 8 percent more per ticket, the airlines say.
The airlines are quick to point out that the situation poses no risk to travelers' safety. But that is simply because air traffic controllers limit the number of planes in the air to allow for the network's shortcomings.
At the heart of the airlines' complaint is the argument that national governments in Europe are obsessed with local sovereignty, refusing to surrender control of the skies over national territories to any supranational authority. Their association supports a plan put forward in the early 1990's by the European Civil Aviation Conference, which includes transport ministers from 33 countries, to reduce the number of control centers and to introduce the latest satellite systems. But with so many fingers in the pie, the pace of change is painfully slow.
Mr. Neumeister points to delays in implementing two key features aimed at increasing flight capacity, one called area navigation, which essentially allows aircraft to move about freely under computer control rather than within the confines of fixed flight paths, and another that will gradually reduce the height of vertical air corridors, allowing aircraft to cross over and under each other at closer intervals. The measures were supposed to be in place by the end of the decade. Both, he says, are hopelessly late.
These assertions meet harsh criticism from the Aviation Conference. Klaus Ludeloff, a spokesman for Eurocontrol, the Brussels-based organization that the conference has designated to implement change, says that in Brussels the first of a series of central flow management units, designed to replace local control centers, is functioning, and a second is planned in Frankfurt in the next year or two. Radar coverage has been improved by reducing 18 national centers to only 8.
Recently, Mr. Ludeloff said all 33 conference members committed themselves in writing to unified traffic control measures. This, of course, is no guarantee that they will live up to their commitments on time. "We are talking," he added, with a tinge of resignation, "about 33 independent states."
Not all the airlines attribute the delays to poor traffic control. Allan Solloway, a spokesman in London for British Airways, which calls itself the "On-Time Airline" but had 48 percent of its flights leave late this summer, depicted traffic control as "manageable." An Alitalia spokeswoman, Maria Bergamin, said increased traffic flow as a result of the end of Europe's long recession may also have slowed departures. Michael Lamberty, a Lufthansa spokesman in Frankfurt, emphasized airport congestion on the ground, caused by insufficient capacity at many airports and by planes lined up waiting to take off.
And not much advice is forthcoming to travelers who want to avoid the delays. They can, of course, shun peak seasons and try to skirt heavily trafficked routes like Paris to London. Or the best advice may be to test alternative modes. Travelers between Paris and London, for example, can take the Eurostar Chunnel train.

Practice, Practice, Practice
 Q. My husband, a serious amateur pianist, and I are planning a trip to Europe. Our itinerary will include London, Paris and Edinburgh. Is there anywhere in those cities he can practice while we are away? -- Patricia Green, New York, N.Y. 
 A. There are a few places that should fit the bill.
In London, the Royal Academy of Music has its hands full with students in the daytime but says evenings and Sundays are available for practice. Two studios are available, one with a grand piano at $18.60 an hour and the other with an upright at $15.50 an hour, calculated at $1.55 to the pound. The academy is at 34 Marylebone Road, London NW1 5HT; telephone (44 171) 873 7373, fax (44 171) 873 7374. Nearest Underground station: Baker Street.
Wigmore Hall has two rehearsal rooms available Monday to Friday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. at $12.40 an hour. The hall is at 36 Wigmore Street, London W1H 0BP; (44 171) 935 2141, fax (44 171) 224 3800. Nearest Underground: Bond Street.
Fazioli Studios has rooms available Monday to Friday from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. Saturday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday by appointment. Rates are $11.60 for a grand and $13.20 an hour for an upright. The studios are at 29 Marylebone Lane, London W1M 5FH; (44 171) 486 0025, fax (44 171) 935 8454. Nearest Underground: Bond Street.
In Edinburgh, Varsity Music has a practice room available Monday to Saturday from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. for $4.65 an hour. Alternatively it will deliver a piano to your hotel room (with the hotel's permission) at a cost of $232.50 a week. The studio, which is a half mile from the main railway station on the A7 road opposite the Festival Theater, is at 8A-10A Nicolson Street, Edinburgh EH8 9DH; phone and fax (44 131) 556 3273. Ask for Seph Turner.
In Paris the Salle Pleyel has rooms available for $10.50 an hour once the daily students have finished their work. The hall is at 252 Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore, Paris 8; (33 1) 45.61.53.00, fax (33 1) 45.61.46.87. Nearest Metro: Ternes.

Pianos Hamm has practice rooms available Monday to Saturday from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. at $9 an hour for a grand and $7 for an upright. Hamm is at 135 Rue de Rennes, Paris 6; (33 1) 44.39.35.35, fax (33 1) 44.39.35.50. Nearest Metro: St.-Placide.

Vietnam's Tet Holiday
 Q. We plan to visit Vietnam as independent travelers next February. When is Tet, the lunar new year, and is it a good time or a bad time to be there? -- J. Tuttle, Orinda, Calif.
A. The Tet celebrations will be held from Feb. 18 to 20, and if joyous but noisy celebrations, with lots of fireworks and milling crowds, are what you have in mind then you are headed for the right place.
Many regular public activities will come to a halt as people take off from work to spend time with families and friends. Many others will be visiting Buddhist pagodas and churches and other public places. New Year's Eve, Feb. 18, is the night for joining the crowds on the streets.
If you haven't booked a hotel room by now, particularly in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, you might have left it too late. The Tet holiday brings thousands of people to those two cities, including Vietnamese from overseas.
And be sure your airline reservations have been made. Because of the large number of visiting Vietnamese, getting in and getting out can be a problem at Tet time.
 
 
The Train in Spain
 Q. I am planning to visit Spain this fall and want to travel by overnight train from Barcelona to Madrid. I would like to reserve sleeping-car accommodations for the journey and don't want to wait till arriving to make them. Can I can do that from the United States? -- Lawrence M. Quigley, Fair Haven, N.J.
A. Tickets and sleeping car reservations for that train can be obtained from Rail Europe, a marketing group that represents rail travel in virtually all of Continental western Europe, and big cities in eastern Europe.
This fall, from Sept. 24 to Dec. 3, the overnight train runs Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. It leaves Barcelona Sants station at 11 P.M., arriving at Madrid Chamartin at 8 A.M. the next day.
The one-way fare is $62 in first class and $41 in second.
The sleeping accommodation is provided in second-class couchettes (seats that convert to beds; bedding is provided) for $24 a person; second-class sleepers for four people at $42 a person; first-class single sleepers at $94 and first-class double sleepers at $58 a person. Prices do not include a $10 handling fee.
The train is the No. 1373. More information: Rail Europe, (800) 438-7245 or (800) 848-7245, fax (800) 432-1329. TERENCE NEILAN

HEADLINE: A School's Pride Suffers a Blow

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
HADDAM and Killingworth -- nestled in Middlesex County, between Long Island Sound and Middletown -- could well have inspired Norman Rockwell paintings, those that capture the essence of small-town New England. Although many of their residents commute to jobs in Middletown, Hartford and New Haven, the towns are far more close-knit than bedroom communities elsewhere. In the two communities people share a pride in the area's rustic charm and its respected regional school system, including Haddam-Killingworth High School, where the girls' field hockey team won a the state championship last year.
But that pride has suffered a severe blow since last month, when 25 of the 32 members of that field hockey team admitted shoplifting about $600 worth of merchandise from two stores while on Nantucket for a preseason scrimmage. 
 No charges were filed by the two stores, and, indeed, the Nantucket Police Chief, Randolph Norris said his department did not become aware of the incident until it began to receive calls from reporters. By then, the 25 team members, had confessed and had been suspended from school for two days.
Chief Norris said in an interview that since the stores -- which have not been identified -- elected not to press charges, his department did not see fit to get involved.
"Shoplifting is a misdemeanor, with the first such offense punishable with a fine of up to $250," he said. "And in such a situation, there's no point in us making arrests, since the matter was settled privately. And we understand that the girls made restitution." That they did, but only after the high school principal, Dr. Richard Carmelich, summoned members of the team and their parents to separate meetings in his office on Sept. 12, two days after the team returned from the weekend trip to Nantucket. Dr. Carmelich did so after the coach, Patricia Kamercia, who is a teacher at the school, informed him that the coach of the Nantucket High School field hockey team had telephoned and told her of the shoplifting accusations. Dr. Carmelich said that the girls admitted their guilt during a meeting with Ms. Kamercia on Sept. 11. At his meetings with the players and their parents, Dr. Carmelich said, he demanded that restitution be made for the stolen items, which included dresses, sweaters, costume jewelry and some other merchandise. "We were all very upset and saddened by the incident, and we think we addressed it forcefully," Dr. Carmelich said in an interview. "In addition, the parents have taken measures on their own. The girls were very forthcoming and showed remorse and realized the error of their ways."
But many townspeople in both Haddam, site of the Region 17 high school, a town of about 6,750 about 15 miles northeast of New Haven, and in Killingworth, a community of 5,000 that straddles the Connecticut River, said that the punishment was much too lenient, and that, in effect, the girls got away with stealing.
"I, like a lot of others, think they got off too easily," said the Haddam Town Clerk, Ann Huffstetler. "Why didn't they prosecute?"
Another Haddam resident, Daniel Clifford, said: "I think the girls involved should be required to do some sort of community service. After all, the incident did affect the entire community." Mr. Clifford's daughter, not a member of the hockey team, is a junior at the high school, which has a swimming pool, a television studio and amenities that other schools might envy.
Jane Carlson, an owner of the Country Market in the Higgenum section of Haddam, which includes the main shopping district and the high school, said, "A lot of people are embarrassed" by the incident. "The matter was dismissed too lightly," she said. "It also wasn't fair to the girls on the team who didn't shoplift, because a lot of people don't know who the guilty ones are. There should have been more punishment."
A year ago, the Haddam-Killingworth field hockey team was the pride of the area after winning the Class C (small school) state championship. After that accomplishment, members of the team wore their jackets, emblazoned with the school's name, proudly. But now, fearful of being taunted, some of the players have left their team jackets at home.
On the field, members of the team, which plays in the Shore Line Conference, have not encountered any taunting from opponents, said the Haddam-Killingworth High School athletic director, Jeff Talbot. "I think the other players have some empathy for our kids on the field hockey team," he said.
The shoplifting incident was the latest in a series of unpleasant events that have caused concern in the Haddam-Killingworth area, where median incomes are around $50,000, well above the state average, and where the education system benefits from tax payments from a nuclear power plant in the village of East Haddam, across the Connecticut River but a part of the town of Haddam.
In August 1994, 15 school buses that serve Region 17, which includes five schools in the two towns, were set afire and destroyed. Three young men who had recently graduated from the high school and are now attending college were arrested and are facing charges. And in recent years, the number of arrests among teen-agers on drug charges has risen to the point where several organizations have been established to try to address the problem.
The last five years have seen bitter battles over the Region 17 school budget. In 1991, for instance, it took nine referendums before voters in the two towns approved the budget. And so far this year, residents have turned down eight budget proposals. The most recent budget rejection was last Tuesday.
"I think the stress and tension over economic insecurity in the area, along with the budget and some other matters, carries down to the kids," said the Rev. Ed Cornell, the pastor of the Congregational Church in Killingworth. "I don't condone the shoplifting, but I think some of these issues affect the adolescents in a negative way. We have to find ways to let the young people let off steam in a healthy way."
Some people believe that the shoplifting incident, while embarrassing to the players, the school and to the towns, was an aberration. "These are good kids who've never been in trouble before," said Dr. Carmelich. "What they did was totally out of character and hard to explain."
He said the results of the experience were both negative and positive. "The negative impact was that both the innocent and the guilty have been treated badly by some adults," the principal said. "The positives are that the kids are glad that they got caught and that they've learned from it, although it's not the way we like them to be taught. Other kids in the school also have learned from the experience. And the matter has actually drawn the student body closer together."
Why did 25 teammates inexplicably go on a shoplifting binge?
"I think a couple of them decided to take a risk, and that the others, who would never have initiated it on their own, decided to follow the leaders," said the chairman of the Region 17 school board, Robert Norton. "And they've all learned an immense and painful lesson."
Both Dr. Carmelich and Mr. Norton pointed out that the high school, which has 520 students, had an excellent academic reputation. Approximately 90 per cent of the students go on to higher education, the principal said. He noted that the students' scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test were consistently higher than the state and national averages. "This year, for example, the combined average score at our school was 977, compared with 908 for the rest of the state and 910 nationally," he said. "As I say, we have a terrific group of kids."
Mr. Cornell said that most townspeople are willing to look past the students' actions. "Our job is not to point fingers but to forgive them and let them know that God loves them," said Mr. Cornell, who devoted his sermon to the parable of the lost sheep on the Sunday after the incident became public.
The president of the Haddam-Killingworth High School Student Government, Molly Danaher, said she thought it was time for the towns to put the entire matter behind them.
"The kids involved are good kids, but what they did was stupid, and they know it," she said. "I guess it's just part of growing up."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Home Equity Loans

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
IN case you haven't heard, the answer to all your financial woes -- not to mention some extra cash for a new car, a Caribbean vacation or your child's college tuition -- could be tucked away in the brick, mortar and wood you call your home.
Home equity loans (formerly called second mortgages) have become the debt of choice for borrowers and lenders alike. 
 Since 1986 -- when Congress eliminated tax deductions for interest on nearly all consumer debt other than home mortgages -- homeowners have been blitzed by lenders eager to lend large sums of money over long periods of time as quickly, easily and painlessly as possible. Consumers responded with a passion, converting billions of dollars of high-interest, nondeductible, credit-card debt into lower-interest, tax-deductible, home equity loan debt.
But as useful and economically appealing as such loans may be when used judiciously, experts say that caution and restraint must be exercised for borrowers to avoid ending up worse off financially then they were when they started. "I think it's scary," said Larry D. Powers, president of Consumer Loan Advocates, a Lake Bluff, Ill., credit counseling company. "The debt that people are absorbing nowadays is astounding."
Just a generation or two ago, Mr. Powers said, homeowners who needed a new washer and dryer would save until they had enough money to pay cash. "But now," he said, "home equity loans are so easy to get that people who need a new washer and dryer say, 'Hey, let's take out a home equity loan and throw in a new refrigerator too.' "
Indeed, he said, while lenders used to insist that home equity loans be used only to increase the value of the home itself, they now encourage borrowers to use such loans for everything from debt consolidation to college tuition. And that, experts say, is how some borrowers can get into trouble.
"Home equity loans are seen as the most wonderful invention on earth," said Dan Lieberman, president of Mirada Home Strategies, a consumer organization in Oakland, Calif. "But because of that attitude, people have a tendency to get sloppy with them." For example, Mr. Lieberman said, using a home equity loan to buy a new car initially appears attractive because the deductibility of the interest on the equity loan effectively lowers the interest rate being paid. And since home equity loans are typically repaid over longer periods of time than auto loans, the monthly payments end up lower than a four-year car loan.
But there's a catch.
"If you took a $20,000 car loan at 10 percent interest for four years, that car is going to cost you about $24,000," said Mr. Lieberman, whose company publishes a booklet detailing the fine points of home equity borrowing. But buying the same car using a 20-year home equity loan at the same interest rate, he said, would end up costing the borrower about $46,320. After the tax deduction for someone in the 28 percent bracket, the cost would be about $39,000. If that isn't frustrating enough, Mr. Lieberman said, imagine how it would feel to still be paying for that car 20 years from now.
Things get even dicier when home equity loans are used to consolidate consumer debt, even though credit-card interest rates are usually higher. "People think they're saving a huge amount of money by consolidating their credit-card debt," Mr. Lieberman said. "But unless they're paying the same total monthly amount as they were before, they're doing themselves a disservice." Again, said Mr. Lieberman, the minimum payments required under a home equity loan's extended repayment schedule could eventually eliminate any savings realized by paying off existing credit cards with the loan, even with the tax deduction.
And then there is the question of what happens when the borrower receives that first "zero balance" credit card statement in the mail. "If you can control your spending, you shouldn't have a problem," Mr. Lieberman said, adding that generally, those who can control their spending probably wouldn't need a home equity loan to consolidate their debts in the first place.
Equity lines of credit can create even more problems for undisciplined borrowers. Unlike home equity loans, which are usually fixed-interest-rate loans for a fixed period of time, equity lines of credit are typically variable-rate and open-ended.
The advantage of such loans, Mr. Lieberman said, is that money is always available and interest is charged only on money borrowed. "The problem is that people treat them like giant credit cards and go out on spending sprees," he said. "You end up spending five years paying off a two-week vacation."
Fritz Elmendorf, a spokesman for the Consumer Bankers Association, a banking industry trade association in Washington, described home equity loans and lines of credit in more glowing terms. "It's the only credit product -- outside of the first mortgage -- that a household needs," he said. "You can use it to buy a car or put the kids through college or put an addition on the house."
Indeed, most experts agree that home equity borrowing -- with its Internal Revenue Service imprimatur, relatively low interest rate and long repayment schedule -- makes sense for homeowners who need the cash stored as equity in their homes. Still, Mr. Elmendorf noted, restraint is essential for using home equity loans wisely and effectively. "It's simply a matter of not using the availability of credit to make purchases that would otherwise be unaffordable or not prudent," he said.
Robert Hobbs, deputy director of the National Consumer Law Center in Boston, said that whatever the reason for securing a loan or line of credit, borrowers should be wary of deals that appear too good to be true.
"People should be careful about teaser rates," Mr. Hobbs said, explaining that equity lines of credit are sometimes advertised with very low initial interest rates that subsequently skyrocket.
David Ginsburg, president of Loantech, a mortgage auditing company in Gaithersburg, Md., said that borrowers should "check the fine print" to see how the interest rate on a variable-rate loan is determined. Typically, he said, lenders use a widely available index -- such as the prime rate -- in conjunction with another figure, known as the margin, to calculate interest rate changes.
"The margin is a fixed amount that's added to the index to calculate the customer's interest rate," he said. "So the smaller the margin, the better for the consumer."
Mr. Ginsburg also noted that many borrowers seem to be unaware of a basic fact of life regarding home equity loans and lines of credit. "A lot of consumers still do not realize that an equity line of credit is basically a credit card secured by your home," he said. "And if you don't make your payments, the worst-case scenario is not pretty. Because if you don't pay the loan, you could lose your home."
In short, a home equity loan should be treated like fine wine: sipped slowly and savored, it can be a rewarding experience. But overindulge, and even the best wine leaves you with a heck of a hangover.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Revenue Stamps On Deeds
Q. When I purchased my house in 1963, United States revenue stamps were affixed to the deed. What are these stamps and are they still necessary? . . . Ellery H. Fancher, the Bronx. 
 A. Robert Jacobs, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that the stamps signify payment of a Federal tax that was imposed on the transfer of real estate at the time. The stamps were issued by the Federal government, Mr. Jacobs said, and were affixed to deeds as evidence of payment. Without such proof of payment, he said, the deed could not be recorded.
"Generally, it is the seller who pays the transfer tax," Mr. Jacobs said, explaining that when stamps were used to prove payment of the Federal transfer tax, the seller would usually write a check for the tax at the time of sale and give that check to the buyer's title company. The title company would then purchase the stamps from the Federal government, affix the stamps to the deed, and record the deed at the appropriate recorder's office.
The use of Federal tax stamps ended in 1968, said William Colavito, a Manhattan lawyer who is chairman of the Real Property Section of the New York State Bar Association.
Shortly after the Federal law expired, Mr. Colavito said, New York State enacted a state transfer tax law that imposed a tax upon most deeds at the rate of 55 cents for each $500 of consideration paid. The law was later amended to increase the rate to $2 for every $500 of consideration and remains in effect today.
As with the Federal tax law, proof of payment of the state taxes must still be provided before a deed can be recorded. "At this point, payment of the tax is indicated by a rubber stamp," said Mr. Jacobs. "That's why they don't use those interesting stamps anymore."
 
Adjusting Rent For Fuel Costs
 Q. Isn't a rent-controlled tenant required to pay a monthly fuel pass-through charge on top of his or her rent? . . . Julius Levy, Manhattan.
 A. According to an information fact sheet provided by the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, a 1980 amendment to the Rent Control Law permits rent adjustments based on the changes, up or down, in the price of various types of heating fuels.
The annual rent adjustment is based on fuel price changes between the beginning and end of the prior year. Generally, 75 percent of the annual change in fuel cost is passed along to tenants on a per-room basis. If annual fuel costs decrease, and the owner fails to report the decrease to the agency and reduce rents accordingly, then all previous increases received will be suspended for a year.
Only tenants in rent-controlled apartments in New York City are subject to such fuel-cost adjustments.
To obtain a fuel-cost adjustment, a property owner must certify that he or she is maintaining essential services in the building and must serve upon each tenant a copy of the state agency's official "Owner's Report, Certification, and Notice of Fuel Cost Adjustment Eligibility." Owners must also file a copy of the report with the agency, together with a schedule of monthly rent increases for all the rent-controlled tenants subject to the adjustment.
If a tenant believes that the owner's request for the fuel-cost rent increase is inaccurate or unjustified, the tenant can challenge it by filing a special form with the agency within 30 days of receipt of notice of the increase. The appropriate form (RAC-2202.13) can be obtained by calling the agency's Rent InfoLine at (718) 739-6400.

HEADLINE: Bringing Downtown Back Up

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
FOR the last 40 years, whenever lower Manhattan needed a shot in the arm, it came in the form of enormous new projects, each larger than the one before: Chase Manhattan Plaza in the 1950's, the World Trade Center in the 70's, Battery Park City in the 80's.
The approach in the 90's may be radically different, one that seeks to exploit the buildings that are already there. The administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been moving on a number of fronts to encourage residential and commercial reuse: tax breaks, zoning changes and landmark designations. 
 Although construction began last month on the New York Mercantile Exchange at Battery Park City, no one expects many more groundbreakings downtown in the near future. A truer sign of the times is the Rudin family's effort to resuscitate 55 Broad Street, an empty 28-year-old tower, as the New York Information Technology Center.
Whether visionary or delusional, the possibility is also being explored of converting some distinguished but obsolete office towers into apartment buildings; cliff dwellings and aeries that would appeal to the same pioneering spirit that colonized SoHo and TriBeCa.
Which buildings? Probably those with smaller floors, which have proportionally more windows and exposures, meaning that daylight can reach more of the interior. Elevation is another factor. Even the hardiest trail-blazer is not likely to move downtown simply to live near the bottom of a dark canyon.
Taking these attributes as a guide, the Environmental Simulation Center of the New School for Social Research pinpointed on its computer model of lower Manhattan every floor 180 feet or more above sea level (typically, about 15 stories above the street), with 8,000 square feet of space or less. The results are shown above in red.
One building that stands out in this view is 40 Wall Street, on which Donald J. Trump holds a purchase option, with the view of turning it into a mixed-use building. But Mr. Trump and other prospective players downtown have been waiting for the State Legislature to act on a package of tax benefits proposed by the Giuliani administration to encourage residential conversion and commercial renovation. The bill was passed in the Assembly June 28 but was not approved by the Senate until Thursday afternoon, by a vote of 53 to 1. Senator Franz S. Leichter, Democrat of Manhattan, cast the only no vote.
"There are developers waiting in the wings for passage of the legislation," said Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, who heads the Lower Manhattan Task Force, together with Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson. "When you look at what the Rudins have already committed to at 55 Broad Street, that's exactly the kind of investment we wanted. I think we're going to quickly see some older buildings take advantage of the benefits to do residential conversions."
The incentive package accompanies a series of zoning changes that the City Planning Commission approved Tuesday, Sept. 19, a day that may prove to have been particularly fateful for lower Manhattan. Also that day, the Landmarks Preservation Commission made the first of a new round of designations downtown and ground -- or at least landfill -- was broken for the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The exchange building, at Battery Park City, will be 15 stories high, with two 25,000-square-foot trading floors. The structure, designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, is to be completed in 1997 as part of the World Financial Center. The Mercantile Exchange merged with the Commodity Exchange last year and is now composed of two divisions, known as Nymex and Comex. Officials estimated that the project would keep more than 8,000 jobs in New York.
The retention of an additional 5,000 or so jobs seemed all but guaranteed Thursday when the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange said it would remain in lower Manhattan rather than move to Jersey City, after New York officials offered a $91 million incentive package. The New York Cotton Exchange is to vote Tuesday on whether to reconsider its planned move in light of the decision by the Coffee exchange.
Even as they play high-stakes retention games with New Jersey, city officials acknowledge that downtown will need to do more to survive than simply hold on to its reputation as a financial service center. They say it will have to grow into what planners are fond of calling a "24-hour" community: with residents, restaurants, stores, maybe even a movie theater.
"The traditional character of the area isn't what business wants today," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission. "The good thing is that you have an immense amount to build on."
TO encourage residential conversion, a 14-year abatement is being offered on property taxes for office buildings that are turned into apartment buildings, beginning the year that a temporary certificate of occupancy is issued for the new use. The abatement is 100 percent for 10 years and then declines by increments of 20 percent over the remaining years.
In addition, a 12-year exemption is being offered from the increase in taxes that an owner would owe due to the higher assessed value of the building. The exemption would be 100 percent in the first eight years and then decline by increments of 20 percent over the following four years.
The zoning changes would relax restrictions on joint living and working spaces, make it easier to convert the very high density office towers that were built before the 1961 Zoning Resolution and allow parking to be provided in converted buildings.
"We've taken away all the regulatory impediments to adaptive reuse of these buildings," Mr. Rose said. "There's a market moment and we're very intent on not letting that moment go by."
"It's a very aggressive program," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, which manages the Lower Manhattan Business Improvement District. "The city estimates that it would produce 200 or 300 units a year. My guess is that it would be higher. People are waiting for the starting gun. Even 2,000 units will significantly change the look and feel of downtown.
"Downtown has fabulous space, spectacular views and universal access to the waterfront," he said. "It will provide a place where middle-class and upper middle-class people can live and walk to work."
But State Senator Leichter, who has questioned governmental incentives over the years, took a skeptical view of the Giuliani plan. "Government is not justified in spending money to support the creation of what is essentially luxury housing," he said.
"What economic justification is there in supporting Donald Trump's conversion of 40 Wall Street?" Mr. Leichter asked. "Is that going to bring back Wall Street and create a lot of jobs in lower Manhattan? I wonder whether we're like King Canute, telling the tide not to come in."
The downtown residential market commands rents of roughly $25 to $30 a square foot annually, or $2,100 to $2,500 monthly for a 1,000-square-foot unit. These rents are about 10 to 20 percent less than in TriBeCa and SoHo. "Without the benefits, you couldn't renovate these buildings and make them come into what the market will bear," said Ann Weisbrod, vice president for economic development at the Alliance (and no relation to Carl Weisbrod).
Residential conversion is not the only goal. To encourage commercial renovation of older buildings, a five-year abatement of existing property taxes and commercial rent taxes will be granted on space that is either newly leased or re-leased. These savings, which would be retroactive to April 1, are to be passed on to tenants. They would apply to buildings constructed before 1975.
The programs could reduce commercial occupancy costs in lower Manhattan by an average of roughly $5 a square foot a year, bringing it down to around $25 a square foot, which is competitive with new space in northern New Jersey, said Connie Fishman, director of planning and development for Deputy Mayor Reiter.
Property taxes would be cut by 50 percent for the first three years of the abatement, but the abatement cannot exceed $2.50 a square foot. The abatement would decline by one-third in the fourth year and two-thirds in the fifth year. There would be a 100 percent exemption from commercial rent taxes in the first three years. The exemption would then decline.
Among the conditions are that large tenants -- more than 50 employees -- must sign leases running at least 10 years. Smaller tenants must sign leases running at least 5 years. Tenants that are relocating must either come from Manhattan, south of 96th Street, or from outside New York City.
If a tenant is renewing, the landlord must invest at least $10 a square foot in improving tenant space or common areas. For newly leased space, the landlord must invest at least $35 a square foot.
In this category is the New York Information Technology Center, a 31-story office tower at the corner of Beaver Street with 400,000 square feet of empty space. The structure is being renovated for information and telecommunication companies, offering data transmission capabilities and rents beginning around $15 a square foot. It is to open next month.
"We're going to be the first project on line and taking advantage of the Mayor's plan almost immediately," said William C. Rudin, president of Rudin Management, which took a calculated gamble and began the renovation before the Legislature acted.
MR. RUDIN said four tenants had been signed for 25,000 square feet, with deals pending for another 150,000 square feet. "The leasing activity has gone beyond our expectations," he said.
"We're looking at our building as a prototype," Mr. Rudin said. "We're hoping this spreads beyond our building and becomes a district. You're going to have the energy of these young software entrepreneurs working around the clock."
Two blocks away is 40 Wall Street, the leasehold of which Mr. Trump intends to purchase. One possibility is a $100 million renovation of the 66-story skyscraper, built in 1929 as the Bank of the Manhattan Company headquarters, into a mixed-use building, with 160 apartments in the tower portion. The building is topped by a pyramidal copper peak that has long been one of the unofficial landmarks of downtown.
Mr. Trump startled preservationists Sept. 19 when he appeared personally before the landmarks commission to speak conditionally in favor of the official designation of 40 Wall Street. Those whose memories went back to 1980 could recall workers razing the Bonwit Teller Building on Fifth Avenue to make way for Trump Tower.
"He came down to support preservation," said Jennifer Raab, chairwoman of the landmarks commission. "People's jaws were really dropping."
For his part, Mr. Trump said: "I have a lot of respect for the current commission. Jennifer Raab's philosophy meshes with what I think, so I went down and made a lot of people very happy."
"Forty Wall Street is a great building," Mr. Trump said, "but I don't want to be inhibited from bringing it back to greatness again." For instance, he would not want to be stopped from gilding the copper top of the building. "That's an important element from a marketing standpoint," he said.
The Wall Street tower is one of about 20 buildings and a historic district in lower Manhattan that are on the landmarks agenda. The commission has already designated four structures around Bowling Green:
* 1 Broadway, which was remodeled in 1921 to serve as headquarters for J. P. Morgan's steamship combine, the International Mercantile Marine Company. On the facades are mosaic coats of arms representing the company's chief ports of call.
* 11 Broadway, completed in 1898 as the Bowling Green Offices. The facade is rich with Greek architectural elements.
* 25 Broadway, completed in 1921 as the Cunard Building. Cunard's former steamship ticket office, now a post office, has an octagonal rotunda under a 68-foot-high dome that is covered in rich and colorful murals. One of the least known and most ornate public rooms in lower Manhattan, the great hall received a separate interior landmark designation.
* 26 Broadway, completed in 1928 as the headquarters of the Standard Oil Company. A colossal oil lamp atop the building's spire still attests to its origins.
OTHER early office towers currently under consideration are the former American Express Building (65 Broadway), the Empire Building (71 Broadway), the former American Surety Building (100 Broadway) and the former Equitable Building (120 Broadway), which was so frighteningly massive that it helped spur the first Zoning Resolution in 1916.
The commission is also weighing the creation of a Stone Street Historic District, taking in 15 small buildings on two blocks south of Hanover Square, including India House, a 142-year-old individual landmark that was once home to the Cotton Exchange.
As part of the process, an economic development plan is being prepared by the Praedium Group, a real estate consulting firm, suggesting some of the uses for the buildings. And an architectural master plan has been drawn up by the firm of Beyer Blinder Belle, including streetscape and facade improvements. "It's a pre-approved plan, so you can be in and out in a week or so," Ms. Raab said.
"My goal is to have the regulatory plan approved at the same time, or very close to the same time, as the district itself," she said. "I'm trying to explain to owners that I really want to be their advocate down here. I want to help this area become revitalized."
One of the more daunting hurdles to residential revitalization is the lack of open space. A new urban design plan by Peterson Littenberg Architects, sponsored by the Battery Park City Authority and J. M. Kaplan Fund, calls for the creation of several small parks throughout lower Manhattan.
Residential buildings tend to cluster around each other, said Jon McMillan, director of planning for the authority. "If, indeed, there is so much undervalued real estate in lower Manhattan and more office space than anyone could need," he said, "why not acquire office buildings, tear them down and put in place a park? You could vastly improve the value of real estate around that park."
The computer model at the New School could be used to search for the potential locations of such parks, based on where the likeliest residential redevelopment might occur. "It allows you to poke at reality by combining visual and non-visual information," said Michael Kwartler, director of the Environmental Simulation Center.
The model can highlight dozens of attributes besides floor size and elevation -- use, age, landmark status, number of elevators, floor-to-floor height, floor area and the extent to which it exceeds or falls short of current zoning. Soon, with the addition of data on 267 buildings from Cushman & Wakefield, the model will be able to pinpoint vacancy rates as well.
The completion of the model was underwritten by the Kaplan Fund. The cochairman of the fund, Richard D. Kaplan, an architect, has taken on lower Manhattan as a kind of personal crusade.
"Those species survive that maximize available resources, I'm reminded by Darwin," he said. "The available resource of downtown is an incredible base of fantastic buildings. Now is an opportune time, as rents and prices drop, for a new kind of city to grow up out of this old one.
"Can we turn the great dowager queen of American cities into a charming princess at the ball?" Mr. Kaplan asked. "It's the first time anyone has thought of this question in an area so dense and so full of history."

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Champions Seek Use for Old Tunnel

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: EDGEWATER

 BODY:
It is literally a hole in the wall now, a place obscured by weeds and bushes, and an invitation for trash, crushed soda cans, golf balls, rags and other debris.
But the Susquehanna Tunnel was once an important rail passage cutting through the Palisades, linking the Hudson River waterfront to the state's interior. And the tunnel's storied past, as well as its possible future use as a light-rail corridor, has Albert F. Cafiero exasperated. 
 Mr. Cafiero, chairman of the Transit Committee of Bergen County, a private advocacy group, says any future use of the tunnel may be compromised by the current widening of River Road here, right across the street. "The road will destroy the right-of-way, and the tunnel as a resource is going to be lost," he said. "We can't have any more cars. We should use that tunnel."
Edgewater, county and state officials disagree that the tunnel and the road are mutually exclusive. Furthermore, they say the River Road project is crucial to alleviating stop-and-go traffic and jump-starting the borough's moribund economy.
"The two-lane road was at levels of service D and F, and the time it took to get out of a place of employment in Edgewater was 15 or 20 minutes for some people," said Chester P. Mattson, director of Bergen County's Department of Planning and Economic Development.
For those who don't know Edgewater, the one-mile tunnel might be easy to miss. It sits under an elevated stretch of River Road, a few hundred yards from the riverfront, its mouth veering away at a 45-degree angle.
It was built in 1892 at the height of industrial activity in the region. For years, the tunnel's double-track lines carried coal and other freight to the waterfront. As industries died or moved, usage dropped. In 1990, its last year of operation, only two cars traversed the tunnel each week. Now, the tracks are gone, replaced by an oil pipeline run by the Amerada Hess Corporation, said Walter Rich, president and chief executive of the New York Susquehanna and Western Railway in Cooperstown, N.Y.
The tunnel had been suggested as a passageway for the proposed Hudson-Bergen Light Rail Transit System. But it was rejected, much to Bergen County's disappointment, in favor of a tunnel in Weehawken.
Meanwhile, River Road continues to be reconfigured. For a four-mile stretch, the two-lane road will be widened to four lanes, with a fifth in the middle of intersections for left turns. The project will be done in two stages, each two miles: the southern section is expected to open by early spring, at a cost of $7 million, about half of which is coming from the developer, G. Heller Enterprises of Englewood Cliffs. The speed limit figures to be 40 miles an hour.
The widened road complements the adjacent development of Edgewater Commons, a 428,000-square-foot shopping center It is to open by June.
This is not good news for Mr. Cafiero and his allies, who fear that the road will become a highway at the foot of the Palisades and that the subsequent pollution will be too much to bear.
"Nobody is overseeing this," said Susan O'Kane, a Hoboken environmentalist, adding that the River Road project is part of a "stealth highway" from the George Washington Bridge to the Bayonne Bridge.
There is the question of cost, however. Refurbishing the tunnel would cost more than $100 million, Mr. Cafiero said, and that doesn't include the trolley system, which could cost $500 million. The road, by contrast, might run $15 million.
"That tunnel can be used, and we all like to see mass transit, but mass transit for the waterfront is 10 to 20 years away," said Mayor Bryan Christiansen of Edgewater. "Meanwhile, what does Edgewater do? Sit and watch as property values go down?"

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
October in Atlantic Highlands: Dancing, Music, Knockwurst, Beer

BYLINE: By CHRISTINA JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The site of what is considered New Jersey's oldest Oktoberfest is a pavilion of dark wood and brick, set high on the hills of Atlantic Highlands' Scenic Drive in Monmouth County.
Each year, the restaurant, called the Hofbrauhaus, celebrates the betrothal of Princess Therese von Sachsen-Hildburghausen to the Bavarian Crown Prince (later Ludwig I), a party that began in 1810. It has become so popular that it begins in mid-September and runs to mid-November, attracting more than 12,000 hungry, thirsty devotees who come on weekends to stuff themselves with sausages, clap to the animated cowbell musician and the three-man oom-pah band and, of course, toast the dancers. 
 The restaurant is more than 45 years old, and has been in the hands of Hilda and Thomas Lesbirel for the last 19. They intend to turn over control to their son, Christopher, soon. None of them have ever been to the ultimate Oktoberfest in Munich, they say, because Oktoberfest here has always been such madness.
Q. What is Oktoberfest about?
HILDA LESBIREL -- What is it in Munich? It's a big beer party. No one is celebrating that Prince Ludwig is married to Princess Therese. Half of them don't even know why they are there. They are just there to have a good time.
Q. And Oktoberfest beer?
CHRISTOPHER LESBIREL -- It's the first beer of the season. It's a little darker than amber in color and has a slightly caramel-y flavor. They do serve it a little warmer in Germany than we do.
Q. Why are there so few German restaurants?
HILDA -- What has happened is that no one has come from Germany any more. All the Germans came over after the war, you see, because of economic conditions at that time. Those people are now in their 60's and 70's. The tradition is slowly being lost. Second-generation Germans, if there's something to celebrate, they're out, but they don't eat the German food as much. It's very, very hearty food. It's not at all good if you are calorie-conscious, and this is what has happened.
Q. What is German food?
THOMAS LESBIREL -- Mostly meat. There's the traditional knockwurst, bratwurst, smoked pork chops. We also have the rouladen, which is the rolled beef stuffed with onions, pickles and mustard; we have an Oktoberfest sampler platter where you get the rouladen, the traditional pork schnitzel and one sausage, served with the German noodle spatzle, covered with a nice hearty brown sauce. Don't forget the kalbshaxen, which is the veal shank. It's the whole lower leg of the veal. There's probably a pound of meat on it. It's served on a platter with a knife sticking out of the top of it. That's for the big eater.
Q. Do people eat this way every day?
HILDA -- Absolutely not. At one point in time in southern Bavaria, they were farmers; they ate like this every day. They also worked in the fields every day. And in the cities, no one eats like this because everyone would be 250 pounds.
Q. Are there many Germans in this area?
HILDA -- Union was at one point heavily populated by Germans, as was New Brunswick, with Germans and Hungarians.
Q. People are eating less meat and drinking less, and there are fewer native Germans. Does that make you nervous?
THOMAS -- We look at it this way: We are one of the few surviving German restaurants. There's not a lot of competition. There's only three of us in New Jersey that operate a brauhaus with entertainment. So yes, is there a time when our menu may have to totally change with our restaurant? Yes. CHRISTINA JOHNSON

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas Lesbirel, left, taking a break with patrons at the bar of the Hofbrauhaus in Atlantic Highlands. (Julio A. Ibarra Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

VILLELLA'S TROUPE
Edward Villella, the American dancer-choreographer who helped change America's stereotypical perception of male ballet dancers, brings his Miami City Ballet to the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College today at 3 P.M. 
 Drawn from the New York City Ballet, Dance Theater of Harlem, the Joffrey Ballet and the Boston Ballet, the 33 members of the troupe exemplify Mr. Villella's own energetic and technically precise style. Formed in 1986, the company has performed throughout the United States, Europe, Israel, South America and Central America.
Mr. Villella was heavily influenced by Balanchine during his years with the New York City Ballet as a member of the corps and later as a principal dancer from 1957 through the 60's. In 1975 he won an Emmy for his CBS television production of "Harlequin," and he later produced and directed the Public Broadcasting Service's "Dance in America" series for a year and a half.
Tickets for today's performance are $21 to $40 and may be obtained by calling 251-6200 or Ticketmaster at 454-3388.
 
ON WOMEN'S FORUM
 Two women who attended the World Women's Conference in Beijing will talk about the experience today at 2 P.M. in the White Plains Library at 100 Martine Avenue.
Leila Doss, retired United Nations Assistant Secretary General for Personnel Services, was an accredited observer at the Intergovernmental Conference from Sept. 4 through 15, representing the Federation of Associations of Former International Civil Servants.
Nancy M. Yanofsky attended the Non-Governmental Forum in Hairou from Aug. 30 through Sept. 8 as executive director of the Pro Choice Resource Center of Mamaroneck.
The program, to which admission is free, has been sponsored by the League of Women Voters of Westchester and the library. Call 422-1400 for more information.
 
ART EXHIBITION
 Igor Trout Fine Arts, a four-month-old gallery in New Rochelle, has a new exhibition opening on Thursday, featuring the work of the partner-owners Gail Nicholson and Richard Leon. Paintings and pastels of their travels through Spain, Mexico, Central America and the United States are indicative of their admiration for the representational-expressionist style of the Bay City School in San Francisco, best exemplified by Richard Diebenkorn.
Igor Trout is a play on the name of a well-known art dealer in Manhattan: Ivan Carp. The entrance to the high-ceilinged, large-windowed studio, warmed by carpeting and draperies, is on Memorial Highway, but the address is 519 Main Street over the Starlite Deli.
Also exhibited are works by Marne Rizika, Michael Morse, Robert Nickson and Paul Jumar, former classmates of Ms. Nicholson and Mr. Leon at the Art Students League in Manhattan. In its continuing campaign to revitalize the downtown area through the arts, the city made several vacant storefronts available to the gallery's artists as exhibition space.
Viewing hours at Igor Trout are Mondays through Fridays from 5 to 7 P.M. and Saturdays from noon to 5 P.M. "We haven't given up our day jobs yet," Mr. Leon said, explaining the limited weekday hours. He is a building contractor, and Ms. Nicholson is a freelance textile designer. An opening reception will be held on Thursday from 5 to 9 P.M. and an open house is scheduled on Saturday from noon to 5 P.M. For more information, call 654-9330.
 
THREE EXHIBITIONS
 Three simultaneous exhibitions sponsored by the Westchester Arts Council may be seen through Nov. 23 at the Association of Community Based Artists of Westchester in Mount Vernon, at Pace University Choate House Gallery in Pleasantville and the Rye Arts Center in Rye.
Three variations on a theme, allocated respectively to each venue are "Cultural Fantasies," "Natural Fantasies" and "Fantasy in Form," executed in a variety of mediums by 50 emerging and established professional artists who live or work in the county. A few of the names are Diane Brawarsky, Blanche Dolmatch, Nils Hill, Linda Nisselson, Creighton Michael and Michael Torlen.
Rosemary Cohane Erpf, curator of the show, chose the theme after viewing works in numerous slide registries, museums, galleries and studios.
The Acbaw Center, at 128 South Fourth Avenue, is open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and the phone number is 667- 7278. For hours at Pace on Bedford Road (Route 117), call 773-3694. Hours at the Rye Art Center, 51 Milton Road, are Mondays through Fridays, 9:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. and 1:30 to 5 P.M.; Saturdays from 1 to 4 P.M. The phone number there is 967-0700.
 
FALL FOLIAGE RUN
 There is still time to enter the Scarsdale Historical Society's Annual Fall Foliage 3.1-mile run today at 3 P.M., or the 1.55-mile walk at 2:30. Check-in time is from 1 to 2:30 at the society headquarters, 937 Post Road, Scarsdale, and registration fees are $10, $8 for people younger than 18.
Tom Kline, a master walker (masters are at least 50 years old), will give a brief talk on walking and health at 1:30.
Awards will be presented to the first three top male and female runners according to age groups, and trophies will go to the overall male and female winners and to the winning male and female masters. The phone number for more information is 723-1744.
 
NATURE TALK
 Dr. Richard Jogodnik, veterinarian, wildlife expert and head instructor of Trout Unlimited Inc. Fishing Schools, will be the speaker at the organization's monthly meeting on Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. at the Fox Lane Middle School on Route 172 in Mount Kisco.
His subject will be a premiere fishery in the country, exceptional for running ice-cold through the middle of the New Mexico desert. He will discuss fishing and wildlife in and around the San Juan River in Navajo Dam, N.M., and the tourist area of Mesa Verde National Park.
Trout Unlimited meetings are free. The nonprofit ecological organization monitors natural water resources and reservoir systems for fishing potential.For more information about the program or classes in fly-fishing, call 941-6342.
 
LECTURE ON IRAQ
 A section of southern Iraq that was virtually unknown to the outside world until the late 1980's will be revealed in a talk by Edward Orchsenschlager, professor of anthropology and archeology at Brooklyn College. He will speak today at 3 P.M. at the Desmond-Fish Library in Garrison-on-Hudson.
As part of a series of expeditions undertaken by the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University and the Metropolitan Museum of Art beginning in 1968, Lagash, the ancient capital of Sumeria, now known as Al-Hiba, was studied in an effort to better understand its early and current cultures.
etal and economic changes.
The library is at the intersection of Route 9D and 403. Admission is free. For more information, call 424-3020. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: A Fulbright Winner Is Off to Sri Lanka

BYLINE: By CHUCK SLATER 

 BODY:
I'M an adventurer at heart," said Dana Quante, a 29-year-old graduate of White Plains High School and Nazareth College of Rochester. Today she will begin a very special adventure: an academic year's study in Sri Lanka on a Fulbright Fellowship.
Not that Ms. Quante spent the summer at her family's White Plains home -- she was on a summer scholarship in Italy, studying Italian at the walled medieval city of Siena. But a Fulbright is, well, very special. 
 Of 4,488 applications for Fulbrights from the American academic community last spring, only 885 were granted. In New York State, Ms. Quante is one of 87 successful candidates among 546 applicants. Since the late Senator J. W. Fulbright was instrumental in the 1946 Congressional legislation "to foster mutual understanding among nations through educational and cultural exchange," about 200,000 college graduates and postgraduates have taken part in the Fulbright program.
Ms. Quante is well suited to it. Besides her love of adventure, she carries a 3.98 grade-point average from Nazareth.
"The director says Dana was the best of the bunch of undergraduates chosen," said Dr. Alec Southerland, the English professor at Nazareth who is the Fulbright program representative on the campus. "She is extraordinarily versatile and a very quick study."
Also, enthusiastic. Ms. Quante's voice fairly bubbled over the phone from London as she talked about her coming adventure.
"I will be attending the University of Peradeniya in the center of the island," she said, "near the large city of Kandy. I will be studying the ancient language of Pali, the canonical and liturgical language of Buddhism.
"Pali is a dead language related to Sanskrit and spoken in the western part of India during the time of the Buddha. That was circa 500 B.C.E. -- Before the Common Era, to be politically correct.
"What I will be studying is the Pali Canon, called Tipitaka. My proposal entails, hopefully, a collection of poems in this Tipitaka, which are attributed to women elders of early Buddhism. This will parallel a study of women's religious and socioeconomic authority and autonomy today."
Ms. Quante, who was in London being prepared by Tissa Jayatilaka, a Sri Lankan representative of the United States Educational Foundation, said she was impressed by what she has learned of Sri Lankan women.
"Sri Lanka is a very special nation in South Asia," she said. "It is special economically. The human development index is 86, which is quite high. Women's literacy is 87 percent, which is tremendous for a so-called third world country."
There is also a 12-year-old civil war going on in Sri Lanka, formerly Ceylon. The adventurer shrugs it off. "I'm definitely not in danger," she said. "The Fulbright committee wouldn't have sent me if I were."
Her mother tries to shrug it off. "I'm a little nervous," Nancy Quante said. "But she tells me not to worry."
Ms. Quante, the fifth of six children, has been surprising her mother for a long time.
"When she was 2, she suddenly recited the alphabet backward," Mrs. Quante recalled. "We didn't know she knew it forward. "As a child, the encyclopedia was her basic recreational reading."
As a child, Dana was partly responsible for her family's move from the Bronx to White Plains. "One of her teachers in the Bronx thought it would be better for her academic growth," Mrs. Quante said.
Hank Quante, Dana's father, has worked his way up from an employee to the owner of the Gedney Way gas station in White Plains. He said he is a little awed by his daughter's award. "I didn't realize just how big a deal the Fulbright is," he said, "but my customers keep congratulating me."
In her Fulbright presentation, Ms. Quante wrote, "You've got to remember, I'm a blue-collar girl from the Bronx." She does.
In the telephone interview from London, she said: "My whole personality was formed in my early childhood in the Bronx. I always go back to that center inside me."
Professor Southerland, who himself completed a Fulbright in Sri Lanka, said: "Her versatility comes partly from having met all kinds of people. She has also worked all kinds of jobs."
Ms. Quante interrupted her college education to work as the house manager of a professional regional theater in Rochester. "You meet a few hundred different people a night," she said.
Starting today, she will be meeting a lot more.
"The Sri Lankans I have met are extremely gracious, inquisitive and lovely," she said. "I can't wait. I love to travel. I love to adapt to a new culture."
Even if it means a change in hair style. She has always worn her brown hair short, but Ms. Quante has not introduced it to a scissors in some time. "For Sri Lankan women," she explained, "their long hair is their pride."

HEADLINE: No Easy Way To Benefit In Britain

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
SO, can Americans profit from the hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign investment that Britain is attracting?
Surely all the savvy stateside investor has to do is identify a few fast-growing British companies that stand to profit from the trend, snap up their shares on the London Stock Exchange and watch their prices rise. 
 If only it were that simple. First, there is the currency risk. If the dollar continues to strengthen against the pound, as many expect it to do, American investors in Britain could take a foreign-exchange hit that would reduce or wipe out gains in the sterling value of their holdings.
Unlike Americans, the Germans, Swiss, Japanese and other big investors in Britain have comparatively strong currencies, which allow them to find good value for relatively low prices when they buy stocks in Britain.
It is no surprise, therefore, that Germany's Siemens and Dresdner Bank, Switzerland's Swiss Bank Corporation and Japan's Nissan and Fujitsu are among the biggest foreign companies investing in Britain. Their home currencies are strong, unlike the dollar.
"When you have a high foreign currency, you can use that to your advantage," said Peter Canelo, an equity strategist at the New York office of NatWest Markets, a unit of National Westminster Bank P.L.C., a big British bank. "You really need superior currency value to take advantage of this. When the currency is on the floor, you're a good seller and not a good buyer."
And there are other potential risks. As in the United States, the threat of a major stock market correction looms in Britain. In both countries, a long bull market has pushed prices close to all-time highs and made bargains scarce.
True, the influx of foreign money is bolstering Britain's economy, but these benefits have largely been factored into British stock prices, economists at brokerage firms in London said.
"It's improved the trade deficit; it's helped to improve management standards in the U.K.; it's taught lessons here. There are positive knock-on effects," said Gavyn Davies, head of research at Goldman, Sachs & Company's London office. But, he added, "It's not obvious how [the American investor] can benefit" from the trend.
ONE strategy suggested by Mr. Davies and by Paul C. Walton, an equity market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, was to buy shares in British companies like GKN P.L.C. and Lucas Industries, which make industrial equipment, and Unitech, which makes electronics parts. All three are likely to be suppliers to foreign companies setting up in Britain.
But, they cautioned, a lot of the smart money in Britain seems to be focusing more on potential players in the current wave of mergers and acquisitions than on beneficiaries of foreign investment.
Some analysts suggest that Americans eager to put their money in foreign stocks might be better off shopping around in Asia or elsewhere in Europe.
Merrill Lynch's international investment strategists, for example, are cautious on Europe in general.
As for Britain, "we've got a moderate underweight on it now," said Thomas C. van Leuven, an international investment strategist at Merrill Lynch in New York. "The U.K. is starting to resemble the U.S.; we see investors getting a little nervous about the earnings outlook."
In Europe, Mr. van Leuven added, "We like the peripheral markets, like Sweden, Spain, Switzerland and Finland."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
In Japan's Facade Of Control

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER; Floyd Norris is on vacation this week.

 BODY:
When the main measure of power in the world was military might, great and small powers dissembled with statistics inflating or minimizing their arsenals. Nowadays, in the struggle to attract capital or keep investors from fleeing, countries are perfecting the art of dissembling by omission.
Last year's champion was Mexico, which hid the numbers that would have tipped off investors that an impending devaluation of the peso was imminent. When the bad news seeped out, investors not only raced for the exits, they pulled out of other emerging markets -- the "contagion effect" that that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin feared would circle the globe. 
 Now Japan, a country that usually drowns in statistical measures of itself, seems intent on seizing this year's title. This week, its ministry of finance admitted that it knew in early August that one of the country's biggest banks lost $1.1 billion during an 11-year fraud at its New York subsidiary. But rather than warn the Federal Reserve and the Treasury that a host of American laws had likely been violated, the financial leaders of the world's second largest economy clammed up for six weeks.
Mr. Rubin, who has championed greater disclosure rules in the post-Mexico era, offered a little lecture when his Japanese counterpart, Masayoshi Takemura, called Wednesday with what was later termed an apology on these shores and a nonapology in Tokyo. Credibility in the markets, he said, means spreading the bad news, as the United States did after the 1987 crash. Anything short of full candor, he told Mr. Takemura, undermines confidence in global markets.
There is reason to wonder if the message sunk in. "I don't think there was anything improper in what we have done," said Eisuke Sakakibara, a top official of the ministry and the leader of a camp that questions how closely Japan should align itself with the United States. He and others attributed the disagreement to "cultural differences."
There are many cultural differences with Japan; this is not one of them. If a Japanese bank president tried to keep such data from all-knowing Finance Ministry -- rather than from foreign authorities -- he would soon be refilling teller machines in the most frigid reaches of Hokkaido. Japan didn't get its reputation as the world's most regulated capitalist economy for nothing.
What was at work here was a radically different perception of national interest. The first instinct of United States regulators would likely be to embarrass and punish the offending bank, to set an example. In Japan, the first instinct is to say nothing that would tear down the banking system's facade of stability. After all, these are the same banks that went to extraordinary lengths to halt all major land transactions as soon as the real estate market began to collapse: If everyone knew how far prices had really fallen, the banks knew they would have to re-evaluate their portfolios and dramatically slash the value of their assets. That self-deception delayed the recognition of how serious Japan's banking crisis had become.
The United States and Japan like to say that despite their constant bickering on trade, their governments work hand-in-glove on the important stuff. But Japan, like Mexico, now joins the ranks of countries where investors will no longer fully believe the government officials who insist that everything is under control.
