HEADLINE: Santa Barbara Journal;
Big-City Problems Hit Close to Home

BYLINE: New York Times Regional Newspapers 

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 14

 BODY:
Stretched between the Santa Ynez Mountains and the Pacific Ocean, this city of 90,000 people has long had a benign reputation as a refuge from the mayhem of Los Angeles, 90 miles south. Even Marcia Clark came here to escape the stresses of prosecuting O. J. Simpson.
But these days, Santa Barbara, colonized by Spanish missionaries in the 18th century, is beginning to show big-city growing pains not unlike those in Los Angeles. 
 Gang violence was unheard of here just five years ago. But now about once a week a gang problem erupts in some area of the city, the police say. Meanwhile, with a sluggish economy, several major high-technology employers have left the city. And although Santa Barbara has long had Hispanic residents, in the past 10 years their numbers have increased, as have the tensions between white and Hispanic residents, particularly in the public schools.
With the approach of the Nov. 7 election, in which 17 candidates are to compete for 4 of 7 seats on the City Council, solving these problems has taken on a new urgency. Civic soul-searching is under way, particularly over how to rejuvenate the economy and cope with the alarming increase in gang activity.
The police say more and more youth gangs have been traveling here on weekend nights from the southern cities of Oxnard and Ventura. Even more distressing, they say, Santa Barbara teen-agers are forming their own gangs on city streets that wind between adobe and red-tile-roofed buildings, some of which date to Spanish rule.
Compared with Los Angeles, the gang problem here is slight. "In our community, it's still manageable," said Lieut. John Thayer, spokesman for the Santa Barbara Police Department. Santa Barbara averages between four and five homicides a year, including those from gang warfare, while on one weekend in August this year, 29 people were shot dead in Los Angeles County as a result of gang violence alone.
But Santa Barbara police are still concerned. Earlier this year, the police department won a $1.5 million Federal grant to pay for educational programs in the high schools and to train officers in anti-gang work, as well as to hire more prosecutors.
While officials develop programs to combat crime, they are faced with another looming problem -- the exodus of technology jobs and the devastating effect on the local economy. For example, in a particularly painful week late last year, a combined 620 layoffs and job transfers were announced by Raytheon Corporation's Electromagnetic Systems Division, which makes hardware for the military, and by the Hughes Corporation's Santa Barbara Research Center, which does work for NASA and commercial space ventures.
Although the majority of Santa Barbara is white, nearly 32 percent is made up of Hispanic residents. The Hispanic population has increased 10 percent since 1980, according to the 1990 census, and with this growth has come increased tensions between different cultures.
In the public schools, for example, a debate has developed over a high school textbook, "The Mexican-American Heritage" by Carlos M. Jimenez, a Los Angeles teacher. The book includes a map showing land once claimed by Mexico that is now part of the United States, including California and parts of six other states in the Southwest. The area is described as Aztlan, the Aztec's mythic homeland.
Sandee Beckers, a school board member, says the book is trying to incite a Hispanic uprising. Deborah Sutherland, a supporter of Ms. Beckers, said in an interview, "The book consistently questions the validity of our existing border with Mexico."
But Grace Florez, the only Hispanic school board member, said in an interview, "It's not written from a Eurocentric perspective, so for all of us that grew up here, it's not a standard history book." And four local principals support the textbook, which continues to be used in the schools.
Still, Santa Barbara's problems, at least at this stage, pale against those of Los Angeles. And city leaders say an even-keeled community temperament and ethnically diverse history make Santa Barbara well equipped to solve its problems.
"I know there are certainly tensions and problems, but Santa Barbara as a community really seems to be together in trying to solve them," said Mike Caston, the superintendent of the Santa Barbara schools who worked for 23 years in the Los Angeles public school system before arriving here last year.
"Santa Barbara's a community that has a long tradition and has always had a large minority population," Mr. Caston said. "Look at community organizations, and there are minorities on advisory boards and in top jobs, in politics and in business."
Mayor Harriet Miller said: "We have a community that's very concerned about the future. There isn't that kind of neighborhood pride in big cities. It doesn't seem to exist in L.A."
Indeed, Los Angelenos continue to escape to Santa Barbara's relative calm. Los Angeles's District Attorney, Gil Garcetti, like his employee, Ms. Clark, recently came here for a political fund-raising event and some moments of peace from the Simpson matter.
"It's not Los Angeles," said Lynn Baragona, explaining why Ms. Clark, her best friend, often visits. "It's a lot less hectic. And everybody here is just a lot nicer."

HEADLINE: Proposed Cuts in Indian Programs Hit Those Who Rely Most on Federal Aid

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: PINE RIDGE, S.D.

 BODY:
With a gray autumn sky clamped like a steel colander over this bleak prairie reservation, Maxine Running Hawk recently talked about how she would keep her 10 children warm in their Government-supplied house this winter, by plugging wall holes with rags and by running the oven with the door off its hinges.
"We hoped to get the repairs done by winter," the 33-year-old Oglala Sioux told Bill Quijas, a visitor from the Tribal Housing Authority. "We can see light through the door. It gets cold in here." 
 But the solemn, pony-tailed housing official was not visiting to offer good cheer. Because of Government action in faraway Washington, renovation of Mrs. Running Hawk's two-bedroom cottage has now been postponed, to next spring, maybe.
Across the remote, far-flung archipelago of American tribal reservations, word is filtering back from the nation's capital that the Republican-controlled Congress has made the deepest cuts in memory in programs that support the ethnic group that is probably the most dependent on Federal aid: the nation's two million Indians.
The bill passed by Congress calls for a 10 percent cut in the budget of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, or $168 million, from last year's total of $1.7 billion. When adjusted for inflation and for Indian population growth, the per capita cut is more than 15 percent, Indian leaders say. President Clinton has said he would veto the legislation.
But cuts in welfare, food stamps and Federal housing subsidies are threatening like the wolf packs that snapped at the buffalo herds that once provided food and clothing for Great Plains tribes like the Oglala Sioux.
According to the 1990 census, 31 percent of Indians earned incomes below the poverty line -- the largest percentage of the nation's five racial groups. Here in Shannon County, which the Census Bureau ranks as the poorest in the nation, the Federal Government is the main support for a tribe suffering from 75 percent unemployment.
"Indians are the most vulnerable group in our society, and also the weakest in terms of political power," Ada E. Deer, the Interior Department's Assistant Secretary of Indian Affairs, said of a group that historically votes Democratic. "Congress found $8 billion to give to a Defense Department that did not even request it, but could find no money to provide an adequate elementary and secondary education for Indian children."
Trying to exploit the one bright spot in the economy of Indian country, Congress also wants to impose a 35 percent tax on casino gambling on Indian reservations. Indians object, saying that tribes cannot be taxed because they are sovereign entities, similar to states.
"Congress didn't want any input from us," Wilbur Between Lodges, president of the Oglala, said after coming home empty-handed in late September from a visit to Washington with other Indian leaders. "We are just here waiting to hear what is going to happen."
Noting that Congress recently passed bills favoring ranchers and mining companies, some Indian leaders say that this fall's legislative action is only the latest chapter in a familiar, 150-year record of Congress's favoring cowboys and miners over Indians.
Others acidly note that the Bureau of Indian Affairs received the largest cuts within the Interior Department, an agency that also includes the National Park Service and the United States Geological Survey.
"Rocks and parks are taking precedence over people," Albert Hale, president of the Navajo Nation, the largest Indian tribe, said recently.
Across the West, in private conversations and public forums, the cuts are provoking bitter debate.
Supporters of current policy say the cuts violate century-old guarantees and are too great, and too swift, for the tribes to absorb. Some critics of subsidies counter that Indians have depended too long on Government aid and that the Government should be promoting self-reliance.
But some Congressional moves would cut programs designed to stimulate economic self-sufficiency for tribes. Congress's budget virtually eliminates the Indian Bureau's economic development program.
In recent years, Indian artwork has mushroomed into a $500 million-a-year industry. But Congress has just passed a measure to halve the budget for the Institute of American Indian Arts in Santa Fe. Reduced to operating with $5 million, the school is cutting its enrollment to 178, from 250.
The proposed gambling tax would hit heavily the Indian gaming industry, which has created about 300,000 jobs nationwide, largely for Indians.
In a surreal scene here, miles of monotonous prairie are broken at this reservation's western edge by blue neon and flashing gold lights, drawing attention to a makeshift casino fashioned out of two double trailers hitched together.
"We employ 120 people, and a lot of them are off the welfare rolls," Wayne Barber, the manager, an Oglala Sioux, said as Nebraska farm couples huddled over poker tables and ringing slot machines. "You have to walk before you run. This could support a hotel, an R.V. park, a golf course."
As most Indian casinos, the Oglala's shares part of its profits with members of the tribe. But the casino is a rare example of private enterprise on the reservation. A century of Federal and missionary education has failed to teach business skills to many Oglala.
Starting with an 1868 treaty that stipulated rations of beef and "good substantial woolen clothing," the Federal Government long ago replaced the buffalo as the primary source of sustenance for the Oglala. Albeit precarious, this safety net has allowed the tribe's population to roughly double in this century, hitting 24,000 today.
The Federal Government is responsible for most of the Tribal Government budget, for the entire Bureau of Indian Affairs budget, for all schools except for one missionary school on the Oglala reservation and for the entire Indian Health Service budget.
"The biggest employers here are the Federal agencies," said Delbert Brewer, an Oglala who is superintendent of the local office of the Bureau of Indian Affairs. "The reservation is 90 percent dependent on the Federal Government -- and if that dries up, we are dead as a nation."
Countering accusations of inefficiency that are often leveled at the bureau, Mr. Brewer said that over the last two years he had reduced his staff to 79 from 120. With one-third fewer employees, he administers 25 programs in a reservation the size of Connecticut.
On this 5,000-square-mile reservation, the largest in South Dakota, the bureau maintains roads, runs schools, oversees all real estate transactions, enforces soil conservation practices, administers programs run under contract by the Tribal Government and pays out $2 million a year in welfare checks.
Next door to the bureau, at the Tribal Government building, Mr. Between Lodges said, "Given the past history of the state working with us, we want to be given a chance to run our own welfare system."
In the halls of the red brick tribal building, the nervous talk is of cuts. About one-third of the tribal police force of 90 officers is expected to be laid off this month. The number of scholarships to the tribe's new four-year community college could be cut in half this year, to 115.
Down the street, stands a federally financed showcase: the bureau's new Jim Thorpe High School. But inside, the principal said he was battling to retain students after losing 40 percent of his teaching positions over the last two years.
"I'm teaching a freshman world history class with 40 kids," said the principal, Gerald A. Ray. The school dropout rate is 60 percent.
Although the bureau is required to finance tribal schools at the same per-student average as the states they are in, Congress approved separate, and unequal, education levels. In a financing pattern that is similar for most Indian education, Congressional financing allows the bureau to spend $2,900 on each high school student here, while South Dakota spends an average of $3,350 for each student in public schools outside reservations.
At the other end of Pine Ridge's rundown main street, at the Tribal Housing Authority, officials are recalculating their budgets to account for a $2 million, or 19 percent, cut in their budget. Most of the reservation's 1,100 public housing units were built in the Great Society era of the 1960's.
Although Oglala poverty has changed little in 30 years, Congress has little interest in Great Society legacies like the Old Crazy Horse Cluster, the crumbling subdivision where Mrs. Running Hawk braces for another South Dakota winter. After the last round of cuts, the authority's annual repair budget amounts to $100 a house.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 2101 words

HEADLINE: Emerging Role For the C.I.A.: Economic Spy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
During the Clinton Administration's tense negotiations with Japan last spring -- with the looming threat of sanctions to cut off Japanese luxury car imports to the United States -- American trade officials were accompanied everywhere by a small team of intelligence officers.
Each morning, they gave Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and his aides inside information gathered by the Central Intelligence Agency's Tokyo station and the electronic eavesdropping equipment of the National Security Agency, sifted by C.I.A. analysts in Washington. 
 Mr. Kantor received descriptions of conversations among Japanese bureaucrats and auto executives from Toyota and Nissan who were pressing for a settlement, and read about the competing pressures on Japan's Trade Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto.
When the negotiations came to a climax in Geneva, the intelligence team was in place at the Intercontinental Hotel, working alongside Mr. Kantor's negotiators, offering assessments of how far the Japanese side could be pressed.
"It was a remarkable performance, because the intelligence agencies finally realized this was the World Series -- the arms control talks of the new age," said one senior Administration official.
"But in the end, did it help much? Beyond some valuable detail we could not have gotten elsewhere, did it tell us much about which way Hashimoto would go? It would be hard to make that case."
Spying on allies for economic advantage is a crucial new assignment for the C.I.A. now that American foreign policy is focused on commercial interests abroad. President Clinton made economic intelligence a high priority of his Administration, specifically information to protect and defend American competitiveness, technology and financial security in a world where an economic crisis can spread across global markets in minutes.
But the transition is a rough one for an agency far less comfortable with capital flows than with Communist foes.
At the Treasury Department, the trade representative's office and the Commerce Department, officials say they now receive a torrent of information from the C.I.A. But in the next breath, they say the quantity is not matched by the quality.
The agency, they complain, often cannot separate the vital from the trivial, and its analysis of economic data is still amateurish. Recently some in the Administration have begun to wonder aloud whether much of the analysis should be farmed out to better-trained experts in Government and the private sector.
The C.I.A. tends "too often to reproduce mainstream, middle-of-the-road views," Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers told Congress last month. He questioned whether it "can add much value" to the financial information and analysis the private sector produces from a wealth of public information.
With an increasing fraction of the $28 billion intelligence budget going to economic matters, the answer to that question may be crucial to the C.I.A.'s future.
At the agency, economics is still more a buzzword than a mission. The new director, John M. Deutch, talks about it often. But in a recent interview, one of the highest-ranking officials of the C.I.A. confessed complete ignorance of the subject. Some inside the agency ridicule the idea that car exports and exchange rates -- which they call "soft stuff" -- are remotely as important as the spread of nuclear weapons and terrorism -- "hard stuff."
Moreover, a generation of American spies trained to steal secrets from Communist enemies is having trouble adjusting to the more subtle world of trade politics. There, economic competitors are also political allies, and a far wider range of players -- industrialists, bankers, and politicians worried about jobs back home -- want their say. Even many who believe in economic spying are asking if the information gained is worth risking some of America's most important alliances.
 
Negotiating
New Territory: C.I.A. at GATT
 In 1993, the Administration asked the C.I.A. for dramatic improvement in three areas where it had previously played only a bit role: supporting trade negotiations, tracking legal and illegal tactics other countries use to win business and spotting financial troubles that can become foreign policy crises, as happened in Mexico last year.
One of the C.I.A.'s first explorations into the new territory came during the 1993 negotiations over the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It provided accounts of discussions among key countries negotiating the worldwide trade accord, focusing on the thinking of the French President at the time, Francois Mitterrand; the French Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, and the head of the European Commission, Jacques Delors.
But in the end, the agency displayed more energy than results, Administration officials say.
"We discovered this doesn't come to them naturally, like an arms-control negotiation," said one senior official who got C.I.A. reports. "Give them very specific direction on a limited basis, with a limited time and scope, where they can give you information that they have gathered electronically, and it's pretty helpful. But the minute that you rely on their political or economic assessments -- well, let me be delicate: their capabilities are limited."
Another top American official was more direct: "The important stuff is garbled. And most of what you get is garbage."
By most accounts, the agency did better in this year's high-stakes negotiations with Japan, where a key question was what the Japanese auto industry was telling -- and was being told -- by the Japanese Government. Partly prompted by intelligence reports, the Americans told the Japanese automakers that negotiators from Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry were misrepresenting American demands.
American negotiators also asked for details of internal discussions between the ministry and rival agencies. Thanks to Tokyo's own internecine rivalries, the C.I.A. got a break.
Most of the secure telephones in the Japanese Government are controlled by the Foreign Ministry. But officials at the trade ministry shunned those phones, both to keep their own diplomats from listening in and because Mr. Hashimoto's chief rival for the prime ministership at the time was the Foreign Minister.
In the end, intelligence proved of limited use in predicting how far Mr. Hashimoto would go. Critics of the unspectacular accord, which chipped away at market barriers without removing them, question whether the result justified the effort. But a senior Administration economic official said the political prominence of the car talks sent an important message to the C.I.A.: focus more energy on economic security.
"We can't go into this kind of thing disarmed," one top official said. Mr. Deutch knows that, the official said: "The question is whether he will have the time to change the culture of the agency."
 
Analysis
On the Big Picture, A Fuzzy Vision
 Government officials who rely on the C.I.A. for economic intelligence say it has failed at the second major task: warning Government officials about imminent changes in other nations' fiscal policies or looming financial debacles.
"The agency is accustomed to a world where it has a monopoly on information," said one senior official who receives daily C.I.A. reports. "If you are interested in Iraq's nuclear weapons program, you don't have many other choices for your information. But if you want to know what the Bundesbank is going to do next, or whether Brazil is thinking of devaluing its currency, there is a lot of competition. And it is hard for the agency to add value."
Many Administration officials suggest that the agency simply does not have the talent for such analysis. "The best graduate students don't go there, and who can blame them?" said one of the Administration's top economic officials. "And yet, when you sit in a meeting, the views of the C.I.A. are often given more weight than the Council of Economic Advisors. Go figure."
Tracking global capital flows or predicting currency crises is beyond the agency's ability, said Allan E. Goodman, a former C.I.A. official and academic dean of Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service.
"We don't have the sources, we don't have the expertise," he said. "To develop an understanding of the people who trade currencies, their motivations, their lifestyles, you'd have to send your people to Harvard, Stanford and Wharton for years. Currency traders keep secrets very, very well, and to penetrate that would be the equivalent of cracking all the Japanese codes in World War II."
 
Enforcement
Blowing a Whistle On Foreign Bribes
 When Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown went to Congress on Thursday with his annual report about how the United States is meeting foreign competition abroad, he brought with him a secret annex.
It focused on tactics used by France, England, Germany, Japan and Canada to win deals, mostly in Asia. Most of the tactics were legal; many are practiced by Washington, including having the President press foreign countries to award business to American firms.
But the unclassified version of the report also cited "almost 100 cases of foreign firms using bribery to undercut U.S. firms' efforts to win international contracts worth about $45 billion," adding, "The foreign firms that offer bribes typically win about 80 percent of the deals."
The C.I.A. asserts that in several cases it has caught foreign companies bribing their way into billion-dollar contracts abroad. When that happens, the agency tells the State Department, which protests on behalf of American corporations and, on occasion, wins. "This is probably an area where our intelligence can be used most effectively," a senior official said. "It's where the agency is getting better."
 
Espionage
Risks and Rewards Of Spying on Allies
When corporate America talks to the C.I.A. about economic espionage, it often pleads for its competitors' secrets -- but in vain.
"If we're willing to do dirty tricks for the defense part of national security, then why aren't we able to do dirty tricks for the economic part?" asks Robert Kohler, a retired C.I.A. official and general manager of TRW Avionics & Surveillance Group.
The agency says it will not ask its officers to risk their lives for companies instead of their country. It will, however, continue to spy on American allies to understand national strategies. That entails its own risks.
The issue has been a constant source of tension in the American Embassy in Tokyo. During the last years of the cold war, American officials told the Japanese that the station was chiefly devoted to keeping track of China, North Korea and Russia's eastern ports. But Japanese officials are increasingly unhappy as it becomes clear that they are a primary target.
Tensions are also growing in Europe. France has spied on American companies for years, planting moles in companies like Boeing and Texas Instruments and breaking into hotel rooms to rifle through attache cases. In late 1993, the C.I.A. stepped up a counterattack.
"No more Mr. Nice Guy," a former C.I.A. chief, R. James Woolsey, has warned publicly. The C.I.A.'s Paris station got in the game -- with disastrous results.
A young aide to the French Prime Minister, Mr. Balladur, found himself being courted by an American woman who introduced herself as public relations director for a save-the-rain-forest foundation. French counterintelligence officers warned the aide, Henri Plagnol, that the woman was a C.I.A. operative -- and told him to play along.
A two-year-long sting developed. A male C.I.A. officer quizzed Mr. Plagnol about key French positions on the GATT talks, especially on agricultural issues and limits on the importation of American movies for French television. He handed the Frenchman 500-franc notes -- about $100 each -- for his information.
Other C.I.A. officers fell under French surveillance. Two sought GATT information from a communications ministry officer. Another tried to bribe an engineer with the state-run France Telecom for information that would help the C.I.A. bug French telecommunications.
In February, the affair blew up when the French publicly demanded the expulsion of the C.I.A. station chief, his deputy and two other C.I.A. officers. The agency's longstanding liaison with French intelligence -- crucial for joint operations such as tracking terrorists -- has been suspended. The C.I.A. inspector general is assessing whether the operation was worth it.

HEADLINE: NATO Chief May Resign Over Scandal

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The NATO Secretary General, Willy Claes, said today that he was considering resigning, after a Belgian parliamentary commission decided this morning to recommend that the country's highest court indict him in a widening arms corruption scandal.
If Mr. Claes were forced to resign, after little more than a year in office, the 16-nation alliance would be leaderless as it enters a crucial period. The organization faces possible expansion to include new members in central Europe and the assumption of a peacekeeping role with up to 60,000 soldiers if a political settlement is reached in Bosnia. 
 Mr. Claes, a 56-year-old Flemish politician, defended himself for six hours Friday before former colleagues in an all-party Belgian parliamentary commission.
The panel is investigating charges that when he was Economic Affairs Minister of Belgium in 1988, his Socialist Party took $1.72 million in kickbacks from the Italian aircraft manufacturer Agusta S.p.A. for a $267 million contract to build 48 helicopters for the Belgian Army.
"I had the opportunity to confirm that I am totally innocent," Mr. Claes said after last night's hearings.
But after this morning's decision by the commission to allow the Belgian Supreme Court to indict him if Parliament votes on Thursday to lift his immunity, Mr. Claes told Belgian radio, "I am absolutely stunned."
Asked whether he would resign, he said, "I must examine the text and think about it before making any decision," and he said he would have to "have the necessary consultations within NATO."
One NATO colleague said it seemed increasingly unlikely that Mr. Claes could hold onto his job, and diplomats said informal consultations were already under way about possible successors.
The more or less declared candidates include Ruud Lubbers, a former Prime Minister from the Netherlands who ran unsuccessfully for the Presidency of the European Union's Executive Commission last year, and the former Prime Minister of Denmark, Uffe Ellemann-Jensen.
Douglas Hurd, who resigned as British Foreign Secretary earlier this year, has also been suggested, as has Lord Owen of Britain, the former Foreign Secretary David Owen.
Lord Owen was the European Union's mediator for the former Yugoslavia until last year, and in that position he was often criticized by American officials for yielding too easily to the Bosnian Serbs.
Mr. Claes, an amateur musician who often makes guest appearances as a symphony orchestra conductor, was Foreign Minister of Belgium when he was picked to succeed Manfred Worner of Germany in September of 1994 after Mr. Worner died of cancer.
But early this year, investigators pursuing the Belgian bribery scandal began putting the spotlight on Mr. Claes. At first, he denied even hearing about illegal payments by the Agusta firm. But in February, after a fellow leader of the Flemish-speaking Socialist Party said he remembered Mr. Claes being at a meeting when the party treasurer, Etienne Mange, said he had heard the Italians were offering bribes for the helicopter contract, he acknowledged his presence.
He insisted, though, that he had told Mr. Mange to reject the offer. The former treasurer has been jailed since February, and his lawyers have said that he ignored Mr. Claes's advice and took the money.
Mr. Claes has maintained that he never knew that any money had actually changed hands, insisting on this even after his former chief of staff at the Economic Affairs Ministry, Johan Delanghe, was arrested and charged in February.
Mr. Claes went ahead with a planned visit to the United States and a meeting with President Clinton in March even though by that time, the Defense Minister of the Netherlands, Joris Voorhoeve, was saying it was time for him to step down.

HEADLINE: South Korea's President, in a Rift With North, Delays Talks

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Saying that he feels "betrayed" and "disappointed" by hard-line Communists in North Korea, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea today ruled out further steps any time soon toward reconciliation and dialogue on the Korean peninsula.
Mr. Kim, speaking in a 90-minute interview on the eve of a trip to Canada and the United States, where he will meet with President Clinton, also dismissed the prospect of a summit meeting soon between the leaders of the two Koreas. "Given the uncertainty surrounding North Korea, I don't think this is an appropriate time to talk about an inter-Korean summit meeting," he said. 
 His remarks underscore the hardening of attitudes in South Korea toward the north, and the degree to which disillusionment and distrust have replaced the hopes for dialogue that had hung in the air as recently as this spring. In June, for example, Mr. Kim had spoken with moderate enthusiasm about the possibility of a summit meeting.
The boundary between the two Koreas, a no-man's-land of mines, barbed wire, tank traps and secret underground tunnels, remains the site of the greatest massing of enemy troops anywhere on the globe.
The United States has a huge stake in peace on the peninsula. While the border between the Koreas is no longer seen as a potential tripwire for World War III, as it was a decade or two ago, it remains a possible battleground involving United States troops and perhaps even nuclear weapons.
Mr. Kim's statements suggest that in Korea at least, the cold war is not only still alive but also risks breaking into a real war at any time.
"Our concern is that because of their desperation or frustration about their declining economy, they may start on a course of adventurous military provocation," Mr. Kim said. He added that signs of this have already become apparent in the last few months, with North Korea's beefing up its armed forces and giving more power to the armed forces.
The mood in Korea today contrasts with optimism that flickered quite recently. Last year, Mr. Kim was preparing for a summit meeting with the North Korean President, Kim Il Sung, when he suddenly died.
Then this spring, North Korea showed unexpected flexibility by asking for rice shipments to ease a shortage at home. South Korea began to ship rice to the north, and hopes grew that a peace process could be built on the sacks of rice.
Then North Korea forced one of the South Korean ships carrying rice to raise a North Korean flag and detained crew members of another on charges of spying. In addition, North Korea continued to hold a fishing boat and crew that it had seized at sea earlier this year.
Mr. Kim said today that the North Koreans had promised that if they received rice, they would release the fishing boat and also stop broadcasting denunciations of the South Korean Government. But the fishing boat and crew remain in northern hands and the broadcasts continue.
"We felt betrayed and we were very disappointed by North Korea's breach of its promises," Mr. Kim said. "North Korea is a very difficult partner to deal with. The ball is in North Korea's court now."
For South Korea to resume rice shipments and other steps toward reconciliation, Mr. Kim said, North Korea must first release the fishing boat and stop the broadcasts vilifying South Korea.
One factor behind Mr. Kim's tough line may be that his own popularity has dropped sharply. His Government has been criticized for being too weak to North Korea, so a tough policy may play well at home.
It is difficult to gauge North Korea's reaction, because North Korean leaders have refused to give interviews. But North Korean broadcasts argue that it was South Korea that deliberately poisoned the climate, and that the breakthrough needed to bring peace to the Korean peninsula is for the United States and North Korea to recognize each other.
President Kim, who in 1993 became South Korea's first elected civilian president in a generation, spoke warmly of the role of the 37,000 United States troops in South Korea in deterring invasion and war. Yet Mr. Kim also called for a revision of the Status of Forces Agreement, the document that stipulates how American soldiers and military bases are to be treated under Korean law.
South Korea and Japan now are both seeking changes in those agreements, largely because of popular resentment at crimes attributed to American soldiers. Mr. Kim warned that anti-Americanism would increase unless the Status of Forces Agreement is amended.
The Governments of both South Korea and Japan say they want to keep American bases. But the irritation at reported crimes and the demands for revising the documents have added to the uncertainties.
Although President Kim has railed at human rights abuses in North Korea, he strongly defended South Korea's rigid national security law, which is used to imprison peaceful supporters of North Korea.

HEADLINE: At Annual Gathering of Business Council, the Mood Is Upbeat

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 14

 BODY:
The great funk that President Clinton said last month was afflicting the American public was nowhere to be seen these last few days, as the nation's business leaders gathered here for the annual meeting of the Business Council.
Rather, their mood was sunny, matching the clear blue skies that shined over this colonial resort. The chief executives were upbeat about both the economy and the eventual outcome of the bickering in Washington over balancing the budget. 
 The executives predicted healthy growth in corporate profits for the rest of this year and for 1996 -- some timed in double digits. They praised the Federal Reserve Board and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, for their management of monetary policy. "The Fed has been able to engineer a soft landing for the first time in history," said Richard M. Rosenberg, chief executive of the BankAmerica Corporation.
And as the gathering ended today, they called on Mr. Clinton to reappoint Mr. Greenspan as Fed chairman when his term expires next spring. "He has done a first-class job," said John F. Welch Jr., chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Company.
John L. Weinberg, senior chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, and other executives did express concern about the direction of interest rates. In a poll of members before the meeting, more than 80 percent of the respondents predicted that economic growth would continue in the 2 to 2 1/2 percent range during the next 12 months. They also saw inflation remaining flat.
"We'd like to see some moderate reduction in interest rates," said Mr. Rosenberg of BankAmerica.
About the only time these chief executives showed reserve was Friday evening, when Mr. Clinton addressed them. He gave a fighting speech -- he has backed off his pronouncement of a nationwide funk -- and recapped his achievements. He asked the executives to help facilitate a budget compromise between the Republican-controlled Congress and the White House.
The Republican plan aims at balancing the budget over seven years and makes deep cuts in Federal spending as well as offering tax cuts. The Democratic plan takes longer to end the red ink and makes smaller spending reductions.
"What I want is to get together with Congress and get a budget out that is an honorable compromise that is better than theirs and better than mine," Mr. Clinton said. "All I'm asking you to do is say, just get together, come up with something."
Throughout the speech, the Business Council members sat stony-faced, rarely interrupting with applause. When the President finished, he received a polite ovation.
The executives seemed less than worried about the budgetary stand-off, even though it threatens to shut the Federal Government if no agreement is reached by Nov. 15. "It's a war dance," said Edwin L. Artzt, who retired in July as chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company but remains on the company's board. "They have to work it out and they will work it out."
Some corporate chieftains are even heartened by the debate. "It's healthy to some degree, because there are tough choices to be made," said Joseph T. Gorman, chairman and chief executive of TRW Inc.
Lawrence A. Bossidy, chairman of Allied Signal Inc., predicted agreement after "another five to six weeks of political theater."
Many executives dismissed the dire predictions that a Government shutdown, should it happen, would roil the financial markets.

HEADLINE: Black Men Say the March in Washington Is About Them, Not Farrakhan

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: CLINTON, Md., Oct. 12

 BODY:
At the Update Barber Salon in a tiny mall here, outside the District of Columbia, no one questions whether Monday's planned march in the capital by thousands of black men is a good thing.
The shop's largely working-class black customers -- the airmen from nearby Andrews Air Force Base, the fathers with their sons -- and the barbers themselves, say the call for atonement, responsibility and unity that is the theme of the Million Man March is long overdue. 
 Much of the media focus has been on controversies about the march. Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam and the initiator of the march, has been denounced by critics as an anti-Semite, race-baiter and homophobe. Some prominent black leaders and organizations have been unwilling to endorse or participate in the demonstration because of Mr. Farrakhan's role and some black women have criticized the exclusion of women by the organizers.
But the men in the barber shop say all these things are beside the point. For them, the march is not about any of that. It's about them.
 "Somewhere along the way we just forgot what we should be about," said Lewis Brandon, an airman. "The march isn't totally a stop sign, but it's a yield sign that says we should hold up."
So when an evening news program on a television in the corner features an interview with Mr. Farrakhan, the usual banter and gibes of barber and client halt.
In the interview, Mr. Farrakhan denies he is a racial provocateur or separatist, saying that he is calling on black men to be responsible to their communities, a message he has been delivering for years. There are nods of approval in the shop. When the announcer tells Mr. Farrakhan that Rep. Gary Franks, a black Republican from Connecticut, has denounced the march and will not come, that one Catholic priest will participate while another disavows the march because Mr. Farrakhan is the sponsor, one customer spits, "Who cares?"
For the men in the Update, the march is an opportunity for black men to address their condition at a time when their median income is half that of white men, where high unemployment seems endemic among black men and low academic achievement seems to be their norm.
"We have to begin with ourselves," said Darryl Pinkston, one of the barbers. "All the answers lie within ourselves."
At the barber shop, the men said the gathering is a chance to air "within the family" the dirty laundry of the black community: the wayward boys and men, deteriorating families, the drugs and crime that have turned once-stable inner city black neighborhoods into killing fields and made black men eight times more likely to be murdered than white men. These men say that it is time to put away poor excuses and elevate good examples, to take public a private conversation about morals and values that has been going on among blacks for more than two decades.
In fact, they hope the Monday march will be cathartic.
"We have to make an atonement," said Tim Taylor, a barber whose brother, Rick, is co-owner of the shop. "We have to begin to take back our neighborhoods. We have to give the brothers who have fallen by the wayside a chance, but bring judgment against them if they continue in the error of their ways."
The men here also see the march as a way to counter what they view as the media's overwhelmingly negative images of blacks, particularly black males. They see the media as invariably racializing America's problems, putting a black face on welfare, a black face on the problems of crime and drugs. This, they believe, has left many blacks afraid to speak out about about moral issues.
"Sure there are some who have defiled themselves, selling drugs, etc., but the bad images of black men are systematically put in place and highlighted," says Rick Taylor, co-owner of the shop.
"I don't see a representative of myself in the media," said Tim Taylor, his brother. "All the images in the media of black men are negative."
"And that's not our state in here," Rick Taylor chimed back. "We're working-class black men working every day taking care of our families. I'm pro-black but any man who doesn't take care of his family is worse than a dog."
The march, they predict, will refute those images and celebrate the majority of black men, who work hard and contribute to their communities. Men like themselves who moved to towns like this for safer streets, better housing and better schools.
Glenn C. Loury, a conservative black economist, has noted that the overwhelming majority of blacks are part of the middle and working classes and has said that only about 10 percent of those who are poor have the multiple problems that have come to represent the community.
"God first, family second," said one man. "If you take care of the family, then the community will be all right."
One force that has remained a obstacle for them, they say, is racism.
The men share tales of racial prejudice -- the wary glance in a store, the arbitrary harassment by police, the assumption that they are, in general, up to no good. They discuss on the reasons behind black-on-black crime, the legacy of slavery. They argue over the need for affirmative action. And while they acknowledge the contributions of strong black women -- several were raised by single mothers -- they say it is easier for black women to get work than for black men.
"Caucasian men fear black men so they hire black females," said Lewis Brandon, the airman.
Ivy Brandon, a 43-year-old computer technician who works for the Washington Metropolitan Transit Authority and is unrelated to Lewis Brandon, drew bitter laughter when he recounted getting call backs for jobs because employers assumed from his name that he was a woman.
Preliminary responses to a study of employer and worker attitudes in Atlanta, Boston, Detroit and Los Angeles sponsored by the Ford Foundation, and as yet unfinished, substantiate some of their experiences. Black men are often seen as lazy and hostile and lacking the go-along, get-along attitudes employers demand in a downsizing economy. Employers complain of the same problems with white workers, but Chris Tilly, a labor economist at the University of Massachusetts, said the widespread negative stereotypes of black men means they are at a disadvantage in job interviews if the interviewer is white.
In many ways, though, black men are reacting to the same thing that are angering white men. Real wages for working class men, regardless of race, have declined sharply over the two decades.
"The reality is that they're all in the same boat," said Harry J. Holzer, professor of economics at Michigan State University, visiting scholar at the Russell Sage Foundation.
Structural changes in the economy and a shift from a manufacturing to a service economy has meant that, the median real wages for full-time male workers have fallen from $34,048 in 1973 to $30,407 in 1993. Young men, ages 25 to 34, have been hit hardest of all. Their wages are down 25 percent.
For those without a college education, the situation is even worse. In 1979, college educated men earned 40 percent more than the average high school graduate, today the gap has nearly doubled with the college-educated earning 75 percent more.
Still, black men have been hit the hardest of all. In the 1970's, 75 percent of black men were able to maintain full-time, full-year employment, said Secretary of Labor Robert Reich. In the 1980's, that number dropped to 50 percent.
"If you compare white men, white women, black men and black women, black men have fallen farthest and hardest in terms of wages, benefits and employment," Mr. Reich said.
The men in the barber shop may not know the statistics or where they fit in a new global economic structure, but they know that something is terribly wrong in their communities and they say they want to put it right, beginning with themselves.
"The march is a line," says another man. "This is where we cut the madness off."
Other men offer their analyses:
"The older generation bears some of the responsibility for where we are," says another.
"Integration, that's where we got off track."
"Prisons -- all these young black men in prison -- it's just a new form of slavery."
The conversation in the barber shop is as thick as the clippings of hair on the floor round each chair. To a man, despite ideological differences, despite sharp clashes over some of its principles, the men say they will attend the march.
It is not, as one man put it, about what is "going on on the podium, but what is going on on the ground."

HEADLINE: Calcutta Hopes as Communists Push Free Marke

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: CALCUTTA, India

 BODY:
Until last fall, American diplomats working in a high-walled compound in one of this city's more prosperous districts were often made to feel unwanted. During the Vietnam War, the street outside the United States Consulate General was renamed for Ho Chi Minh. The gesture signaled the onset of 25 years of demonstrations and harassment that made the consulate one of the most beleaguered American diplomatic posts anywhere.
Then, suddenly, from one day to the next, the protests stopped. Where angry crowds once threw up makeshift platforms against the consulate walls for left-wing politicians to declaim against American imperialism, Calcutta businessmen now line up for visas that will give them a crack at the burgeoning trade between India and the United States. 
 The new mood reflects the wider changes in India, which has sought improved relations with the United States since New Delhi's alliance with the Soviet Union collapsed. Nowhere has the change reverberated more strongly than in Calcutta, the capital of West Bengal, which has been governed since 1978 by a breakaway faction of the Indian Communist Party, the Communist Party of India (Marxist).
While land reforms introduced by the Communists broke up feudal fiefs that had dominated the state of West Bengal for centuries and produced some of the most bountiful grain harvests anywhere in India, the poverty that has made Calcutta a byword for urban degradation has shown little sign of receding.
Now, for the first time in a generation, Calcuttans are beginning to hope that the city's long descent may finally be over. Since September 1994, the government here has formally thrown its weight behind the free-market economic reforms that were adopted by the national Government in New Delhi in 1991.
In place of helter-skelter nationalization, work stoppages that had driven thousands of businesses into bankruptcy, and a general climate of hostility toward outsiders, the Communists here have become arch-apostles for the new doctrines of free enterprise, foreign investment and a work culture that emphasizes productivity over strikes.
These days, visitors calling on Jyoti Basu, the 82-year-old Communist leader who heads the state government as Chief Minister, are likely to find him tinkering with his new desktop computer in the Writer's Building, the colonial edifice that served as the East India Company's headquarters when it ruled much of India in the 18th and 19th centuries.
Mr. Basu himself, immaculate in a homespun muslin dhoti, reminisces about his visit this summer to the United States, where he criss-crossed the country addressing Wall Street bankers and corporate executives from Boston to San Francisco.
Mr. Basu shakes his head vigorously when visitors suggest that the collapse of the Soviet Union helped bankrupt the ideology he has followed since the British authorities imprisoned him for his work as an underground Communist leader more than 50 years ago.
"A debacle has taken place in the Soviet Union, but we don't think it as the end of Marxism," he said.
Still, Mr. Basu speaks of his new policies in ways that make them hard to distinguish from those of the governing Congress Party leaders in New Delhi, who initiated the free-market economic reforms at the national level that have set off a rush for private investment, especially foreign investment, by India's 32 states and territories.
"If you are a Marxist or a Socialist, you must look at the realities of the situation, not what you imagine to be there," he said.
His conversion could have far-reaching implications, and not only for West Bengal, whose 70 million people remain close to the bottom of Asia's social and economic ladder. Although the economic reforms appear to have stalled at the national level, many Indians cite acceptance of the reforms in West Bengal -- a bastion of Indian Communism since the 1930's -- as proof that whatever the short-run political obstacles to free-market reforms, India ultimately has nowhere else to go.
Also, political pundits continue to suggest Mr. Basu as a possible prime minister after general elections expected in March or April. With the Congress Party undermined by allegations of high-level corruption and by divisions over the economic reforms, many commentators predict that the pro-reform wing of the Congress Party could be forced to seek a coalition with left-wing groups, including the the Communists, whose two main factions, including the Basu group, hold 50 of the 545 seats in Parliament.
So far, in Calcutta, the reforms' effects have been limited. Especially during the monsoons, the city presents a dispiriting spectacle of decaying buildings, vast slums where millions survive amid seas of mud and filth, sidewalks lined with the homeless sleeping on mats of sodden cardboard, stick-thin mothers with small children begging a few rupees for food.
Along traffic-clogged avenues in the city center, signs suggest that Mr. Basu and his colleagues have started not so much a revolution as a battle for the city's soul. Ho Chi Minh Street and others renamed by the Communists -- Lenin Street, Karl Marx Street -- testify to old loyalties, as do posters in the bazaars that urge Calcuttans to attend a pro-Cuba congress at which Mr. Basu denounced the United States "imperialism" against Fidel Castro.
But Socialist paraphernalia are dwarfed by billboard advertisements for mobile telephones and whisky and computer courses. And in a building close to the mansion from which Britain's governors general ruled India for 150 years, a close ally of Mr. Basu in the state's Communist hierarchy runs an investment promotion agency -- the West Bengal Industrial Development Corporation -- that many Westerners, including the United States Ambassador, Frank G. Wisner, regard as the best of its kind in India.
Anybody visiting Somnath Chatterjee, the agency's chairman, finds it harder to imagine India's retreating from the free-market reforms. Like Mr. Basu, Mr. Chatterjee can box like a champion on matters of ideology, arguing that the Soviet Union failed not because of repression and economic sclerosis but because, as he put it, "the entire world ganged up on Soviet Russia."
Mr. Chatterjee, 66, who has a second role heading the Communist bloc in the Parliament in New Delhi, greets visitors from behind a desk that would not look out of place in the Oval Office.
When asked how a Marxist adjusts to negotiating with executives from a roll-call of the world's blue-chip corporations -- Caltex, Matsushita, Motorola, Philips, Price Waterhouse, Rolls-Royce, Siemens -- that have signed tentative investment deals, Mr. Chatterjee smiled.
"I am a very practical person, like all Communists," he said. Perhaps with an eye to Communist Party stalwarts who have yet to reconcile to the changes, he added: "Inviting foreign capital is regretful. But from the viewpoint of the people's interests, there is no choice. I have no right to keep them poor."
Mr. Basu and Mr. Chatterjee -- indeed, just about anybody who discusses the matter in West Bengal -- acknowledges another motive. When Britain moved India's capital from Calcutta to New Delhi in 1912, and as late as the 1950's, when Bombay entered the era of rapid growth that has made it India's industrial and commercial powerhouse, Calcutta considered itself India's leading city. Today, after 20 years of shrinking production, it is a distant second to Bombay, but Mr. Basu is confident that "within a few years we will regain our old position."
But before the long climb back, the government will have to convince elements of its own constituency, particularly West Bengal's powerful labor unions, that free enterprise is the key to a better future.
Hundreds of other state-owned enterprises are bogged down by restrictive labor practises and red tape. Many have been technically bankrupt for years, unable to discipline or lay off workers; some, including factories with thousands of workers, have produced nothing at all in recent memory.
The Communist leaders also face an internal party struggle over the new policies. At the party headquarters here, posters of Stalin and Che Guevara adorn the walls. But despite talk of the "dictatorship of the proletariat" and "scientific socialism," there are signs that even the hard-liners have found ways to see old enemies in a new light.
"We are not inviting capitalism to West Bengal; we are inviting capital," said Anil Biswas, editor of the party's newspaper.
Reaching for a dog-eared copy of the Communist Manifesto, he turned to the section on capital and added triumphantly, "Read that, and you'll see that capitalism and capital are two entirely different things."

HEADLINE: Rejecting Elders' Pessimism, Students Jam Medical School

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Doctors in private practice complain about H.M.O.'s. Economists predict that doctors' incomes will fall and there will be fewer jobs for specialists. Physicians forbid their children to enter the field.
And yet, despite this loud, woeful chorus, American college students are stampeding the gates of medical schools in record numbers. Last year, 45,365 people applied to American medical schools, a record, and almost double the number eight years ago. This year, with the final count still out, that record has already been surpassed. 
 The surprising enthusiasm of young people training to become doctors, despite the upheaval in the field, is likely to accelerate and smooth over the transformation of American medicine, a process that so far been rocky.
Rather than war with health maintenance organizations and budget-minded legislators, medicine's next generation is entering the profession expecting to be part of a more cost-conscious medical system oriented to primary care and dominated by managed care. Many medical students say they will work for a salary. Doctors in training are already turning in growing numbers to careers in general medicine, forgoing the specialist's income and prestige.
"The young doctors today are the ones pushing the engine," said Mark Callahan, director of health services research at Cornell University Medical College. "They're receptive to change in a way no one had predicted."
Medical educators debate the causes for the rise in medical school applications, citing the relative security of medicine in a bleak job market or the gritty glamour cast on physicians by shows like "E.R." But many of the 16,000 men and women who this fall donned white coats and rolled back plastic sheets to face cadavers for the first time give a simpler explanation: They think it will be fulfilling and interesting to take care of sick people.
"A lot of us went into medicine for different reasons than doctors 10 years ago," said Jennifer Gonzalez, a first-year student at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. "Everyone knows there are going to be changes. We're not expecting high-paying jobs. I don't mind being forced into primary care. If you go into medicine now, your goal is not money or prestige but simply treating patients."
In dozens of interviews across the country, medical students said they were well aware of the gloomy projections -- hammered home by older doctors in their lecture halls each day. But for the most part, they say they do not share their colleagues' nostalgia for a world where doctors reigned supreme, a world of small practices and big incomes, a world they view as history.
"It's like when people say baseball isn't what it used to be, now that there are three divisions instead of two," said Robert Pratt, a first-year student at Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons. "That may be true. But this is the only game we know."
Medicine has always attracted young people with a desire to help others. But until recently that altruistic route was nicely paved with the promise of being your own boss and getting big money -- particularly for specialists -- and respect. Today those benefits have eroded, leaving many older doctors disaffected -- but many doctors-to-be undeterred.
 
'Dumbest Time,' Friends Warn
 When David Klemer, 39, quit his job as a tenured professor of engineering at the University of Texas to go to medical school this year, his friends were shocked.
"They said that this is the dumbest time in the history of medicine to do this," he said, three weeks into his first year of medical school, and still smiling. "But I wanted to do family practice. To make a difference in people's lives. Money didn't enter into the picture."
Several years ago, doctors' groups warned that the vast changes in health care policy would make the medical market so uncertain that the brightest students would be deterred from becoming doctors. That prophecy has proved unfounded.
"If anything it's getting more competitive," said Dr. Edward Hundert, associate dean for student affairs at Harvard Medical School. "A lot of us think: 'Thank God I'm not applying now because I wouldn't get in.' " For new medical students, the average score on the Medical College Admissions Test has risen steadily, as has their college grade point average, to 3.47, on the border of a B plus and an A minus.
Many students arrive at medical school today with Ph.D.'s or successes in previous careers, Dr. Hundert said. The median age among first-year students has risen almost to 25, up from 22 a decade ago. Forty-two percent are women, up from just over 30 percent in 1984.
Some medical students and educators link the rise in applications to a sense of public duty among young people, in contrast to the "me" focus a decade ago. "I think there's a trend with people wanting more of a connection with society, with doing something meaningful," said Jennifer Anderson, a first-year student at the University of Washington Medical School who said she hopes to practice in a rural area.
Dr. Hundert agreed, noting that entering medical students at Harvard were volunteering in droves for community service projects, like teaching sex education at inner city schools or reading books to children with cancer. Ten years ago, he said, they would have been scrambling to labs. "It may well be that there will be more of a service mentality, which would be a happy thing for medicine," he said.
Dr. Jordan J. Cohen, president of the American Association of Medical Colleges, added that advances in basic science -- and the way they are trumpeted on TV shows or the evening news -- have seduced idealistic young people, who imagine doling out new cures.
But some are more skeptical, saying the popularity is related less to the allure of medicine than to a slump in the economy. They note that new doctors, unlike new lawyers, still tend to have jobs. A recent paper by Dr. Donald Kassenbaum in the journal American Medicine concluded that a significant cause of the rise in applications was the poor job market for college graduates, propelling cautious students toward careers perceived as dependable.
 
Less Boot Camp In Medical Training
 "A lot of people go to college wanting to be either a doctor or a lawyer -- and being a lawyer has a really bad reputation now," said Sacha St. Hill, a first-year student at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, in Newark, who said she wanted to be a doctor, regardless of status or pay.
All agree, however, that reforms in medical training and practice, which have reduced the sacrifices required, have bolstered the trend. Medical schools have de-emphasized rote memorization. Residencies have largely eliminated the requirement of spending every other night in the hospital, an existence part monk and part commando. Many hospitals and H.M.O.'s offer physicians part-time options, attractive to doctors with young children.
"If you're going to have a professional career, medicine allows for the greatest flexibility of life style, particularly in certain types of practice," said Jaymi Fermaglich, a first-year student at Einstein, interested in bioethics. "I have friends who are investment bankers. They work 80 hours and have no control."
Many medical students felt they had little in common with their older colleagues and were by turns amused and annoyed at the ever-present diatribes about the fall of medicine. Students at the New Jersey medical school laughed as they recalled a lecturer who started with a cartoon making fun of H.M.O.'s, and repeated his hatred for managed care 10 more times in an hour.
A number of students acknowledged that the medical system was in dire need of reform. "A lot of the decisions are being taken away from the physician -- what procedures to perform, and how much to charge," said Rachel D. St. John, a student at Virginia Commonwealth University. "It's frustrating, but it needs to be done. It's not working now -- we're not serving the entire public."
Practicing doctors complain bitterly that they must answer to employers, insurers, consumer groups and H.M.O.'s. But these constraints are not nearly as disturbing to medical students, who may have already had extensive contact with H.M.O.'s.
Randall Finley, a first-year student at Einstein, is a doctor's son. But his father, a pediatric gastroenterologist, works for Kaiser-Permanente, a large H.M.O. in California, where H.M.O.'s are the norm. "I haven't made up my mind about H.M.O.'s, but the fact that I don't have to do any of the business side is attractive to me," he said. "All of the doctors I know in H.M.O.'s -- my father's friends -- are happy there."
Almost 25 percent of entering medical students last year said they preferred to be employees, seeing patients for a salary. That percentage has risen steadily for the last eight years.
 
'I Want the Freedom To Do What I Want'
 "Working for someone else and having set hours means you can have a family and a little more free time," said Michele Puszkarczuk, a first-year student at the New Jersey medical school, whose interest in medicine started with putting Band-Aids on dolls as a toddler.
Nonetheless, she said: "I am worried that you won't be able to have control over your patients." Other students worried that their choice of specialty or job might be limited.
Joseph Helft, a first-year student at Einstein, has his heart set on private practice, like that of his father, a general surgeon. He worries that his dream is in jeopardy. "I see working for an H.M.O. as being low down in a big company where you can't make decisions," he said. "I want the freedom to do what I want to do and to specialize in whatever I want. But when I see how fed up my father is, it's scary."
Declining salaries, which have caused problems for older doctors -- with mortgages and children in private school -- are also less troubling to new applicants, who expect medicine to yield a comfortable income, if not the million-dollar practices that some specialists now enjoy.
"Going from $400,000 to probably $120,000 or lowest, $80,000, is not exactly a tragedy," said Jean Paul Rommes, who was an engineer until he entered medical school at the University of Texas this fall. "It's all relative. Eighty thousand is a great salary in most people's minds." He and other students expressed confidence medicine would remain a stable career.
Most students who were interviewed said their families were pleased with their decision to go to medical school. But all agreed that the letter of acceptance was no longer an occasion marked by celebrations and the bragging of grandparents. Many said they had to defend the choice to friends or family.
Stephan Chimosky, 30, gave up a career as a computer consultant to enter medical school this year, despite attempts by his father, a physician, to dissuade him. "I had a well-established career and I had a lot of counseling not to change from family members," said Mr. Chimosky, an M.B.A. who is now a student at the University of Washington.
Although many doctors say they do not want their children to enter the field, the fraction of new medical students whose parents are physicians -- about 16 percent -- is unchanged. And a number of students from medical families said that their parents were supportive.
"A lot of my father's friends say to him 'How can you let your son go to medical school?' " said Chris Morse, a first-year student at Columbia, whose father and grandfather are urologists. "My father's had to make a lot of adjustments, but he's educated me that medicine is changing and it's not so bad. What other job can you see interesting things and change people's lives?"
Next: The shift to primary care.

HEADLINE: Riders on the Storm

 BODY:
The O. J. Simpson case has produced a hot blast of racial disaffection in the country, and no one should be surprised that charlatans of all hues want to use that blast to lift unworthy careers and causes to new heights. Similarly, it is no surprise that Louis Farrakhan is foremost among the callous self-promoters. It is also unsurprising that the Rev. Benjamin Chavis Jr., whose disgraceful behavior almost wrecked the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, should have signed on as director of Mr. Farrakhan's Million Man March.
These two black men have this in common with the white racists of the previous generation. They want to prolong and exploit the nation's racial divisions. Yet their cunning invocations of black family stability and of a potent symbolic event, the 1963 March on Washington, have tended to make people of conscience overly timid about criticizing either their contrived event or the twisted Farrakhan ideology that it is intended to promote. 
 In endorsing the march, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the Black Congressional Caucus have foolishly let a misguided solidarity about the march's public goals divert their attention from the ideas and character of its leader. Mary Frances Berry, chairwoman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, has correctly diagnosed Mr. Farrakhan's pathology as racist, sexist, anti-Semitic and homophobic.
The coalition of black feminists led by Angela Davis and Jewell Jackson McCabe emphasized one of the many dangers inherent in this march. They labeled the march's message that it is "time for men to step forward and women to step back" as an insult to 400 years of burden-sharing by black men and women.
It is understandable that many black Americans will be tempted to overlook Mr. Farrakhan's separatism and Mr. Chavis's financial and personal peccadilloes because of a shared concern about drugs, unstable families, unemployment and violence. But they should realize that Mr. Farrakhan intends to use their support to aggrandize himself and the Nation of Islam. There has been a lot of talk about apples and trees lately. Everyone must recognize that only poisoned apples can fall from Mr. Farrakhan's tree.
In the last few days, even as his mainstream allies tried to buff up Mr. Farrakhan for national consumption or downplay his involvement, the man and his minions have become ever more flagrant in their racist self-promotion. In an interview released by Reuters on Friday, Mr. Farrakhan asserted that Jews, Arabs, Koreans and Vietnamese doing business in black communities are "bloodsuckers." On Thursday, Mr. Farrakhan's chief of staff told a press conference that those who march will be showing that they personally support Mr. Farrakhan and that they look to him as a national leader.
But contempt for the leaders of the march must not lead to any kind of national denial about the underlying realities of race in America. Prejudice remains a historic, thematic problem in American politics and law. The behavior of the Los Angeles police, the ceaseless Beltway war against Government programs that benefit minorities, the commercial excesses of the O. J. industry all attest to the continuing need for healing leadership. The way ahead will be made rougher by talk shows, tabloids and, if recent events are an indicator, perhaps by Mr. Simpson's delusional campaign for some kind of public approbation.
None of that changes one truth that serves this moment. No matter how many well-meaning citizens he can mislead on any given day, Mr. Farrakhan remains a symptom of our ills, not a physician who can heal them.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Tiger in Wait

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
We grew up in the shadow of Fort Stevens, where Lincoln in his frock coat dodged the bullets of Jubal Early's Confederate troops in the battle that saved the capital.
You might say we grew up in the shadow of union. Cynthia and Deborah were my best friends and next-door neighbors. Though they were black and I was white, the significance of the fort escaped us. But it was a good place to go sledding. 
 In those days, we did not need sensitivity training. We had the same desires and disappointments. We played Double Dutch. (Now we would be accused of offending the Dutch.) We snitched the key to my dad's Seth Thomas to tighten our roller skates. We snuck in to see Vincent Price in "The Fall of the House of Usher."
Later, I would understand there were problems. I remember the fight the nuns waged when an amusement park did not want to let the black kids in our class come to a picnic. (They came. Never bet against nuns.) As children, we treated each other with maturity. As adults, we learned to be childish, to pick up and keep up tribal resentments. As the song from "South Pacific" goes, "You've got to be taught to hate and fear, to hate all the people your relatives hate."
Affirmative action has brought the sexes and races into the same room, but with wariness about who might get ahead. Just as men and women in the workplace circle each other, so do blacks and whites. If the sexes can't communicate clearly, why should it be simple for different races?
In the wake of the Simpson verdict, with the polarizing images of black thrills and white chills, and on the eve of the Million Man March, led by a man who peddles racial and religious divisions to promote himself, whites and blacks suddenly seem frozen in a split screen of resentment and incomprehension.
But is it so sudden? Or had we lived and played apart for so long that we lost track of how different our experiences and thoughts and perceptions of progress were?
The truth is that Washington has never become truly integrated. Whites cluster west of Rock Creek Park, in tony neighborhoods like Cleveland Park and Georgetown. Blacks live on the other side of the park, in nice middle-class neighborhoods, and beyond, in the dangerous, desolate places that are not listed on the tourist maps. We work together, but then, mostly, we retreat to separate worlds.
I went back to Rittenhouse Street, where it had seemed so easy to understand how blacks looked at the world, to see how they felt about the march and this split screen of O. J. Simpson and Mark Fuhrman.
(The truth is that the racist detective was my worst nightmare, too. My father was also a police detective. As a reporter, I avoided working on any stories about police brutality or corruption. I couldn't bear to know about bad cops poisoning the quiet bravery of good cops.)
I talked to Kelvin Tabbs, a 22-year-old college student in a Raiders cap, who said that white liberals are upset about the Farrakhan march because "they do not have the power to control blacks and choose their leaders.
"All these white people say, 'Don't blame me for what my forefathers did.' But they're missing the point. It's still going on, but it's a hidden agenda. I'm an ex-football player, a big black guy. Every time I walk into a store, people look at me suspiciously until I smile and start talking. We don't judge whites by the way they look, even if we see a guy who looks like Jesse Helms coming down the street."
Ray Thompson, a 40-year-old Navy veteran who is an electromagnetic signal analyst, was unpacking fishing gear from his car. He knows that Louis Farrakhan has a divisive message, but he thinks blacks need to hear his credo of economic independence. "Sometimes it seems that racism is like violence, a circle that has no beginning and no end," he said, softly. "People taking revenge for actions against them, or perceived actions, or historical actions. It's like Bosnia. Where does it end? When do we say: Both sides are guilty -- let's stop and move forward from here?"
He thinks that if we can talk to each other, instead of about each other, coded racism can be uncoded. "It's like a tiger lying out there, hiding behind the bushes," he said. "I'd rather know the tiger is there. That way, I may stand some chance of dealing with it effectively."

HEADLINE: Clinton Asks Men to Pledge Never to Strike Any Woman

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton called on the nation's men today to pledge to "never, never lift a hand against a woman for as long as we live."
Mr. Clinton, who as a youngster intervened to stop his stepfather from beating his mother, made the appeal "not just as a president, or a father or a husband, but also as a son who has seen domestic violence first hand." 
 The President, in his weekly radio address, said the Republican-controlled Congress was bent on reducing the Government's domestic-violence programs by $50 million, hampering "our efforts to protect battered women and their children, to preserve families and to punish these crimes."
Mr. Clinton's overall message appeared aimed at people upset at O. J. Simpson's acquittal last week on charges of murdering his ex-wife and her friend. Mr. Simpson has admitted that he battered Mrs. Simpson.
On Monday, in a speech at the University of Texas in Austin, Mr. Clinton is set to address the racial divisions highlighted by the Simpson trial.
The speech coincides not only with the debate over the Simpson verdict but with Monday's rally of black men in Washington.
"I imagine he will address the need to bring Americans together and to shun those who advocate hate," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary.
Mr. Clinton has also remained focused on his budget battle with Congress.
And in a speech Friday night in Williamsburg, Va., he appealed to the chief executives of the nation's 100 largest corporations, all members of the Business Council, to broker an "honorable compromise" with Congress.
"The only thing I won't do," Mr. Clinton said. "I will not let balancing the budget serve as a cover for destroying the social compact; for cutting back on education, wrecking the environment or undermining our obligations to help protect our children and treat our elderly people decently because it is not necessary to balance the budget."
Delivering the weekly Republican radio address, Senator Pete Domenici of New Mexico took exception to Mr. Clinton's criticism of Republican budget cuts.
"America's budget deficit is growing at a rate of $482 million a day, but President Clinton won't support the balanced budget plan because he says balancing the budget in seven years is too fast," Mr. Domenici said. "It's not too fast for the unemployed, or underemployed, who can't get good work because of the deficit's stifling effect on job creation."
In his own radio address, Mr. Clinton noted that his Administration's crime bill, voted into law last year, also included the Violence Against Women Act, which he said combined sanctions against abusers with aid to the police, prosecutors and shelters.
But he said government alone could not prevail.
"The real solution to this problem starts with us, with our personal responsibility and a simple pledge that we will never, never lift a hand against a woman for as long as we live," the President said.

 CORRECTION:
