SECTION: Section 2; Page 49; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1188 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Lifting the Sights of a Neighborhood Tired and Low

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
WHEN IT COMES TO MEDIA coverage of Los Angeles, the rule seems to be: if you bash it, they will come; if you build it, they'll stay away in droves. Stage an earthquake, ignite a riot, and it will make the cover of Time magazine. But where are the helicopters, the television cameras, the real-time, live-action coverage that in a less topsy-turvy world would allow us to watch the completion of a new building by Eric Owen Moss?
From the roof of the Samitaur Building, the most recent project by this brilliant 52-year-old Los Angeles architect, you can spot Fedco and other stores in the South-Central section that were looted during the 1992 riots after the verdict in the Rodney King beating. Then, plumes of smoke curled toward the sky as dusk crept over the city, and across the country, people were glued to their television screens trying to figure out what was going on. 
 Today, at the corner of Corbett Street and Jefferson Boulevard, it's clear that at least three things are going on. Samitaur is a football-field-length office building dramatically raised 21 feet off the ground by a long row of round steel columns. Beyond that, the building is a vote of confidence by Frederick Smith, the developer, in a part of town that has become synonymous with urban unrest. And not least, it's a prototype for an ambitious idea that Moss and Smith have been promoting for several years: a half-mile urban-renewal project designed to boost the civic profile of South-Central.
A.R. City (for Air Rights City), as the plan is called, would make use of the space (air rights) above an abandoned spur of the Southern Pacific Railroad that loops through Culver City along the edge of South-Central. The spur was originally built to pick up freight from manufacturers once clustered in this district of low-rise industrial sheds. Now, the spur serves mainly as a reminder that industry has dispersed, much of it gone overseas in search of cheap labor. And the rail cut itself stands as a symbol of the economic disparities that divide this city.
Moss's A.R. City plan is designed to mend the tear in the urban fabric and also to reverse the area's economic decline. The rail cut would be converted into a linear park with trees, seating, pedestrian walkways and recreational areas. The strip would be punctuated by buildings raised over it on steel trusses. These would house theaters and other cultural organizations as well as commercial tenants. Combining elements of the traditional urban park with the suburban industrial park, A.R. City would be, in effect, a post-industrial park for a forward-looking city.
The Samitaur (named after his development company) could be a prototype for the kinds of buildings Mr. Smith envisions. Situated a few blocks from the rail spur, it hovers over a driveway that runs between a warehouse with corrugated metal walls and a squat brick building that once housed machine shops. It was designed to foster the coexistence of light industry with upscale enterprises -- design studios, small movie-production companies -- that have gravitated to Culver City in recent years. In theory, the purpose of raising the building was to let trucks continue to service the industrial tenants. But these tenants have gone and given the present economy, it is likely that offices will eventually be housed in the building's ground-floor spaces.
 MOSS'S MAIN GOAL, however, in raising the building was to provide visual excitement. Many of his most important projects are interior renovations. While stunningly inventive, they are often invisible from the street. At Samitaur, Moss lifts his architecture emphatically into the public domain. And the building's muscular upward push is part of the message Moss wants to share.
The long, bar-shaped building, connected at one end to a renovated industrial shed, has stucco walls the color of weathered copper. A grid of thin steel strips divides the stucco into square panels, enlivening the flat surface with glints of silvery light. Square, punched-out windows echo the grid.
On the street side of the building, an outdoor staircase is molded into a flamboyant whirl of plastic form; Moss calls it "the pumpkin." The teethlike cut of the stairs, the empty window sockets, evoke a jack-o'-lantern visage. The top of the pumpkin is carved into a bowl shape with a rim that frames a disk of southern California sky. When a plane flies overhead, bisecting the disk, it's a reminder that this is a legendary city of people who came hoping to find things looking up.
Halfway down the building's length, there's another boldly articulated stair. Here, water will splash down from the roof into a pool, while an opening in the wall reveals an urban panorama surprisingly like a seascape: the rounded roofs of the disheveled old factories appear to roll toward the Samitaur like waves of rust.
The Samitaur will make an excellent landmark; but a half-mile-long loop of city laid out by Eric Owen Moss? Isn't that just another architect's wild utopian dream? Is it even desirable? Like it or not, the dream isn't that farfetched. Smith and Moss have already remade a number of old factory sheds along National Boulevard in Culver City. Besides reversing a declining part of the city, their efforts have produced some of the most vigorous architecture of our time.
But does it portend anything affirmative for the residents of South-Central? Or would the invasion of upscale businesses into impoverished, predominantly black neighborhoods simply further displace an already marginalized population? I confess that Eric Moss's work inspires me with a sense of optimism that I can't justify by empirical evidence. Cleaner streets, a lower crime rate, a higher standard of living: there's no proof that design per se can improve an urban environment in material terms.
But are these the only, the best, standards with which to measure a building's impact? In his book "Emotional Intelligence," Daniel Goleman argues that optimism produces measurable rewards. It improves performance; it is contagious; it can make the difference between win or lose. Moss gives form to similar ideas. His optimism isn't naive.
The Samitaur does not turn away from its depressed surroundings. On the contrary, the design's emphasis on providing views of the city gives you a clear sense of where you are. And A.R. City depicts no serenely humming modern Utopia. The plan's fragmented, incrementally pieced-together cityscape doesn't exclude uncertainty, or even doubt. But it pushes past ambivalence. It suggests that a picture of hope may be harder to construct than an image of despair, but that the ingredients for both are in sight.
Goleman hopes that one day schools will offer courses in emotional intelligence. Moss's projects strike me as such a form of education. The knowing spontaneity of his forms, the hands-on approach implicit in their strong, sculptural contours, the relationship they describe between a city's vitality and the creative potential of its individuals: these coalesce into tangible lessons about how a city should face its future.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 29, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 15 about a Los Angeles urban renewal project known as A.R. City and about one of its components, the Samitaur Building, misstated their locations within the city. The project is intended for an area of Culver City adjacent to Baldwin Hills, not for South-Central. The Samitaur Building is situated in an unnamed district of Los Angeles between Culver City and Baldwin Hills, a site of riots after the Rodney King verdict in 1992 -- also not in South-Central.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 51; Column 5; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3869 words

HEADLINE: The Reopening of the Frontier

BYLINE: By JON MARGOLIS; Jon Margolis is a former national political correspondent for The Chicago Tribune and now lives in Vermont.

 BODY:
JOHN MURPHY'S GRANDFATHER HELPED CONQUER the frontier.
That earlier John Murphy had tree-claimed -- planted 10 acres of trees in return for 160 acres of North Dakota farmland -- in 1882, two years after the United States Census counted 37 people in Foster County, not even 1 for each 10 of its 450 square miles. 
 That made it "unsettled." By the census bureau's reckoning, Foster County needed 900 folks to even be considered a "frontier settlement," and it needed 2,700 -- 6 per square mile -- to emerge from frontier status altogether. It got there by 1900, 29 years before the present John Murphy was born on that same farm, outside what had become the thriving village of Bordulac, N.D.
"I went to school right here," says Murphy. He was driving a visitor out to his farm, slowing down as he approached what remains of the settlement -- a grain elevator, a small bar and a few white frame homes. "We had our own school district, all the way through high school. By then, my father had the farm, and it was a few hundred acres."
It's now a few thousand acres and there are no schools in Bordulac and no businesses except a grain elevator and a small bar. Murphy turned 1 year old when Foster County's population peaked at 6,353 in 1930. It's been going down ever since, to 3,983 in 1990 -- 8.6 per square mile and falling. Simply put, the frontier is coming back.
While hardly anyone was paying attention, something quite extraordinary happened to a huge swath of the United States: it emptied out. In five states of the Great Plains, there are more counties with fewer than six persons per square mile than there were in 1920. In Kansas, such counties cover more territory than they did in 1890, when the census inspired Frederick Jackson Turner's celebrated and controversial essay about the passing of the frontier. Even the number of counties with fewer than two persons per square mile is on the rise. There were six such counties in North Dakota in 1990; some experts think there may be as many as 20 in the year 2000.
What remains of human settlement in the rural Great Plains is a Federal welfare project, sustained by Government farm programs and even more by Social Security and Medicare. This is the country of lonely old women, the widows who don't want to move South and whose children have gone elsewhere to find jobs. There are small towns in western Kansas, in the Dakotas and in the Oklahoma panhandle where nothing thrives except the drugstore and the clinic, if there is one. Or maybe an "antiques" shop where the merchandise is really the detritus of several attics, and the proprietors are an elderly couple who don't have anything better to do.
White settlers defeated -- all but extinguished -- the wilderness, the American Indians and the buffalo. Now the descendants of those conquerors find themselves besieged by an unusual alliance -- nature and technology.
"A hundred-sixty acres was never big enough for this country, even back then," Murphy says. He is driving just past his farm now, along broad, level fields newly seeded with spring wheat, the earth still black with an occasional hint of light-green fuzz. Beyond the fields is a line of trees, their darker green leaves almost gray under a dreary sky. Beyond the timberline are more fields, stretching farther than the eye can see. Whatever this country may be short of, it is not space.
What it is often short of is moisture. This is east of the hundredth meridian, but just barely, and annual rainfall is not much above the semiarid level. "With the machinery we have today, the chemicals and all, even 1,000 acres is really too small," Murphy says. "You need a sizable operation these days just to pay for the machinery you need to farm all that land."
So every year there are fewer farmers, meaning fewer customers for the local stores, hence fewer stores and fewer towns. Bordulac is gone and Barlow, up in the northwest corner of the county, is going. As he explains this, Murphy drives past an abandoned farmstead. At first glance, it looks like a silhouette against the gray sky. That there are only a handful of such relics does not mean that the farms are thriving; it means local folks scavenge the lumber.
"THERE USED TO BE 27 BUSINESSES HERE," SAYS PAUL KLINDWORTH. He sits behind the counter of a little grocery store that he manages, one of the last three businesses left in Hamberg. "I have a picture of all the businesspeople here somewhere. I could show you."
But he doesn't seem anxious to rise from his chair; there is something about Hamberg that breeds torpor. This is a frontier outpost that has fallen, but in this different kind of war the vanquished are permitted to live on in occupied territory. Three of the remaining residents are Klindworths and four are Schneiders, including two of Mrs. Sylling's grandchildren, who go to school in Maddock, some 20 miles up the road in the next county. It takes them "close to an hour" each way, she says.
"But there used to be a school here. There it is up on the hill. This used to be quite a town."
Whether Hamberg was ever quite a town is a question of taste. It was at its largest -- 187 souls -- in the 1920 census. That there was a school of some substance is unmistakable. Its remains are indeed visible up on the hill, bestriding it in graceful but forlorn grandeur. At one time, the school dominated the town, a symbol of the people's faith in the future. In a sense, it dominates the town still.
In fact, there is nothing unusual in Hamberg about abandoned buildings. That's most of what Hamberg is. More than half of the 30 or so houses stand empty, most for so long that they are now uninhabitable. They stand, many of them, behind lilac bushes on the few flat, wide streets of the town.
"Bozo owns lots of them," Klindworth says. "He owns the school, too, just for the lumber. He doesn't want to sell any of these places. Bozo, he gets something old, a house or a car, he just doesn't want to sell it." Bozo, Klindworth explains, is his brother Clarence, the owner of Earl's Bar, one of the other two businesses in town. The third is the meat locker owned by Mrs. Sylling's son-in-law.
Clarence Klindworth was not around to explain why he would not sell any of his houses, nor to explain why, at age 66, he has recently started to go dancing, at least according to Mrs. Sylling, a widow of about the same age. He has not, she says, gone dancing with her. "I'm too old," she says, implying with little subtlety that she thought he was, too. Whether this is self-knowledge or resentment at not being invited is no doubt a subject of some discussion in town, but it cannot be conclusively determined here, and neither Clarence Klindworth nor Earl's Bar has a telephone. Clearly, though, Klindworth does not see much need to try to revive Hamberg. Neither does Orella Sylling.
"It's great here," she says. She works part time at the post office, and while she acknowledges that she doesn't have much of a social life, she does have a superb garden -- corn, beans, radishes, beets and onions -- and the garden, her yard and her grandchildren keep her busy.
"This place is big enough for me," she says. "I would have liked to live all my life on a farm. I could never live in a bigger town."
Not to worry. What is happening in Hamberg and scores of small Plains towns is nothing less than the unsettling of the West or at least part of it, the reversal of that process so central to a thousand movies and the nation's sense of itself. Besides economic growth and technological progress in this country, the winning of the West symbolizes the nation's expansive optimism and its commitment to civilized order.
Maybe the country will have to reassess itself. Depopulation of the rural Great Plains has been going on for decades. Now begins its endgame -- the disintegration of local institutions. Even towns bigger than Hamberg are withering, and rural counties are becoming too empty to continue as separate entities. If enough of them become that empty, at some point someone will ask this question: Is North Dakota necessary?
 "IT ISN'T A STUPID QUESTION," SAYS RICHARD RATHGE, THE director of the North Dakota State Data Center in Fargo. Not that it's likely to happen, Rathge insists. But it has been discussed.
How could it not be? Rathge's center projects that by 2010 there will be about 627,000 North Dakotans, some 9,000 fewer than there are now, despite healthy growth in the Red River Valley (Fargo and Grand Forks), which are not really part of the Great Plains, and stability in Minot and Bismarck. So the rural areas will become even emptier.
Rathge's numbers might be optimistic. He assumes that the state's two air bases will survive and that some new business ventures will succeed. Make just a few pessimistic assumptions and what looms in 2010 is a state of fewer than 600,000. That's bigger than Wyoming or Vermont and not much smaller than South Dakota. But those states are growing. And they are growing in more than one region; even South Dakota has a thriving metropolis at each end -- spiffy Sioux Falls in the east and funky Rapid City in the west. If North Dakota loses many more rural residents, almost half the population would live in the state's eastern fringe. Much of the other half would be in Minot, if the air base does not fall victim to world peace, and around Bismarck, but only because the state government is there.
So who needs a state government? What about having one Dakota? Or how about letting Minnesota annex the Red River Valley -- culturally it's Minnesotan anyway -- and let the other neighbors divide the hinterlands?
Better yet, spin off the sparsely settled stretches of both Dakotas and Nebraska and Kansas, along with the equally empty eastern stretches of Montana, Wyoming and Colorado, and let it all revert to territorial status. Now there's a step that would neatly symbolize the victory of the new frontier and the inversion of the winning of the West -- decommission a state or two and make some of the continental United States a territory again.
Ed Schafer has heard this discussion before. He sips from his can of Coke, smiles a bit quizzically and while he calmly explains why he does not think this will happen, he does not argue that it is impossible. This is not without significance because Schafer is the Governor of North Dakota, and governors are not accustomed to discussing the possible demise of their states.
"Well, what's the appropriate time?" he asks. "I refuse to design a government here for the option of people giving up. To throw in the towel and say, 'Let's design a government that works for 600,000 people and forget it.' Our role is to provide the atmosphere and the arena of performance so that people live and work here."
The Governor, a Republican of the moderate school, can discuss the dismantling of his state with a certain detachment because it is hardly imminent. In fact, it's all quite unlikely. Under the Constitution, abolition requires a vote by a state's legislators, who would thus be voting themselves out of a job. This is not the customary behavior of state legislators. As a formal entity, North Dakota is probably safe. As a society, it could die.
OF COURSE, THAT WON'T HAPPEN IF FOSTER COUNTY AND places like it start growing again, which is what will happen if John Murphy has anything to say about it. He does. He's the chairman of the County Commissioners, and from his office in the stately domed county courthouse in Carrington, he acts as commanding officer of the cavalry that is fighting the latest and probably last American frontier war.
If Foster County can't prevail, it's hard to think of a rural county on the Great Plains that can. Compared with most others, Foster County has a lot going for it -- energetic young people, a modern hospital and a new motel. And thanks to an intense local effort that Murphy helped orchestrate, Carrington is home to the Dakota Growers Pasta Company mill, a $40 million hunk of concrete, pipes, oven dryers, computers and 200 employees.
This, according to the experts, is exactly what North Dakota needs. It's "economic development," it's "diversification" and it's "value-added," the new buzzwords of the West. Why should rural areas just raise the raw material for others to process? If they could process it right at the source, they'd keep the jobs and the money here, and that would save the region.
Up to a point, John Gardner agrees.
"The pasta plant fits into the region and its role," he says. "We grow food."
Gardner is another officer in the army of the frontier. He and his wife, Julie, live in the Putnam House, which they bought in 1991 for $52,000. It sits right on Main Street, commanding the city's portals, a huge American four-square with pillars. T.N. Putnam, a founding father of the town, built it in 1907. A few years ago, somebody was going to take it away, jack it up on a truck and haul it to Jamestown, about 45 miles away.
"This was in the late 80's, at the depths of disillusionment around here," Gardner says. "Taking that house would have taken something significant from the town."
He's an agricultural scientist, the director of the North Dakota State University Research Extension Center in Carrington. That's where John Murphy and a group of other energetic folks first met to plan their campaign to attract the pasta mill.
Gardner was all for it. "It was good for the local economy," he says, "and it was good for the people to do it." Three big corporations make most of America's domestic pasta. "To challenge that structure, that's empowering."
To Gardner, the process was as important as the jobs it produced. He's all for economic development, diversification and value-added. He knows they are necessary. But he knows they are not enough.
It's a message that is starting to be accepted, grudgingly, in these parts.
"THIS LITTLE TOWN ISN'T IN SUCH BAD SHAPE," JOHN MURPHY says. He is guiding his 1979 Buick up Carrington's wide, straight Main Street to the grain elevator, three gray towers with reddish-orange and rust-brown piping crisscrossing among them. The elevator is where Main Street crosses the railroad tracks. The other, smaller businesses lie mostly to the east.
"You see, all these stores are occupied," Murphy says. "It wasn't like that a few years ago. The farm economy had been depressed and that attitude, it gets a little bit contagious. Getting that pasta mill, that changed the whole mental attitude around here."
Sounds easy. Attract a new plant, perk up the town and revive the rural Great Plains. As it turns out, it isn't that easy, and the very fact that some people think otherwise shows that old fantasies die hard.
This region has long been plagued by the delusion that some economic miracle would transform the rural West into a garden. Once, people here were convinced that "rain follows the plow," as though cultivating the land would seed the clouds. There are still some who believe that the small farm can revive, or that coal and oil deposits in the western Dakotas will attract thousands, or that "telecommunications" (the folks who call you up during dinner to sell you another credit card) will save the prairies.
But it doesn't add up. It was admirable the way everyone in Carrington worked to attract the pasta co-op. It would be nice to conclude that it will keep Foster County from sinking below frontier-level population density. It might. Most likely it won't.
First of all, the plant could fail. "This is the best start-up I've ever been involved in," says Tim Dodd, who runs the Dakota Growers Pasta Company. But he is under no illusions. "We feel like we're going to succeed. But like any new company, there's risk involved."
Let's say it succeeds, grows, has 250 or 300 employees in another five years. That's what Rathge assumed when he made a population projection for Foster County, and he projected more decline -- from the 1990 figure of 3,983 to 3,165 in 2010, or just about 7 people per square mile.
And this is just one county. Are there enough value-added enterprises to turn around the population decline in 40 rural counties?
"No, I'm afraid not," says Larry Leistritz, an agricultural economist at North Dakota State University in Fargo. Leistritz is a firm believer in value-added cooperatives. He's helping start them. He knows they aren't enough.
That's because all these local efforts cannot outweigh the national and global factors that will hurt the region. Lower farm subsidies, for instance. The great farmland would not be harmed. But most of that is in Illinois or eastern Iowa. "A lot of the Great Plains is on the margin of whether you want to farm it or not," Leistritz says. "We probably plowed up a lot of land that never should have been plowed."
A result of the impending reductions in Federal farm subsidies is that some marginal land will be converted from grain to grazing. So what happens to the land now used for grazing? "Central Wyoming," Leistritz says, "probably gets left to the antelope."
Central Wyoming and perhaps a bit of Kansas, Nebraska and the Dakotas. Maybe the Great Plains were simply destined to become emptier. Maybe Frank and Deborah Popper had a point when they wrote that depopulation should be encouraged so that the area could be transformed into a national eco-park, a "buffalo commons," a term that still enrages Dakotans even though the Poppers have amended their proposal. No one has yet suggested giving the Plains back to the Indians. But it's a thought.
Or maybe there's one other possibility, a kind of economic development that is not economic development as the term is usually understood.
WHEN JOHN AND JULIE Gardner bought the Putnam House, they didn't live in it. They made it the headquarters of a nonprofit local cultural society, with the idea that the group would buy it. (It never did -- the cultural society decided that buying the house would be too risky.) There were concerts, recitals, art exhibitions and literary discussions, and in a town with no bookstore or art gallery, the cultural society was a hit. It still is, even though the Gardners now live in the house.
 No, the Gardners do not expect Carrington to turn into the Athens of the Plains. But they do suspect that their frontier war will be won, if at all, as much by culture as by cultivation. This might seem absurd. But it's less absurd than believing that a few pasta plants will repopulate the prairie.
The Gardners and some others have figured out that the people who are here will stay and that others will come only if they want to; that what the Great Plains really have to offer is something intangible. It isn't that grain and pasta are unimportant. It's that agriculture is more than just growing crops. "A farm community," Gardner says, "is both -- farms and a community."
And the real attraction, he says, is "the landscape, the social structure, the way of life. Those are the things that make people want to live here." Value-added and economic development are not the modern versions of rain follows the plow. They are necessary, as are the lignite coal and the oil in western North Dakota and the telecommunications companies that have brought a few thousand jobs to the state.
But they aren't enough. Taken together, they can't make up for all the jobs lost by farm consolidation and labor-saving technology. People will return to the rural Great Plains only if they want to live here.
Here? Where it's 100 degrees in July and 30 below in January? Where there is neither a mountain range nor a forest worthy of the name, in the only state along the nation's northern border that lacks a trout stream? This is not, as Richard Rathge puts it, one of the "amenity areas." The people who can work at home with a modem, or who can run a small company out of a little building anywhere that has a good phone hookup -- they aren't coming here. They're going to Montana, the Ozarks, the Carolinas or northern New England. Who would come here?
Well, maybe you would. Think about it for a minute, some of you who live in places that are too crowded. There are places that are too empty. America could use some population redistribution. Consider the possibility that you are a Plains person.
Start your own trend -- rural North Dakota chic. For about $40,000 you can buy a very nice house in Carrington. Drive 13 miles west to Sykeston and there's a beauty for $16,000. Or try Hamberg. Get three or four friends or relatives, talk Bozo into selling and buy up half the town. Then you won't be lonely. And at those prices, you'd have plenty of money left for a big satellite dish and high-resolution television, for occasional trips to places where you could see a big-league ball game, a good show and a restaurant meal that was not a hunk of beef. The infrastructure is there. North Dakota has all the latest wiring and switches, not to mention good roads.
What would you get? Clean air, good schools, no crime, no traffic jams, people who are so friendly that it takes some getting used to. A life surrounded by austere and haunting beauty. A sense of tradition, here in the state where Teddy Roosevelt discovered the West, here in the home of great Americans -- Eric Sevareid, Lawrence Welk, Roger Maris.
You'd get space, endless acres of rolling prairie, on which wheat is grown, livestock graze and deer abound. Where ducks by the tens of thousands nest in sloughs in the spring, where they and the snow geese fly overhead in the fall. They are shootable, by shotgun for a month in autumn, by lens all year long.
 O.K., THE BEAUTY OF THE PLAINS IS AN ACQUIRED TASTE. "We lack a certain charisma," Leistritz admits. At first, the prairie may seem flat and monotonous. But look again. It undulates. Yes, all is green in the spring and brown in the winter, but those are different shades of green and brown, as there are different species of swallow and owl, duck and goose. More closely examined, this is a land rich in natural variety.
Human variety, too. More than anything else, what the immigrant to the rural Great Plains would gain is a certain sense of community, the kind that is fading elsewhere, the kind in which you have to participate. "At first, it might seem a bit stark," Gardner says. "But the winters here are a wonderful time for creativity, for introspection, for getting to know people."
And whether or not your friends followed you, you would be on the cutting edge of a trend. Because as it turns out, rural North Dakota is not the only place trying to deal with the transformation of an economy, and a society, in which producing material necessities has become insufficient for prosperity. Wheat farmers are no different from auto workers, loggers and mill hands. The world simply does not need as many of them as it once did.
No, the Great Plains are not alone in facing this change. It's just that the choices are a bit starker out here, making it harder to hide from the realities. Maybe rural North Dakota is as good a harbinger of the future -- its dangers and promise -- as you can find.
It's . . . well, it's a whole new frontier.

HEADLINE: In Arizona Politics, a Personal Fiscal Crisis

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Despite his name, J. Fife Symington 3d, and his social pedigree as a great-grandson of the New York coal baron Henry Clay Frick, the saga of Arizona's Governor sounds more like South America than Southwest United States.
In September, a few weeks after celebrating his 50th birthday in London and Paris, Governor Symington came home to this desert capital to declare that he was unable to pay nearly $25 million in debts. 
 The legendary optimism and bounce of this strawberry blond Republican may falter on Oct. 31, the day lawyers for creditors are to grill him in Federal Bankruptcy Court here. In applying for personal bankruptcy, Governor Symington, a former real estate developer, listed only $61,795 in assets that could be used to liquidate debts of $24,788,325.
Although Mr. Symington is believed to be the first governor in this century to file for bankruptcy, the petition is not denting his upper-class style of living. Creditors are not expected to be able to attach the roughly $30,000 a year he earns from trusts set up for descendants of Mr. Frick, an industrialist best known to New Yorkers for endowing the Frick Collection, the art museum on Manhattan's East Side.
Equally untouchable, is the wealth of the Governor's wife, Ann Olin Pritzlaff Symington, a granddaughter of the founder of a chemical conglomerate now known as the Olin Corporation. A prenuptial agreement negotiated 20 years ago kept the Symingtons' money separate.
"About all they own together is a television," said a lawyer here for the Governor.
But, while Mr. Symington may absolve himself of all responsibilities for his debts in the court of law, he may not fare so well in the court of public opinion.
"Symington can stiff-upper-lip this one all he wants," said Earl de Berge, a veteran Arizona pollster. "Politicians can recover from blunders, from stupidity. But the one thing that is extremely difficult to recover from is breach of trust."
The bankruptcy filing was unethical, said 48 percent of voters polled by Mr. de Berge's company, the Behavior Research Center.
But down at the Mercado, a shopping mall that is one of the Governor's many failed ventures, Kare Lockhart, owner of the Frontier Boot Corral, predicted on Friday that voters would soon forget it all: "In three years, this will be done and gone. In three years, chances are that he will be re-elected."
In recent years, Arizonans have witnessed a series of corruption scandals and political embarrassments.
The national savings and loans collapse of the late 1980's is symbolized today by Charles A. Keating, a Phoenix banker who is now in jail. In the early 1990's, seven state legislators were convicted of charges stemming from payments made by an agent posing as a crooked lobbyist.
In 1988, Gov. Evan Mecham was removed from office after he provoked a nationwide boycott of Arizona by opposing a state holiday for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Mr. Symington was elected in 1991 on a platform that touted the sharp business acumen of a developer who had weathered the state's real estate collapse of the late 1980's.
The Governor has proved to be an enthusiastic free marketeer, cutting taxes and spending. He has chastised welfare mothers and divorced fathers who fall behind on child support payments.
The bankruptcy has provoked sharp debate in the letters and editorial columns of The Arizona Republic, the leading statewide newspaper.
"What's the difference between an unwed mother filing for welfare and Gov. Fife Symington filing for Chapter 7 bankruptcy?" asked a letter writer, Robert Gregory of Phoenix.
Class and regional undertones sharpen the debate. His listing in the Social Register notes that he was born in New York and graduated from Harvard in 1968. The Governor is a distant relative of the late Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri. To finance the Mercado, he borrowed $10 million from union pension funds, largely those of Arizona blue collar workers like carpenters and masons.
"Symington, whose lineage includes millionaires of days gone by, is married to a business heiress, has sent his children to the most elite schools in the Valley, and now expects the Arizona public to believe that his assets total $61,000," wrote Cassio Saverino, of Peoria, Ariz.
But other Arizonans defended their Governor, saying his 13 failed projects here were only part of a wider economic hurricane that swept real estate markets in the region in the late 1980's.
"Nobody put a gun to the heads of the clowns running the pension funds who got greedy," wrote Neil C. Alden of Phoenix in another letter to the Republic. "Their speculative investment went sour."
The Governor, who did not respond to interview requests last week, has said that his bankruptcy has placed him in the company of other leaders who endured financial setbacks, including Thomas Jefferson and Harry Truman.
Some political analysts say the Governor timed his bankruptcy filing -- nine months into his second term -- in order to get it over with in time for a re-election bid in 1998.
But with 75 creditors gearing up for a protracted bankruptcy fight, it is unclear how many voters will agree in 1998 with his 1994 slogan: "I like Fife."
The filing is expected to give new life to a Federal grand jury that since 1991 has been interviewing lawyers, accountants, and bankers about Mr. Symington's business activities.
According to Phoenix newspapers, investigators are trying to determine if the Governor used state contracts and state jobs to defray personal legal and accounting expenses.
In addition, the grand jury is reportedly investigating whether Mr. Symington committed a felony by submitting false financial statements when seeking bank loans.
According to these statements, Mr. Symington suffered a one-year, $35 million negative swing in his personal finances. In June 1990, Mr. Symington said he had a net worth of $12 million. In May 1991, he said he was $23 million in the red.
Lawyers for creditors also want to know if he made illegal property transfers to his family before filing for bankruptcy. In a May 1990 financial statement, Mr. Symington said that he owned $250,000 worth of "art, jewelry, silver and antiques."
Last month, in his bankruptcy petition, he listed only a $100 watch and a $500 wedding ring. Both were listed as "exempt" from creditors.

HEADLINE: Clinton Asks Men to Pledge Not to Strike Women

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton called on the nation's men on Saturday to pledge to "never, never lift a hand against a woman for as long as we live."
Mr. Clinton, who as a youngster once stopped his stepfather from beating his mother, appealed "not just as a President, or a father or a husband, but also as a son who has seen domestic violence first hand." 
 The President, in his weekly radio address, said the Republican-controlled Congress was bent on reducing the Government's domestic-violence programs by $50 million, hampering "our efforts to protect battered women and their children, to preserve families and to punish these crimes."
Mr. Clinton's overall message appeared aimed at people upset at O. J. Simpson's acquittal last week on charges of murdering his former wife and her friend. Mr. Simpson has admitted battering Mrs. Simpson.
On Monday, in a speech at the University of Texas in Austin, Mr. Clinton is set to address the racial divisions highlighted by the Simpson trial.
The speech coincides not only with the debate over the Simpson verdict but with Monday's rally of black men in Washington.
"I imagine he will address the need to bring Americans together and to shun those who advocate hate," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary.
Delivering the weekly Republican radio address, Senator Pete Domenici of New Mexico took exception to Mr. Clinton's criticism of Republican budget cuts.
"America's budget deficit is growing at a rate of $482 million a day, but President Clinton won't support the balanced budget plan because he says balancing the budget in seven years is too fast," Mr. Domenici said. "It's not too fast for the unemployed, or underemployed, who can't get good work because of the deficit's stifling effect on job creation."
In his own radio address, Mr. Clinton noted that his Administration's crime bill, voted into law last year, also included the Violence Against Women Act, which he said combined sanctions against abusers with aid to the police, prosecutors and shelters.
But he said government alone could not prevail.
"The real solution to this problem starts with us, with our personal responsibility and a simple pledge that we will never, never lift a hand against a woman for as long as we live," the President said.
Mr. Clinton is traveling extensively this week, with speeches and campaign fund-raising events in Connecticut, Texas, California, Ohio and Iowa. On Saturday, he flies to New York to address the United Nations General Assembly and to meet privately with other world leaders.

HEADLINE: Company Takes Over Unloading At Market

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
With a dozen displaced workers looking on angrily, and under a heavy police guard, a newly hired company began unloading fish and seafood last night in the latest phase of the city's campaign to rid the Fulton Fish Market of organized crime.
Before the first arriving cargo of halibut, swordfish and flounder was unloaded, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a brief walking tour through the market. He said the changes in the unloading practices there were "a new beginning" in improving business conditions at the market in lower Manhattan. 
 "This is going to be a real improvement in the right direction for an important part of New York City," the Mayor said. "It is the right thing to do and something that should have been done 20 or 30 years ago."
Within several hours last night, long unloading delays occurred. Drivers of refrigerated trucks that deliver the produce from the Atlantic and Gulf coasts said they had never previously seen such delays. The trucks were lined up on South Street for about a quarter of a mile.
The Fulton Fish Market, the nation's largest wholesale seafood distribution center, is an important cog in the city's economy. It generates about $1 billion a year in sales, salaries and other business dealings.
On Friday, the city awarded a two-year unloading contract to the Laro Maintenance Company of Bay Shore, L.I., a company with no experience in the seafood distribution business. Laro has been involved mainly in cleaning office buildings, airports and the Statue of Liberty.
Laro's owner, Robert Bertuglia Jr., said last night's delays were understandable. "The other companies have been here 70 years," he said. "Give us seven days and I promise you a cleaner and better market."
Under the agreement with the city, Laro will unload refrigerator trucks on a first-come, first-served basis.
The six companies that were ousted on Friday and replaced by Laro were known as unloaders. For 60 years, they had been the self-appointed companies to unload cargo at the market. They charged wholesale dealers about $2 million a year. The displaced companies also had territorial rights and determined among themselves the order of unloading.
Because fish is a perishable product, the companies, according to city officials and Federal investigators, have had an economic stranglehold on the flow of supplies into the market. City officials said Laro would cut unloading costs by about 20 percent.
At 7:50 P.M., 50 Laro employees began unloading the first tractor-trailor. The truck came from the Tidewater area of Virginia with a cargo of swordfish, halibut and flounder.
At the market's main arrival point, Peck Slip and South Street, Laro crews in red and orange jumpsuits swarmed around the truck and unloaded the fish by hand onto wooden pallets. The produce was then transported on forklifts to the merchants' stalls a short distance away.
Trucks from Poppin, Wis., and Riverhead, L.I., were the next to be relieved of their fish and seafood cargo.
John Gillio, the owner of Jet Unloaders Inc., standing behind the police barricade on South Street, looked on with a grim expression. "They've taken away my business and heritage," he said. "My family has been here 60 years, and Giuliani, overnight, has reduced us to nothing. I never gave a dime to anyone in organized crime, I worked too hard for my money down here."

HEADLINE: Newspapers Cut Spanish-Language Publications

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
In the last few years, the surge in the country's Hispanic population and the success of Spanish-language radio and television have caused newspaper publishers across the nation to try to cash in. Start new Spanish supplements and Spanish editions, they ordered. Then they sat back to wait for the advertisements and dollars to roll in.
Que horror! The expected Hispanic readers never turned off their radios and televisions, advertisers never arrived and shareholders of the newspaper companies wanted to know why cash was pouring out, not in. Now the publishers are shutting their new sections or at least cutting them back. 
 In Los Angeles, Fort Worth and Chicago, newspapers have reversed course. And on Friday, The Daily News of New York confirmed that it too might close its bilingual newspaper, El Daily News, just four months after introducing it.
Across the nation, profit projections based on the surge in Hispanic buying power and notions about community service have confronted the realities of heavy competition from radio and television, rising newsprint costs and restive shareholders.
Initially, said Gilbert H. Bailon, president of the National Association of Hispanic Journalists and an editor at The Dallas Morning News, "people wanted to do it because they wanted to provide coverage for a community," confident that Spanish-language sections would win profits and praise. "Now," he added, "the bottom line is becoming more difficult."
Two years ago, The Los Angeles Times expanded Nuestro Tiempo, its Spanish-language supplement that had come out 15 times a year, and began publishing 400,000 copies weekly. "This exciting new publication expands our efforts in the largely bilingual and Spanish-speaking segment of the market," said David Laventhol, then the publisher of the Los Angeles Times, in his own newspaper.
Three months ago the paper announced the closing of Nuestro Tiempo. Though the Los Angeles area has a Hispanic population of about five million, at least two-thirds more than that in the New York area, the expanded section never gained enough advertisers to become profitable. After large shareholders of the newspaper's parent, the Times Mirror Company, brought in Mark H. Willes from General Mills as chief executive this year in an effort to generate higher returns, patience for Nuestro Tiempo and other money-losing newspaper operations quickly ran out.
In 1990, Times Mirror had hedged its bets by purchasing a 50 percent stake in the local competition, La Opinion, the nation's largest Spanish-language daily. Now Times Mirror will join with La Opinion to issue a less ambitious weekly section, Para Ti, with about half the circulation of Nuestro Tiempo, which will feature life-style articles instead of hard news. La Opinion will write and print the section, The Times will distribute it and both newspapers will sell advertisements.
Times Mirror is hardly alone. The Chicago Sun-Times has stopped distributing a separate Spanish newspaper with its Sunday issues. The Fort Worth Star-Telegram is scaling back the circulation of its weekly bilingual section, La Estrella, which was introduced last year. Even ventures as stable and successful as The Miami Herald's Spanish-language sibling, El Nuevo Herald, have had their staffs trimmed as part of broad campaigns to cut costs.
Heberto Gutierrez, president of Inventiva Inc., a leading Hispanic advertising agency based in San Antonio, said his clients looked to radio and, if they had the money, television. "You're going to go with what provides the biggest impact, which is sight, sound and action -- television and radio," he added in an interview.
Publishers having to cut back or close their Spanish-language supplements can only envy last year's 25.5 percent gain, to $454.2 million, in spending on television advertising aimed at the Hispanic market, as measured by Hispanic Business magazine. While most Spanish-language ventures by major newspapers were started in the last few years, the largest Hispanic markets had two or three television stations and half a dozen radio stations a decade ago. "They got there first," said Dick Tobin, president of Strategy Research, a marketing research company based in Miami.
La Estrella has been pruned to 12 pages from 16, and its circulation is being cut to about 115,000 from about 145,000. The Star-Telegram is owned by Capital Cities/ABC, which the Walt Disney Company has agreed to acquire.
There has been stiff competition in the print market from independent Spanish newspapers in many cities with large Hispanic populations. In New York, El Daily News has failed to break readers' loyalties to El Diario-La Prensa, the city's 82-year-old Spanish-language paper. Competition and distribution glitches have kept the circulation of El Daily News below 15,000, at least 10,000 lower than what the company, whose principal owner is Mortimer B. Zuckerman, had hoped for.
The Santa Barbara News-Press in California decided that its separate Spanish newspaper, El Nuevo Tiempo, which it began publishing in September 1993, could better survive independently, and it was sold in January. "The advertising revenue didn't materialize," said Raul Gil, El Nuevo Tiempo's former publisher. He cited a lack of newspaper readers in the relatively poor Hispanic community, a downturn in the region's economy and the small size of the Santa Barbara market. The News-Press is owned by The New York Times Company.
Although Miami Herald executives are discussing whether to expand El Nuevo Herald's circulation to the north, they meanwhile want to economize by cutting its news staff to 88 from 96. "Knight-Ridder is showing a good profit, the stock is up, but that doesn't mean The Miami Herald is allowed to burn up capital," said Mr. Tobin, the Miami market researcher. A new chief executive at Knight-Ridder Inc., the Herald's owner, has committed himself to raising profits and cutting costs.
Despite circulation that has stagnated over the last few years at about 101,000 daily and 126,000 on Sunday, El Nuevo Herald remains profitable. But Miami's Cuban community is more prosperous and better educated than the Hispanic populations in many other areas.

HEADLINE: Western Voices Break Into the Debate Over Sterling Forest

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: WARWICK, N.Y., Oct. 12

 BODY:
For more than a decade, there have been two competing visions for Sterling Forest, the privately owned woodland that blankets an area the size of Manhattan with hemlock and alder, providing a home to black bears and otters and even a few rare northern cricket frogs.
One vision calls for development, the other for preservation. 
 Now new voices, with a Western twang, have chimed in. A handful of Republican members of Congress, opponents of Washington's vast land holdings in their home states, say that any Federal role in preserving Sterling Forest as a two-state park -- as the Republican Governors of New York and New Jersey have requested -- is simply inappropriate.
"Do I have a basic philosophical dispute with this?" said Representative Helen Chenoweth, a freshman Republican from Idaho, where the Federal Government owns two-thirds of the land. "Yes."
In recent weeks, Ms. Chenoweth and other House Republicans, mostly freshmen from Western states, have said they oppose a plan, already passed in the Senate, to provide $17.5 million to help buy Sterling Forest from the Swiss insurance company that owns it. In budget-cutting times, they argue, the Federal Government owns too much land already, and poorly manages what it has.
If successful, their opposition could tilt the scales toward a plan by the forest's owners to build one of the largest planned communities in the Northeast: a project that would put homes for 35,000 people, golf courses and eight million square feet of commercial and industrial space in the 17,505-acre forest in Orange County, only 40 miles north of New York City.
The development plan, which would retain three-quarters of the forest as open space, has divided local residents, many of whom would welcome the economic boost such a large project would bring.
The opposition in Congress has worried Republican and Democratic officials in both states. The contention illustrates how the Republican Party can fragment along regional lines on environmental and other issues, like the proposal to distribute Medicaid money in a way that would benefit growing states in the West and South at the expense of the Northeast.
After testifying late last month before the House subcommittee where the opposition is centered, Bernadette Castro, a Republican and the Parks Commissioner in New York, said she was troubled by some members' doctrinaire opposition to the purchase.
"I think it's a political, philosophical issue with them and I'm trying to get them past that," said Ms. Castro. "They are freshmen and I don't think they understand the impact of a flippant decision they might make."
Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, a Democrat from upstate New York who is on the subcommittee for National Parks, Forests and Lands, agreed: "Particularly this new crop that was elected last year, somehow they have a very parochial view of the world. They have a very difficult time -- really a seeming inability -- to relate to the circumstances of other people in other parts of the country."
The special concerns of New York and New Jersey include preserving open space -- a commodity much more valued in the East than the West -- and protecting drinking water. New Jersey, which has already bought the 2,000 acres of Sterling Forest that laps into that state, wants to preserve the rest because drinking water for two million people comes from the Ramapo and Wanaque watersheds fed by streams there. Moreover, seven miles of the Appalachian Trial thread through the northern part of the forest.
The fight over Sterling Forest, once part of the huge holdings of the Harriman family, has picked up steam this year on several fronts: after taking office in January, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, who grew up in nearby Peekskill and often hikes around the Hudson Highlands, came out strongly for preserving the forest, agreeing with a study that called the proposed development of 13,000 clustered homes in five hamlets "a good plan, but in the wrong place."
Then in June, Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, forced the $17.5 million for the park purchase into a larger Senate bill on Alaskan land by threatening to bottleneck other bills before the Energy and Natural Resources Committee.
Meanwhile, New York has pledged $10 million, as a start toward the purchase, matched by $10 million from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey. Ms. Castro said she expects $5 million in private money, bringing the total near $45 million.
But even if the $17.5 million in Federal money stays in the final legislation, Ms. Castro acknowledges that there is no guarantee that the owners, the Zurich Insurance Group of Switzerland, would sell the forest for $45 million. Informal estimates of the land's value range from $50 million to $200 million -- an ambiguity that feeds the Western Republicans' opposition to spending Federal money on the proposed park.
"This is not a philosophical struggle," said Michael Hardiman, the spokesman for Representative Richard W. Pombo, a California Republican elected in 1992. "This is cold, hard common sense in management of Federal land."
Mr. Hardiman said his boss argues that the Federal Government already owns 700 million acres of land nationally, 55 percent of the total area in Oregon, for example. The Government has no business buying more parkland, he said, until it resolves struggles out West over how best to use land that many area residents feel should be in state or private hands.
"The Federal leviathan called the Interior Department is constantly seeking to expand its empire," he said. "We have got to revise Federal land management policies before we buy one more acre, aiming toward looking at what Federal land we have now, what can be sold to the private sector."
Other Republicans argue that Sterling Forest, where small areas have already been developed with a ski area and 300 houses, is not "nationally significant" enough to warrant spending Federal money. And some agree with the developers' contention that the proposed project would have little if any impact on the watersheds.
But Ms. Castro and New Jersey officials, along with the Congressional delegations of both states, are pressing their contention that preserving Sterling Forest is important and that the owners' willingness to sell, despite questions about price, offers a timely opportunity. Moreover, Ms. Castro said the park would require no Federal involvement beyond the initial financing: the park would be managed by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, a bi-state agency chartered by Congress.
"My only concern is the ideological argument, because factually I think there is no argument," she said.
Despite the opposition in the House subcommittee, Congressional aides say the measure is far from dead, especially because Mr. Bradley appears to have made it a personal priority for his last term in office. "There might be a high price to pay for it, but if they are willing to pay that price, it might have a good chance," one aide said. "But it's going to be a tough sell."

Map of New York and New Jersey border highlighting Sterling Forest.

HEADLINE: In Japan, Aid For Developing Chip of Future

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
In an effort to sharpen its competitiveness in electronics, Japan is planning a large Government-financed program to develop advanced techniques for manufacturing semiconductors, displays and computers, officials said on Friday.
The new effort, tentatively called the Super Advanced Electronics Technology program, will be financed initially by 10 billion yen, or $100 million, included in a package of measures announced last month to stimulate Japan's sagging economy. 
 The project is taking shape as Japan's manufacturers of semiconductors are feeling squeezed. South Korean companies have essentially caught up to Japan's electronic giants in their specialty, memory chips, while the United States has maintained a lead in microprocessors and other chips that do more advanced information processing tasks.
Japan has long been known for Government-backed efforts to move the nation into specific industries. In the 1970's, the VLSI Project -- it stands for very large system integration -- helped Japanese companies capture the world lead in the memory chip market.
But as Japan's electronics companies have become bigger and stronger and able to finance their own product development, the projects run by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry have shifted more toward basic research.
Katsuhiko Kaji, deputy director of the industrial electronics division at MITI, said the new project would work on basic materials and techniques that would be needed 10 years from now rather than on particular products.
These will include ways for making semiconductors with circuit patterns less than 0.1 micron in width, compared with several tenths of a micron in today's most advanced chips. The project also will work on techniques for measuring features that small. A micron is a millionth of a meter.
Mr. Kaji said a consortium of companies was expected to be set up next year to conduct the research. He said theministry wanted to continue the project for at least five years, but the annual financing probably would be far less than in the first year.
Mr. Kaji said the project might be open to some "competitive" non-Japanese companies, but added, "We will not welcome free riders."
In a separate development, 10 Japanese semiconductor companies are planning to work together to help introduce computer-chip manufacturing equipment that can handle silicon wafers that are 300 millimeters, or about 12 inches, in diameter.
The project would require 5 billion yen, or about $50 million, to start, and would need a budget of about $40 million a year, an industry official said, adding that there will be no Government financing.
Currently, chips are made from silicon wafers that are 200 millimeters, or 8 inches, in diameter. The change to 12-inch wafers, which is expected to take place toward the end of the decade, would allow far more chips to be made from a single wafer, cutting manufacturing costs.
The project is sponsored by the Semiconductor Industry Research Institute Japan, an organization formed last year by Japanese semiconductor companies to work on ways to increase the competitiveness of Japan's industry. The members of the institute include NEC, Toshiba, Hitachi and Fujitsu.
American companies, led by the Sematech consortium, are also planning a project to help develop manufacturing equipment for 12-inch wafers.
Taro Okabe, acting executive director of the Japanese institute, said there was a chance the two nations would cooperate.

HEADLINE: Mr. Chirac's Troubled Start

 BODY:
Jacques Chirac's presidency of France began last spring with a burst of energy and high public expectations. But the initial mood was deflated when the new Government could not deliver on its beguiling campaign promises of swift and painless economic revival. Mr. Chirac, whose term runs until 2002, still has plenty of time to turn things around. But he needs to begin making the tough economic policy decisions he evaded as a candidate and in his first few months.
Nobody, least of all someone with Mr. Chirac's long experience in government, should have believed it would be possible to slash unemployment, reduce taxes and sharply lower budget deficits all at the same time. The new Government tried to pursue these conflicting objectives, but the result has been a frustrating stalemate. 
 So the solid majority support Mr. Chirac enjoyed in May has evaporated. Prime Minister Alain Juppe has sunk even lower after barely escaping prosecution for providing his family with city-owned apartments at below-market rents in his former job as Deputy Mayor of Paris. The Juppes must vacate their apartments by the end of the year to avoid formal charges.
As Americans well know, politicians everywhere love to court voters with promises of tax cuts and balanced budgets. But when the same voters protest reductions in services and entitlements, politicians tend to back off, leaving deficit reduction for another day.
In France, however, such procrastination is no longer possible because of strict European Union requirements that France cut its budget deficit almost in half by 1997 to qualify for entry into the planned European Monetary Union. Joining the monetary union is the centerpiece of French European policy. But the deficit target cannot be met without unpopular cuts, unpopular tax hikes or both.
Two months ago, Finance Minister Alain Madelin proposed cutting civil service pensions and was forced to resign. More recently, Mr. Juppe announced a public-sector pay freeze, which was greeted last week by a national work stoppage. Unions also fiercely oppose any reduction in France's traditional five- to six-week annual vacation. The Government could strengthen its hand by pushing ahead with public-sector deregulation. But it hesitates, fearing a political backlash.
Similarly, unemployment, the most potent issue in French politics, cannot be greatly reduced without sacrifices by those now employed. In an integrated global economy, it is not possible to sustain uncompetitive wage and benefit levels without paying a huge price in deficits or jobs. Like his predecessor, Francois Mitterrand, Mr. Chirac is learning that France's ability to indulge in populist economics is sharply constrained by the more orthodox policies of its main European partners.
Mr. Chirac has a deserved reputation for obstinacy in day-to-day battles. But in his long career he has also demonstrated that he can learn from past mistakes and sharply change course when necessary. That is what he needs to do now.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: THE MARCH ON WASHINGTON: THE PARTICIPANTS;
A Bus to the Black March: 31 Men, Hope and History

BYLINE: MICHEL MARRIOTT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Somewhere along the gently rolling expanse of rural North Carolina today, a 430-horsepower workhorse of the open road plowed north on Interstate 85 and into a predawn darkness.
Inside this bus, while some tried to snooze away the miles, others tossed in their seats with restless anticipation. For most, the 12-hour journey from Atlanta to Washington was less to a place than to an appointment with black hope, history and renewal. 
 The busload of 31 black men, some graying and one not quite fully grown, were bound for Monday's Million Man March on the Mall. And that destination, simply that, infused nearly every gesture, expression and observation made along the trip, and, at times, the bus itself, with a deeply felt racial significance.
Jimmy Binion, who does engineering and design work for a telephone company in Atlanta, saw in the bus a symbolic response to the slave ships. Those vessels carried blacks, cramped and weary, to "negative" futures, he said, while today's ride was a "totally positive journey," with a cooler of soft drinks and trays of cold cuts to boot.
But when the bus, amply named "Go'in Places," finally pulled off the highway for a desperately needed breakfast stop at a roadside Shoney's restaurant, the decision swiftly led to a stern, yet good-natured, lecture on racial economics -- after most on the bus had wolfed down eggs, sausage, grits, gravy and fried potatoes.
"We just spent $150 in a white-owned establishment on our way to a march to protest about the economic conditions that we find ourselves in," the Rev. Ra Kabeer, a 52-year-old minister with the First African Presbyterian Church in Atlanta, said over the bus's public address system. The trip's organizer, Trina Ross, one of three black women making the trip but promising not to attend the all-male march, said the bus would stop at a black-owned restaurant on the return leg. Everyone appeared pleased.
Like Mr. Binion, who is 45, Mr. Kabeer felt himself to be on no ordinary ride. "We are here under the appointment of destiny," he said.
The march-bound bus was only one of thousands of scheduled busloads of black men that began arriving on Saturday in response to a call for a million men to join in a day of fasting, male bonding, soul-searching and atonement. Regional organizers of the march said many of the buses would be arriving on Monday just in time to drop passengers in the capital between midnight and 4 A.M. In addition, thousands more black men are expected to arrive here soon by air, vans and automobiles.
As preparations for the event neared completion, debate continued over the role of Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, who had issued the appeal.
But on this 40-foot-long, gray and lavender bus, little but praise was heard whenever Mr. Farrakhan's name was raised, as it often was.
"I've been following him for a long time, since I was 5 years old," said David LeGall, 35. "I would have to say he is the most inspirational, most educational teacher in the United States."
Shortly before the bus left the parking lot of the First African Presbyterian Church -- four hours late -- the men gathered in the two-story, brick and wood building and discussed Mr. Farrakhan, who is widely regarded as one of the most controversial black leaders in America.
Aboard this bus, there was little patience with the criticism that has come from many whites and some blacks about Mr. Farrakhan's role and his history of anti-Semitic and other inflammatory remarks.
That was not the picture they had of the man. The Rev. Mark Lomax, the soft-spoken pastor of the church, said he had met with Mr. Farrakhan, and 35 other religious leaders, a month ago in Atlanta and had been thoroughly impressed. "He is a prophet and he's down with the people," the Rev. Lomax said, adding, "We don't let our faith differences get in the way of our common agenda."
A common response for anyone who raised any questions about Mr. Farrakhan's role was that the march transcended any single man.
During today's trip, march-bound passengers packed into cars sometimes honked and waved in solidarity as they sped past the bus, which pleased L. Vernon Allwood, the director of community relations and special projects at the School of Medicine at Morehouse College. A veteran of the 1963 March on Washington, Mr. Allwood has been directing through churches 20-week manhood training sessions for black boys 12 to 14 years old. He echoed a call of the march in emphasizing that black men must take greater responsibility in raising families.
Between Arabic and Christian prayers, bouts of political debate and hours of reading pocket-sized copies of the Koran and the Bible, the ride rocked with old-fashioned fun.
"I didn't have any idea what to expect when I got on this bus," said Charles M. Canty, a real estate salesman in Atlanta and the father of four. "I only knew one person." With a chuckle, he added, "You could have all been a bunch of gangsters." He was greeted with laughter.
"This is a bus of fellowship," Otis Thomas Jr., 49. "There's a whole bunch of brothers here I've never seen before, yet we act like we've been around each other for a long time.
"That's what's going to happen at the march," he added. "That makes me very excited."
Many of the men on the bus were middle-aged and middle-class, but that didn't stop them from showing a definite flair for the Afrocentric. A glance over the tops of the bus seats revealed almost as many African-style kufi hats as baseball caps.
Claude Marshall, a 54-year-old man with a close-cropped scalp, began talking about his days in the Vietnam War and his one big regret.
"When the March on Washington happened in 1963, I was 22, and I didn't go," Mr. Marshall lamented. "Now I wish I did. I didn't think it would amount to much.
"But I told myself if there was another, I would go," he went on. "There wasn't anything significant enough for me to bother with until this march, and I'm going."

HEADLINE: THE MARCH ON WASHINGTON: THE OVERVIEW;
Debate on March, and Farrakhan, Persists as Black Men Converge on the Capital

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
A stream of black men began arriving here today for the Million Man March conceived as a demonstration of black unity, even as many prominent supporters of the rally continued to wrestle with the debate that has sprung up over the role of the event's chief organizer, Louis Farrakhan.
Many of the 11,000 buses march organizers say are destined for Washington began arriving over the weekend. Today at the rally site, the Mall between the Capitol and the Lincoln Memorial, hundreds of black men strolled in the sunshine, many with their sons, many posing for pictures before the White House or the Capitol with their fists raised in a sign of pride. 
 Planes arriving at the three airports serving Washington brought scores of men who intend to participate, and Amtrak trains pulling into Union Station were jammed with marchers. But a vast majority of the march participants are expected to arrive in the early hours of Monday, creating the strong possibility of chaotic traffic patterns and miles of backups.
Planned by the Nation of Islam for more than a year, the rally has been promoted as a national "holy day of atonement and reconciliation" for black men to pledge responsibility to themselves and their families and to promise to reject behavior that has led many of them to abandon their children, commit crimes and indulge in drugs.
Mr. Farrakhan remained at the center of the debate about the march today, but some supporters continued to argue that his role was being given too much prominence.
"Whites are more likely to see this as a rally of divisiveness," said Ronald Walters, a political science professor at Howard University, who like other supporters acknowledged the disgust with which many people view Mr. Farrakhan for his years of racist and anti-Semitic comments.
But Mr. Walters argued that with retreats on welfare programs and a paucity of good jobs, problems facing blacks have reached such desperate levels that the politics of one individual grows insignificant beside the everyday worries over adequate food, housing and employment.
"For most blacks, this is about pain," Mr. Walters said. "The discussion of Farrakhan is a side issue for us."
Organizers have predicted that more than a million men will attend from around the country, a crowd that would make it the largest political demonstration in the city's history, far surpassing the 250,000 who heard Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. speak at the civil rights demonstration in 1963.
The rally has won the support of many leading black groups, like the Congressional Black Caucus and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, as well as prominent individuals, like the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and big-city mayors, like Dennis Archer of Detroit, Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington and Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore, all of whom said they planned to attend.
But many other respected black voices, including leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the National Urban League and the National Baptist Convention, have not endorsed the march, citing Mr. Farrakhan's racist oratory and the separatist agenda of the Nation of Islam as wrong ideals. Roy Innis, chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, said this weekend that march organizers were "exploiting the legitimate aspirations of the rank and file of black America."
Expressing many of the same sentiments, black political figures, like Representative John Lewis, a Democrat from Georgia and a veteran of civil rights battles in the 1960's, and two black House Republicans, J. C. Watts of Oklahoma and Gary A. Franks of Connecticut, said they did not plan to march.
In New York, H. Carl McCall, the State Comptroller, was adamant about refusing to attend. "My reasons for not going are based on my longstanding disagreements with Farrakhan," Mr. McCall said. "I personally cannot participate in anything he is leading."
Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Democrat from Harlem, and Representative Floyd Flake, a Democrat from Queens, did not plan to march either, though Mr. Rangel, despite his district being heavily Jewish, was careful not to criticize Mr. Farrakhan.
But several officials said that they planned to attend, and that they considered the march important. "Anytime you put that many people together in unity, it's excellent," said Adam Clayton Powell 4th, a New York City Councilman who represents East Harlem, parts of the Upper West Side and the South Bronx.
The march has also been denounced by black women's groups and gay and lesbian groups for excluding them from participating. While several black women, including Maya Angelou, the poet, and Rosa Parks, from the early civil rights period, have been invited to speak, all others have been urged to stay home -- from their jobs, their errands and the march -- in a show of solidarity.
But, as many leading black voices have withheld their support, they have nonetheless expressed sympathy for the goals of the march. To shore up support, organizers last week backed off an assertion that support for the march equaled support for Mr. Farrakhan, fearing that larger issues might be obscured by Mr. Farrakhan's reputation among many blacks and whites as a racist and hatemonger.
"There's a racial divide in our country, and this march can help heal it," said the Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis, national director of the march who was dismissed last year as executive director of the N.A.A.C.P. over the use of association money to settle a sex discrimination charge.
"If we can improve our quality of life, we can renew benefits to other people," he said. "If we can stop black-on-black crime, all crime will go down. If we can build strong economic development, if young men can find employment, if they can get a good education, then the whole of society benefits. When you hold down black people, you hold down the whole country."
State Senator David A. Patterson from Harlem said he could not be at the march but said today that he supported the ideals behind the march.
Mr. Jackson, a former Presidential candidate, expressed ardent support for the march today. And while he would not condemn Mr. Farrakhan for his views, Mr. Jackson urged critics to consider "the state of emergency in which the black community finds itself."
"Pain and predicament is driving this march," he said, laying specific blame on conservatives like Speaker Newt Gingrich and Associate Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court for their role in promoting an agenda against Government support for people in need. "Many cities now have two new buildings, a new jail and a new ballpark. Between those two mountains is a canyon where jobs are sucked out and youth are sucked up."
Mr. Jackson evaded several attempts to be pinned down on his level of support for Mr. Farrakhan.
Despite the calls to separate the leader from the event, the march on Monday could prove a turning point for Mr. Farrakhan, who is known by many Americans mostly for his racist comments.
Mr. Farrakhan, who canceled two television appearances today, citing exhaustion, stirred more criticism last week when Reuters television released an interview in which he called some Jews and other ethnic groups "bloodsuckers" for the way they have operated businesses in black communities.
On Saturday he said those comments were taken out of context.
 On behalf of Mr. Farrakhan and other leaders of black organizations, Mr. Jackson offered to open a dialogue with prominent American Jews, much in the way Mr. Farrakhan offered last week to meet with officials from the Anti-Defamation League of the B'nai B'rith.
Matching the swiftness and response of the League, Rabbi Marvin Hier of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles rejected any conversation between Jewish leaders and Mr. Farrakhan until Mr. Farrakhan "publicly apologizes for his bigotry and anti-Semitism."
Like many critics of the march, Mr. Hier said he could not look past Mr. Farrakhan to consider any positive message that might reach blacks on Monday.
"The only reasons we have not come out and told people not to go is because many have already arrived," he said. "It's ridiculous to think you can separate the message from the messenger," he said. "You can't."
