HEADLINE: THE MARCH ON WASHINGTON: THE ORGANIZER;
In the End, Farrakhan Has His Day in the Sun

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
A sea of black men at his feet, the Capitol at his back and millions watching him on cable television, Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, delivered the kind of speech today that he often makes to his religious faithful on a lazy Sunday afternoon back home in Chicago. It was part inspiration, conspiracy theory and numerology, with a good dose of black nationalism and the joys and necessity of bootstrap capitalism. He attacked white supremacy in one breath and then turned around and condemned what he called the failures of black manhood.
"I point out the evils of black people like no other leader alive," the Muslim minister bellowed, a group of stern-faced members of the Nation's paramilitary detail, the Fruit of Islam, at his sides and back, dressed in their dark blue uniforms. 
 The speech, or "lecture," as he called it, began in bright sunshine and ended near dusk more than two hours later, as thousands of those who had come for his Million Man March began leaving to catch buses back to their cities and towns around the United States. According to the National Park Service, they had answered his call 400,000 strong for a day of prayer and protest; organizers put it at more than a million.
The 62-year-old grandfather has been working toward this moment for nearly four decades, since his days as a Calypso singer billed as "The Charmer," but especially in the last 17 years, as he traveled the country talking to small crowds in small churches.
As he methodically went about rebuilding the Nation of Islam in his image, most people beyond black neighborhoods ignored or dismissed him as the head of a sect with a penchant for bow ties and bean pies. And more recently, his public image has been haunted by accusations of anti-Semitism, sexism and homophobia. Just last Friday, in a broadcast interview released by Reuters, he accused some Jewish and Asian business owners of being "bloodsuckers."
But at least parts of his message of pride and anger have struck a chord across class lines, from the brother on the block to the brother in the board room.
"Minister Farrakhan is like E. F. Hutton," said Derick Williams, a 25-year-old resident of a Washington public housing project. "When he speaks, black people listen."
At major events, Mr. Farrakhan often speaks as long as he did today, or longer. At times today he stirred the crowd to cheers, as when he rebuked his critics and delivered his message of black empowerment. "Whether you like it or not, God brought the idea through me, and he didn't bring it through me because my heart was dark with hatred and anti-Semitism," he said, adding, "If my heart were that dark, how is the message so bright, the message so clear, the response so magnificent?"
But other parts of the speech left many baffled. "What is so deep about this number 19?" Mr. Farrakhan asked at one point. "Why are we standing on the Capitol steps today? That number 19, when you have a nine, you have a womb that is pregnant, and when you have a one standing by the nine, it means that there's something secret that has to be unfolded."
At least for this day, Mr. Farrakhan may have earned himself top billing in the drama of black political leadership. But as impressive as the sea of black men on the Mall was, it is unclear what it will mean for Mr. Farrakhan or what it says about the heart and direction of black America.
The turnout makes one thing clear. Mr. Farrakhan, unlike anyone else in some time, has tapped into a deep and wide sense of discontent in black America. Roger Wilkins, a historian at George Mason University, said Mr. Farrakhan had become a powerful voice largely by default.
"Responsible black people," Mr. Wilkins said, "have been trying to get the attention of the Democratic Party and the Republican Party for a long time to tell them that black people were unemployed at double-digit levels for two decades, that black teen-agers are in trouble, black families are falling apart largely because they do not have adequate incomes. White people have not listened.
"Their response," he continued, "was Gingrich's programs to punish the poor. By ignoring moderate black leaders, they sowed the seeds for the emergence of Farrakhan as a more important figure."
Mr. Farrakhan started his own version of the Nation of Islam in 1978, three years after the death of his mentor, Elijah Muhammad, the founder of the Nation 60 years ago.
In 1980, 15,000 people turned out to hear Mr. Farrakhan speak in New York City, and he has been packing them in ever since, said Lawrence H. Mamiya, a professor of religion at Vasser College, who has studied the minister and his Nation for years.
"I think he would like to be perceived as one of the legitimate leaders of black America," Mr. Mamiya said. "I think one reason he called for the march is he feels that the Nation of Islam, in order to grow, will have to begin including people from the member class."
Still, Mr. Mamiya said, Mr. Farrakhan "remains an enigma to those of us who study him."
"How do I characterize his politics?" Mr. Mamiya asked with a laugh. "Disruptive. You can never predict what he is going to say."
Mr. Farrakhan is a Booker T. Washington-style conservative and a Marcus Garvey black nationalist. He lives in the lap of luxury in an integrated neighborhood on Chicago's South Side, just blocks from some of the city's worst black poverty.
He is often portrayed as a militant, but much of what he says sounds ghost-written by a Republican, with its talk of self-help and bootstraps. He is a Muslim but tends to quote more frequently from the Bible of his youth.
In the year before this march, Mr. Farrakhan was devoting time to reconciliation and image polishing. In January, Malcolm X's daughter, Qubilah Bahiyah Shabazz, was charged in Federal court in Minneapolis with trying to hire a hit man to kill Mr. Farrakhan, whom Malcolm X's family had long suspected of playing a role in his death.
But instead of speaking out against Ms. Shabazz, Mr. Farrakhan condemned the Government, saying Ms. Shabazz had been set up. That led to a public embrace by Malcolm X's widow, a show of unity and healing that went a long way toward enhancing Mr. Farrakhan's reputation beyond the Nation.
That is a prospect that worries Prof. Adolph Reed, a professor of political science at Northwestern University.
Professor Reed said the march was a symbol of a growing sense of desperation in many blacks, including middle-class blacks who fear attacks on affirmative action.
"People are feeling pinched and threatened, and a lot of political leaders don't seem to have any answers," Professor Reed said. "People like Farrakhan feed on that sort of desperation. The substance of his message and agenda meshes well with right-wing Republicans."
But Professor Reed's concerns seemed far removed from the black men who had listened to Mr. Farrakhan for more than two hours. After the minister had finished, they hugged and shook hands with friends and strangers. Then they headed home past dozens of vendors selling T-shirts, videos, books and candy bars. Most of the items had a picture of a smiling Louis Farrakhan.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Fearing Japanese Bank Frailty, U.S. Agrees to Give Future Help

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Worried by the financial health of Japanese banks, the Federal Reserve has arranged to provide Japanese financial authorities with billions of dollars almost instantly in exchange for Treasury bonds and bills in case of a sudden cash crisis, Government officials said tonight.
While the Federal Reserve has responded to shortages of credit in the past by paying cash for huge sums in Treasury securities, the new agreement appears to be the first time in memory that the Fed has sought in advance to guard against a possible crisis. 
 The plan seems to be aimed particularly at providing money quickly for use by Japanese regulators if one or more Japanese banks run into trouble and need a bailout during trading hours in the United States -- nighttime in Japan. The Japanese financial markets are closed then and the regulatory agencies are closed, as well.
The move appears to reflect deep concern among American financial officials about the potential for trouble among Japanese financial institutions, many of which are far larger than the biggest banks in the United States. The arrangement with Japan would give American regulators a presumably risk-free way of dampening the shock waves from any possible Japanese liquidity crisis.
In such a crisis, a Japanese bank with more assets than liabilities might nonetheless find itself suddenly unable to raise enough ready cash to meet a debt due immediately. In the worst case, that could potentially set off a chain reaction of defaults affecting banks around the world.
Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa and chairman of the House Banking Committee, said tonight that he had recently been briefed by the Federal Reserve on the arrangement, which he praised as a prudent precaution. He said that it was virtually risk free, unlike the American-led bailout of Mexico, because the Fed would be accepting Treasury bonds and Treasury bills in exchange for the cash.
The deal would also allow Japanese financial authorities or big banks to raise immense amounts of cash without the potential disruption of financial markets and soaring interest rates that might accompany any Japanese move to sell huge quantities of Treasury securities. The Japanese central bank keeps large sums invested in Treasury securities at the Federal Reserve, and the new arrangement would allow a few regulators in Tokyo to move fast in the middle of the night there to raise money for a bank that had financial difficulties during the day in the United States.
The Japanese newspaper Asahi Shimbun reported last Thursday that the Government might borrow money from the Federal Reserve using Treasury securities as collateral. Japan's central bank denied the report today as wrong, but did not elaborate.
The Japanese banking industry has suffered a spate of bad news lately, forcing banks to begin paying slightly higher rates of interest as some foreign lenders perceive new risks. The bad news ranges from the failure of five financial institutions in the last year -- two last month -- to disappointing ratings by Moody's Investors Service to the disclosure of a $1.1 billion loss at Daiwa Bank from unauthorized trading in New York.
Over the last few months, officials at the Fed and the Treasury Department have tried to work behind the scenes with their Japanese counterparts to stabilize the situation, while minimizing their worries in public for fear of driving investment capital away from Tokyo.
Even so, foreign banks, concerned about Japan's banking crisis, are trimming their loans to Japanese financial institutions. That has raised the risk of a potential liquidity squeeze.
"There appear to be many banks that are facing great difficulty in raising foreign funds," Izumi Tagawa, a spokesman for the Chuo Trust and Banking Company, said today. Mr. Tagawa quickly said that his own bank, which is turning a profit mostly from stock sales, was not experiencing a problem raising money overseas.
Some Japanese financial institutions have recently been forced to turn for help to the country's biggest banks. Or, they have had to take their yen deposits and convert them into American dollars to meet financial obligations overseas, Japanese and foreign bankers and analysts said in interviews in Japan.
Mr. Leach, one of the Federal Reserve's closest allies on Capitol Hill, hinted at the arrangement during his opening remarks at a hearing he held today on the Japanese banking industry, which is struggling to cope with at least $400 billion in bad loans.
"While our Government does not expect an unmanageable situation to arise," he said, "it is prepared to cooperate fully with Japanese authorities to facilitate in any emergency liquidity for Japanese banks operating in the United States. It is also working closely with Japanese authorities to render appropriate advice and support with the understanding that the Japanese Government has the resources internally and externally to handle any problems on its own."
In a telephone interview tonight from his home, Mr. Leach said that the plan was aimed at preventing a sudden shortage of ready cash in the Japanese financial system, known in banking parlance as a lack of liquidity. A strong supporter of the American-led bailout of Mexico last winter, Mr. Leach drew the distinction between that effort and the new arrangement.
The Federal Reserve plan, he added, "is intended as a symbol of cooperation and the capacities of the Federal Reserve, which are rather enormous."
Fed officials declined to comment on all this today. Treasury Department officials would also not comment.
Many Japanese executives, discussing the same set of problems before Mr. Leach's hearing began, acknowledged in Tokyo that their industry suffered from liquidity problems abroad.
But they deny that the problems hamper their own institutions, an unsurprising stance, since a bank that admits to difficulties may be admired for its candor, but the admirers will not lend to it.
A study released here today by the Congressional Research Service said that two of Japan's major banks had to pay 19 basis points more for their short-term borrowings of dollars in London last month than comparable European and American banks. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The Congressional service did not identify the two banks.
Japanese banks hold $400 billion in United States Treasury bonds, and account for 9.4 percent of all lending in the United States, the Congressional Research Service said, warning that a severe banking crisis in Japan could divert some of that money away from the United States.
But financial-industry experts testifying at today's House Banking Committee hearing played down that concern. "I don't see that we should be afraid of significant disinvestment in America" because Japanese banks still need to lend money to valued Japanese corporate customers doing business here, said Alicia Ogawa, a securities analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia in Tokyo.
It was not clear tonight whether Japanese authorities would have to sell Treasury bonds and bills to the Federal Reserve with no hope of recovering them. The alternative would be for the Fed to lend cash to the Japanese central bank while holding the Treasury securities as collateral.
Mr. Leach said that no legislation would be needed to carry out the Federal Reserve's arrangement, and that he did not expect any serious criticism of the plan in Congress.
"It's an understanding with Japanese banks and authorities -- it is not anything beyond the power of the Fed," he said. "It is patently reasonable; I don't think there would be any objection."

HEADLINE: Coast Guard Plans to Leave Governors I.

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

 BODY:
The United States Coast Guard will close its base on Governors Island in New York Harbor by the end of 1998, ending its storied and secluded 212-year history as an American military installation and potentially becoming, by the end of the century, one of New York City's most valuable pieces of real estate.
In closing the installation, the Coast Guard's New York-based operations will cut 500 of its 1,800 workers. The rest will be scattered to bases of operation in Staten Island and Bayonne, N.J., but most -- nearly 1,000 -- will be relocated to bases in Tidewater, Va., and Charleston, S.C. 
The decision to vacate the 175-acre island -- the largest Coast Guard base in the country -- was made yesterday in Washington by Admiral Robert E. Kramek. The move will save an estimated $30 million a year; the Coast Guard needs to cut $400 million annually from its budget of $3.8 billion. The closing will be announced formally at a press conference scheduled for today.
Coast Guard officials said yesterday that the cuts would not diminish their search-and-rescue duties or patrol and enforcement efforts in and around New York Harbor.
"For us, the goal is to provide the best service to the public at the lowest possible cost, and we think this does that," Lieut. Pat Philbin, a spokesman for the Coast Guard, said last night. "We targeted infrastructure, which was the primary factor in our decision, and not necessarily the economic impact to New York City."
The dismantling of the base, scheduled to begin next spring, will leave vacant the historic island, which lies in the shadow of lower Manhattan's skyline, instantly making it one of New York City's most desirable chunks of real estate.
The island, accessible only by ferry and helicopter with Coast Guard permission, is an unspoiled town with 4,000 residents, a hotel, beauty salon, bowling alley, movie theater, nine-hole golf course, Burger King restaurant and, best of all, glorious vistas of lower Manhattan and the Statue of Liberty.
In 1627, a Dutch official bought Governors Island from the Manahatas Indians for two ax heads, a string of beads and some nails. Earlier this year, the Congressional Budget Office estimated the island is worth $500 million, but several Congressional aides said yesterday that that price would be "a bargain."
If legislation now before Congress passes, New York City and New York State would have the right of first refusal to buy the land from the Federal Government. The legislation, passed by the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, would bypass the laborious procedures that require making the land available for other public uses, such as city dumps, before the land is offered for sale.
In anticipation of the Coast Guard decision, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed a task force last month to study the future of the island. The committee, whose head is Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, is made up of members of the Economic Development Corporation, the City Planning Commission and the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
"We don't know what the ultimate outcome will be, but we are going to allow the task force to explore the many possible uses for the island," said Lenny Alcivar, an assistant press secretary for Mayor Giuliani.
However, if the city and state decide to pass on negotiating a price with the Federal Government, the land is likely to be auctioned to private developers, who have expressed much delight about the prospect of building on the island. The developer Donald M. Trump has described the island as "great visually, great artistically and great for security."
A major factor in the closing of Governors Island is its high cost to run, Coast Guard officials said. Another factor is the high cost of living borne by its 4,000 workers and family members.
"It is expensive for our families to live in that area," said Lieutenant Philbin, the Coast Guard spokesman based in Washington.
The dismantling of the installation will occur gradually over the next three years. "We are not going to all leave at once and just turn the lights out," said Lieut. John Shallman, a Coast Guard spokesman in New York.
The Coast Guard will begin relocating its New York operations to sites at Rosebank and Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island, with nearly 325 jobs relocating there, many of them held by the petty officers who manage the flow of the hundreds of boats and ships that use New York Harbor every day. Another 150 personnel will move, along with several Coast Guard cutters, to Bayonne.
Representative Susan Molinari, a Republican, lobbied to have the Coast Guard relocate to Staten Island. It was also her idea to amend legislation to give New York City and New York State the first chance to buy Governors Island.
"This is great news for Staten Island," Ms. Molinari said last night. "The Coast Guard plan saves tens of millions of dollars and pumps some of it right into the North Shore."
By the end of the century, the Coast Guard will leave for good, turning the tiny island over to the Government's General Services Administration, which will then try to sell it.
In the meantime, the Coast Guard officials who live and work on the island are not looking forward to their last day there, Coast Guard officials said yesterday. Most of them requested assignment on Governors Island, and some have lived there for years.
In a way, the base closing is an eviction for them.
"How can you not love New York City?" said Lieutenant Shallman, who has lived on Governors Island for almost four years. "We live in a small-town atmosphere in the middle of the largest, busiest metropolitan area in the world. Sure, we'll miss it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A prime patch of New York real estate -- Governors Island in New York Harbor -- is set to be vacated by the United States Coast Guard. (Associated Press, 1986) (pg. B3)

HEADLINE: THE MARCH ON WASHINGTON;
Excerpts From Talk By Clinton In Texas

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's address today at the University of Texas, as recorded by the Federal Information Systems Corporation, a transcription service:
In recent weeks, every one of us has been made aware of a simple truth: white Americans and black Americans often see the same world in drastically different ways, ways that go beyond and beneath the Simpson trial and its aftermath, which brought these perceptions so starkly into the open. The rift we see before us that is tearing at the heart of America exists in spite of the remarkable progress black Americans have made in the last generation. . . . 
 The rift between blacks and whites exists still in a very special way in America, in spite of the fact that we have become much more racially and ethnically diverse and that Hispanic-Americans, themselves no strangers to discrimination, are now almost 10 percent of our national population.
The reasons for this divide are many. Some are rooted in the awful history and stubborn persistence of racism. Some are rooted in the different ways we experience the threats of modern life to personal security, family values and strong communities. Some are rooted in the fact that we still haven't learned to talk frankly, to listen carefully and to work together across racial lines.
Almost 30 years ago, Dr. Martin Luther King took his last march with sanitation workers in Memphis. They marched for dignity, equality and economic justice. Many carried placards that read simply, "I am a man." The throngs of men marching in Washington today -- almost all of them -- are doing so for the same stated reason.
But there is a profound difference between this march today and those of 30 years ago. Thirty years ago, the marchers were demanding that dignity and opportunity they were due because in the face of terrible discrimination, they had worked hard, raised their children, paid their taxes, obeyed the laws and fought our wars.
Well, today's march is also about pride and dignity and respect -- but after a generation of deepening social problems that disproportionately impact black Americans. It is also about black men taking renewed responsibility for themselves, their families and their communities. It's about saying no to crime and drugs and violence. It's about standing up for atonement and reconciliation. It's about insisting that others do the same and offering to help them. It's about the frank admission that unless black men shoulder their load, no one else can help them or their brothers, their sisters and their children escape the hard, bleak lives that too many of them still face.
Of course, some of those in the march do have a history that is far from its message of atonement and reconciliation. One million men are right to be standing up for personal responsibility, but one million men do not make right one man's message of malice and division. No good house was ever built on a bad foundation. Nothing good ever came of hate. . . .
There is still unacceptable economic disparity between blacks and whites. It is so fashionable to talk today about African-Americans as if they had been some sort of protected class. Many whites think blacks are getting more than their fair share in terms of jobs and promotions. That is not true. That is not true.
The truth is that African-Americans still make on average about 60 percent of what white people do and more than half of African-American children live in poverty. . . .
On the other hand, blacks must understand and acknowledge the roots of white fear in America. There is a legitimate fear of the violence that is too prevalent in our urban areas. . . .
We must all take responsibility for ourselves, our conduct and our attitudes. America, we must clean our house of racism. To our white citizens I say, I know most of you every day do your very best by your own lights to live a life free of discrimination.
Nevertheless, too many destructive ideas are gaining currency in our midst. The taped voice of one policeman should fill you with outrage.
So I say we must clean the house of white America of racism. Americans who are in the white majority should be proud to stand up and be heard denouncing the sort of racist rhetoric we heard on that tape, so loudly and clearly denouncing it that our black fellow citizens can hear us. White racism may be black people's burden, but it's white people's problem. We must clean our house.
To our black citizens, I honor the presence of hundreds of thousands of men in Washington today committed to atonement and to personal responsibility, and the commitment of millions of other men and women who are African-American to this cause. I call upon you to build on this effort to share equally in the promise of America. But to do that, your house, too, must be cleaned of racism.
There are too many today -- there are too many today, white and black, on the left and the right, on the street corners and the radio waves, who seek to sow division for their own purposes. To them I say: "No more. We must be one."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a speech at the University of Texas, President Clinton called on Americans of all backgrounds to "clean our house of racism." Afterward, he greeted some members of the university band. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Wall Journal;
Swords to Plowshares: A Coda to the Cold War

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: WALL, S.D.

 BODY:
For 30 years, the unmarked chain link fence on Dale Keyser's dry pasture land enclosed a 36-ton missile that could fly over the North Pole and carbonize a Russian city in less than 30 minutes.
Today, in an era of disarmament, Mr. Keyser calculates that the same security fence designed to foil Soviet saboteurs should also be able stop South Dakota deer. 
 "It's right by my hayfields -- it'll be easy to use as a hay corral," Mr. Keyser, a 76-year-old farmer, said of his recently deactivated Minuteman II missile site. "Other ranchers may find it handy to use theirs as a cattle corral."
In a coda to the cold war, demolition crews working under Air Force contracts methodically moved across this landscape of grasslands and gullies last summer, imploding empty underground missile silos.
Because of an arms reduction treaty signed by President George Bush in 1992, all 150 Minuteman missiles in South Dakota have been removed from the silos, which are about 80 feet deep. The missiles have been dismantled for recycling or saved in warehouses; the 1.5 megaton warheads have been sent to Texas for disassembly.
"If you don't have the gun, the bullet is not much use," said Tim Pavek, a civilian missile engineer who directs the silo destruction program from Ellsworth Air Force Base in Rapid City, 30 miles west of this town of 834 people in southwest-central South Dakota.
With the Air Force paying $185,000 to destroy each silo, Gene S. Williams, president of the Missile Area Landowners Association, believes the Federal Government is "pouring more good money down the hole."
"It seems like an awful lot of dollars to destroy something that, given the way the world works, they may be building 5 to 10 years from now somewhere else," Mr. Williams said.
Maj. Joseph Mecadon of the Air Force, the public relations officer at Ellsworth, mourns the lack of public interest in the deactivation program. "We're taking a step back from the nuclear abyss -- nobody knows, nobody cares," said Major Mecadon, recalling that disarmament demonstrations were regular events at South Dakota silos in the late 1980's.
Although few ranchers will admit to missing their missiles, there is a bit of ICBM nostalgia sweeping this desolate corner of the High Plains. And for a rural town like Wall, the end of the arms race means washboard roads and higher electricity rates.
Scattered over a thinly populated area the size of New Jersey and Connecticut combined, the Minutemen silos and launching centers required a 1,000-mile access network of smoothly graded gravel roads, maintained with Air Force money. With the departure of the missile system, which was the largest customer for several rural electric cooperatives, electricity rates here are expected to rise.
Under the present schedule, ranchers next year will be able to buy back at fair market value the one-acre to one-and-a-half-acre missile sites they sold to the Federal Government during the Kennedy Administration. The Air Force also plans to abandon a 1,500-mile network of buried cables that linked the silos and launching control centers.
Some of the bittersweet feelings about disarmament flowed last year at a farewell Fourth of July dinner dance for the 44th Missile Wing. With a section of the Berlin Wall standing as a backdrop, speakers hailed the wing's "11,000 days of vigilance." Each of the 1,000 guests received a souvenir set of gold-plated missile launching keys.
South Dakota's three-man Congressional delegation attended the banquet, testimony to the fact that Ellsworth Air Force Base remains the state's largest employer. Hoping to soften the economic blow caused by the departure of the 1,700-member missile wing, politicians began promoting a patriotic tour package: Mount Rushmore in the morning and missile sites in the afternoon. Rushmore is only a two-hour drive from the missile sites.
For today's generation, shaped by nuclear movies ranging from "Dr. Strangelove" to "The Day After," a cold war museum would offer a tour of a preserved missile silo site and an underground launching center. To that end, the National Park Service is preparing for Congressional review a proposal for a Minuteman Missile National Historic Site.
With 99 of the 150 silos already demolished, the Air Force has spared one silo and one launching center to be part of the proposed museum. Both sites are conveniently situated close to Interstate 90, the major highway linking the Badlands National Park and Mount Rushmore.
To some, cold war history may seem a little too fresh. At the launching center, code-named Delta One, a Garfield cartoon still hangs over the mess hall's food window and a Mr. Coffee machine still stands on a Formica table in the lounge. But 31 feet below this 1960's suburban style house where missile crews were billeted, real history begins.
At the base of the elevator, a painted rocket emblazoned with "USAF" blasts through a shredded Soviet flag. The eight-ton steel and concrete "blast door" to the launching control center is decorated with more missileer artwork: a Minuteman II rocket painted on an imaginary pizza box, with the slogan, "Worldwide delivery in 30 minutes or less -- or your next one is free."
Inside, a visitor can sit in the launching commander's chair, inspecting the key-and-code system designed to prevent the accidental triggering of a Minuteman missile armed with a bomb 100 times the destructive power of the one dropped on Hiroshima in 1945.
Installed in the early 1960's, this intimidating wall of electronic gadgetry has a total computing power of 4k -- the equivalent of a modern pocket calculator.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a missile-launching control center that has been spared from demolition, a visitor can inspect an electronic launch verification panel designed to prevent the accidental triggering of a nuclear holocaust. (Paul Meridith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TJX Will Buy Marshalls Chain From Melville

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The Melville Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its faltering Marshalls division to the TJX Companies for $550 million in cash and stock.
The deal, analysts said, would provide some needed consolidation in the fiercely competitive discount clothing business. 
 Under the terms of the transaction, TJX will put up $375 million of the purchase price in cash. The remaining $175 million will be in the form of TJX junior convertible preferred stock.
To help pay for the acquisition, TJX, which is based in Framingham, Mass., said it would cut its annual dividend in half, to 28 cents a share, saving $20 million a year. The company said it would also stop a share-buyback program.
Investor reaction to the sale, which had been rumored for the last two weeks, was muted. On the New York Stock Exchange, the shares of Melville rose 50 cents, to $35.50. TJX's stock dipped 12.5 cents, to $14.50.
The deal is expected to bolster TJX's position in the discount-clothing market, giving it 495 Marshalls stores in 40 states and Puerto Rico. TJX operates the T. J. Maxx chain of 571 stores and had $3.8 billion in sales last year. Marshalls had sales of $2.8 billion.
The president of TJX, Bernard Cammarata, is said to have told analysts that he expected that TJX would close 190 of the combined company's stores.
"I think it was a smart, strategic decision" for TJX, said Jeffrey Edelman, a retailing analyst with C. J. Lawrence Deutsche Bank. "They are taking out a competitor, and it allows them to generate economies of scale. Now they have to execute and prove to us they can manage the transition."
Much of the success of the purchase will depend on the degree to which the combination will ease competitive pressures in an industry in which distinctions between various types of businesses have become blurred, analysts said.
"The price differential between off-price stores and department stores has been narrowing," said Donald J. Trott, who follows the industry for Dean Witter Reynolds. By buying Marshalls, TJX believes it "can widen that price differential out and rationalize some of the excess capacity in the industry," he said.
The sale is the first big move by Melville, which is based in Rye, N. Y., since its announcement last December that it was beginning a strategic review of all its businesses in an effort to generate greater value for shareholders.
Although Marshalls represented about 25 percent of Melville's $11.3 billion in sales last year, profits at the division have been declining over the last few years. Melville's biggest operation is the CVS drugstore chain.
During a telephone conference call with Wall Street analysts, Mr. Cammarata of TJX disclosed that pretax operating earnings at Marshalls fell by 20 percent in 1994 from 1993 and were down again so far this year, Mr. Trott of Dean Witter said.
In an interview, Stanley P. Goldstein, Melville's chairman and chief executive, said, "There is no question the off-price business has been struggling for the last couple of years."
As part of the strategic review, "we had to decide whether we wanted to be a buyer or a seller" of discount stores, he said.
"As things transpired," he said, "we decided to sell our business to an entity like T. J. Maxx. And we will still retain an interest in the equity of the combined companies."
In connection with the sale, Melville said it would take an after-tax charge of $195 million in its fourth quarter. The company said the sale would reduce fourth-quarter operating earnings as a result of lost sales in the holiday season.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Privatizing in Hungary: A Door Reopens

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
It has been hard lately to take privatization in Eastern Europe seriously. Just look at the case of Hungary over the last year.
When foreign investors seemed to have locked up a deal to buy a dairy, the purchase was scotched in favor of a lower offer by a local farming cooperative. "Very important political reasons" were cited. 
 Last December, when a Dallas hotel company was on the verge of buying the Hungar Hotels chain, Prime Minister Gyula Horn stopped the deal and ordered an investigation that led to the dismissal of the privatization commissioner.
But now, there seems to have been a reversal. After more than two years of bumbling along, Hungary has put up for sale the crown jewels -- its oil company, its electricity- and gas-distribution industry, its major banks and a second stock installment in the state telephone company, Matav. (A consortium of Deutsche Telekom and Ameritech already owns a 30 percent stake.)
Global players in oil and gas, electricity and telecommunications are knocking on Hungary's door, apparently convinced that the country is at last getting serious about privatizing its largest companies.
The Government has hired investment bankers, including CS First Boston, Kleinwort Benson, Merrill Lynch and Deutsche Bank, to market the companies and hopes to raise nearly $2 billion in coming months.
"The interest in privatizations here is very strong," said Sunil Sabharwal, head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Budapest. "That is quite obvious by the number of major companies that are looking at MOL," referring to Hungary's state oil and gas company, which plans to sell stock beginning in mid-November.
Indeed, bankers predict that over the next year, more money could be poured into privatizations in Eastern Europe by foreign investors than in all the previous years combined.
In July, the Czech Republic raised $1.45 billion for a stake in its state telephone company bought by a consortium led by Koninklijke PTT of the Netherlands that included Swiss Telecom and AT&T.
The Government also recently completed the sale of a 49 percent stake in two of its largest refineries, Kralupy and Litvinov, to a consortium of Royal Dutch/Shell; Conoco of the United States, a unit of Du Pont, and AGIP of Italy for $180 million, plus a promise to invest $520 million more over five years.
And it is also getting ready to privatize its steel, mining, electricity and chemical industries later next year.
In Poland, where very few of the major state-owned enterprises have been sold to private investors, the Government is taking the first serious steps, Western bankers say. It recently set up a system under which 14 investment funds, with heavy representation of foreign capital and managers, will control about 400 state-owned companies.
In Hungary, polls show that the public is opposed to the selloffs, but the Government seems to have little choice. It is burdened with almost $22 billion in debt and is running big budget deficits. Selling state assets is one way to get bloated numbers of employees off public payrolls and repay some of the debt.
The sale of the 30 percent stake in MOL will represent the first time an oil company in Eastern Europe has gone on the block and one of the few times any government has offered to sell its national oil company.
MOL has several advantages. One is its sheer size. It dominates the economy, accounting for 90 percent of the nation's oil and gas production, refining and reserves. It is a fully integrated energy company, engaged in everything from exploration to importing natural gas from Russia, refining crude oil and operating a chain of gas stations. And its Duna oil refinery south of Budapest is considered "among the most sophisticated units in the Central and East European region," according to a recent report by Nomura Securities in London.
The same report estimated that the oil and gas reserves of MOL were worth $1.8 billion, greater than its current market value of $1 billion. (The Government currently owns 88 percent of MOL, while municipalities own 7 percent and individual investors have 5 percent.)
The global public offering that Merrill Lynch and Kleinwort Benson are planning in November is expected to bring in at least $300 million for the 30 percent stake.
But hopes for a smooth sale were nearly dashed on Sept. 12, when the Government dismissed two top executives at the company and replaced them with Lazlo Pal, a hard-line Socialist who is a leader of the far-left faction of the Socialist Party, the renamed Communists. A Russian-trained engineer with no experience in the oil business, he was dismissed as trade minister in June for opposing the privatization program.
In particular, he has opposed passing management control of strategic industries to foreign companies.
"I just don't know what the Government was thinking," said a prominent investment banker, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "How are you going to parade such a man before the international investment community in a credible way?"
Officials, though, were quick to defend Mr. Pal.
"We felt MOL needs a more dynamic personality at the head to get the privatization going," said Tamas Suchman, the Minister for Privatization.
And Mr. Pal issued a statement saying he fully embraced the Government's privatization plan.
In the end, the appointment was seen as an attempt by the Prime Minister to give Mr. Pal a visible appointment and blunt any political interference he might create.
But it did not make investors feel any more comfortable about attempts to persuade them that now was the time to buy into Hungary, especially since the Government has apparently scrapped plans to let a large energy company buy a controlling interest in MOL.
"Several American oil companies were interested in buying MOL," Peter Fath, executive director of the American Chamber of Commerce, told a local newspaper here. "Their top executives made repeated visits to Hungary, and Prime Minister Horn promised at the time that MOL would be available for strategic investors. He changed his mind. And now Mr. Pal is at the head of MOL."

HEADLINE: Pakistan Arrests 40 Officers; Islamic Militant Tie Suspected

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Oct. 16

 BODY:
In a move that has underscored growing political tensions in Pakistan, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Government has disclosed that it secretly arrested 40 army officers last month, one of them a two-star general, on suspicion that they were linked to Islamic fundamentalist groups.
Since confirming the arrests in a meeting with Pakistani newspaper editors on Saturday, Ms. Bhutto has imposed an official silence. But newspapers in Pakistan, citing Government officials, have said the officers were rounded up in Islamabad, the Pakistan capital, on Sept. 26, and taken to a military prison in the city of Quetta for questioning. 
 Some newspaper reports in Pakistan have said the officers are suspected of plotting to overthrow the Bhutto Government. But Western diplomats in Islamabad said a more likely explanation was that the Government, eager to enhance its ties with the United States and promote possible American arms deliveries, was responding to pressures from Washington for a crackdown on Islamic terrorist groups that have used Pakistan as a base.
For years, there have been allegations that officers of the Inter-Services Intelligence agency have been involved in arming and training Islamic fundamentalist groups that have mounted terrorist attacks outside Pakistan. Some Pakistan newspaper reports have said the most senior officer seized in the September roundup, Maj. Gen. Zahirul Islam Abbasi, who was the army's director general of infantry at the time of his arrest, previously served in the intelligence agency.
Diplomats who suggested that Ms. Bhutto's purpose in ordering the arrest had been to strengthen ties with the United States noted that in February she approved a joint operation in Islamabad by United States and Pakistani intelligence agents that captured Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, a prime suspect in the World Trade Center bombing in New York in February 1993 that killed six people and wounded more than 1,000. Mr. Yousef is now awaiting trial in New York.
The arrest of the officers is the latest in a series of developments that have underlined growing political instability in Pakistan. In recent months, the Bhutto Government has been arresting opposition leaders and placing new constraints on Pakistan's newspapers, and otherwise acting in a fashion that has caused critics to suggest that Pakistan's fragile democracy could be at risk.
In a new blow to the Government on Sunday, Nasir Hussain, the husband of Ms. Bhutto's sister, Sanam, was arrested at Karachi airport on suspicion of involvement in the slaying that day of a dissident member of the governing Pakistan People's Party. Ms. Bhutto's father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was Prime Minister in the 1970's, was hanged in 1979 after being convicted by a military court of involvement in the killing of a leading People's Party dissident.
According to published reports in Pakistan, those arrested last month included, besides General Abbasi, a colonel and at least 38 other officers. The arrests had been rumored in Islamabad for some time, but Pakistani newspapers ran no reports about them until Ms. Bhutto's remarks on the weekend.
Even then, the Prime Minister was elusive. "Some individuals are under investigation, but it is premature to say anything," she said. "When the investigations are completed, details will be known, and the nation will be taken into confidence."
One newspaper, The Daily News, said today that the officers had been arrested on suspicion of "violating service discipline" and "hatching a conspiracy to overthrow the Government by capturing the command of the Pakistan Army." The army has seized power on several occasions, ruling directly for 25 of the 48 years of Pakistan's existence.
But officials of the Bhutto Government who discussed the issue guardedly on the telephone played down the reports of a coup plot, saying an attempt to topple the Government would have required more than 40 officers, and more than one general.
But diplomats said Ms. Bhutto was more likely to have been prompted by events in Washington, where a joint House-Senate conference will shortly take up a measure passed by the Senate last month that would allow the first military sales in five years to Pakistan. An amendment to the foreign aid appropriations bill that was introduced by Senator Hank Brown, a Colorado Republican, would allow the United States in the coming year to deliver $368 million in military equipment that Pakistan bought in 1990, before the passage of the so-called Pressler amendment that banned military and economic aid to Pakistan until it abandons its covert nuclear weapons program.
Under the Brown amendment, Pakistan would get three Orion anti- submarine aircraft, air-to-air and surface-to-surface missiles, radar equipment and parts for Cobra helicopters, as well as parts and equipment for F-16 fighter-bombers that are part of Pakistan's front-line arsenal. The amendment would also make possible millions of dollars in direct economic aid to Pakistan.
But the measure is expected to face stiff opposition in the House-Senate discussions, and could be vetoed by President Clinton for other reasons even if it survives in the final version of the appropriations bill approved by the two houses.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bond Prices Retain Gains From Friday Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rebounded from early weakness yesterday to finish mostly higher, although the long bond was unchanged, with its yield remaining at a 20-month low of 6.30 percent and its price at 107 21/32.
Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said dollar weakness influenced the Treasury market to open on a down note after Friday's big rally. And there was some light profit taking after Treasury securities rallied strongly on Friday. 
 Among the hurdles facing the market in the days ahead are the resolution of the Federal budget battle and the size of the supply of Treasury securities that will be coming to market over the next few weeks. Federal authority to spend and borrow money expires next month unless the budget issue is resolved.
"Traders are wondering how any sort of debt-ceiling pressure will affect the Treasury auction schedule," Mr. Hamilton said. "Most seem to believe that there is a chance the Treasury may have to cut the size of this week's two- and five-year note announcement because of debt ceiling restrictions.
"Others aren't quite as concerned about the risk of hitting the ceiling this week, but the November refunding announcement could be affected if the resolution is not passed soon."
The lack of supply in the near term, he said, would lift prices of shorter maturitites.
But the market consensus is that there is very little likelihood that the Treasury will default on any of its debt. "What they could do instead is postpone a couple of the weekly bill auctions," Mr. Hamilton said, "something the Treasury has done in the past when the debt ceiling was reached." Postponing a couple of the auctions would mean that investors would be somewhat limited in choosing securities. Tomorrow, the Treasury will announce the size of its next auction of two- and five-year notes.
At the auction of new three-month and six-month bills yesterday, interest rates were sightly higher, underscoring a point made by Margo Evashevski, a Treasury analyst at MMS International in San Francisco. "Bills have seen less demand than the rest of the curve lately, given how far they are below the Federal funds," she said.
The rate for a three-month issue was up one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.32 percent, while the six-month issue was up 2 basis points, to 5.34 percent.
The December bond futures contract pulled back from the contract high set on Friday with investors declining to increase commitment without more proof that the economy was slowing and inflation was no danger.
Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research in Boston, said it was a quiet day in the futures market, with much of the time spent absorbing Friday's large gains. She said it appeared that 116 20/32 was the major support level for the week.
The December contract went as low as 116 28/32 on the day, with the high at 117 12/32. "Below 116 20/32, another support level would be a full point below at 115 20/32," Ms. Mesch said. "This is still a buy-on-the-dip market, and I would only change my mind about where the buy will turn, if within the next three days we're no higher than 117 15/32. Then I would consider the probability that the market would pull back to the lower stands of support." Yesterday she said the bond contract settled at 117 2/32.
The contract held above the support seen at around 117, but off the high of 117 19/32 set last week.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that August business inventories rose four-tenths of a percent, higher than the expected one-tenth of a percent and the rise of three-tenths of a percent in July. The cash market and futures trading in debt remained weaker after the data, which showed the highest monthly gain in a year.
The next interest rate reduction and market rally may hinge on whether a budget accord can be fashioned by Congress and the President. Most traders agree that the market has priced in most of the good economic news for now.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
The Air of a Holiday in an Ailing City

BYLINE: By Evelyn Nieves 

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J.

 BODY:
CARLAH MYERS and her two daughters were fairly skipping along Linden Street, taking in the morning. They looked like a postcard for Disney World, all three wearing smiles and Mickey Mouse shirts. And with the sun beating down a mid-October chill, if you squinted past the boarded row houses, their downtown neighborhood looked almost pretty.
It surely seemed a little different, for a Monday. Calmer, quieter. In the narrow business district, pedestrians stepped lightly and traffic moved at Sunday speed. It felt like a holiday. 
 "It's a great day to be alive," said Ms. Myers, who is 25. "Even in Camden." She didn't even mind that her daughters, 8 and 7, were out of school and that she had to drag them to the Laundromat. "All for a good cause," she said. "We firmly believe it."
Happily for city officials, she was not alone. When Camden decided to close the schools yesterday in observance of the Million Man March in Washington, it marked a first: the first time a school district shut down for an out-of-town rally where not everyone was invited. (The School Board said that so many employees had asked for the day off, it would have cost too much for substitutes. Parents could have rebelled. They didn't.)
And considering all the controversies surrounding the march for black men -- that it excluded black women, and everyone else; that it was organized by the Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan, famous for his divisive speech; that it asked blacks to boycott white businesses for the day -- you might have expected more criticism on the street.
But the march was endorsed in this predominantly black city at the highest levels. The Mayor, Arnold Webster, took the day off to attend. So did the schools superintendent, Roy Dawson. Women, while not allowed to go, were among those who cheerfully waved to the 1,000 or so men who boarded buses before dawn for their day of atonement and reconciliation at the National Mall.
"I know about 20 guys who went, including my brother," Ms. Myers said. "I'm proud of them."
SOME men who did not go said they would have liked to. Clay Price, an electrical contractor who opted to work ("I've got a family to feed"), said that if a similar rally were held here, he would try to make it. "We really need to address our situation," he said, shaking his head.
If there was ever a place that personified the thousand social ills the Million Man March organizers hope to address, Camden is it. It was almost too easy here to obey the march organizers who told blacks not to work today (the jobless rate hovers at about 22 percent), not to shop (more than half the residents live in poverty) and not to spend money (two-thirds receive some type of public assistance).
There are no movie theaters or major shopping centers, and the aquarium is out of reach for many residents. It costs $9.95 for adults and children over 11 to get in, $6.95 for younger children. (Ms. Myers took her daughters once. "It cost us about $50 for the day," she said. That, she added, is what she makes for two full days as a baby sitter.)
Neighborhood watch groups do their best, but violence persists. Last week, when two men were shot to death after an argument at a Chinese fast-food restaurant, the number of people murdered this year climbed to 47, four short of the record set in 1992. With 87,500 residents, Camden is moving closer to the top of the list of cities with the highest murder rates in the nation. The lead editorial in yesterday's Camden Courier-Post ("Camden police force could use outside help") suggested the Mayor call in the National Guard.
With all the good work and intentions of nonprofit community associations, much of Camden is falling down. On some blocks, all of the houses are boarded, some falling apart. Other blocks are barely breathing. (In some cases, drug dealers sitting on stoops and men sharing bottles of hard liquor on the corner are the only signs of life.) The vacant lots in many neighborhoods are hardly vacant. They are garbage repositories, strewn with broken furniture, refrigerators and burned debris.
If only the march organizers had offered an alternative to staying home and staying put. They might have asked: stay home -- and pick up one piece of trash on the street. Bring one can from the back of the cupboard to a soup kitchen. Take the heroin addict at the corner to a clinic. Clean up one little "vacant" lot.
THAT idea made Ms. Myers and her neighbor, Gladys Ramos, crack up laughing. "You would've gotten a lot more men going to the march and a lot more women complaining," Ms. Myers said. Her daughters were riffling through a battered algebra textbook that someone had left at the Laundromat. Was their father at the march? "I wouldn't know," their mother said.
"I do wish they would've invited everyone," said Ms. Ramos, who is raising her 3-year-old daughter alone. "They could have said, this is a day for black men, but everyone is invited to encourage and support us, for a change."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With school canceled in Camden, N.J., yesterday for the Million Man March, Shanera McCray, from left, Nakyta McCray, Larea Lee and Karen Wiggins watched the coverage, hoping for a glimpse of their fathers. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mitsubishi May End Its Chrysler Tie

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation is considering dissolving its United States car production agreement with the Chrysler Corporation by 1999, an official of the Japanese car maker said today.
Mitsubishi produces about 100,000 cars a year for Chrysler at its Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America plant in Normal, Ill. 
 A Mitsubishi spokeswoman said Hirokazu Nakamura, Mitsubishi's chairman, had told Japanese reporters recently that if the American auto maker wanted to go independent after the current vehicle-production arrangement expires in 1999, Mitsubishi's plant in Illinois would build only Mitsubishi models. It now also produces Eagle Talon, Chrysler Sebring and Dodge Avenger models for Chrysler.
The Japanese economic newspaper Nihon Keizai reported over the weekend that Chrysler saw little necessity for receiving supplies from Mitsubishi because of a "recovery in competition."
The spokeswoman said Mitsubishi would increase the number of dealerships by 60 in the United States by 1998 from the current 500 to strengthen its sales there.
But she refused to provide further details, saying that final decision on whether to renew the arrangement has yet to be made. She said negotiations between the two companies had yet to be held.
Chrysler buys Mitsubishi sports cars built in Japan and sells them as Dodge Stealth models. It also buys Mitsubishi small cars built in Japan and sells them as Eagle Summit models.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 605 words

HEADLINE: America Arms Turkey's Repression

 BODY:
Turkey lags behind only Israel and Egypt in receipt of American military aid. Washington has approved $7.8 billion in military sales to Turkey in the last decade -- and has provided grants or loans to cover most of it. This year, unless dramatic events take place in the current House-Senate conference, Turkey will get $320 million in American credits to finish production -- in Turkey -- of F-16 fighter planes.
America has traditionally used such aid to maintain its friendship with a strategically crucial ally. But the aid is now being used to prolong a war that both destabilizes Turkey and betrays American values. The State Department has acknowledged that Turkey is using the F-16's and other American weapons to strafe Turkish villages in its war against a Kurdish guerrilla group, killing thousands of civilians and leaving millions homeless. Washington should end the sale of weapons used in the war, and condition further military aid and sales on Turkish respect for human rights. 
 One-fifth of Turks are Kurdish, a minority so repressed that its members are even forbidden to speak Kurdish in many public settings. In 1984 the Marxist Kurdish Workers' Party, or P.K.K., began a brutal civil war, killing many civilian officials and Kurdish opponents. The Turkish Government responded with an even more brutal campaign to bomb and burn Kurdish villages. It has prosecuted even peaceful Kurdish politicians, writers and human rights workers whose only crime was describing the human rights violations. An American reporter for Reuters, Aliza Marcus, may be sentenced to three years in jail for her reporting from Kurdish areas. The P.K.K. is weak, but the Government has made little progress toward winning the war. Polls show that Turks overwhelmingly favor a political settlement.
Turkey's human rights record has caused several European countries to cut off military relationships -- although Germany just resumed aid -- and has so far denied Turkey coveted membership in the European Union. But the White House has allowed Turkish troops to pursue the P.K.K. into Kurdish areas of Iraq that America protects against Saddam Hussein. The Turkish incursions have killed many civilian Kurds.
Since the Turks' war against the P.K.K. escalated in 1992, American military aid to Turkey has escalated as well. Washington now provides 85 percent of Turkey's arms imports and 90 percent of its military aid. Despite the efforts of Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, and Representative John Edward Porter, an Illinois Republican, to curtail aid, Congress has not yet managed to block or place conditions on substantial amounts of Turkish military aid.
Turkey has escaped a cutback because of its strategic importance. America depends on military bases in Turkey, and wants Turkey to spread its moderate brand of Islam to Central Asia and its pro-Western views to the Balkans and the Mideast.
The Turkish Government and the Clinton Administration argue that any cuts in arms transfers would weaken and radicalize Turkey. But the war itself poses a greater threat to Turkey's stability and prosperity. Its Islamic party, a relatively moderate one, gained support after a ban on Kurdish parties left it as the only non-mainstream alternative.
Any further aid should carry human rights conditions that would promote a political solution to a war that has undermined Turkish democracy, boosted the power of the military, drained the economy and divided Turkey from its European allies. Placing such conditions on assistance would also reduce America's complicity in Turkey's repressive internal war.

HEADLINE: Dow Declines 9.40 Points, Despite Technology Issues' Gains

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stock prices weakened yesterday, beginning with a round of computer-guided sell orders and ending with anticipation about expected earnings reports from Intel and Microsoft.
Intel, after the stock market closed, said its third-quarter profits rose 38 percent, to $1.05 a share; its shares closed up 3/8, at 63 1/8. Microsoft, which is scheduled to report its results today, advanced 1/2, to 86 3/4. 
 "The market did not really have a big move one way or the other," said Don Hays, director of investment strategy at Wheat First Butcher Singer in Richmond. "It digested some of Friday's gains and backed off a little."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.40 points, or 0.20 percent, to 4,784.38. Among the broader averages, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 1.47 points, or 0.25 percent, to 583.03 and the Nasdaq composite index eased 0.25 point, or 0.02 percent, to 1,018.13.
Declining issues topped advances on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,210 to 1,061. Turnover on the Big Board was moderate, dropping to 300.8 million shares from 374.7 million shares on Friday.
"The tug of war is starting, and it will get even worse after the earnings season," Mr. Hays added. "Some people thought that the economy was too hot in January, and now there are growing concerns about a recession."
Food stocks declined after CPC International reported an earnings gain that analysts found disappointing. CPC fell 1/2, to 69; Kellogg dropped 1 1/2, to 72 5/8; and Procter & Gamble slumped 7/8, to 79 3/8.
Retail issues lost ground, spurred by concerns over speculation that Kmart may file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. K-Mart, which plunged to a five-year low Friday, continued to fall yesterday, closing down 7/8 at 10 1/2. Wal-Mart, which said that the retailing climate remained difficult in this price-cutting period, declined 5/8 to 22 1/2.
Financial companies were also lower. Chase, which reported a 7.8 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings, lost 1, to 64 5/8. Nationsbank, which posted a 23 percent gain, fell 3/8, to 71 1/4. Meanwhile, American Express slipped 1/4, to 44 1/2.
Many technology stocks, however, moved upward. In addition to Intel and Microsoft, Dell Computer advanced 1 1/4, to 84 1/4; the Andrew Corporation increased 1 3/4, to 46; and Zebra Technologies rose 2 7/8, to 56 3/4.
Medical-equipment stocks gained on a favorable earnings outlook, with Nellcor Puritan climbing 3 3/8, to 53 7/8, and Lunar surging 3 1/4, to 34 1/8. Texas Utilities jumped 1 3/8, to 36, on traders' expectations of improved financial performance.
A number of special situations suffered significant setbacks yesterday. The Equity Corporation International, a funeral-home operator, said third-quarter net income would fall below Wall Street estimates; its shares dropped 2 3/4, to 20 1/2. Cincinnati Microwave, which announced that it expected to report a third-quarter loss, declined 2 1/2 to 8. And International Lottery, which said that MCI Communications was questioning an order for phone-card dispensing machines, slipped 2, to 10 3/4. MCI ended off 1/8, at 24 1/2.

HEADLINE: Observer;
He Filled a Vacuum

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
So it was left to Louis Farrakhan to act. It is hard to say why without speaking realistically of the state of American politics, which has less and less to do with anything of consequence.
Surely somebody of stature, Democrat or Republican, ought to have felt obliged to act long ago. It is hardly a secret that one of the country's most dangerous problems is the increasingly desperate situation of its young black male citizens. 
 The portrait of a nation in trouble is etched in the statistics on black unemployment rates, black school dropouts, rising imprisonment of young blacks and killings of black youngsters by black youngsters.
When a large portion of a nation's youth is being thrown away, or hustled into prisons, or lowered into graves, it takes a remarkable capacity for indifference to say that, well, it's a pity, but it's not our problem, it's a problem for the black community, black churches, black neighborhood leaders.
It is hard to see how a multiracial nation can avoid damage if its leaders refuse to deal with its gravest problems on ground that they are distinctively problems of race.
This mistake was made by President Eisenhower 40 years ago and swiftly regretted, for Eisenhower was a serious man, serious about government's duties. He tried to avoid the multiracial reality of America in the Arkansas school desegregation crisis by arguing that race passions resided in the human heart, which could not be changed by government action.
When Arkansas's white Governor Faubus proposed to let the white human heart express itself by defying a court desegregation order, however, Eisenhower used the Army to preserve government by law.
Everybody now knows about the problem of the young black male, and nobody with power has done anything about it. To be sure, President Clinton has gone into the occasional black church and made the correct sounds, but where is the high-powered, bipartisan, interracial Presidential commission empowered to recommend executive and legislative action?
Have the leaders of the black community put pressure on White House and Congress to wake up? If so, the pressure has been as that of a feather pillow on the pyramid of Cheops.
Who are the leaders of this black community, anyhow? Are there any, or are they just fictional creations of the media? Maybe the "black community" is fictional, too. Why shouldn't it be? After all, there is no such thing as a "white community," no group who can sensibly be called "white leaders."
Maybe it is tired old racist thinking to keep talking about a "black community" complete with "black leaders." Maybe it makes more sense nowadays to drop all that separatist language and say, "There's nobody here but us Americans."
The Clinton Administration is not the first to do nothing about the desperate situation of the young black American. Doing nothing about it has been the unswerving policy of Presidents back as far as Richard Nixon. Not incidentally, it was Mr. Nixon's so-called "Southern strategy" that rebuilt the Republican Party on white hostility to the Democratic record on civil rights.
Nor are the dynamic new Gingrich conservatives engaged with the problem. The Contract With America may ask us to assume that its blessings will lead, one of these days, to more secure childhoods, better schooling, better jobs and a full dinner pail for young black men, but in the meantime it is explicit about the need to cut welfare.
If a single Republican Presidential candidate has spoken of the matter that produced the Million Man March, it has been a pianissimo performance.
Let's not forget, either, the fierce and forbidding tetchiness of many black people, which discourages whites from discussing the problem. It is understandable that a politician might ignore the subject entirely when he fears that getting involved may earn him the epithet of "racist."
Some kind of action was overdue. There was a vacuum to be filled. Politics has declined into a game for overgrown boys and their high-tech toys. You win by finessing reality. So finally it was left for Louis Farrakhan to act. It made a lot of people so mad they could spit. That often happens when good people have done nothing.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Profits Surge At Ameritech For Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The Ameritech Corporation said today that its third-quarter profits from operations rose nearly 11 percent as a result of an increase in the number of its telephone lines and the traffic they carried.
The Chicago-based regional Bell telephone company said its net income more than doubled, mainly because of one-time items. The results met analysts' expectations. 
 Ameritech reported profit from operations of $464.3 million, or 84 cents a share, compared with $419.1 million, or 76 cents, a year earlier.
Including one-time items in both quarters, net income totaled $512.5 million in the latest quarter, compared with $250.9 million in the 1994 quarter. Third-quarter revenue rose 6.7 percent to $3.38 billion, from $3.17 billion.
Ameritech said it posted a record 4.4 percent increase in the number of phone lines to more than 1 million. Oren Shaffer, chief financial officer, said the record growth was due to increased marketing efforts by Ameritech. The amount of traffic on Ameritech's network rose 8.7 percent, the company said.
The rise in earnings was powered by "strong local-service revenue gains driven by record growth in access lines and successful new product introductions," Connie Luecke, a Duff & Phelps analyst, said in a research report.
Ms. Luecke cautioned that Ameritech's earnings growth would slow next quarter as the "trend of declining depreciation expense reverses," Luecke wrote.
Telephone-line growth was better than expected, according to Richard Klugman, an analyst at Paine Webber Research.
And the number of cellular customers rose 47 percent from a year ago to 1.67 million. The increase was buoyed by a low "churn rate" of 12 percent annually, Ameritech said. By comparison, the industry average for "churn" -- the rate at which customers leave one company to buy cellular services from another -- is about 31 percent annually, according to Economic Management Consultants International, a market research firm in Washington.
One-time items in the latest quarter's net income included a gain of $6.9 million, or 1 cent a share, for job cuts and a gain of $41.3 million, or 7 cents, from the sale of certain cellular operations. The 1994 quarter's results included a charge of $168.2 million, or 30 cents a share, for job cuts.

HEADLINE: What Economists See

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Nobel laureate in economics Robert E. Lucas Jr. told the press (Business Day, Oct. 11) that the United States economy "is in excellent shape." I see stagnant real wages, large-scale unemployment and underemployment, increasing inequality of wealth and income shares, rising poverty, persistent racial disadvantage and much more that burdens most people. 
 When I studied economics, the test that mattered was the well-being of people and their communities. The 1986 pastoral letter of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, "Economic Justice for All," summed it up well: what the economy does to people and for people.
Are we looking at the same economy? Or have economists so narrowed their vision they cannot connect the intellectual world they live in with the real world they purport to explain?
 
SUMNER M. ROSEN
New York, Oct. 12, 1995
The writer retired as professor of economics at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
French and Italian Politics Send Mark Up and the Dollar Down

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most other leading currencies yesterday as new political troubles in France and Italy bolstered the German mark.
The political uncertainty raised doubt that the two Governments would make the tough budget choices needed to meet requirements for European monetary union laid out in the Maastricht treaty, and it sent some investors seeking security in the mark, analysts said. 
 The slide of the franc and lira against the mark weighed on the dollar because some of these transactions were executed through dollars. Traders will sell, for example, francs and lire for dollars and then sell those dollars for marks.
Nevertheless, the dollar remained well within recent ranges yesterday. Since Sept. 22, the dollar has traded between 1.4058 and 1.4440 marks and 97.50 and 101.81 yen. Trade reports from the United States and Japan, to be released today and tomorrow, might give the dollar clearer direction, traders said.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar slipped to 100.63 Japanese yen from 100.97 yen on Friday. It fell to 1.4235 marks from 1.4265 marks and to 1.1543 Swiss francs from 1.1547 francs. But the British pound slipped to $1.5740 from $1.5755.
The French franc slumped after the nation's central bank surprised investors by cutting its 24-hour loan rate. The franc suffered another blow when the newspaper Le Monde reported that Finance Minister Jean Arthuis was embroiled in an investigation of possibly illegal political financing.
The decision to cut its 24-hour loan rate by a quarter-point, to 7 percent, came just a week after the French raised the rate by 1.10 percentage points to shore up the franc.
"The fact that the Bank of France rather prematurely cut rates this morning quite surprised investors," said Callum Henderson, senior currency analyst at MMS International.
Lower French rates reduce the return that investors receive on franc-denominated deposits and often make the French currency less attractive. The franc was last at 3.4868 francs to the mark, weaker than 3.4772 late Friday in New York.
The mark gained versus the Italian lira after former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi threatened to oppose Italy's 1996 budget. On Saturday, Mr. Berlusconi, who still heads a conservative coalition, was ordered to stand trial on corruption charges, a case that could hurt his chances to regain high office.
