HEADLINE: Crackdown on Mob at Fish Market Brings Chaos

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
The first day of New York City's latest crackdown on Mafia domination of the Fulton Fish Market dissolved into chaos early yesterday as hundreds of workers staged a wildcat strike, virtually halting seafood distribution and prompting Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to threaten a temporary shutdown of the market.
Asserting that some workers and merchants were trying to sabotage his plan to clean up the market, Mr. Giuliani warned that he might reorganize it by hiring new workers and by licensing different merchants to do business there if disorder continued. Under a law that went into effect on Sept. 1, the city has the power to determine who can work and run businesses in the market, the nation's largest wholesale seafood distribution center. 
 Police officers were out in force early this morning in an effort to avoid a repeat of the disruptions.
The predawn walkout yesterday came hours after the city installed a new company, the Laro Maintenance Corporation, to unload fish and seafood there and evicted six companies that Federal investigators said were suspected of being linked to mobsters.
Almost no seafood or fish was sold at the Fulton market yesterday. Buyers for city restaurants scrambled to line up other sources of seafood and fish, and most said they were able to assure a steady supply.
The workers who walked off their jobs were employees of the approximately 60 wholesale seafood vendors that operate at the market. They said their job action was a show of solidarity with the 40 employees who lost their jobs when the six unloading companies were evicted.
The eviction and the walkout produced hours of confusion and tension for workers, the police and the market's customers. At one point, the market was plunged into almost complete darkness when master electrical switches were tampered with and employees roamed around the market, disrupting operations.
The tension continued into this morning, as the police escorted wholesalers to and from the market. When the wholesalers arrived to deliver their fish, they stopped at a checkpoint for police officers to enter the trucks; the officers then stood by as each truck was unloaded, and later escorted it out of the market to another checkpoint several blocks away.
For some out-of-town wholesalers, what would normally have been a two- or three-hour delivery turned into a journey that found them in the city for almost 24 hours.
Some distributors said small retail stores in the New York area might soon be without seafood or fish if the market was disrupted another day or two. They said they would have to seek supplies from markets in Philadelphia, in Boston and on the Pacific Coast, raising the likelihood that customers would pay higher prices.
Wholesale dealers in the market said their individual losses in potential sales yesterday ranged from $20,000 to $100,000. Representatives for the 60 vendors estimated that far less than half of the 500,000 pounds of fish that flows into the market each workday was delivered, but because of the chaos, virtually no buyers could enter the market.
"If there is a repeat performance tonight of last night," a stern-faced Mr. Giuliani said yesterday at City Hall, "we will close the market, and we will reconstitute the work force and we will make certain that the work force is not influenced by organized crime, not influenced by corruption and not influenced by the desire to commit illegal acts or to extort people who do business there, or the city of New York.
"It would be better for the city actually not to have the Fulton Fish Market if it's going to be operated the way it has been for the last 40, 50, 60 years."
More than 100 million pounds of fish and seafood are sold each year at the market, generating about $1 billion a year in business.
But for decades, officials say, much of that money has wound up in the pockets of organized crime, setting off a seemingly endless series of often-futile crackdowns by law enforcement agents.
City officials, Federal prosecutors and a temporary Federal administrator have charged that the six evicted companies, known as unloaders, were a mob-influenced cartel dictating fees paid by the dealers and the manner in which trucks were unloaded. By doing so, the officials contend that the companies had an economic stranglehold over the movement of perishable supplies into the market and were not permitting dealers to switch companies.
The owners of the six unloading companies have denied any ties to organized crime and none have been indicted or charged with a crime.
Under the new system, officials say, the Laro company has cut unloading costs by about 20 percent and guaranteed to unload cargoes on a first come, first served basis.
But from the moment the Laro workers took over late Sunday night, confusion and congestion reigned, and most wholesale dealers said the old system was more efficient than the new arrangement.
The drivers who brought seafood in refrigerated 18-wheel trailers from ports as far away as New Brunswick in Canada and the Gulf of Mexico complained that the Laro crews were incompetent, mishandling the forklifts and pallets used to remove cargo and transport it 50 to 60 feet to merchants' stalls. Laro, based in Bay Shore, L.I., has no experience in seafood distribution. The company's business has largely involved cleaning office buildings, airports and the Statue of Liberty.
The drivers said that if the disruptions continued, seafood suppliers and transportation companies would shy away from the market because of possible financial loses.
"They have no idea what they're doing," said Bryan Sullivan, a driver for JDS Refrigerated Transporation of Chelsea, Mass., who waited seven hours to be unloaded. "They're doing everything wrong."
Frank Minio, a dealer and the owner of Smitty's Fillet House, said he was stuck with 20,000 pounds of cod, sole, red snapper and tuna. "I'm not sure what happened, but no customers showed up," he added.
Owners of three of the six ousted companies, standing near their former work sites early this morning, criticized Laro employees, and denied any Mafia influence in their businesses or assertions that they were trying to disrupt the market.
"We have no intention of causing trouble," said Jerry Prisinzano, owner of one of the companies. "We just want to get our businesses back."
The revised unloading system is the most critical step taken by the Giuliani administration to revamp the market under new regulatory powers granted by the City Council. In March, one of the two main market buildings was gutted by arson and since then the administration has substantially raised rents for dealers and also evicted six merchants who failed background checks.
Robert Bertuglia Jr., the president of Laro, who worked through the night at the market supervising crews, said many wholesalers and drivers were sympathetic to the ousted companies and their 40 employees and had tried to slow the unloading process. Mr. Bertuglia said between 58 and 65 trucks were unloaded.
An additional 20 trucks could not be unloaded, he said, because employees of the wholesale dealers, who are called journeymen, intimidated Laro employees. All 50 of his employees were forced to leave at 5:30 A.M. under police escort.
"We did a hell of a job," Mr. Bertuglia said, "considering all the intimidation and obstacles we encountered."
The sympathy that Mr. Bertuglia saw from the drivers did not seem evident in the long line of trucks waiting to enter the market. Frustrated drivers clanged incessantly on ear-shattering tractor-trailer horns to protest unloading delays that in some cases reached up to 15 hours.
Grim wholesalers said that the new and inexperienced unloading crews brought in by the city were unable to deliver most of their consignments before 3 A.M., when buyers show up.
For several hours, the market was plunged into almost total darkness after someone tampered with master switches for the huge fluorescent lights that illuminate the wholesalers' stalls along South Street on the banks of the East River near the Brooklyn Bridge.
When morning came and the market's day ended, wooden crates and cardboard boxes filled with salmon and lobsters from Bucks Harbor, Me., oysters from Chesapeake Bay and Whiting from Mastic Beach, L.I., were piled in front of the dealers' stalls. Merchants said the only way they could preserve the supplies was by caking it in ice.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 401 words

HEADLINE: Nafta Costs Mexico More Job Losses Than U.S.;
Long-Shaky Peso

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Oct. 12 news analysis on the Mexican $52 billion rescue operation engineered by the Clinton Administration demands some redress. 
 Democratic Congressional critics -- notably Richard Gephardt, David Bonior, Marcy Kaptur -- and others like the Economic Policy Institute's Jeff Faux and Thea Lee made a clear connection between the North American Free Trade Agreement and the peso collapse in December 1994.
Mexico was running a current account deficit of $23 billion to $25 billion in 1994, which reflected an overvalued peso that exaggerated American exports to Mexico and minimized Mexican exports to the United States, creating a substantial trade surplus in favor of the United States.
Proponents of Nafta extrapolated this surplus as a permanent feature of the American-Mexico economic relationship and urged that the excess of exports over imports from Mexico meant the trade agreement would create 170,000 net new jobs in the remainder of the decade.
The critics argued that this surplus was unsustainable and that it was being financed largely with "hot" money -- funds seeking a higher return than they could obtain in more conventional financial markets. But these funds were volatile, subject to interest rate increases in the United States and flight at the merest hint of political difficulties, of which there was no lack in Mexico.
Even impeccably establishment economists such as Rudi Dornbusch of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and John Williamson of the Institute for International Economics testified to this effect in May 1993, six months before Nafta was approved by Congress.
Why didn't Mexican and United States authorities address the already evident overvaluation of the peso? Because they were determined to obtain Congressional passage of Nafta and to assure victory by the governing party candidate in the Mexican presidential elections in August 1994 so as to consolidate the economic strategy that led to the trade agreement.
Devaluation of the peso would have exposed the artificiality of the United States trade surplus with Mexico and the bankruptcy of the net-new-jobs argument derived from that surplus, the basis on which the North American Free Trade Agreement was sold to the American public.
 
JEROME I. LEVINSON
Bethesda, Md., Oct. 12, 1995
The writer is adjunct professor, international relations, American U.

HEADLINE: Business Assails Democrats on Pension Bills

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Big business fired back today at Democrats who argue that Republican legislation would endanger Americans' retirement security.
The Chamber of Commerce, the National Association of Manufacturers and other industry groups released two studies by consulting firms supporting legislation that would permit companies to withdraw funds from employee pension plans. 
 House and Senate committees have approved different versions. The more expansive House proposal could lead to withdrawals of as much as $40 billion, generating extra revenue for the Government because the money would then become taxable.
The Clinton Administration has denounced the provision as a pension raid that would drain money invested on behalf of workers, running the risk that some pension funds could fail if interest rates and the stock market dropped sharply.
The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the Federal agency backing pension funds, said 22,000 plans covering 2 million retirees and 11 million current employees could potentially be affected.
But one study released by the business groups, by Towers Perrin, said the provision would result in "only a tiny increased risk" that a plan would become underfinanced.
Another study, by Watson Wyatt Worldwide, said the pension agency's worst-case assumption for evaluating the safety of pension plans -- a 1 percent drop in interest rates combined with a 10 percent drop in securities prices -- "has never happened over the past 70 years."

A SALUTE TO A HARBOR OASIS
When Capt. Kevin Ray first heard eight years ago that he would be transferred from his Coast Guard posting in New Orleans to Governors Island, at the foot of Manhattan, his heart plummeted like an anchor. But as word spread around the hushed, campus-like haven of Governors Island that the Coast Guard had decided to close the base after 29 years, Captain Ray allowed that there were more than a few things he would miss about the place. SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1363 words

HEADLINE: Vote Leaves Iraqi as Winner and West at a Loss

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 17

 BODY:
On Monday, as Saddam Hussein was celebrating his 99.96 percent approval rating in Sunday's referendum on his presidency, 25-year-old Malek was loitering outside a hospital here, looking for a customer for one of his kidneys.
The gaunt young man, who has been out of work for two years and would not give his full name, seemed oblivious to the fanfare surrounding the official celebration, in which the Government-controlled media was lavishing every imaginable praise on President Hussein. 
 Malek's major preoccupation was finding an elusive Libyan who he thought would pay $550 for a healthy kidney, a small fortune in Iraq's depressed economy.
"At first my parents were opposed, but I have to support them and two brothers and a sister," Malek said as he sat at a teahouse in a Muslim Shiite neighborhood of Baghdad. "Now they see the necessity."
Five years of economic sanctions, imposed by the United Nations after Iraq invaded Kuwait, have deepened the poverty and despair of Iraqis to the extent that Baghdad has become a center for wealthy Arabs in search of organs for transplant.
But the sanctions seem to have had little impact on Mr. Hussein or the power structure over which he presides unperturbed and, according to many Iraqis and foreign diplomats, secure.
Although the Iraqi leader's downfall has become the undeclared condition for lifting the economic siege -- at least as far as the United States and its Arab gulf allies, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, are concerned -- Mr. Hussein's domination of Iraq appears to be growing, periodically reaffirmed by the ability of his Baath Arab Socialist Party to mobilize a downtrodden population almost at will.
"If this referendum proves anything, it is that the party is firmly in control of Iraq and Saddam runs it with an iron fist," a Western ambassador here said. "If they can organize a referendum like this in less than three weeks, mobilize party cadres in every village, hamlet, town and city, produce precise lists for eight million voters and march all of them to the polls to say 'yes' unanimously, it means they are not about to fall.".
Mr. Hussein, who made no public appearances during the referendum, was sworn in today as President for another seven years in a televised ceremony. His Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, pledged political reforms, including parliamentary elections next year, although previously promised reforms have not materialized.
In Karbala, a stronghold of the Shiite minority about 55 miles south of Baghdad, the streets were nearly deserted on Sunday, but the polling stations were full of people waving their "yes" ballots for all to see.
The population in Karbala rose up in revolt against Mr. Hussein's rule in March 1991 after the Persian Gulf war. Ironically, the brutal suppression of that rebellion was overseen by Lieut. Gen. Hussein Kamel al-Mahjid, a son-in-law of President Hussein who defected to Jordan in August.
But when the referendum results were announced in Karbala on Monday evening, 270,867 voters there, where many families lost relatives in the uprising, had said "yes" to the President's continued rule.
Not one had voted "no," the Government said.
Judging by scores of impromptu interviews here in the last week, however, it is not clear that Saddam Hussein would have been rejected had the voting been free.
Many Iraqis simply do not understand why their country is prohibited under the United Nations sanctions from selling its oil and blame their predicament on foreign attitudes that extend beyond a personal vendetta against President Hussein to a longstanding prejudice against Arabs in general.
Even those who dare voice dissident views in the privacy of their homes express contradictory sentiments as to who is responsible for Iraq's miseries, their anger alternating between President Hussein and the West.
"About a year ago, it became clear that even Saddam understands he has to comply with the United Nations conditions" for easing the sanctions, including full disclosure of information on weapons of mass destruction, a dissident poet said. "The regime speaks openly of its intention to comply on radio and television. But the more it does, the more it appears the American aim is not just contrition but the destruction of Iraq as a unified nation, and the humiliation of Iraqis as a people.
"It is time for the world to re-examine the notion of using sanctions to obtain political aims," the poet continued. "Castro is still there after 35 years of sanctions. In Iraq, it has been five years. If there were any chance that people would rise again, they would have risen by now."
Instead of rebelling, Iraqis appear preoccupied with the struggle to survive from one day to the next.
On Baghdad's largest shopping avenue, Saadoun, Dawood Hillal did not want to hear about politics or who is to blame for Iraq's tribulations.
"Please don't ask silly questions," the pharmacist said, standing amidst rows of empty shelves. "We have 11,000 children dying of malnutrition here every year. Nothing can justify this genocide.
"For every 50 people that come in, I can help one, maybe," he said. "Before the war, we had 5,500 varieties of subsidized medicines in Iraq. Now we have 100 categories, and most of what I get of those hardly lasts for five days."
For its part, the Government has been actively reinforcing its defenses.
In private conversations, Government officials say they believe that the sanctions may continue for some time, at least until the presidential elections in the United States, more than a year from now.
In a two-hour conversation, Information Minister Hamid Yusif al-Hammadi, a close confident of President Hussein, gave the impression of a leadership that has deftly shifted the blame for Iraq's plight to the West while blunting the impact of the economic sanctions.
"There are some good aspects to the situation," Mr. Hammadi said. Imports of food have plummeted from 75 to 30 percent, he said, and productivity, particularly in agriculture, has increased as consumption has been forced down.
He said that the Government has allowed one of the most severely affected segments of Iraq's 20 million population, the nearly 1 million Government employees on fixed incomes, to seek outside jobs to supplement its pay.
With the money that remains from the more prosperous times before the 1990 invasion of Kuwait, Iraq is launching several labor-intensive projects including the construction of three major dams, south of Sammarra and north and south of Mosul.
And Government-controlled rationing of food insures that most Iraqis get half their needed calorie intake.
"The upshot is: There are hardships, but this is not Rwanda," Mr. Hammadi said. "If the United States thinks it can use starvation as a weapon against Iraq, it will be frustrated."
The country's chief vulnerability appears to be the acute shortage of medicine.
A waiter at a restaurant frequented by several foreign reporters here slipped a note to one as he left. It said: "Dear sir, sorry to trouble you. I know you are very kind and therefore, when you leave the country, could you give me whatever medication you have. I'm poor and I have a big family. The winter is coming. Any antibiotics would be a great help."
However, none of these miseries appear to touch those who run the country.
Shortly before the voting started on Sunday, the nationalist Russian politician, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the highest-ranking foreign observer invited to monitor the referendum, bounced happily into the lobby of Baghdad's Rashid Hotel following what he described as a sumptuous banquet with President Hussein.
"The President is in a very good mood; he was philosophical and relaxed," declared Mr. Zhirinovsky, who was making his fourth visit to Iraq.
Mr. Zhirinovsky was received with great fanfare on his arrival on Sunday and taken to a Baghdad palace where he feasted with President Hussein, Mr. Aziz, the Deputy Prime Minister, and other top officials on what he described as "a beautiful fish -- a presidential fish -- in a palace that the Americans couldn't and didn't bomb during the last war."

HEADLINE: Yale Degree, Minus the Fabled Dorms

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 17

 BODY:
With their ornate neo-Gothic towers, gated courtyards and oak-paneled dining halls, the dormitories here at Yale have come to epitomize a certain ideal of what college life should be like: "A stage set made in Hollywood for a musical about Oxford," the British magazine Punch wrote of the campus.
For more than a half-century, the residential colleges, as Yale refers to its undergraduate living quarters, have been viewed as much more than dormitories. These intimate communities of 400 to 500 students, who dine, study and party together, is touted by university officials as the centerpiece of the Yale experience. 
 So why, in 1995, are hundreds of the best and brightest fleeing these hallowed dorms, which now number 12, to live on their own in New Haven, a troubled city that prospective freshmen often cite as a reason to go to Harvard?
"If I were to put in three words why people move off campus, it would be 'food, food, food,' " said Tim Randall, a junior from Old Saybrook, Conn. To make dorm life bearable, he equipped the patio outside his room with a Weber grill and hot tub that he brought from home.
"This is terrible," moaned another student, as he showed a visitor his dorm room. "I'm 20 years old and I'm sharing a room with a bunk bed."
Richard C. Levin, Yale's president, said, "I've talked with some students who are going off campus for cable television," adding that this was a minority.
There is no single explanation for the exodus, but this year, a record number -- about 890 of the 5,100 undergraduates -- have moved off campus, up almost 70 percent from the roughly 530 living outside the colleges five years ago. Students and university officials point out that rising Yale board prices -- now accounting for $6,630 of the $27,630 term bill -- have coincided with a sharp drop in New Haven rents. While some dorms have become run-down, the neighborhoods surrounding Yale have been redeveloped, with university support, and appear to have become safer.
At the same time, students seem to be less tolerant of doubling up in a small bedroom (only seniors are guaranteed singles) and living without the latest amenities.
True, the campus living conditions are not dramatically different from years past, and Yale undergraduates have survived them, even enjoyed them, for decades. Alumni even talk fondly of the food.
But this is a new generation of students. Right now, many say, it is simply not cool to live in the dorms.
Although Yale is unusual among most American colleges in housing the vast majority of its students on campus, it is not alone in experiencing this exodus. The percentage of undergraduates living off campus nationally has increased to 85 percent from 80 percent five years ago, said Barbara Jacoby, director of the National Clearinghouse for Commuter Programs, based at the University of Maryland.
While part of that increase can be attributed to the growth of community colleges and urban colleges, Dr. Jacoby said that the shift is relevant to almost all colleges, going beyond economic reasons. "It's also a life-style issue," she said. "Students want out of in loco parentis."
At a few state college campuses in the Midwest, dormitories have been boarded up, and housing administrators across the country have taken steps to upgrade their dormitories. At the University of Nebraska at Lincoln, the school has added hundreds of single rooms and special meal plans, built new parking spaces adjacent to dorm rooms and rewired the buildings for computer hookups and cable television.
"It's not the same as when I started college in 1963," said Doug Zatechka, housing director at the University of Nebraska. "We see more and more students who had their own room, their own TV, their own stereo, their own telephone and their own telephone number. It's more difficult for them to share a dresser and space."
"I'm not blaming them," he added. "They're coming in here with 18 years of experience, and we have to adjust."
Yale, too, is taking the issue seriously.
To address the complaints of dilapidated dormitories, including tales of mice, cockroaches, heatless winter nights and leaking ceilings, Yale is renovating all its dormitories and is scheduled to complete the job in the next five years. In response to complaints about the food, the university has offered a more flexible meal plan that gives students $100 in credit per semester at off-campus restaurants.
Mr. Levin has also prohibited any sophomores from moving off campus, starting next year. (Freshmen are already forbidden to do so). And he appeared a little perplexed as to why such a step would be necessary.
"To me, I find it surprising that students who have the opportunity to live in such a beautiful place don't take it," he remarked. "They will have the opportunity to cook their own meals for the rest of their lives."
Yet on a recent morning, Sara Glassman, a 21-year-old junior from Minneapolis, relished the chance to show the two-bedroom, sixth-floor apartment that she called "an oasis above New Haven."
"It's a matter of independence," said Ms. Glassman, who chose Yale, in part, because of the residential colleges. She had lived in one for two years, enjoyed it and was ready to move into an apartment with a kitchen, a bathroom that she did not need to share with nine other students and a bedroom large enough for her desk.
True, the elevator in Ms. Glassman's building was broken, the front door was unlocked and the walls between apartments appeared thin, but none of that dimmed her enthusiasm. "This is a very in building," she said, noting that dozens of undergraduates lived there.
Another off-campus resident, Richard Kim, a junior, explained that Yale's diversity may make living in cramped quarters more challenging today than it had been a decade ago.
Take his roommates' taste in music, Mr. Kim said. "Stan listens to Gangsta Rap, Ian's into the Vh-1 scene, and I'm into the club-rave like thing. Rex is into alternative music. Any time you walk into the house, you can hear five different CD players on."
Last year in the dorms, Mr. Kim added, there was room for only one stereo, and it was not easy reaching a music consensus..
Other students complained that the dorms did not offer the amenities they had at home. On Monday night, Mr. Randall emerged from his hot tub and said that the master at his college had recently told him it would have to go.
"You have to put up with a lot of grief to stay on campus," he said.
Still, Mr. Randall said he would not move off campus. "When else in your life can you walk out your door, have 15 people walk by your door and know them all," he said. "It's the Yale experience."
It is not easy to generalize about who moves off campus. There are athletes who want to live together and cannot do it on campus because they were assigned to different colleges. There are politically active students, who want to be more in tune with New Haven.
And there are vegetarians who prefer to do their own cooking. Donnan Steele, a junior who describes himself as a "vegan," said he lost 20 pounds freshman year trying to survive on the dining hall fare.
Some at Yale worry that students are clustering into like-minded groups in off-campus apartments, weakening the heterogeneous character fostered by the college system. But others say that the students maintain their ties to their colleges and do not necessarily segregate into exclusive cliques.
Many say that they are motivated by the chance to save money. Fergus Cullen, who graduated in 1994, estimated that he saved $1,000 a semester.
Yale officials say that they bear some responsiblity for their predicament. Most of the undergraduates live in the Dwight neighborhood, west of campus, and that is the area that Yale has worked extensively to improve, placing a University police substation there, remodeling an apartment building and winning a $2.4 million Federal urban renewal grant.
The influx of undergraduates, Mr. Levin said, is "the consequence of our own success."

HEADLINE: Move to Prevent Default Stirs White House-G.O.P. Clash

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today took the first of a series of actions meant to insure that the budget battle does not force a default on Government payments at the end of this month.
But Republican leaders immediately charged that the White House was manipulating Government finances in an effort to force Congress into raising the debt limit before the current budget battle is over. 
 At best, the tactics announced today by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin will allow the Government to keep paying its bills for a few days into November before hitting the national debt limit, the ceiling on borrowing set by Congress. Republican leaders have said they will embed legislation raising the limit in their version of the budget, a bill President Clinton has vowed to veto.
Today's action stepped up the maneuvering, with Mr. Rubin saying that the moves will cost taxpayers in the form of higher interest rates and charging that Republicans bear the responsibility for those costs because they have brought the United States to the brink of default.
Speaker Newt Gingrich fired right back. He said late today that he had offered a short-term increase in the debt limit to Mr. Rubin, but was ignored. "We're certainly trying to work with them," he said. "They've done nothing to negotiate on this." He also said Mr. Rubin was "remarkably irresponsible" for saying that the Government would hit the debt ceiling by Oct. 31, rather than on Nov. 15, the date Mr. Gingrich said he previously understood would mark the real deadline. But a review of Mr. Rubin's public comments over the past few months shows that he has consistently said the limit would be reached by the end of October.
But beyond the politicking, Mr. Rubin is playing a delicate political and financial game, attempting to send virtually opposite messages to domestic and foreign audiences.
At home he is warning of a financial calamity, telling the Republicans that they are risking America's unblemished credit rating and forcing the Treasury to take actions that will increase the Federal Government's interest costs. But abroad, Mr. Rubin is trying to calm the waters, telling foreign investors -- who hold approximately a quarter of the Treasury's debt issues, that default is "unthinkable." The fear is that foreign investors would pull out of the market for Treasury securities rather than take the risk of being caught in a battle between Republicans and the White House, a battle in which their interest payments might be held hostage.
"This is no way for a great nation to conduct its financial affairs," Mr. Rubin wrote today in a letter to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader and the leading candidate for the Republican nomination for President, and to Mr. Gingrich. Congress's continued unwillingness to raise the debt limit, he warned, "is now causing disruptions, for which Congress must assume full responsibilities."
For weeks now, Mr. Rubin's staff has been spewing statistics about the cost of even a fractional increase in interest rates. Republicans say that the figures are a scare tactic: Today Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who heads the Senate Budget Committee, threatened to call Mr. Rubin to testify at hearings about just when the United States would run out of money.
The steps taken today are reminiscent of moves made during the last battle over the debt limit, during the Bush Administration in 1990. The Treasury said today that it will reduce, to $6 billion, the size of a weekly Treasury bill auction scheduled for next week. That assures that the Treasury can go ahead with a longer-term bond offering at the end of the month without hitting the debt ceiling.
Mr. Rubin also announced that until the debt limit issue is resolved, Treasury will no longer issue a special type of non-marketable securities to state and local government for "refunding," a rough equivalent to refinancing a house mortgage with a lower-rate loan. Again, Mr. Rubin said the Treasury's intent was to forestall hitting the debt limit. But by barring help to local governments, Mr. Rubin is effectively triggering some pain for Republican lawmakers back in their home districts.
"We wanted to make this real, something concrete," said a senior Treasury official involved in the planning.
In fact, few think that the United States would actually default on its debt -- something that has never happened in the country's history. But an actual default would not be necessary to rattle investors. Just the specter of default, Administration officials have said repeatedly, would scare away enough potential investors that the Government might have to raise interest rates in order to attract buyers. The cost of that move would depend on how long the stalemate with Congress dragged on.
Private economists and analysts have been preparing estimates of the ripple effect of any interest rate increases. Mitchell J. Held, managing director of research at Smith Barney, said recently that a default could lead to a sharp decline of the dollar, and an increase in interest rates of as much as half a percentage point if the standoff dragged on. But once the issue was resolved, he said, rates would bounce back and "it would be viewed as just a political exercise."

HEADLINE: Profits at Nation's Big Banks Continue to Grow Briskly

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The country's biggest banking companies continued to show yesterday that their profits grew briskly in the third quarter. But there are increasing signs that the good times for banks may be coming to an end.
Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that its earnings fell 2 percent, to $877 million in the third quarter, because of an increased tax rate. But its profit before taxes increased 10 percent, to $1.39 billion. Citicorp earned $1.62 a share, slightly higher than the $1.58 expected by analysts. 
 The Chemical Banking Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest bank, surprised analysts by earning $477 million in the third quarter, up 9 percent from a year ago. It earned $1.70 a share, above analysts' expectations of $1.58. Chemical's revenues were down, but its profits were bolstered by lower expenses and a lower tax rate.
Several regional banking companies, including Banc One and Wells Fargo also posted higher earnings yesterday.
"The banks are all reporting earnings in line with or better than expectations," David S. Berry, the research director at Keefe Bruyette & Woods.
At the same time, there are several signs that the favorable environment for banks may be ending. While loan volume is still increasing, the pace of growth declined at many banks, analysts said. Moreover, loan losses are edging up, particularly from consumer lending. At Banc One, for example, loan losses increased 30 percent, to $108.7 million.
"Credit quality has clearly bottomed and is rising," said Carole S. Berger, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. "It's not alarming unless unemployment starts to increase." Not all banks have been affected. At Citicorp, "Consumer credit quality appears to be stable, as you would expect with the state of the economy," Tom Jones, Citicorp's chief financial officer, said at a meeting with analysts.
The climate, however, continues to be conducive for more of the huge bank mergers that have been sweeping the industry. The strong earnings have been lifting bank stock prices, allowing acquirers to make expensive deals with their own shares. Yet the prospects of slow revenue growth and increasing loan losses are prompting smaller banks to sell out at what could be their peak prices.
Over all, while Citicorp's profits largely met analysts' expectations, the results reflected $30 million in tax benefits that were not anticipated. As a result Mr. Berry, the analyst, called the bank's performance in the quarter "a little light."
Citicorp's consumer banking business earned $522 million, up 10 percent, on strong gains in consumer branch banking worldwide and its credit card business, especially in Asia. In the United States, credit card loans increased by 19 percent from a year ago to $42 billion.
Earlier this year, Citicorp announced that it was reducing the business it does with some large companies and scaling back its assets. The effects of that plan were reflected in profits of the Global Finance division, which fell by 19 percent to $351 million. The bank's portfolio of lower-yielding commercial loans and trading securities fell by $9 billion in the quarter to $86 billion, moving quickly toward a goal of $80 billion.
Trading revenue is down from earlier this year, but even from a year ago.
Losses from bad loans increased by $70 million from the second quarter although the amount of past-due loans fell slightly.
Citicorp continued to be among the most profitable of the large banking companies, earning a return on equity of 20 percent in the quarter.
Chemical's results were dominated by lower costs rather than growth. Expenses at Chemical fell to 58 percent of its revenue compared with 63 percent a year ago, helped by a $42 million reduction in its deposit insurance premium.
Chemical posted a sharp increase in fees from corporate finance, largely reflecting its strong loan syndication and junk bond underwriting activities. Trading revenue of $213 million was the same as a year ago, but up from earlier this year.
Earnings from credit cards also increased with card loans up by 30 percent to $10.3 billion. Profits from mortgages declined, and other areas were flat.
"Almost all of the areas had improved returns," said Peter Tobin, the bank's chief financial officer. "Some from revenue growth, others from expense management."
Chemical posted above-average profitability, measured by a return on equity of 17.3 percent.
Chemical's pending merger with the Chase Manhattan Corporation will be completed early next year, pending regulatory approvals. Yesterday Chase said its third-quarter earnings fell by 7.8 percent.
Banc One, based in Columbus, Ohio, said it earned $331 million in the quarter up 17 percent from a year ago. In the 1994 period, however, the bank took a $40 million charge related to acquisition costs. The bank's operating earnings increased only 2.5 percent.
Banc One earned 83 cents a share, just better than the 82 cents predicted by analysts.
The bank said that loans increased 13.4 percent, to $69 billion, from a year go, with the fastest growth coming from credit card and real estate construction loans.
Its return on equity was a respectable 17.1 percent, up from 14.8 percent a year ago. Banc One shares closed unchanged yesterday.
Wells Fargo, of San Francisco, earned $261 million, up 20 percent for the quarter. Its per-share earnings of $5.23 well exceeded analysts expectation of $4.60. And its return on equity was a record 30.1 percent.
"Wells really blew the doors off," Ms. Berger of Salomon said. "I've never seen a bank with returns that high."

HEADLINE: As Prices Soar, Paper Becomes Precious Commodity for Schools

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
At the Peter Fitzpatrick Elementary School in Pepperell, Mass., teachers get in line twice each day. Once in the morning and again at noon, they come for their daily ration of paper.
At another Massachusetts school, students write on the back of scrap paper donated by Nynex, the telephone company. 
 Around the country, paper has doubled in price in the last year, and some schools, especially in smaller districts where there is less room for budget maneuvering, are hurting for something to write on.
"In business, the paper price is passed on to the business, the business passes it on to their customers, but we can't pass it on to anybody," said Kathy Corley, principal of the Saltonstall Elementary School in Salem, Mass. "You can't say, 'Kids, bring in another $1 because paper prices have gone up.' "
At Fitzpatrick Elementary, Nancy Beringer, a third-grade teacher, said the shortage was making it hard for her pupils to practice penmanship because they were not getting enough practice on the wide-lined sheets usually handed out by teachers. "Their P's go into their L's, so it gets frustrating," she said.
Industry officials said a boom in the global economy, combined with a slowdown in the construction of paper plants, had driven paper prices up sharply. The paper market last boomed in 1989, and companies rushed to build plants, but the recession began just as many of the plants began operating, causing prices to plummet.
"We invested a lot in capacity because the economy was very good, and then we went in the tank," said Barry Polsky, a spokesman for the American Forest and Paper Association, a trade group in Washington. "So now we have to pay off the loans we took out to open those plants" instead of building new ones.
In constant 1994 dollars, copier paper cost an average of $1,028 a ton in 1989, $700 a ton in 1992 and about $1,160 this year, said Harold Cody, a San Francisco analyst who publishes The Pulp and Paper Forecaster, a newsletter.
Victor Atkins, principal of the Cashman School in Amesbury, Mass., said this year's order was never filled by his supplier, so he appealed to parents and businesses.
Nynex donated outdated stationery, and a printer donated stationery with misprints so students could write on the blank side.

HEADLINE: Political Wiretapping Scandal Reminds Estonia of Soviet Era

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: TALLINN, Estonia, Oct. 17

 BODY:
A political scandal over telephone tapping that brought down the Estonian Government last week has led many people here to wonder how far the country has come from the days when Soviet police agents spied on citizens without regard to law.
Yet the fact that Prime Minister Tiit Vahi assumed responsibility for the scandal by handing in his resignation, even though he was not personally implicated, suggests that democracy is taking hold here. 
 Despite the tapping scandal and several other recent scandals that have shaken Government agencies, Estonia has gained a reputation for stability.
"Political and economic progress here has been the fastest of any former Soviet state," asserted a foreign ambassador in Tallinn. "It is commonly said that Estonia is the star pupil in the class."
The principal figure in the tapping scandal was Edgar Savisaar, one of the country's most prominent politicians. Mr. Savisaar, a one-time Communist bureaucrat, was a leader in the movement that won Estonian independence from the Soviet Union in 1991, and served as the country's first post-independence Prime Minister.
Last month, the Estonian police arrested six men who were seeking to arrange a clandestine weapons sale. One turned out to be an employee of a shadowy company called Security Intelligence Agency, which is owned by two former K.G.B. agents and, according to Estonian newspaper reports, counts underworld figures among its clients.
The police raided the company's office and found a series of tape recordings of conversations between Mr. Savisaar, who was then Interior Minister, and senior politicians including Prime Minister Vahi.
A former aide to Mr. Savisaar who worked for the company said she had made the recordings without his knowledge, but later acknowledged that this was untrue. Mr. Savisaar then admitted making the tapes, but said he had done so only to keep a record of commitments by others, and refused to resign his Cabinet post.
Angered by his refusal, Prime Minister Vahi dismissed him on the grounds that his actions were "inadmissible in a just and democratic state," and also handed in his own resignation and that of his Cabinet.
"As Prime Minister of Estonia," he explained, "I am responsible for the country's image."
In an address to the nation after the Government's resignation, President Lennart Meri called the scandal "a crisis of democracy."
"We must ask ourselves: Does power belong to the people if surveillance equipment is in the hands of others?" the President said. "And we must conclude that if this is indeed the case, the Republic of Estonia has reached a crossroads -- whether to prevail or be destroyed once again."
"Cleansing does not weaken, but strengthens the state," he added. "Watergate saved the United States of America."
Many Estonians shared the President's concern, and the press has been full of demands that politicians adopt a more stringent moral code.
"This scandal is extremely serious, and cannot be considered simply part of the growing pains of a new democracy," said Siim Kallas, a prominent member of Parliament. "We came from a society where the K.G.B. was above the law. You never knew if you were being watched or if your telephone was being tapped. People fear that the same practices still exist today, and this scandal is evidence that they do."

HEADLINE: Newburgh Is Divided Over Race Track Plans

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: NEWBURGH, N.Y.

 BODY:
Richard Gayton and Ron Morehead are crazy about fast cars the way some people lose all sense of proportion over vintage wines or the Grateful Dead.
Like a Deadhead trailing his cherished band, Mr. Gayton, a 42-year-old body shop owner, travels the country on weekends to feel a familiar thrill, in his case rocketing his souped-up, logo-festooned Oldsmobile Achieva to 150 miles an hour in 9 seconds. Mr. Morehead, who owns a Volvo-Honda dealership here, has not raced since the 1970's but takes off for Gainesville, Fla., Indianapolis and beyond to follow the drag-racing exploits of his two sons and their Chevrolet Camaros. 
 "My son's winning the Grand National in 1987, I put it up there with the day my children were born and my daughter's wedding," said Mr. Morehead, who is 48.
In this economically languishing area 60 miles north of Manhattan, people like Mr. Morehead and Mr. Gayton are revved up like 500-horsepower hot rods at the news that a mysterious group of promoters wants to build a $70 million automobile race track right next door, inside the vast Stewart International Airport property. Plans call for a hotel and theater complex as well as an 80,000-seat stadium with a 2.5-mile track for stock cars and Indy cars and a half-mile drag strip.
The proposal would bring auto racing, which is perhaps the nation's fastest-growing spectator sport, into the rich New York City market; what has primarily been a regional attraction would thus be given the national sweep of baseball or football. A New York-area track -- the closest major tracks now are in Nazareth, Pa., and Long Pond, Pa., more than 100 miles away -- would join tracks being built in Los Angeles and Dallas-Fort Worth, as well as Orlando, Fla., at Disney World.
"When I thought of race tracks," said Arthur Wilcox, "I thought of a guy in a pickup truck, dungarees, a flannel shirt and a Marlboro hat." Mr. Wilcox is chairman of the Stewart Airport Commission, an advisory group that has given the proposal the green light. "But the more I looked at it, the more I realized this is a major industry," he said.
The promoter is a company called Empire State Motorsports, based in Westport, Conn. Its spokesmen are its president, Raymond DiMaria, a former freelance sports producer for ABC who specialized in "Up Close and Personal" features, and its vice president for communications, John Chuhran, a former sportswriter for Gannett Suburban Newspapers.
Supporters say the proposal could help revive the city of Newburgh, which has battled decay for decades, by generating 3,000 construction jobs, 3,000 permanent jobs and millions of tourist dollars, as well as sales taxes. It could also, they say, be the salvation of the 9,600-acre Stewart Airport property, which after 25 years of imagining itself as a fourth New York jetport remains a small regional airport surrounded by 8,000 acres of woods.
But there is strong resistance to the race track, and it stems not just from fears of noise and clogged country roads. Critics say the promoters have disclosed almost nothing about their investors. Residents worry that the promoters could flee, leaving a dead track where industry or park land might have flourished.
"Who are they?" asked George Meyers, the town supervisor of New Windsor, where most of Stewart Airport sits. "Three guys can walk into your office and tell you anything."
How can two men who earned their living in the news business attempt a project like this?
Mr. DiMaria, a Long Islander who gives his age as 40 plus, says that his family has long sponsored drag racing and that several times during the last eight years he has tried unsuccessfully to stage a Grand Prix outside the Nassau Coliseum. Mr. Chuhran says he worked in public relations for two years for Championship Auto Racing Teams, the sanctioning body for the bullet-shaped, ground-hugging Indy cars.
They say their backers can afford to spend the $70 million for a track plus $7 million for a ramp from Interstate 84 that would enable spectators to reach the track without flooding rural roads. But they say they fear that people might overcharge their backers if they are identified.
"If you're going to buy a piece of real estate and, say, you want $30,000 and he finds out you're worth a million," Mr. DiMaria said, "well, the price of poker just went up."
In recent days, Mr. Chuhran has identified Gerald Katell, a major commercial real estate developer in Los Angeles, as a partner. Mr. DiMaria says the investors will prove their wherewithal before construction starts by buying a performance bond -- an insurance company guarantee that they have enough resources to complete the work.
The project won approval Aug. 29 from the Stewart Airport Commission to start engineering and environmental analyses on a 360-acre site. That decision remains to be acted on by the state's Department of Transportation, which operates Stewart. But an important player will be the State Department of Economic Development, whose spokesman, John Melia, says Empire State Motorsports has yet to submit any concrete financial information.
A lot of money may be riding on a decision.
Professional car races drew a paid attendance of 14.3 million last year. The stock car industry alone has tripled attendance in 15 years and generates $2 billion a year in revenue. As a result of this mushrooming market and growing television broadcasts, companies like Tide, Eastman Kodak and Goodyear are eager to pay the $5 million it can cost to operate a stock car and turn the cars themselves into speeding billboards for their products.
The promoters, however, have received no assurances that the major sanctioning bodies would add Stewart to their schedules. Kevin Triplett, spokesman for the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, said the year's schedule of 34 weekend races was already at capacity. But, he admitted, when faced with a concrete proposal from the nation's largest media market, "it would be very difficult to say no."
"You find the rock and you find the hard place and we'll be there," he said.
Another major question is whether car racing will be popular in New York, where most people are accustomed to racing only to the subway or bus. The promoters are banking on a broadening appeal for the sport, pointing out that the racing fan's average income of $42,000 is greater than the national average and that one-third of fans are women.
More than 12,000 Hudson Valley residents have signed a petition supporting the Empire State project, many of them from the valley's racing subculture.
"Can you imagine a run-down place like Newburgh getting pumped $20 million in three days?" Mr. Morehead asked. "There's nothing here. Who wants to raise his kids and see them leave the area because there's nothing here?"

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Some Try to Insure Against a Japan Bank Failure

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 17

 BODY:
When international bankers have nightmares these days, they have nothing to do with ghosts or goblins, but with the liquidity of the Japanese banking system.
Bankers here say that plans by Federal Reserve authorities in the United States to pour emergency funds into the Japanese banking system in the event of a crisis will help bankers sleep better. They say that the plan will ease concerns about a lack of liquidity -- the ability to settle debts when they come due -- but they add that the underlying problems remain as a long-term challenge. 
 "This is sort of like a nuclear deterrent," S. David Snoddy, a bank analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities Tokyo, said of the bailout plan. "The reason you have it is so you never have to use it. It's designed to reassure the market."
But the involvement of the Federal Reserve also has a downside: is may be bringing more attention to the liquidity problems of Japanese banks.
While analysts praise the rescue plan disclosed on Monday, which would infuse funds into banks if they ran short of money, they also warned that Japan's financial system was still stuck with several practical problems. These include hundreds of billions of dollars worth of bad debts, chronic dollar shortages, higher costs for overseas money, and a dim outlook.
In the 1980's, Japanese banks used to be considered among the world's strongest, able to tap funds worldwide at the lowest prices.
But these days, the fear is that if banks are not given credit they are counting on, they might not have enough money to meet their obligations. The result is that they could default on a contractual requirement to honor foreign-exchange trading transactions or swap transactions, or to meet other obligations.
Such a default could ripple through the world banking system, affecting liquidity at other banks and conceivably setting off further defaults. Another fear is that in a crisis, Japanese may dump Treasury bonds or other American assets, raising interest rates and creating dislocations in the American money markets and the overall economy.
Those concerns are leading bankers to curb credit -- and to worry about the effects as they do so.
Almost everyone interviewed emphasized that a major banking crisis was very unlikely.
Yet in the last few weeks, some Japanese institutional investors have grown so concerned that they are looking for ways to buy a form of insurance to protect themselves, to hedge against a plunge in the value of the bank stocks they hold, according to bankers here. Japanese financial institutions often hold large blocks of stock in banks with whom they have close ties or cross-shareholdings.
Selling these holdings is not feasible because this would both offend the banks and send stock prices plummeting. So the Japanese institutional investors are taking the unusual step of quietly, almost secretly, inquiring about buying put options against the bank whose stock they hold. A put option is a bet that the underlying stock will fall within a certain period; its value soars when the stock plunges.
Some of the puts are for periods as long as three years. That suggests that the purchasers believe it will be several years before the banks are out of the woods.
Their concern no doubt arises from what they see: Not only are weaker Japanese institutions tapping stronger banks for dollars, but they have to pay a "Japan premium" when they borrow funds abroad. Indeed, some banks are finding that borrowing is now so expensive that they can get dollars more cheaply by taking their yen deposits to the foreign-exchange markets and converting them to dollars.
In other cases, banks are finding that their credit lines have been trimmed, so that they cannot borrow funds abroad at any price.
The Japanese Government refused today to comment on any arrangement with American authorities, but it has said that there was no reason for alarm about the risks of tighter credit. Some analysts say the international concern is an overreaction to what the Government estimates is at least $500 billion in bad real estate loans, about one-third of which are unrecoverable.
Various Japanese bankers have said that the Government is already providing a disguised form of assistance to struggling banks. They said that the nation's central bank, which manages foreign-exchange reserves, sometimes parks some of those funds as deposits at Japanese banks, which can then be used to finance overseas commitments, aiding liquidity.
The central bank declined to comment on the practice.
The amount of Japan's asset holdings -- including its foreign reserves, which totaled $179 billion at the end of September -- gives foreign bankers some measure of comfort in the Government's ability, in theory, to stem any liquidity squeeze. Japanese authorities have said that they will not allow any of Japan's largest money-center banks to fail, and many foreign analysts say the Government probably means what it says.
The problem, however, is that the Finance Ministry has not yet worked out a bailout scheme that it could turn to immediately in a crisis.
"I have a worry, a concern, regarding a financial panic," said Yukiko Ohara, a banking analyst at UBS Securities Japan Ltd. "The system is very vulnerable to increasing overseas concern."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
G.M. Surprise: Profit Beats Expectations

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 17

 BODY:
A year ago, the General Motors Corporation reported surprisingly little profit for the third quarter. Investors gasped, and then stampeded.
Today, G.M. surprised auto analysts with third-quarter earnings far higher than they expected. But as the auto giant eagerly described its turnaround, investors, mesmerized by slicker high-technology stocks, only yawned. 
 These days, with auto companies predicting little if any growth in the United States or in Europe next year, it seems to take the threat of a hostile takeover to lift an auto company's stock.
By contrast, I.B.M. -- which last year delighted Wall Street on the same day G.M. disappointed it -- reported a weak quarter today. Yet its stock still surged, apparently caught up in the wave of buying that swept through technology issues. [Page D2.]
Today's report showed that G.M. is continuing to untangle its knotted North American automotive operations. Although production of cars and trucks increased in the quarter, G.M. reported that its costs for materials and overtime dropped substantially, cutting the loss incurred a year ago in North America.
Over all, G.M., the world's biggest auto maker, reported third-quarter net income of $642 million, up 16.3 percent from last year's level of $552 million. In North America, G.M. lost $93 million, well below a loss of $363 million last year.
Worldwide, G.M.'s revenue increased 8.6 percent, to $37.5 billion. The earnings came to 42 cents a share, up from 40 cents last year.
Most analysts had expected that G.M. would post a decline in earnings. Despite the pleasant surprise, G.M. shares closed at $46.50, unchanged on the day, in tepid trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"More and more, what investors are thinking is that this is a no-growth business," said Maryann Keller, an auto industry analyst with Furman Selz in New York. "The picture of the auto market is one of limited growth for now, with bottom-line improvement coming from more effective cost control." That outlook, she said, is not "the kind of thing that gets your blood surging."
The Big Three auto makers say that the Federal Reserve has successfully engineered a soft landing for the economy. G.M., for example, predicts that the auto companies will sell about 15.3 million vehicles in the United States in 1995, 100,000 fewer than last year. For 1996, G.M. expects the market to grow, but only about 2 percent, J. Michael Losh, G.M.'s chief financial officer, said today.
While it may dampen investors' enthusiasm, the market's stability is clearly allowing G.M. breathing room to improve its efficiency and strengthen its balance sheet, judging by today's report. As it straightened out last year's botched new-car introductions at its factories, G.M. increased its share of the car and truck market in the United States, to 32.2 percent in the quarter from 31.5 percent in last year's third quarter.
G.M. had an advantage over its domestic competitors in the quarter because it did not have major model changeovers. The Ford Motor Company, which has introduced a new version of its Taurus sedan, is expected to post sharply lower earnings on Wednesday. Last Wednesday, the Chrysler Corporation reported that its net income dropped 46 percent in the third quarter, to $354 million, largely because of the introduction of its new mini-van.
In North America, G.M.'s losses narrowed. "The biggest year-to-year gain is from the improvements in terms of material costs," Mr. Losh said. Pension expense also dropped. And G.M. said its overtime costs fell by $100 a unit, or about $118 million.
Costs incurred by G.M. in offering customers incentives to buy cars also declined, to an average of $671 a vehicle from $935 last year. That is substantially lower than Chrysler's average of $870 in the third quarter. Mr. Losh said he expected G.M.'s incentive costs in the fourth quarter to remain about the same as in the third.
G.M.'s international operations lost ground in the quarter with profits falling to $111 million from $232 million in the third quarter last year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Reports of Economic Easing Give Lift to Prices of Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities ended mostly higher yesterday.
The 30-year bond's price rose 11/32, to 108. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.28 percent, from 6.30 percent on Monday. It was the lowest yield since Feb. 2, 1994. 
 Traders attributed some of the rally in the cash and futures markets to the Johnson Redbook report on retail sales, released yesterday, which was favorable for the market. The report said that sales for the first two weeks of October were down 1.9 percent from the previous period.
In the day's other economic news, the Federal Reserve said that capacity utilization at the nation's factories fell to 83.9 percent in September from 84.2 percent in August, while industrial production fell 0.2 percent in September, after a 1.1 percent rise in August. All three reports fit the description of an economy that the bond market likes: slow to moderate growth, with few inflationary pressures.
The Treasury announced that it was selling $19 billion in new three- and six-month bills on Monday, down $7 billion from the previous two auctions. Some market participants believe that the reduction in the size of the weekly auction may have to do with the issue of raising the nation's debt ceiling, which is still being hammered out in Congress.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said, "In order to penetrate the formidable 6.25 percent resistance level for 30-year bonds, the market will need further, substantial evidence of much weaker economic growth, or the completion of a comprehensive, credible and gimmick-proof budget-reduction agreement."
He said he thought that at the very least, the Treasury market needed to pause and consolidate before the next major price yield swing was determined.
He also said that yields could rise if there were a major jump in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank's index of regional business activity, which is to be reported tomorrow, or a larger-than-expected announcement on the size of the auction of two- and five-year notes next week. That will be announced today.
The price of the December bond futures contract, which touched a new high of 117 23/32 in the morning, eased in the afternoon. It was the third time in four sessions that the contract hit a new high. The futures market opened above the previous day's high of 117 16/32 and rallied immediately to the new level, which apparently gave the market jitters as some participants had difficulty believing that the rally could remain intact, traders said.
In the municipal bond market, prices were little changed as New York City sold $945 million in bonds with yields as high as those offered by some Treasury securities.
Money managers said many investors skirted the secondary market to get at the attractive yields on the New York sale. Prudential Securities tentatively priced the bond with a 30-year maturity to yield 6.30 percent, but good investor demand allowed underwriters to get a better price and to lower the yield by about 5 basis points. A basis point is equal to one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Serial bonds were priced to yield from 4.20 percent for an issue due in 1997 to 6.15 percent for one due in 2016. A bond due in 2020 was priced to yield 6.20 percent.
City officials said they had received $2.6 billion in orders for the overall issue, allowing them to increase its size.
The bonds are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's.

LENGTH: 467 words

HEADLINE: The Fulton Fish Market Battle

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's bold drive to end mob domination of New York City's Fulton Fish Market has entered a critical phase and deserves strong public support. The city has begun a new first-come, first-served system for unloading delivery trucks at the bustling wholesale fish and seafood distribution center in lower Manhattan. This is intended to replace the old system under which unlicensed crews, setting their own rules, were free to extract payoffs and inflated fees for prompt unloading of perishable cargo.
The first day of the new system produced chaos. There were long unloading delays, disrupting business and virtually halting the flow of seafood to local restaurants. One cause was the inexperience of the company to which the city had awarded a two-year unloading contract. The drivers who bring seafood from as far away as the Gulf of Mexico complained that the new crews were incompetent. 
 But there was also a deliberate effort to sabotage the cleanup, clearly engineered by organized crime elements fighting to hold their turf. Someone tampered with the master light switches, plunging the market into darkness. Hundreds of workers, mainly employees of the market's 60 wholesale seafood vendors, staged a wildcat strike to show solidarity with the 40 workers who lost their jobs when the city evicted the six unloading companies. Officials have charged that all six are linked to organized crime and have routinely engaged in extortion simply by refusing to unload the fish quickly unless the wholesalers paid exorbitant fees.
A large portion of the estimated two million pounds of fish that flow into the market on a normal workday went undelivered Monday morning, and almost nothing was sold because few buyers for restaurants and retail stores could penetrate the truck congestion, the forbidding darkness and the intimidating swirl of protesters.
Yesterday Mr. Giuliani showed his resolve by issuing a stern warning and sending in more police. He has threatened to shut the place down if another wildcat strike occurs. He has also threatened to replace the existing work force if necessary, to install honest management and to end the intimidation that has driven up fish prices and driven wholesalers to other markets on the East Coast.
More turbulence may lie ahead. In March, the market was set ablaze by an arsonist. The Mayor is clearly facing a rough crowd eager to maintain its economic stranglehold. But Mr. Giuliani has the right background and instincts to stand up to the mob. He can be counted on to stay the course. The bully boys of the market have had their way for too long, at everyone else's expense.
Ending the atmosphere of intimidation is critical not just for the market's economic future but for the city's business climate generally.

HEADLINE: Aid for the World's Poorest

 BODY:
The new Republican majority in Congress wants to eliminate government services that private markets could also provide. Yet it has aimed its budget knife at a valuable program -- economic aid to the world's poorest countries -- that could not possibly survive without Federal funds. Drastic cuts approved by the House and Senate threaten to grind dreadfully poor people into deeper poverty.
Under President Bush's leadership, the United States committed itself to contributing about $1.3 billion next year to the International Development Association, an affiliate of the World Bank that provides very-low-interest loans to poor countries. As part of its deficit reduction program, the House and Senate want to renege on that commitment and reduce the contribution to between $577 million, the House figure, and $775 million, the Senate's figure. 
 Neither figure makes fiscal or ethical sense. The I.D.A. loan program is cost-effective. Every dollar in American contributions leads to $4 or $5 more in contributions from other industrialized countries. To save a few hundred million out of a $10 billion-plus foreign aid budget, Congress would trigger a $3 billion reduction in I.D.A. loans.
The loan program is also politically effective. By inviting poor countries to open their economies to trade and adopt market reforms, I.D.A. loans are a cheap way for Congress to spread capitalism. The program's multilateral nature insulates recipient countries from pressures to warp their economic programs to suit the narrow export interests of individual donors. I.D.A. programs worked well in Korea, Thailand, Turkey and Indonesia. They are working well in Ghana and Bolivia.
Critics of the I.D.A. say that third-world countries would become more prosperous more rapidly if they relied more on private capital and far less on World Bank handouts. This criticism applied, at least until recently, to World Bank loans for dams and other infrastructure projects. As the new president of the World Bank concedes, private capital markets are willing and able to extend such loans. But private investors will not bail out sub-Saharan Africa and other economic disasters. Over 70 percent of private lending to developing nations goes to fewer than a dozen countries. Sub-Saharan Africa claims only 2 percent.
The I.D.A., not private capital, fights the spread of AIDS. The I.D.A. helps pay for schools. The I.D.A. finances women's health and childhood nutrition programs. The World Bank has shifted its priorities from investing in concrete to investing in people. No one else can take on this role. Do American taxpayers really prefer to save themselves about $2 a year rather than leading the world to help those eking out an existence on less than $2 a day?

HEADLINE: Journal;
Fixated on Farrakhan

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
At a time when white Americans can't agree among ourselves on anything, here at last is one opinion that unites us all, liberal and conservative, Democrat and Republican, rich and poor: Louis Farrakhan is a hate-filled demagogue with a divisive, separatist ideology and an appalling record of racism, sexism, anti-Semitism and homophobia.
This judgment is to my mind as indisputable as it is unoriginal, and nothing happened at Monday's march to alter it. Mr. Farrakhan's efforts to strike a benign pose were fatally compromised by his speech's lunatic digressions into crypto-mysticism and self-deification. His offer to open a dialogue with Jews was cynical and meaningless, given his refusal to acknowledge his history of hate speech, let alone apologize for it. His retinue of brownshirts injected the chilling trappings of fascism into an event otherwise resplendent in spirituality and peace. 
 So white America agrees: Louis Farrakhan is up to no good. But now that we've all said that as loud as we can, where do we go next? Should we keep saying it over and over, louder and louder, and hope that Mr. Farrakhan will just go away?
Apparently so, our politicians tell us. Monday began with President Clinton firmly denouncing Mr. Farrakhan and ended with Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich both following suit and attacking Mr. Clinton for not denouncing Mr. Farrakhan by name. Perhaps tomorrow Phil Gramm will accompany his attack on Mr. Farrakhan with an attack on Mr. Dole for not attacking Mr. Farrakhan at greater length.
This game can be played indefinitely with short-term political profit, since no white candidate is ever going to lose by decrying the Nation of Islam. But what exactly is being accomplished? Yes, Mr. Farrakhan is a menace and must be watched vigilantly. Still, white America makes a fetish of him at its own peril.
The pre-march attacks on Mr. Farrakhan did nothing to deter 400,000 African-Americans, only a minority of whom support the Nation of Islam, from turning up in Washington to express their impassioned desire to stem the economic and social collapse of their own communities. Now that the march is history, attacks on Mr. Farrakhan are not going to erase the powerful and substantive message of most of its participants. By continuing to fixate on Mr. Farrakhan, rather than the legitimate concerns of the 400,000 marchers, white politicians only give their nemesis more credibility and power. It is the failure of the entire political establishment to heed the spiraling crisis of the black underclass in the first place that gave the extremist Mr. Farrakhan his opening to seize a resonant mainstream issue as his own.
That opening keeps getting larger. In the two weeks of racial turmoil that have fallen between the O. J. Simpson verdict and Monday's march, the paralysis of white political leadership has been embarrassingly pronounced. The verdict that preoccupied most Americans yielded only some cautious homilies from President Clinton in a newspaper interview and shilly-shallying from most of the Republican field. At last week's forum of G.O.P. Presidential candidates, a visitor from Mars might never have guessed that the O. J. verdict had rocked the country or that the Million Man March was in the offing; there was so little talk about Topics A and B that Jack Kemp chided his fellow Republicans for muffing "an incredible opportunity to step into the vacuum."
Mr. Clinton, at least, did give a thoughtful address on both white and black racism -- but from the remote perch of Austin on Monday, just as the Million Man March hit its stride at the Mall. Is it leadership to give such a speech in lockstep with Mr. Farrakhan's event rather than a step or two ahead of it? The healing, philosophic long view of Mr. Clinton's remarks seemed out of sync with the moment anyway -- more appropriate to the inflammatory immediate aftermath of the Simpson verdict than to the day of the march. And since the speech offered no specific policies, the only sound bite in it not drowned out by Mr. Farrakhan in the evening news was, inevitably, the attack on Mr. Farrakhan.
Well, Mr. Farrakhan is a bad guy, all right. But if this is the sole message white America can send to black America in the wake of the Million Man March, his reign has only begun.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Flight Away From French Franc Continues to Undermine Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most leading currencies yesterday for the second consecutive day as economic uncertainty in France continued to steer currency traders toward selling francs for dollars and then selling those dollars for German marks.
The French National Assembly began to debate the 1996 budget yesterday. Some analysts questioned whether the French Government can cut spending enough to help shrink its budget deficit. 
 "The Government's credibility has been damaged because they are already anywhere from 20 to 40 billion French francs under target on the revenue side for the current fiscal year," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics. "There is natural concern in the French Parliament that much the same will be seen in 1996."
Because of such concerns, traders are skeptical that France will be able meet the criteria for a single European currency in 1999. As a result, traders shifted from French francs into German marks.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar slipped to 100.41 Japanese yen from 100.63 yen on Monday. The dollar fell to 1.4147 marks from 1.4235 marks and to 1.1480 Swiss francs from 1.1543 Swiss francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5731 from $1.5740.
The French franc traded in New York at 3.5092 francs to the mark, weaker than 3.4868 late Monday in New York. The mark was also bolstered against the French franc yesterday by continuing fallout from the Bank of France's surprising move on Monday to cut its 24-hour lending rate to 7 percent, from 7.25 percent. Only last week, the central bank had increased the rate to 7.25 percent from 6.15 percent to bolster the franc.
The rate cut "may give the impression they are not prepared for a prolonged interest rate defense of the franc," said Malcolm Barr, an economist with Chemical Bank.
Growing uncertainty about whether the White House and the Republican-led Congress will be able to strike a deal on the budget hurt the dollar.
The White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, reiterated during a news conference yesterday that President Clinton would veto any balanced-budget plan he found unacceptable, even if it contained a necessary increase in the debt ceiling.
"Any negative news on the budget is not going to be very dollar supportive at all, especially with the dollar trading at the low end of its trading range," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president and and senior foreign exchange dealer at Credit Agricole in New York.
