HEADLINE: Industrial Output Down In September

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Industrial output declined for the first time in five months during September as cool weather curbed electricity consumption, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Production decreased two-tenths of 1 percent. Output at factories alone increased two-tenths of 1 percent, but that was not enough to offset a 5.4 percent drop in utility output. 
 Industrial production had increased 1.1 percent in August, when hot weather kept power demand high.
In today's report, the Federal Reserve also said that factories operated at 83.8 percent of capacity in September, down from a revised 84.2 percent in August.
All told, the data did little to change the outlook for slow growth and tame inflation.
 "The manufacturing sector is far from smoking here, but it is making advances," said John Ryding, an economist at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. September's drop in output, he said, "is not a sign of weakness, it's a sign of cooler weather."
 The decline in production was bigger than the consensus forecast among economists for a decrease of only one-tenth of 1 percent. Still, the data did not appear weak enough to strengthen the case for another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve when its policy-making committee meets on Nov. 15.
Analysts have been divided about whether the Fed will cut rates again at that meeting, or at the following meeting, on Dec. 19. At meetings in August and September, Fed officials took no immediate action on interest rates.
 The decline in the rate of factory use bodes well for slower inflation. The rising use of factories, mines and utilities tends to contribute to higher costs because businesses are forced to pay workers overtime and bring older and less efficient equipment on line.
 "The Fed is on the sidelines waiting for the Federal budget negotiations to clear up," said Scott Brown, an economist at Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. Once that hurdle is removed, Mr. Brown said, the Fed is likely to lower rates to bolster economic growth.
 A rate cut would be justified because "the economy is not firing on all cylinders at the same time," Mr. Brown said.
 Excluding the output of motor vehicles and parts, today's report showed, industrial production increased four-tenths of 1 percent in September after rising 1.2 percent during August. Mining output climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in September.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Industrial Production" tracks index of total industrial production, seasonally adjusted, from April 1994 through September 1995. (Source: Commerce Department); "Capacity Utilization" tracks total output as a percentage of capacity, seasonally adjusted, over the same period. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Rockefeller Center lands a tenant, Siegel & Gale, to take the entire third floor at 10 Rockefeller Plaza.

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
IN the largest deal at Rockefeller Center since the owners of the Manhattan landmark filed for bankruptcy protection in May, Siegel & Gale, the corporate identity and communications company, has taken 51,000 square feet, the entire third floor, at 10 Rockefeller Plaza.
Robert Saporito, Siegel & Gale's chief financial officer, said the bankruptcy was "helpful to our deal" and had worked in his company's favor. 
 The lease for the space, between 48th and 49th Street, is for 21 years and totals $45 million, reflecting an average annual rent in the low $30's a square foot, Mr. Saporito said. The company is to move early next year from space on two floors at 1185 Avenue of the Americas, near 47th Street. The new offices are just above the studios of NBC's "Today" show, in a 17-story building that was formerly the Eastern Airlines Building.
Stuart I. Romanoff of Cushman & Wakefield, who with a colleague, Donald A. DiRenzo Sr., represented Siegel & Gale in the deal, said the primary concern had been "tenant-improvement dollars." A key to the agreement, Mr. Saporito said, is the more than $2 million the company is to receive in financial considerations from the landlord to design its new space and create an alpine rock garden on the terrace that wraps around the third floor.
He said negotiations had begun before the bankruptcy filing, which took place after Siegel & Gale had agreed on a base rent but before the lease was signed. "The bankruptcy was something we had to consider," he said, "but in the long run we were given priority by Rockefeller Center because we were their biggest deal since the bankruptcy."
In an article in Siegel & Gale's in-house publication, Mr. Saporito said that Rockefeller Center needed "to show that they're still in business, still making deals, and that they can still provide construction money to sweeten the deal." He said that without the bankruptcy "they wouldn't have given us all the concessions that they have."
Alan L. Stein, senior vice president for marketing at the Rockefeller Center Management Corporation, said that the "fundamental economic terms of the transaction were unaffected by the bankruptcy" and that the "financial incentive package would have been the same with or without bankruptcy."
The landlord contribution, Mr. Stein said, "was appropriate for the space, the creditworthiness of the tenant and the rent the tenant is paying." He said that because a third-floor space did not have the views that higher space had, it was important to spend money to beautify the terrace. The vacancy rate at the 16 buildings owned by Rockefeller Center is 6.9 percent, he said.
Mr. Saporito said that the site offered the flexibility and high ceilings his company had been seeking. Siegel & Gale wanted its staff of 110 people on one floor because it felt that working on separate floors hindered collaboration, he added.
 
Flatiron Area Grows
 Retail growth in the Flatiron District continues. The Limited Inc. has leased 8,200 square feet at 130 Fifth Avenue, in a former Chemical Bank site at 18th Street, where it plans to open its 12th Express store in Manhattan. And Aveda, a Minneapolis-based international beauty emporium, has taken 1,000 square feet a block north, at 140 Fifth.
They will join Armani, Kenneth Cole, Joan & David, the Gap, Banana Republic, 9 West and other stores that have flocked to Fifth Avenue below 23d Street and made it a thriving shopping area.
"The Limited was looking for some time to do a store in the Flatiron District," said Benjamin Fox of New Spectrum Realty Services, who with the Georgetown Group represented The Limited.
 
New Jersey Buildings Bought
 In what brokers say is the largest commercial real estate deal of the 1990's in New Jersey based on square footage, the Lincoln Equities Group of Garden City, L.I., has bought three buildings totaling 816,681 square feet.
The deal involves the Meadows Office Complex in the Meadowlands in East Rutherford -- two 12-story buildings, a total of 571,876 square feet, 92 percent occupied -- and the fully leased 244,805-square-foot Rockaway 80 in Rockaway in Morris County.
The price was "in excess of $54 million," said Sean Brady of the Financial Services Group of Cushman & Wakefield of New Jersey, who with an associate, David Bernhaut, handled the transaction for Lincoln Equities, which develops and invests in properties in the New York region.

HEADLINE: The Chandelier That Earned $1.5 Billion

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
Above the stage of Bushnell Memorial Hall, the giant chandelier was swaying to the music like some weighty sea creature. From the wings came the plaintive cry of the Phantom: "I a-m your a-a-n-gel of mu-usic . . . " The downtown streets of this city are usually empty after dark. But for a month and a half recently, nearly 2,500 people showed up six nights a week at the Bushnell to see what may be one of the most successful shows of all time: "The Phantom of the Opera."
Since it opened in London nine years ago, Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical about a lovesick loner in the Paris Opera has played some 27,000 performances in nearly 60 cities around the world, from Singapore to Basel to St. Paul. 
 Along the way, "Phantom" has grossed $1.5 billion, outearning even the most successful movie ever made, "Jurassic Park." Another Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, "Cats," has made more money than "Phantom," so far, but it has been playing longer and its touring days are waning. The grosses of "Phantom" are about equal to another blockbuster, "Les Miserables." However, more people have come to see "Phantom" than "Les Miserables." The "Phantom" tour is booked through 1998, and it may outstrip both its competitors.
" 'Phantom' has played in larger theaters and has run longer in most places than any other show in modern history," said Cameron Mackintosh, the producer of "Phantom," "Les Miserables" and "Cats."
" 'Phantom' sells itself easier than any other show I have ever worked on, or known about."
In Toronto, "Phantom" has been performed for six years and has grossed $325 million. "It is a monster!" said Garth Drabinsky, the show's Canadian producer. "It is the king of all shows."
In an era in which movies dominate American culture, what is it about this musical with a hero who has a face like melted cheese, and a 1,000-pound chandelier for second lead, that lures audiences in droves, including people who rarely go to the theater? It's certainly not the reviews. When "Phantom" opened in New York in 1988, critics generally jeered at its banal lyrics, the impoverishment of its music, its Liberace-like homage to the candelabra and the chandelier, its kitsch.
Even Mr. Lloyd Webber can't really explain the show's success. "I started from the premise of wanting to write something that was a high romance," he said. "It doesn't stand up to huge intellectual scrutiny. There's no one who doesn't feel they wish they hadn't been born different, that their fingers were longer, or something. At the end of the day, it's overwhelmingly high romance."
Rocco Landesman, the producer and president of Jujamcyn Theaters, and a rival of Mr. Webber's, has sat for seven years at his desk opposite the Majestic Theater on Broadway at 44th Street, watching the crowds flock to "Phantom" even in late summer and mid-winter, chronically slow periods. "I've been very depressed about it," Mr. Landesman said with a laugh the other day.
He attributed the show's success to the public's "primal response to live theater."
"People like the mythic story of 'Phantom,' of the innocent girl and a mentor," he said. "But the success of the show has a lot to do with its theatricality; you can't see that on film. When that chandelier moves down over the stage, imagine that on TV: it would be meaningless!"
" 'Evita,' " said Mr. Landesman, mentioning another Lloyd Webber musical, "is not as embracing and appealing. 'Les Miserables' is more of a downer. 'Phantom' is a real romantic story. 'Phantom' is more thrilling than 'Cats.' "
So strong is the desire to bring in "Phantom" that communities are willing, even eager, to spend significant sums to accommodate the lavish production. According to the show's technical production manager, John H. Paull 3d, "theaters routinely spend $50,000 to $100,000 in structural steel modifications each, just to drop the chandelier."
To lure "Phantom" here to Hartford, where it just completed its run, the Bushnell undertook a major capital campaign, raising $3 million from the state, businesses and individuals to renovate the theater, which was built in 1930. The stage also had to be reinforced so that the 1,000-pound chandelier could plummet at the end of Act I, and to hold the two-and-a-half-ton portable proscenium.
In Salt Lake City, John Ballard, a local presenter, said he had been "begging" for "Phantom" and had spent $200,000 modifying the Capitol Theater. The show is coming next March.
The producers of "Phantom" say all that money is a good investment. For every dollar spent on tickets, they claim, at least $2 goes back into the local economy, for dinners out, tuxedo rentals, baby sitters.
In Denver, where "Phantom" played from November 1991 to February 1992, 177,103 people -- from 6 surrounding counties, 43 states, Canada and Austria -- saw the show in the downtown district. According to a study by the Denver Center for the Performing Arts, assisted by the Greater Denver Chamber of Commerce and others, the show grossed more than $19 million. But its impact on the local economy was more than $40 million.
With its grand orchestral strokes, its arias with their melting tessitura, its flashing strobe lights, the 550 pounds of dry ice it consumes each night for the foggy scenes under the Paris Opera, "Phantom" appears to be the perfect theatrical vehicle.
In the United States, there are no fewer than four "Phantom" companies: on Broadway, in San Francisco and two on tour. Each of the touring companies is equipped with 28 trucks to transport the show's stage decks, prosceniums, 230 costumes, 150 wigs and 479 spotlights. There are duplicate sets so that companies can leapfrog across the country; the cast that was in Hartford, where the show closed on Oct. 7, went into previews in Providence, R.I., five days later.
"We've got it down," said Alan Wasser, the show's general manager. "If we're moving a distance of less than 800 miles, we can close on Saturday and open in the next city on Tuesday."
In some ways, "Phantom" is more about scenery and effects than actors or story. Unlike other musicals, the leading role is not identified with any one star. The "Phantom" is not a face. He is a mask. In the past, Broadway musicals required a singer with a big voice that carried. Now, because of portable microphones, "Phantom" doesn't need a major star to sing the role. All of this makes touring easier. In Hartford, the Phantom was played by Thomas James O'Leary, who also played the role on Broadway, after Michael Crawford (he also played Monsieur Andre and Monsieur Reyer). Adrienne McEwan, a trained operatic soprano, was the ingenue, Christine Daae.
To make sure the music is up to standard, Mr. Lloyd Webber employs a full-time staff of musical supervisors who travel from London to Basel to Cleveland checking on "Phantom" productions. "It's the first time a show like this has toured without compromising Broadway," said Mr. Wasser. And in most cities, audiences are paying close to top prices for tickets too. In Hartford, the best tickets cost $60; on Broadway, they're $67.50.
The producers of "Phantom" have followed the same techniques as the producers of traveling shows at the turn of the century, reassuring audiences that they are getting the real thing, not a second-rate copy of a New York production. Just as touring companies in the 1880's and 90's were preceded by notices in local newspapers and billboards describing the cost, spectacle and authenticity of the show to come, publicists for "Phantom" supply local journalists with statistics on everything from the number of beads on the chandelier (35,000) to the number of AAA batteries used each night in the portable mikes (about 25).
At the end of the first act in Hartford one night recently, the Phantom -- as usual -- was growing increasingly jealous about Christine's relationship with the second lead, Raoul. "He was bo-ound to love yoooo . . . " sang the Phantom. Above the stage, the lights on the chandelier flashed a warning. Then, suddenly, the chandelier, all 1,000 pounds of it, crashed down over the audience, missing them by a few feet before it was pulled up again.
The crowd interrupted the orchestra's descending line with applause. It was as if they had been waiting forever for this moment, carefully publicized by the show's producers in local newspapers before the show ever came to town.
"Awesome," said 12-year-old Daniel Kushner. "I'd rather come here than go to a movie."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The Sad Story of the Sioux's Betrayal

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

A GOOD YEAR TO DIE
The Story of the Great Sioux War
By Charles M. Robinson 3d
412 pages. Random House. $27.50.
The story told by Charles M. Robinson in "A Good Year To Die" rests on two sad truths. The first is that the Fort Laramie Treaty, signed in 1868 between the United States Government and the tribes of the Sioux Nation, recognized a vast tract of territory in southern Montana and northern Wyoming to be "unceded land." This was land that in effect still belonged to the Indians and that no white person had the right to settle or even cross without Indian permission. That unceded land was in addition to the half of South Dakota west of the Missouri River, which the treaty designated the Sioux Reservation. 
 The second sad truth is that the Great Sioux War of 1876-77, was fought a mere six years after the treaty was signed. The United States, reneging on the agreement, drove the Indians off the unceded land and forced them to give up their right to exclusive use of the reservation as well. In 1874, gold was discovered in the Black Hills. Prospectors and others rushed to the territory. Efforts to buy the land back from the Indians for $6 million were rejected. And so, urged on by military commanders like Philip Henry Sheridan of Civil War fame, the United States, under President Ulysses S. Grant, embarked on a military expedition to destroy Sioux power for the sake of American economic expansion.
Mr. Robinson's book is a detailed account of the arduous, dreary and morally dubious military campaign that ensued as the United States Army, after some attempts that are legendary for their ineffectiveness, eventually defeated such warriors as Crazy Horse and Sitting Bull, thereby effectively ending not just the Sioux's independent power but their way of life as well. It is a sobering story, one that Mr. Robinson, the author of several books on the Old West, tells with scrupulous fairness to both sides. Histories of the Indian wars formerly described events from the Government's point of view only, and Mr. Robinson's use of Indian accounts to portray life inside the Sioux camp are part of a welcome trend to write a more complete and balanced history.
Unfortunately, however, "A Good Year to Die" never really comes to life as a historical panorama. Mr. Robinson details just about every event in the campaign against the Sioux. He describes every skirmish, names every commander and gives a bit of background information on the major participants, white and Sioux, including Indian chiefs like Black Elk, Red Cloud and Wooden Leg. He talks about the Army's most famous Indian fighters, like Alfred H. Terry, Ranald Mackenzie and, most famous of all, George Armstrong Custer. When an army unit sets out into the field, Mr. Robinson identifies every unit and how many men are in each. On the Indian side, if four scouts are sent out to reconnoiter enemy positions, Mr. Robinson tells us the names of all four.
This makes for a complete and dutiful account, unvarnished by romanticism or melodrama. But the historical figures in the drama remain strangely featureless and undeveloped despite Mr. Robinson's efforts to enumerate their qualities and eccentricities. The military actions, which were almost all small, blend into a blur of hard marching, dreary endurance and brief battles. The book's well-drawn maps show the main army campaigns against the Sioux, most of which took place along the rivers of the unceded territory. Still, the reader is left puzzling over some skirmishes that are fuzzy in his text.
But there are lessons to be drawn from Mr. Robinson's account, not least of them that the Great Sioux War was not very great. It was more of a wilderness police action than a full war. The entire post-Civil War Army was limited by Congress to 25,000 soldiers. Forces on either side in the conflict rarely amounted to more than several hundred combatants. The total Government dead in the war was 283, the majority of them lost in the famed showdown between Custer and Crazy Horse at the Little Big Horn. Indian casualties, while no doubt greater, are not known. In the end, what defeated the Indians was less enemy firepower than economic destitution. Kept under constant pressure by United States troops, the Sioux were unable to replenish their supplies. After incredible hardship and privation, they finally had to give up or perish.
In this sense, Mr. Robinson early on strikes the right theme: that the Great Sioux War marked the inevitable end of a way of life in North America and its replacement with a kind of sedentary dependence on the white man's bureaucracy. White settlement had made the Plains Indian culture, which required easy access to open spaces and seasonal hunting, impossible to sustain. The war was the last, futile resistance to the rules of white society by charismatic chiefs like Crazy Horse. The final holdout, Sitting Bull, who briefly escaped to Canada rather than become a reservation Indian, did come back to the United States voluntarily. He ended his glorious warrior's career as a performer in Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show, learning to write his signature so he could sign autographs for a fee.
"We are weak compared with you and your forces," one Indian leader, Little Chief, told the Government commander who accepted the Sioux surrender. "We are out of ammunition; we cannot make a rifle, a round of ammunition or a knife; in fact we are at the mercy of those who are taking possession of our country."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Trade Surplus Narrowed in the Year's First Half

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Japan's huge trade surplus narrowed to $56.19 billion in the first half of this fiscal year from a revised $59.21 billion in the comparable period a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.
Despite the 5.1 percent drop, the surplus was still large enough to help push the dollar below 100 yen briefly after the release of the numbers. The American currency later rebounded back over that figure, helped by what bankers said was intervention in the foreign-exchange market by the Bank of Japan. Late today in Tokyo, the dollar was trading at 100.34 yen. 
 Tokyo's politically sensitive trade surplus with the United States fell 13.9 percent, to $23.32 billion, in the six months through September, from $27.08 billion a year earlier. For September alone, the surplus was $4.42 billion with the United States.
A Ministry of Finance official said the figures showed that the surplus was continuing on its downward course of the last few months.
"Basically, our trade surplus is on a declining trend," he said. "We hope that the surplus will decline further with the implementation of Government economic stimulus packages such as the one announced on Sept. 20."
In September alone, Japan's overall trade surplus fell to $11.29 billion from a revised $11.96 billion a year earlier, marking a third straight month of year-over-year declines. In August, the surplus stood at $5.97 billion.
The September surplus exceeded some economists' forecasts of $9.7 billion to $10.6 billion, partly reflecting the recent weakness of the Japanese currency. But others expected the larger number.
"I was not surprised to see the figure," said Tetsuro Sawano, an economist at the Nikko Research Center.
Yuichi Matsushita, manager of global strategy at Nikko Securities, said, "The decreasing trend in the surplus is still on its way, and we foresee fiscal 1995-96 will be a much smaller number than several years ago, so we don't worry about a further possible increase in the trade balance."
The yen has fallen sharply from a high of 79.75 to the dollar in April to near its level of a year ago. As a result, the yen has lost its previous effect in raising the dollar-based value of Japanese exports, economists have said.
With the volume of imports tending to grow at a much faster pace than that of exports, the shrinking trend in the surplus will stay solid for the time being, economists said.

HEADLINE: Themes From a March Resonate

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Monday, Lavale Thomas attended the Million Man March. Today, he was in Marsha Karim's pre-law class at Eastern High School here telling a room full of rapt students how he put entrepreneurship to work for himself.
"Part of the inspirational message of the march was to keep economic power within the black community," said Mr. Thomas, who owns Kidd-Kard Services, a company that makes identification cards for pre-schoolers and day care centers in Atlanta. "I want you to know there is an alternative to the streets." 
 It was a message the students were eager to absorb. Their questions came thick and fast: How did you get a loan? Was it harder for a black man to get banks to lend money than a white man? Would blacks buy from other blacks? What did he give back to the community?
Mr. Thomas, a former Green Bay Packer running back, said building a business was sometimes tough, but that perseverance paid off. Talking about it to students, he said, was one way he contributed to the community -- along with donating a portion of his profits to schools where he lives. Mr. Thomas went to the school at the invitation of his cousin Reynauld Smith, a social studies teacher there.
"We used to look to the Government for all the answers," interrupted Mr. Smith. "But we can't say: 'give me,' 'help me,' 'I need' anymore. We have to start asking the question: 'What can each and every one of us do to help our community?' "
Many in the class, which offers early training for students interested in careers in the law, had attended the march. They said they were inspired, empowered, awed and excited about the possibilities ignited by the gathering of thousands of black men on the Mall for a day of atonement called by Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam.
It was a sentiment repeated all over the city today -- from a group of black bicycle couriers to office workers and taxi cab drivers. Like the adults, the students had diverse views about it. "It felt so good to see them together," said Jamanea Gunter, 15, of the marchers.
"I didn't think it was going to be such a success," said Zeaneteria Starks, 16.
Cedrece Watson, 15, was put off by the concentration of news reports on Mr. Farrakhan.
But Kalimah Adbul-Sabur, 17, said there was nothing wrong with what Mr. Farrakhan had said. "It's like some people don't want to hear that they've made mistakes," she said. "We as black people have made mistakes. But others, it's like they know it but don't want to hear it."
They paused to ponder what they themselves could do. Many of them come from neighborhoods wracked with crime. Nearly all knew someone who was dead or in prison.
Jamilla James, 16, her voice cracking with emotion, talked about her own neighborhood where "you see drug dealers running all day long" and how she spent her efforts on keeping a brother away from their lure.
"I don't want my little brother, who is 12, to get caught up in that," she said. "So I try to keep him busy, keep him involved in his homework, keep him cleaning the house. I tell him that he can ask me anything."
An older brother is in jail, she said, and had "gotten off track, but he talks to me and I try to support him, too."
Martrelle Pyatt, 16, said her family made a special effort to support the men in the family. When someone found a job listed in the newspaper that was in the suburbs but did not have the money to travel for an interview or to get lunch, the family would pitch in.
Ilandus Swinson, 15, who had attended the march, said he had heard the message of how important it was to respect women. "When they tick me off now, I won't use the B word," said Mr. Swinson. "If I'm tempted, I'll just pray to the Lord."
"B word?" "B word?" "What's the B word?" echoed around the class to laughter.
Shana Potter, 16, said she would demand more respect from the young men and try to rise above the "petty differences" that often annoyed her.
"I'll just focus on my career," she said. "I plan to be an attorney, then a judge."
The class offered a time of mutual confidences between the young people and the adults. Ms. Karim told about her black, white and Native American heritage, about the inspiration at the 1968 civil rights march led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and her disillusionment with the United States in the wake of his death. She told the students that she had once so despaired of race relations in the United States that she considered leaving the country. Instead, she said, she found her inspiration in teaching in the community where she lived.
Eric Love, 16, had attended the march, but said he wondered why every issue in the country always was tinged with racial overtones.
"I still want to see that day when just people can come together," he said.

HEADLINE: After March, Lawmakers Seek Commission on Race Relations

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Seeking to build on the momentum generated by Monday's rally of hundreds of thousands of black men in Washington, six members of Congress today asked President Clinton to appoint a national commission on race relations, while Louis Farrakhan, who organized the gathering, suggested that the event had made him a force on the national scene.
"I know you do not know me," Mr. Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, said at a news conference, "but I know you will get to know me. And you're going to have to live with me. To some, I am a nightmare. But to others, I am a dream come true." 
 With the memories of Monday's rally fresh in their minds, politicians, academics and civil rights leaders groped today to find meaning in the Million Man March, wondering if it represented a watershed in race relations or a one-day love-in with no lasting effect.
Commentators, intellectuals and others agreed that the rally, coming in the aftermath of the divisive acquittal of O. J. Simpson on murder charges, focused the attention of the nation's leaders on the subject of race as no recent events have. And indeed, the two events prompted extensive statements by President Clinton and Speaker Newt Gingrich.
What was clear was that the event -- which, the Park Police said, drew a throng of 400,000 to the nation's capital -- captured the attention of much of the country. Officials at the Cable News Network said today that 2.2 million households tuned in to Mr. Farrakhan's rambling and complex speech -- meaning that more people watched the two-hour-long address on CNN than any other speech this year, including Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Message and the Pope's address to the United Nations.
"We got the kind of numbers that basic cable only sees for first-run movies," said Howard Polskin, a vice president at CNN.
And it was equally clear that the event elevated Mr. Farrakhan's standing and posed a dilemma for traditional civil rights organizations.
At today's news conference, the Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., who helped organize the event, said he would convene a meeting of the National African American Leadership Summit -- a coalition that has included the Nation of Islam -- next month to plan a political and economic agenda that would seize upon the momentum built from the march. Mr. Chavis invited groups like the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the National Urban League and the National Baptist Convention, which declined to endorse the march, to participate in next month's meeting.
In doing so, he placed these groups in the same vexing position they were in before Monday's rally: Either shun Mr. Farrakhan or embrace an effort that will include him and risk alienating white, especially Jewish, supporters.
Today, six members of the House wrote Mr. Clinton urging him to appoint a bipartisan commission to study race relations in the United States since the 1960's and to then make recommendations for improvements. The lawmakers said they envisioned a panel similar to the Kerner Commission, which in 1968 issued a report concluding that the United States was "moving towards two societies, one black, one white -- separate and unequal."
The biracial, bipartisan group of members of Congress who asked that the commission be appointed were: Representatives Charles E. Schumer and Charles B. Rangel, Democrats of New York; Delegate Eleanor Holmes Norton, Democrat of the District of Columbia; Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia; Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, and Representative Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida.
But even as the group was pleading for steps to build understanding between blacks and whites, organizers of Monday's rally were accusing the Park Service of racism and of deliberately underestimating the size of the crowd at 400,000.
At his news conference today, Mr. Farrakhan said that "racism, white supremacy, and the hatred of Louis Farrakhan disallows them to give us credit" for breaking the record for the largest crowd to ever gather on the Mall. The record was set by the 1964 inauguration of President Lyndon B. Johnson, which attracted 1.2 million people to the Mall.
Officials with the Nation of Islam threatened a lawsuit to force the Park Service to issue what they insisted was the true number of the size of crowd.
The squabbling over the size of the crowd threatened to draw attention from an event that people from the far ends of the political spectrum agreed was a milestone.
The rally prompted Mr. Clinton to give a major address on race relations at the University of Texas at Austin in which he chided blacks and whites to "clean their houses" of racism. The peaceful march also drew comments from Mr. Gingrich.
"The march ought to be a wake-up call for all of America," Mr. Gingrich told a group of conservatives who were celebrating the 10th anniversary of Radio America on Monday night. "And, in a wonderful irony, typical of American history, all of us owe Louis Farrakhan a thank you for having told all of us, if the pain level is great enough for him to be a leader, then we all have a lot bigger challenge to lead."
But beyond agreeing that the rally caused the country to think about race relations -- at least for one day -- there was little consensus on whether the event, with its twin calls for blacks to take more responsibility for their actions and for the country to atone for its sins against blacks, would produce much change.
"Obviously, a lot of goodwill was built yesterday," said Hugh Price, president of the National Urban League. "It was a very spiritual experience and there is quite a good chance that it will be built into increased responsibility, changed behavior and heightened engagement in civic life on the part of black men."
But others were not so sure. Some said that while a change in the behavior of many black men would go a long way toward solving some of the problems of the inner city, it was not the only answer.
Glenn Loury, a black conservative economist, said he was impressed by the rally and its themes. But he was caught up short when asked if it would have any lasting effect.
"Be better fathers and better husbands," said Mr. Loury, a professor of economics at Boston University. "It all sounds kind of empty when you say it out loud. It makes sense and these things should be done. But it doesn't sound like much of a program."
The discussion over the rally's significance went beyond the country's intellectual elite.
As drug dealers plied their wares nearby, Eugene Hampton, 28, and Lamont Beckham, 55, got into a spirited argument on a bench in Wilson Park in Compton, Calif., an economically depressed city south of Los Angeles.
"He's a good role model for the generation to come and the young people my age," Mr. Hampton said of Mr. Farrakhan.
But Mr. Beckham would have none of it. "To me, Farrakhan is mostly out for himself, not for blacks, and that's the way I think," he said. "And to me, he has a personal thing about the Jews, and there are some statements he never should have said about them."
Mr. Beckham was also unimpressed by Mr. Farrakhan's speech. "It's the same things he was saying in the 60's, it's just that a new generation hasn't heard it before," he said.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Turkey's Premier Asked To Form a Government

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Turkey's President asked Prime Minister Tansu Ciller to form a new government today, a day after she resigned because Parliament rejected her old one.
President Suleyman Demirel asked Mrs. Ciller to stay on after she patched together a partnership with the Republican People's Party on Monday. The center-left party had belonged to Mrs. Ciller's original governing coalition, but bolted last month over her economic austerity plan. 
 Mrs. Ciller formed a minority government after the coalition collapsed, but it failed on Sunday to win a vote of confidence.
Mr. Demirel canceled an official visit to Washington this week because of the political crisis, which erupted over Mrs. Ciller's austerity program.

HEADLINE: On an Oasis in New York Harbor, a Bittersweet Salute

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
When Capt. Kevin Ray first heard eight years ago that he would be transferred from his Coast Guard posting in New Orleans to Governors Island, at the foot of Manhattan, his heart plummeted like an anchor.
"When I looked at the set of orders," he said yesterday, "I thought, 'I'm going to have to slit my wrists.' New York? I had absolutely no desire to come to this city." 
 But as word spread around the hushed, campus-like haven of Governors Island that the Coast Guard had decided on Monday to close the base after 29 years and to disperse the island's residents as early as next summer, Captain Ray allowed that there were more than a few things he would miss about a place "that quickly grew on me."
"And what's not to like?" he said. For four years his quarters have been an elegant 100-year-old red-brick Victorian mansion, built for the Army officers who inhabited the island before him, with a makeshift woodworking shop set up in the basement and an attic bedroom offering an extraordinary view of Manhattan's downtown skyline.
"I will never again, I think, live in a house the likes of the one I live in now," he said yesterday in his office.
Captain Ray, who is not a golfer, said he might even miss harvesting the golf balls that seem to collect in his front yard, just a slice away from the first tee at the base's popular nine-hole golf course. "There are so many aspects of this place that are unique, like a very small town in the heart of the biggest city," he said.
In the offices and on the narrow streets of the island the Dutch called Nooten Eylandt, or Nut Island, because of its thick groves of chestnut trees, there were many who echoed Captain Ray's sentiments yesterday. They said that while they had never been exactly enamored of the busy city that loomed on the horizon, they had grown to love their life on the island, in a cloistered community that seemed somehow plucked from a forgotten America, more Andy Griffith than Kojak or Seinfeld.
"Because they predominantly come from small-unit backgrounds -- we operate in smaller communities -- New York City is a bit of a change for many of our people," said Capt. James D. Garrison, the deputy commander of the Coast Guard's Maintenance and Logistics Command Atlantic, during a news conference to announce the closing.
But the island itself, said Lieut. John Shallman, the Coast Guard's spokesman on the island, "is a place where people don't lock their cars and many of them don't lock their apartments." It is a place where a ticket to see a first-run movie at the base's theater still costs only $2, and where many officers eat lunch at home with their families, because home is often just a few hundred feet from the office down a cobblestone street.
"We are a self-sufficient community, with schools and restaurants and housing and virtually everything we need right here," said Lieutenant Shallman, who added that he knew people who had not set foot off the island for years, except for a trip out of the state or country.
It is exactly this self-sufficiency, though, that led to the Coast Guard's decision to close the base -- the largest piece of a plan to reduce overall spending by $400 million over the next four years. Because the base is on an island, the Coast Guard had to provide all the municipal services that its personnel needed to live there, at an operational cost of about $54 million a year.
More than 1,000 Coast Guard members will soon be transferred to bases in Tidewater, Va., and Charleston, S.C., "where our people can live on the economy, and we don't have to provide these services," Captain Garrison said. Most of the personnel will be transferred out by next summer, and the island, owned by the Federal Government, will be fully turned over to the General Services Administration by 1998.
While the closing is a disappointment to Coast Guard personnel, many of whom will have to uproot their children from the island's school, Public School 26, and leave their historic residences behind, it will be even harder for many civilian employees, for whom the decision is essentially a pink slip. As many as 250 of the island's 700 employees are expected to be laid off as the base's operations dwindle in the next three years, officials said.
"Twenty years ago when you went to work for the Government, the one thing you were sure of was job security," said Richard T. Kenney, a civilian maritime relations officer who also worked at two other military complexes, the Brooklyn Army Terminal and the Brooklyn Navy Yard, when they were shuttered. " And now it's one of the shakier jobs you can have."
As they worked and talked with each other about the news, several members of the Coast Guard said that one of their only regrets about the closing was that they were leaving behind a piece of real estate that could end up being fiercely fought over by developers and turned into a playground for the rich.
"It was kind of nice, living in a place where so many people are probably envious of your views and your space in this crowded city," said Lieut. (j.g.) Charlene Ditty, an engineering officer.
But she added that the "novelty of New York" quickly wore off for her and her husband, also in the Coast Guard, and they are more than ready to leave.
And there are also those like Seaman Arizona Guastaferro, 21, who came to the base from a 270-foot cutter stationed in New Bedford, Mass., for whom the closing holds no emotional overtones at all, except perhaps relief.
"When I came here, I thought this was the most depressing place I'd ever seen, sort of gloomy" said Seaman Guastaferro, who works for the base newspaper. "It's like a small town where everyone knows what you did before you even do it, you know?"
After nearly a year on the island, he said, "I'm going to be happy to get back out into the real world again."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 20, 1995, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Coast Guard's decision to close its base on Governors Island referred incorrectly in some editions to Seaman Arizona Guastaferro, who expressed remorse over the shutdown. The seaman is a woman.

HEADLINE: Monthly Gap In U.S. Trade Down Sharply; Exports Surge

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
A surge in exports cut the nation's trade deficit sharply in August, to $8.8 billion, the smallest monthly gap so far in a year of generally expanding deficits, the Commerce Department reported today.
The unexpectedly strong sales abroad buoyed the dollar in world currency markets today and led analysts to raise estimates for growth in the economy during the third quarter. Exports reached a record despite a lack of significant growth for some major trading partners; imports were essentially flat. 
 The $2.4 billion narrowing in August was almost entirely the result of higher exports of American merchandise, mainly civilian aircraft, computer accessories, semiconductors and automotive products. There was virtually no change in exports of services or in imports of goods or services.
"We are encouraged by the bounce in exports," said Robert E. Mellman, an economist at Morgan Guaranty, which now predicts that gross domestic product will post a 2.7 percent rate of expansion when the Commerce Department publishes its first estimate of third quarter growth at the end of next week. The bank, citing a rise in inventories reported earlier in the week, had been expecting G.D.P. to rise at a 2 percent pace.
The Clinton Administration was quick to boast of the much narrower August deficit, which was accompanied by a $300 million downward revision for July.
"Obviously, we're encouraged -- it's export led," Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said in a telephone interview from Jerusalem, where he announced an agreement with Israel to expand sales of American farm products. He also noted that goods exported over the last 12 months grew 15.7 percent, thereby surpassing the growth of imports, which was 15.4 percent.
Western Europe, however, accounted for nearly all of the smaller trade gap in August as the deficit with Japan was essentially unchanged at $5.1 billion and the deficit with China grew by $600 million, to $3.9 billion.
The ever-rising imbalance with China, now 77 percent as large as the American deficit with Japan, compared with 56 percent in August 1994, aroused Administration concern.
"It is disturbing to see that again our trade deficit with China increased," Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown declared in a statement from Hong Kong. Mr. Brown had just completed a series of meetings in Beijing in which he expressed the Administration's "firm commitment" to a better balance in economic relations.
Despite the lower August trade gap, economists here noted that the deficit so far this year still ran 17 percent higher than the swollen 1994 pace and would no doubt exceed last year's total of $106.2 billion.
Looking back over the last several months, said Michael P. Niemira, economist at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York, "we're seeing a slowdown both on the export and import side." Both categories, the department's figures show, declined in June and July.
Over all, the United States registered a $13.8 billion deficit on goods, which was partly offset by a $5 billion surplus from such services as tourism, insurance and royalties.
Exports climbed 3.7 percent in August, to a record $65.7 billion, more than making up for declines of 1.5 percent in June and 1.8 percent in July. Imports, reflecting subdued demand from a moderately expanding American economy, held steady at $74.5 billion.
While the Administration pointed to a fifth consecutive month of narrowing in the deficit with Japan, the change in August was so small as to disappear in the rounding, at $5.1 billion. Imports of Japanese cars, however, edged down $200 million.
Japan reported its own trade figures today, showing an overall surplus for September at $11.29 billion, down from a revised $11.96 billion a year earlier. In trade with just the United States, Japan said it ran a surplus of $4.42 billion, down from $5.82 billion a year ago. For the first half of the fiscal year, through September, Japan's overall surplus narrowed to $56.19 billion, from a revised $59.21 billion a year earlier.
United States exports to Mexico, which are about 10 percent lower this year because of that country's economic crisis, perked up in August to help trim the American deficit $200 million, to $1.1 billion. The deficit with Canada, meanwhile, widened $400 million, to $1.6 billion. Unlike the aggregate figures, those for individual countries are not adjusted for recurring seasonal variation.
The deficit with Western Europe contracted sharply -- to $769 million from $3.1 billion in July. The United States experienced either smaller deficits or higher surpluses with all 10 of the listed countries, the biggest changes being with Germany and Belgium followed by Italy, the Netherlands and Sweden.
On a three-month moving average, the American trade deficit declined to $10.4 billion from $11.1 billion, today's report also showed.
For advanced technology products, the August surplus climbed to $672 million from $252 million in July, but it was only half what it had been in June.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. LAWMAKERS SCRAMBLE TO PASS A MEDICARE PLAN

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
On the eve of a crucially important Medicare vote, House Republicans today opened a vote-trading bazaar to line up a majority and joined their Senate allies in accusing the Clinton Administration of playing political games with the national debt.
After tinkering with Medicare allowances for rural areas and dealing with complaints about other measures, from lobbying to nursing-home payments, the Republicans expressed confidence that they had persuaded enough doubters to pass their Medicare proposal on Thursday. [Page B12.] 
 Although Speaker Newt Gingrich cheerfully described the bargaining as "a little bit like Christmas shopping," his closed-door efforts were the most serious business of the day. Medicare is the bloodiest political battlefield of this fall's budget wars, and the first test of the Republican effort to balance the budget by the year 2002.
Even so, there was plenty of time for intense posturing over the national debt, as each side demanded that the other abandon political advantage for the sake of the national interest. All day long the White House and Mr. Gingrich traded offers and non-offers, and then charges and countercharges, on a temporary increase in the debt limit.
The Treasury Department calculates that an increase must be enacted by early November, when, it says, the Government will reach its current, $4.9 trillion ceiling on public borrowing.
But Mr. Gingrich, after suggesting a temporary debt-limit increase that would allow Congress and the White House time to try to resolve their differences over the 1996 budget, backed off and complained that the Administration was playing political games.
"We have no belief the Treasury has accurate figures," he said. "I want to look at the facts. Who knows what the truth is? I don't have a clue."
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, agreed, although a little less forcefully. He said he was not "trying to cause any calamity in the Government," but insisted that the Administration "stop playing games."
The Administration responded with confused disappointment from Michael D. McCurry, White House press secretary, who said of the Republicans, "It's impossible to predict where they're going to be from one moment to the next, you know." The White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, offered regretful exasperation, saying, "I don't think the game-playing on the debt ceiling is a responsible thing to do."
The Republicans had an easier time with a gleeful celebration of a remark, delivered on Tuesday night at a Houston fund raiser, in which President Clinton said he thought he had raised taxes too much.
The Republicans interrupted a session of the Senate Finance Committee, which was trying to pass a $245 billion tax-cut measure, to offer unusual congratulations to the President. "I have to say maybe I agree with President Clinton this time," said the chairman, Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware.
The committee, delayed by Democratic objections, worked into the night on the tax cut before deciding to recess for the evening and reconvene on Thursday. The measure, whose main element would give a $500-a-child tax credit to most families, has the support of all the Republicans on the committee and will probably go to the full Senate for a vote later this month. It will be part of the budget reconciliation bill, which will also include reductions in the growth of entitlements like Medicare and Medicaid.
"We're here to reduce taxes," Mr. Roth declared, "for the purpose of creating growth."
But Democrats held that cutting taxes was bad policy, especially when it was being done in conjunction with lower spending for Medicare, Medicaid, education and other Government programs.
The Senate measure follows the general path of even deeper tax reductions approved by the House last April. But the Senate proposal differs from the House bill in several important respects, which will have to be resolved in a House-Senate conference before the budget reconciliation bill can go to Mr. Clinton. These are the major differences:
The Senate bill would give the $500-a-child tax credit to single parents with annual taxable incomes up to $75,000 and to couples with incomes up to $110,000. The House bill would allow parents with adjusted gross incomes up to $200,000 to claim the credit.
Like the House bill, the Senate bill would reduce the top tax rate on capital gains, the profits from the sale of investments, to 19.8 percent for individuals, from the current 28 percent. But the senators did not accept a House provision that wouldallow the value of investments to be adjusted annually for inflation.
The Senate measure would not lift the maximum income a retiree could earn without forfeiting some Social Security benefits; nor would it repeal a provision, enacted in 1993, that increased the portion of middle- and upper-income retirees' Social Security benefits that is subject to taxation. The House bill would take both these steps.
The senators did not go along with House-passed provisions that would repeal the alternative minimum tax, for wealthy taxpayers with large write-offs. Nor did they agree with the House plan to give businesses a more favorable schedule for depreciating their investments in plants and machinery.
Like the tax cut, the Republicans' Medicare proposal drew heavy fire from the Administration again today. In renewing a threat by Mr. Clinton to veto the entire budget reconciliation bill, Alice M. Rivlin, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, attacked its "deep, unwarranted cuts in Medicare that would raise costs for beneficiaries and sharply cut payments to providers, jeopardizing access to, and the quality of, care."
In a letter to Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, the New York Republican who heads the House Rules Committee, Ms. Rivlin said, "The President has made it clear that he will veto any reconciliation bill that includes Medicare" cuts of that size.
Undaunted, Republicans went ahead with intense tinkering on the Medicare bill today. As Mr. Gingrich observed, "Any time you are in the last 48 hours before a major vote, 17 people show up who suddenly figure out you need their vote and they have this one thing they haven't gotten yet."
Seventeen is indeed a crucial figure. If 17 Republicans defect on Thursday, and if no Democrat crosses party lines to vote for the bill, it will be defeated.
Responding to complaints by Representatives from rural areas, for example, Mr. Gingrich engineered an increase in the amount that health plans in less populated counties would be guaranteed when they enlist elderly Americans in managed care, a major goal of the bill. Such plans had been promised no more than $200 a month, but the bill was changed to guarantee them at least $250. Even so, rural lawmakers said that was still not enough, and some were saying they would oppose the bill.
Another major change was made to that part of the reconciliation bill that deals with Medicaid, the Federal-state program that pays medical costs for the poor, the disabled and thousands of elderly nursing home residents.
As originally drafted, the bill would have allowed states to seize money and property from the spouses and adult children of nursing home patients to pay for their care before any Medicaid money would have gone to help them. Current law prohibits tapping the resources of spouses and adult children, and the latest revision would continue that practice.
Representative Thomas S. Bliley, the Virginia Republican who heads the House Commerce Committee, announced this reversal from the bitterly protested provision in the bill that his committee had approved.
"In the Commerce Committee, we pride ourselves on our ability to listen and to make improvements in legislation when called for," he said in a statement. "We should not risk a single American going to the poorhouse just because a spouse or parent had to enter a nursing home."


GRAPHIC: President Clinton and Congressional Republicans have some simple disagreements over the budget. But they are being played out in very complicated ways, as both sides engage in a high-stakes game of chicken over the laws governing the nation's ability to borrow money. Here are some of the terms and factors in the debt debate.
 
Deficit: Each year's overspending by the Government -- revenues minus spending. The Government covers this shortfall by borrowing money -- issuing Treasury bills, notes and bonds.
 
Debt: The accumulation of borrowing to cover those yearly deficits, plus interest.
 
Debt ceiling: A statutory limit on the amount of money the Federal Government may borrow to finance deficits. The limit must be approved by both houses of Congress. Right now, the debt ceiling is $4.9 trillion. The debt is expected to reach that level around Oct. 31, according to the Treasury Department.
 
Hitting the ceiling: When the debt ceiling is reached, the Government would be unable to issue new Treasury notes to raise the revenue needed to write checks -- for everything from Social Security payments to paper clips for the Pentagon. The problem is particularly acute at this time of year, when the I.R.S. is bringing in relatively little revenue.
 
Temporary increase: A stopgap increase in the debt limit, for days or weeks.
 
Default: Failure to pay debts when due, and a lot will be due soon. On Nov. 15, the Treasury must pay $25 billion in interest and $33 billion in principal on Treasury bills coming due that day. The next day, $44 billion more comes due. The United States has never defaulted on its debts and the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, has repeatedly called the possibility "unthinkable."
 
Rescheduling: Despite Mr. Rubin's confidence that default can be avoided, he has begun taking steps to postpone the crunch. Even as he does so, he and others are worrying that such preparations or the threat of default could frighten investors, particularly the foreigners who hold roughly 25 percent of U.S. debt. As a result, the Government might have to pay more interest to attract purchasers of government bonds. (pg. B12)

HEADLINE: Million Man March Puzzles a Houston Suburb

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: CHANNELVIEW, Tex., Oct. 18

 BODY:
"Get out, get a job, take care of your family, and don't kill people," said Tracie Bratton, offering her own distillation of the theme from the Million Man March in Washington.
"Now that's a good message," added Mrs. Bratton, who caught grainy glimpses of Monday's huge rally on the small black-and-white television here at Hauck's Hair Haven, a beauty salon where she works. "Who in the world is going to disagree with a message like that? But what I don't understand is, why did they direct it only at black men? I mean, they should have opened it to all men." 
 Like a lot of white people here in this largely white, working-class outpost of the Houston area, the 30-year-old Mrs. Bratton freely admits that there are a lot of things about race relations these days that she just does not understand.
Not the appeal of Louis Farrakhan, the leader of both the march and the Nation of Islam. Nor the jubilation so many black people seemed to feel at the acquittal of O. J. Simpson. Nor the reason for all those black men to get together and express black pride or black anger or "what, exactly, this rally was supposed to be all about" in Mrs. Bratton's words.
"It's unnecessary, really," added one of her customers, Anna Baize, 24, a bartender whose hair was wrapped in tight curls for a perm. "I thought all that was over in the 1960's. It's like, get a life."
No place in America can offer a perfect snapshot of white attitudes about race relations. But this blue-collar town, home to chemical refineries, polyethylene plants and an infamous woman accused of trying to murder the mother of her daughter's chief cheerleading rival a few years back, does offer a look at the gulf suggested in many polls between how many white Americans and black Americans view everything from Mr. Simpson's trial to the need for affirmative action.
Many white people here, for instance, present it as a matter of indisputable fact that black people can get jobs more easily than whites these days. And while many white residents here went out of their way to express benign sentiments about Monday's rally and its aftermath, many of their comments could be construed as doubled-edged -- patronizing, or worse -- and may thus illustrate the very racial divide that they say should be erased.
"There could have been a riot," said 36-year-old Julius Honeycutt, a ponytailed man who works as a machine operator at a plastic bottle plant here. "It was a success because nobody got hurt. That's the way I look at it."
At the lunch break at the construction site for a new high school, a group of white electricians, all from Channelview or nearby towns, found themselves in disagreement over what the march and its message might accomplish.
"I think it was good," said Tim Savell, 38, an expressive man wearing jeans and work boots, who said he had "no problems" with a blacks-only rally. "The point was, blacks should be more responsible. If they get off welfare, that's going to help all of us out. And let's face it, many of the problems are in black neighborhoods. There are kids in the ghettoes who don't have any fathers. There are high death rates for youths. Drugs. The prisons are full of blacks."
But Wayne Garrett, 49, said the march was little more than an empty publicity stunt.
"I'm not sure it's going to change black people at all," he said, shaking his head. "The point was to see how many people they could get together, show how many votes they have.
"But as soon as they get back home," he continued, "they're going to be back on food stamps, back on welfare. Blacks are always talking about discrimination -- the white man is doing this, the white man is doing that. It's everybody's fault but theirs. I don't think that's going to change."
Dwayne Phillips, 24, another electrician at the construction site, said he liked the message but was appalled at the chief messenger, Mr. Farrakhan.
"He's as prejudicial as they come, trashing the Jews and everything," Mr. Phillips said. "They picked the wrong guy. It's like Pee Wee Herman selling Nike shoes or something. That's not going to work. You need a Michael Jordan."
The other white workers nodded in agreement but quickly fell into dispute over who the best black preacher for black self-reliance would be. Mr. Phillips suggested the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a choice met with several side-to-side "no" headshakes from colleagues. Gen. Colin L. Powell got a few "yes" nods.
"Martin Luther King was probably the best man for the job," offered Mr. Savell. "But he's dead."
Even as speakers and marchers at Monday's rally talked about the lack of economic opportunity for black men, many of the whites here seemed to have a startlingly different view.
"What makes any of this a black issue?" said Mrs. Bratton, the hairdresser. "There are whites, Chinese, Mexicans that are poor.
"It's an issue for them -- yes, if not more so than blacks," she said. "If you have three men applying for a job -- a black man, a Hispanic man and a white man -- it's pretty much always going to be the black man gets the job because he's black. Don't ask me who made the rules. That just seems to be the way it is these days."
Miss Baize, her customer, also said she detected a racially tinged double standard in the fact that the blacks-only rally even took place on public property.
"If a white man had led a rally like this, people would have had a fit," she said. "In fact, it wouldn't have been allowed. Black men have a rally, and it's all about black pride. But if whites had a rally, it'd be, 'Uh-oh, it's the Ku Klux Klan.' "
Although only 15 miles from Houston, which is a racially mixed city and the country's fourth largest, Channelview is an insular world of tidy ranch houses and mobile homes.
It has been the scene of calamities -- a compressor explosion at a chemical plant that killed 17 people in 1990, and the floods and fires that seemed to bring literal hell and high water to the town a year ago -- that have served, people here say with a touch of pride, to make the community all the more tight-knit.
But in some ways, the sense of detachment here made Monday's march of hundreds of thousands of black men seem all the more remote, a bit like watching a lunar landing on television.
Many here said they did not quite "get it" when asked what the rally was all about, and others watched the rally or news accounts of it with suspicion, amusement or total disinterest. Some said they knew absolutely nothing about the rally until asked about it by a reporter.
"I've been working 12-hour shifts," said Mike Meek, an electrician. "I haven't heard a thing about it."

HEADLINE: Ohio Mortgage Bank Settles Discrimination Complaint

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The Justice Department extended its campaign against racial discrimination in the banking industry today, reaching a $420,000 settlement with a big Ohio lender accused of charging higher fees to black applicants for mortgages than to white applicants.
The Huntington Mortgage Company, a unit of Huntington Bancshares Inc., agreed to pay the money in response to a Justice Department complaint -- filed along with the settlement today -- that the company had charged higher fees to 117 black applicants in the Cleveland area than to white applicants. The fees consisted mainly of points, which are payments made by mortgage applicants when their loans are approved and which are typically equal to 1 to 3 percentage points of the balance of the mortgage. 
 The Justice Department said today's case was the first in which it had applied fair-lending laws to bank fees on mortgages. Other lending cases since the Clinton Administration began a push to enforce the laws had involved banks that it said were charging higher interest rates to minority borrowers or avoiding doing business in minority neighborhoods.
The company acknowledged that the 117 black applicants had paid more. But it denied any violation of the law, contending that the Justice Department had not looked at a broad enough sample of mortgage applications to demonstrate racial discrimination.
"The Department of Justice's analysis focused on a statistical aberration relating to the Cleveland office of the Huntington Mortgage Company during a limited time period," the company said. "In order to avoid protracted and even more costly litigation, the parties have agreed to resolve this controversy voluntarily."
But Deval L. Patrick, the Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, said the pattern did not occur by chance.
Paul F. Hancock, the chief of the housing section in the Justice Department's civil rights division, said the agency had not found evidence of discrimination in Huntington Mortgage's offices in any area other than Cleveland. The overcharges were said to have occurred from 1991 to 1993, when many banks were still training their staffs on fair-lending laws as the Justice Department began stepping up its enforcement of the 27-year-old legislation.
Bank examiners found no evidence of discrimination during a review of Huntington in 1994, Mr. Hancock said, adding, "When this was brought to their attention, they took some very positive steps."
The $420,000 will be divided among the 117 applicants in proportion to the amounts by which they were said to have been overcharged. The money is "two or three times" greater than the overcharges, a Justice Department official said.
Based in Columbus, Ohio, Huntington Bancshares is the nation's 37th-largest bank as measured by total assets. Its shares fell 56.25 cents today to close at $23.25 in heavy Nasdaq trading.
Lending officers have some discretion in the points they charge on a mortgage, and they generally keep part of this fee, giving them an incentive to charge more. Because the points are not related to the riskiness of the loan, there is no reason for black applicants to be charged more points than white applicants, and banks need to train their lending officers to make sure that this does not happen, Mr. Hancock said.
James D. McLaughlin, the director of Federal agency relations at the American Bankers Association, a trade group based in Washington, said that banks were trying to improve training. But he objected to the Justice Department settlement, saying that there had been no clear rules until now on mortgage points.
"It's a case where there were no clear rules beforehand and now we're getting our wrists slapped afterwards," he said.
Mr. Hancock said that the fair-lending laws clearly barred discrimination on the basis of race or national origin in any lending activity.
The Justice Department also reached a $500,000 settlement today with the Security State Bank of Pecos, a tiny institution in Pecos, Tex., that the department accused of charging higher interest rates to Hispanic applicants for consumer loans. The Federal Reserve Board first noticed a pattern in the interest rates in 1993 and asked the Justice Department to investigate.
Bank officials did not return telephone calls seeking comment.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Argentina's fiscal virtue is no match for outside forces.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
MEXICO got into big economic trouble last year because the besieged ruling party dared not ask for sacrifice from an electorate that has yet to taste the fruits of growth. Argentina, by contrast, has not budged from the tough policies instituted by a popular democratic Government -- policies that paid off in rapid growth with stable prices from 1990 through 1994.
Yet many forecasters expect Mexico to shake off its economic hangover before Argentina emerges from a recession induced by Mexico's indulgences. And even with the benefit of hindsight, few economists argue that Argentina could have dodged this fate. What's going on here? 
 The short answer is that virtue is not always a guarantee of reward in a global economy driven in part by the self-fulfilling prophecies of footloose investors. The long answer is that Argentina is paying for the sins of generations of past mismanagement. "It's a gamble" for Argentina to hold the line on current policies, argues Rudi Dornbusch, an economist at M.I.T., "but it's a gamble without a realistic alternative."
When the Mexican peso collapsed last December, the shock spread through Latin America as investors rushed to sell local currencies in expectation of other devaluations. Yet Peru and Brazil bounced back quickly, notes Lawrence Krohn, an economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland, while Argentina has foundered. Argentina's widely respected Finance Minister, Domingo Cavallo, has been reduced to presiding over pep rallies for Wall Street, explaining over and over that Argentina will not deviate from the path of economic righteousness. "All he can do is jawbone," Mr. Krohn says.
The explanation lies in Argentina's decadent past. For most of this century, Argentine governments used the ability to create money as just another tool to buy off powerful interests: unions, public employees, the military. As a result, Mr. Dornbusch said, "the economy was essentially dollarized" by the late 1980's: nobody would use the local currency as a store of value or write a contract dependent on its purchasing power.
So in 1991 to prove that Argentina was absolutely, positively going to mend its ways, Mr. Cavallo persuaded his boss, President Carlos Saul Menem, to put monetary policy in a vault and throw away the key. The exchange rate was fixed at one Argentine peso to one American dollar. Much more important, the Government legally committed itself to holding a dollar in the central bank for every peso in currency outstanding and in private bank deposits with the central bank.
As part of a sweeping set of changes that included a conservative fiscal policy, the opening of markets to competition from imports, the weakening of unions and the privatization of most state-owned monopolies, the system has worked. Inflation is down to roughly 3 percent. And with the help of robust foreign investment and a blistering 5 percent rate of productivity change, the economy grew at a rate of almost 8 percent annually from 1990 through 1994.
But this passive monetary policy, known in the jargon of economics as a currency board, has a couple of striking disadvantages when the going gets rough. The most obvious is that Argentina cannot directly expand the money supply to reduce interest rates and stimulate the economy out of recession. Perhaps more important, the Government cannot act as a lender of last resort, providing cash to banks when panicky depositors demand their money back.
Mr. Dornbusch is convinced that "Argentina will be the next Chile," making the leap to modern free-market capitalism in this generation. But that bright future, he says, could be postponed indefinitely if the banking system breaks under the weight of a confidence crisis induced by the current recession. And his caution is reinforced by his own estimate that prices and wages will have to fall considerably before Argentine exports are fully competitive in world markets.
Others are more optimistic. Steve Hanke, an economist at Johns Hopkins University and an adviser to Mr. Cavallo, denies that the Argentine peso is overvalued. He even argues that "the Mexican peso devaluation has been a blessing in disguise" because it hastened the privatization and consolidation of Argentina's inefficient banks. Jose Barrocal, an investment banker with James Wolfensohn & Company in New York, has not spotted that particular silver lining. But he says that "the worst is over," and that the Argentine economy should start growing again in 1996.
Argentina starkly reveals the strengths and weaknesses of the currency board idea. What Mr. Barrocal calls "the clarity and symbolism" of this bulwark against inflation "is already attracting foreign investment that would have gone to Brazil." But the country's current predicament makes it all too clear that the world's smaller economies are now prisoners of forces beyond their reckoning.

HEADLINE: Cuba, Eager for Tourist Dollars, Dusts Off Its Vacancy Sign

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
There was a time not too long ago when travelers arriving here from the capitalist world typically were members of solidarity delegations coming to express support for the Cuban Revolution. As they disembarked, they would be greeted by political slogans and posters of Fidel Castro and Che Guevara.
Nowadays, though, the passengers being disgorged from the many flights that land at Jose Marti International Airport are more likely to be Canadian, European or Latin American tourists in search of sun, sand and surf. And while the vacationers wait to clear customs, they are surrounded not by propaganda but by murals touting the diversions that await them: scuba diving, windsurfing, nightclubs. 
 Six years after the collapse of the Soviet bloc forced the Castro Government to re-evaluate its entire economic model, Cuba is once again emerging as a prime tourist spot in the Caribbean. Tourism is now the country's second-largest source of foreign exchange and, propelled by double-digit rates of annual growth, may soon pull even with the slumping sugar industry.
"The steady and sustained development of tourism is something that the Cuban Government regards as being of the utmost importance," said Miguel Brugueras, deputy director of Cuba's National Tourism Institute, the Government body that oversees the industry.
Government officials here report revenue of $850 million from 616,000 foreign visitors in 1994 and anticipate that some 800,000 tourists will spend slightly more than $1 billion this year. By contrast, in 1988, the last full year before the Soviet empire disintegrated, 309,000 people visited Cuba and spent just $189 million.
Before Mr. Castro came to power in 1959, Cuba was the principal tourist destination in the Caribbean, attracting 300,000 visitors a year, 80 percent of them Americans. But that influx was cut off by Washington's 34-year trade embargo against Cuba. For many years the Communist Government derided tourism as corrupt and demeaning, and resumed it only because of the disappearance of the Soviet bloc, which accounted for 85 percent of Cuba's foreign trade.
To accommodate an anticipated increase in visitors, the Cuban Government has embarked on a major hotel construction and renovation drive. The bulk of the construction has been in Varadero, 125 miles east of here. Along miles of glittering amber sands, Spanish, Mexican, French, German other foreign chains now operate hotels catering to European and Canadian travelers.
Cuba is also scheduled to re-enter the cruise business, from which it has been virtually absent for three decades. Under an agreement signed with the Italian company Costa Crociere, a 480-passenger cruise ship, the Costa Playa, will call at Cuban ports beginning in late November.
"In the Caribbean, that's one of the most important sources of income," Mr. Brugueras said, "but this is something that is not up to us. We will truly be able to open to cruise ship passengers only when the United States permits it."
He was alluding to the major hindrance to Cuba's tourism project: the absence of the United States, which would naturally be its largest market. The embargo forbids American citizens to spend money in Cuba and prohibits passenger ships that stop in Cuba from docking in the United States in the same voyage.
But Mr. Brugueras shrugged that off. "American businessmen are losing a magnificent opportunity," he said. "They are going to have to be alert, because this is something that we are not going to abandon."
