HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
The Devils' Golden Boy

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

DATELINE: SECAUCUS, N.J., Oct. 18

 BODY:
The face behind the mask is almost pretty, still soft, without edges, in the very last period of boyhood. A blond curl spills over a broad, unlined, forehead. Pale blue eyes are framed by golden lashes. The full lips are quick to smile above a cleft chin. The voice, enhanced by the sauce of Canadian French, is low but enthusiastic.
"When we play Philadelphia," said Martin Brodeur, the eager collector, "I'll get an autographed stick from Lindros. In 15 years, Eric will be a legend and my kid will be very happy to have the souvenir."
Brodeur's kid, Anthony, is all of 4 months old, but then Brodeur is all of 23 years. He is also the best goalie in the National Hockey League. Tuesday night, in his worst game in recent memory, New Jersey lost, 3-1, to an undeveloped Edmonton team. Brodeur expects the Devils to be hotter Thursday night when they play Detroit in a rematch of their Stanley Cup finals.
"There are nights when you feel so big in the net, you think only a lucky bounce will beat you," he said. "And there are nights you are so small the puck goes right through you.
"I love to be in goal, to be the last line, to be all alone. But being all alone, talking to no one, so intense, you can drain your mental energy. So I try not to think too much, not to invent what will happen before it happens, not to get nervous by thinking, 'If they score now, it's tied, and then they'll score again and beat us.' So, I just go with the game, take what it gives me, and try to give it back."
What may read like cosmic philosophy sounded at lunch today, at a Route 3 restaurant called the Stadium Cafe, like a young man narrating his wonder years. Brodeur, large for a goalie at 6 feet 1 inch, 205 pounds, is comfortable in his skin, relaxed, eager to explain himself. Like most goalies, he dreams of being a forward and scoring; back in Montreal, in street hockey games with the pals he left behind, he always plays forward and tries to beat them with the tricks and shots that N.H.L. forwards use to try to beat him.
He started out as a forward; well into his career, at 7, he was asked to wear the pads of a back-up goalie for a team of 8-year-olds that needed a warm body on the bench. Naturally, the 8-year-old goalie was injured, so the understudy took the stage and has been there ever since. He liked it.
He was the Devils' first draft choice in 1990, and he was rookie of the year in 1993-94, and a key to their championship last season. The Devils won their first four games this season, and Brodeur gave up only five goals. But during warm-ups Tuesday night he sensed the streak might be over. The Devils were not up. Byrne Meadowlands Arena, whose wide angles dissipate the roar of the crowd, was only half-filled. Many of the Edmonton players were youngsters unknown to the Devils, but they knew every Devil on the team to beat.
Twelve hours later, over a turkey sandwich and coffee, Brodeur had already shrugged the loss away. He is known for his lack of emotion on the ice, his even temper, his consistent steadiness; he is thought to be unusually mature for his age. He thinks he is merely economical with his energy. During commercial timeouts, he skates in circles, winks at friends in the crowd and makes an effort to empty his mind of the game. He takes deep breaths, a technique taught by the Devils' goalie coach, Jacques Caron.
"There are goalies more spectacular than me," he said, "but I don't think I'd be better if I put mustard on my saves. I'm too big to sprawl around. And I have such good teammates. They take care of the passer and I take care of the shooter."
Once, in a wildly atypical move during the Eastern Conference finals against Philadelphia last year, Brodeur attacked a player who had just knocked him down. Stretched out on the ice, Brodeur slashed at the knees of Gilbert Dionne, then got up and jumped on him. Both men received two-minute penalties. Brodeur still regrets his response.
"It was selfish," he said. "It could have been costly to the team."
"You could have hurt the guy."
He shrugged. "That's the game."
"But you showed you were tough," a companion suggested. "You wouldn't take it."
"I don't need that reputation," he said. "Guys will bug you, talk trash, try to get you to snap again. Of course," the lips widened, "I can't guarantee it won't happen again."
Brodeur was bred for this. The youngest of five children, he followed two older brothers into sports, one of whom pitched in the Expos' farm system. His father, now a well-known sports photographer in Canada, was a minor league and Olympic goalie. Growing up in Montreal, he worshiped hockey in its holiest city. When the Devils played there last Saturday night, the crowd at the Forum gave him an ovation and the captain of the Canadiens, Mike Keane, asked him for an autographed stick.
Life in New Jersey has been low-key and sweet. He says he enjoys going unrecognized at movies and malls and during trips to the city with his wife, Melanie, a hometown sweetheart: "I get the fun of fame, and the loss of privacy, during the summer in Montreal."
It seemed as though he might not make it back to New Jersey for his third season. Drastically underpaid his first two years, at about $140,000 per, he held out this season for twice what he eventually settled for, an announced $5.3 million over three years. Compared with what other goalies are getting, that was considered a management coup.
"Money is an issue because you never know how long you'll play," he said. "But once you're paid over a million, there's no shame. At 23, that's a lot of money. I was stuck business-wise because they know that all I want to do is play hockey. We'll see what happens when the contract is up. I'll be 26. Until then, I'm sure I'll be able to put some peanut butter on my toast."
